title: Normal Garbage Pickups Scheduled for Next Week
description: Normal New York City garbage-collection schedules will be resumed next Monday or Tuesday at the earliest, Sanitation Department spokesman said yesterday.

title: A WEST GERMAN GUN IS SELECTED BY ARMY FOR NEVII BATTLE TANK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The Army, in a major step toward the longsought goal of standardizing weapons in the Atlantic Alliance, announced today that a West German gun had been chosen over British and American weapons for use on the new United States battle tank in the 1980's.

title: Albany Committee Delays Confirmation of Posner To Compensation Board
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31The nomination of Seymour Posner, a strongly prolabor Democratic Bronx Assemblyman, to the Workmen's Compensation Board ran into unexpected difficulties today as the State Senate's Finance Committee voted to postpone his confirmation in a session that broke up in loud argument.

title: Young and Owen See No Gain in Talks With Rhodesia Guel;rillas
description: VALLETTA, Malta, Jan. 31British and American officials reported no progress tonight as they emerged from a second day of talks with the leaders of the guerrilla struggle in Rhodesia.

description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. Jan. 31 (AP)Led by Ron Perry's 191:60ints and finishing with .substitutes playing, Hely. Cross beat 13rOwn, 9170,.tonight.

title: Deaths
description: IROOlivia (nee Hitchcock). On January 30, 1978. In her 92nd year. Beloved wife of the late S. Hinman Bird. Devoted mother of the late Olivia B. Oakley, Barbara B. Inganni, and Marys B. Hoagland. Also survived by seven grandchildren and seven greatgrandchlldren. Services private. In lieu of flowers contribution to St Stephen's Church, Armonk N.Y. 10504 would be appreciated.

title: Hunt for Satellite Debris Widened
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Jan. 31New evidence of fallen debris from the Soviet spy satellite, Cosmos 954, has led American and Canadian scientists to expand and intensify their reconnaissance of the frozen northern Canadian wilderness.

title: New York Finds CashBalanceUp; Experts. Puzzled
description: New York City expects to have almost twice as much cash on hand at the end of the current fiscal year than projected a month ago, but budget experts do not know why.

title: Esther Bien, Editor and Publisher Of Girl Scout Magazines, Was 79
description: Esther R. Bien, editor and publisher for 22 years of magazines published by the Girl Scouts, died Sunday in Deaconess Hospital in Buffalo. She was 79 years old and lived at 215 East 80th Street in New York City.

title: 33 of 195 in a New Port Unit Audit Accused of Faking Their Expenses
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey reported yesterday that an audit had uncovered faked or inflated expense accounts submitted by 33 of 195 executives and employees that had been audited, and that at least six face possible criminal prosecution.

title: Rangers Make Pitch To Get Soviet Stars
description: Having locked up the bidding for two top Swedish players now in the World Hockey Association, the New York Rangers have opened negotations with the Soviet Union for members of its national teamtalks that should benefit, other National Hockey League teams.

title: City Dog: A Mixed Breed
description: PERHAPS it is indeed true that the worldor at least the city is divided into two kinds of people: those who carry leashes, and those who don't. For it seems that, with the possible exception of rushhour traffic and mayoral elections, the subject of dogs can summon up some of the most heated arguments to be had, both from those who are devoted owners and those who think it is cruel, selfish, or just plain unsanitary to keep a dog in the confines of a city apartment and let it relieve itself on the curbing of city streets. Even those knowledgeable on the subject can clash on the specifics of keeping a dog in the city. Companion or protector? Purebred or mixed breed? Big dog, little dog?

title: Hunter 84, Livingston 74
description: Hunter College placed [we men in double figures, led by Rod Blake's 10 points, in defeating Livingston, College, 8474, last night.

title: Fritz Mondale at 50
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Vice President Walter F. Mondale was 50 the other day, a very dicey time of life,

description: Because: of television scheduling conflicts, the White House had difficulty yesterday setting a time for. President Carter's speech tonight on the Panama Canal treaties.

title: Fordham Defeated By Army, 8974
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 31 (AP)Matt Brown. scored 20 points and Gary Winton chipped in with IS as they sparked Army to an 8974 victory over Fordham tonight.

title: Manly Strength Is So Exhausting
description: Alice's eyes were nervous and she hunched forward and dropped her voice. Do you want me to give you the money under the table? she whispered. She was saving me from public shame. She was taking us to dinner at a restaurant on the Champs Elysees in Paris, but she was saving my manly pride. The world would not know my degradation.

title: The Split Over Diet and Health
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 31Despite decades and dollars spent in searching out the relationship between diet and health, the American scientific community remains divided over the issue.

title: Airco, in Seeking Bids, Also Retains Salomon
description: Airco, Inc., opposed to a $43-a-share takeover bid by BOC International Ltd. as too low, said yesterday that it had retained Salomon Brothers to find a new bidder for its stock.

title: Reporters Notebook: The News In Housewares. Is Multipurpose
description: What's new, is more than an idle conversation opener at product trade exhibitions such as the National Housewares Manufacturers Association show held in Chicago earlier this, month. What's new? is, in fact, the lifeblood of the industry. Lew Salton, chairman of the innovative Salton company sate, orten manuracturers do not bring out something new because they think it's terrificoften they feel that unless they, have something new,, there will be nothing to draw buyers to their bboths.

title: F.A.A. Challenged to Allow Tests Of Antenna in BritishU.S. Clash
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The Federal Aviation Administration was challenged yesterday by a British manufacturer and a United States Congressman to permit immediate tests of an advanced antenna that figures prominently in the BritishAmerican quarrel over a new aircraft landing system.

title: Cards Send Dobler to Saints in FourPlayer Trade
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 31 (AP)The St. Louis Cardinals needed a fierce pass rusher. The New Orleans Saints were loqking. for a speedy wide receiver. In a fourplayer National Football League deal today, both got what they wanted.

title: World Skiers, Like Businessmen, Switching Teams
description: GARMISCHPARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Jan. 31Much was revealed ilbout the big business of international Vkiing today, as the women's downhill race at the world Alpine championships was postponed. A long and heavy snowfall, combined with thick fog, made the course slow and hazardous.

title: U.S. EXPECTS DELAY IN SALE OF LEASES ON GEORGES BANK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The sale of oil and natural gas leases off the coast of Massachusetts is likely to be delayed for several months as a result of court action in Boston, according to Federal officials.

title: Profit Drops 70% In Fourth Quarter For Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, parent company of Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner & Smith. the nation's largest brokerage firm, announced yesterday a profit decline of 70 percent for the fourth quarter of 1977 and 58.8 percent for the full year.

title: Jets 7, Nordiques 2
description: QUEBEC CITY, Jan: 31 (UPI)--Ulf Nilsson scored three goals and assisted on a fourth tonight to lead the Winnipeg Jets to a 72 victory over the Quebec Nordiques.

title: INQUIRY ON BLACKOUT ASSAILS POWER POOL
description: A report on an independent investigation of last summer's blackout in New York City strongly criticizes the state power pool, which is charged with assuring adequate supplies of electricity at minimum cost, and urges that a new management body be created.

title: As a Main Course, Soup's On
description: TWICE within the past few weeks I have been invited to break bread with two impeccable cooks who served the most welcome fare for winter feasting, and in both cases they were main course soups. That, to my mind, is certifiable trend. And if it isn't, it should be.

title: A Dying Woman Gets Last Wish
description: NEWARK, Jan. 31A terminally ill Cuban woman, who yearned to become a United States citizen but who could not participate in naturalization ceremonies last week because she was hospitalized with cancer, had her dream fulfilled today at a special ceremony at the Beth Israel Medical Center.

title: Polaroid Foresees Record Earnings
description: The Polaroid Corporation expects record earnings for both the fourth quarter of 1977 and the full year, William J. McCune, the company's president, announced yesterday in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: 16 CITIES IN JERSEY CITED ON POLLUTION
description: TRENTON, Jan, 31At least 16 New Jersey cities. have not taken sufficient steps to control carbon monoxide and other air pollution, and it may become necessary for the slate to control automobile traffic and to limit the location of industry, the State Department of Environmental Protection said today.

title: NEUTRON 130MB STUDY IRKS PENTAGON AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Pentagon officials are strongly objecting to a new Arms Control and Disarmament Agency report that concludes that American deployment of the neutron bomb could incease chances of a nuclear war.

title: PRICES FARMERS RECEIVE ON RAW PRODUCTS UP 2%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)Prices that farmers receive for their raw prodticts rose 2 percent from December to January, the fourth straight monthly increase, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Anne Bancroft Ill, Clolda To Close for This Week
description: Performances of Golda, starring Anne Bancroft, will be suspended for the rest of this week, starting with today's matinee, because of Miss Bancroft's illness.

description: Page C10

title: Economic Index Advanced 0.7% For December
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)The Government said today its index designed to signal future economic trends increased by a substantial seventenths of 1 percent in December, pointing to probable strong performance of the economy in the months ahead

title: Swiss Team Sets Mark In 2Man Bobsled Drills
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 31. (AP)The Swiss team of Hanz Hiltebrand and Alain Piaget shattered the track record today in qualifying for the world twoman bobsled championship, which will be held next weekend.

title: Seoul Will Permit Tongsun Park to Testify to House
description: `..WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The South Korean Government said today that Tongsun Park, who has testified that he gave $1 million to American officials and Congressmen, would be permitted to appear before a House committee investigating charges that members of Congress accepted bribes and bther illicit favors from Koreans.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Jan. 31African members of the Security Council, in a tactical move to maintain pressure on South Africa and the West, agreed today not to press for an immediate showdown vote on two controversial resolutions.

description: TRENTON, Jan. 31Because of the death of his nephew, Governor Byrne canceled today a projected trip to Washington, where he had planned to appeal for more Federal funds for New Jersey cities at a White House conference on economic problems.

title: Newspaper of Slain Nicaraguan Editor Leads Strike
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan.  31--As soon as a nationwide strike began here last week, the opposition newspaper, La Prensa, jcinsd the protest by stepping up its campaign against the Government and by refusing to take advertisements.

description: KEENE, Calif., Jan. 31. (UPI) HCesar Chavez today ended the nationwide boycotts by the United Farm Workers Union against lettuce, table grapes and Gallo wine.

title: .Metals Futures Regain Ground; Coffee and Cocoa Prices Decline
description: Precious metals futures prices rebounded yesterday as the dollar dipped in value against foreign currencies. Many futures traders had expected the dollar to firm M response to the smaller-than-expected trade deficit figures released last Monday, a f ternoon.

title: Orange Picking At the Local Grove
description: As welcome as a sweet and pungent orange may be at any time of the year that sun-warmed, sun-brightened fruit has a special appeal during the cold stray months of winter. Not only does The spicy, tropical flavor of oranges provide a luxurious lift for both palate and psyche, but this cheery citrus, fruit has a high vitamin C content so important during this season.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31If, as President Carter suggested yesterday, nuclear reactors in space are outlawed, a result would. be to: deny an economical source of power to supersatellites of the future, such as those that would be used for direct television broadcasts.,.

title: TrainingSite Bill Passed
description: DENVER, Jan. 31 (UPI)Legislation that could result in an Olympic training center being built in Colorado Springs received final approval in the State Senate today and was sent to Gov. Richard Lamm. to be signed into law. The bill, approved by a 267 vote, earmarks $125,000 in Federal money- to conduct a site analysis and an economicimpact study of a proposed facility.

title: Senate, 7420, Passes Bill to Add 48,000 More Acres to Redwood Park
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 31In an effort to protect some of the world's oldest and tallest trees, the Senate today passed bill authorizing the addition of 48,000 acres to Redwood National Park in northern California.

title: Explosion Injures Three Workers
description: AMESBURY, Mass., Jan. 31 (AP)An explosion demolished a house this morning, damaging a house across Main Street and injuring three workers who were frantically trying to shut off gas to nearby buildings. The injuries were minor, officials said. Damage to a buried gas line had been reported by water workers, and the area had been evacuated..

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: FOR YEARS, so called television comics, primed by their unseen stables of gag writers, have been simultaneously regaling and terrifying the rest of the country with accounts ofcrime in New York.

title: Whimsical February
description: February probably will be capriciousit usually but there is excuse for that. February is the last full month of winter, by the almanac at least, and the traditional battleground of warring weather systems. It be- gins with the absurdity of Groundhog Day, celebrates romance in midmonth, and includes an extra day every four years. February is the only month that still am proximates the lunar monthone of man's earliest units of timeyet on occasion it passes without a full moon.

title: Oscars Stir Redgrave Dispute Anew
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31-Nomina tion ballots for the yearly Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences awards ere put in the mail yesterday, and as was predictable, there is already a. minor controversy surrounding the Oscars.

description: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 31 (Reuters)Gen. Oscar Molina Pallochia became Prime Minister, Minister of War, and commander of the army today. The 54-year-old general replaced Gen. Guillermo Arbulu Galliani, one of 14 senior officers who retired yesterday after 35 years of service.

description: Several businesses have aided the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, including one that recently moved to New York City.

description: ALBANY, Jan.. 31A new demand by the Koch administration that New York State commit itself to a substantial program of more than one year of aid has stalled negotiations on the state's role in helping New York City close its budget gap, parties to the negotiations said today.

title: Spanish Royal Visit Takes Vienna Back To Hapsburg Times
description: ,VIENNA, Jan. 31This city, which cannot or will not forget it was once the capital of a great empire, Was bathed in. regal nostalgia today as it welcomed young royaltyKing Juan Carlos of Spain and his Queen, Sofia.

title: Police Interview Cliff Robertson in Begelman Case
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31Cliff Rob ertson, the actor, interviewed by the police for the first time in the David Begelman case, told them today that his name had been forged on a $10,000 check issued by Columbia Pictures in 1976making official what he had said only informally before.

title: Two Promoted at Carling

title: .U.S. Checking on Settlements
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3l The State Department said today that it had asked the American Embassy in Tel Aviv to look into Israeli presS reports about three new settlements on the West Bank,

title: An ExSmoker's Own True Facts
description: LONDONWhen, after 12 years of smoking, T quit last year. I congratulated myself both on my selfdiscipline and the lucky accident that allowed me to substitute the taste of pencil erasers for cigarettes without too much discomfort. I never stopped to wonder why I had finally quit; it was enough for me that I had.

title: Charnin in Cabaret Act
description: MARTIN CHARNIN, who staged Annie and wrote its lyrics, is not one to let anything go to waste. First, he turned his experiences with Annie into a book, Annie, a Theater. Memoir. Now he alas recycled his career as a lyric writer to create a nightclub act that he is presenting at the Rainbow Grill this week and next.

title: Gregory Herbert, Saxophonist With Blood Sweat and Tears, 30
description: AMSTERDAM, Jan. 31 (AP)Gregory Herbert, a saxophone player and member of the rock group Blood Sweat and Tears. was found dead today in a hotel room. A search of the room uncovered some drugs, the police reported.

description: CAMBRIDGE,'Mass., Jan, 31Today, e'tre after tha eltect:ti^r:la Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, Harvard University released the papers of A. Lawrence Lowell, whcise review commission affirmed the guilty verdict.

title: Proposed Amendment Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)--Critics of the Panama Canal treaties charged today that a proposed_Senate amendment guaranteeing United States defense rights and priority passage for its warships in emergencies was a sugarcoated political maneuver that failed to protect the security interests of this country.

title: Murray Louis Dancers Due at Academy of Music
description: The Murray Louis Dance Company will return to the Brooklyn Academy of Music on March 9 after a fiveyear absence front that hall. The company will appear through March 12, and from March 16 through March 19. Mr. Louis's Schubert, a work for eight dancers set to the Trout Quintet, will receive its New York premiere on opening night.

title: New York Finds Cash Balance Up; Experts Puzzled
description: New York City expects to have almost twice as much cash on hand at the end of the current fiscal year than projected a month ago, but budget experts do not know why.

title: Patients Unaware Surgeon May Be a Beginner
description: Patients in many of New York's most prestigious hospitals are often unaware that the doctor operating on them is not the fully trained surgeon they engaged, but a physician who is a surgical trainee, or resident, working under the surgeon's supervision, according to a report issued yesterday by the New York State Assembly's Medical Practice Task Force.

title: CALIFANO WANTS CURBS ON HOSPITALIZATION FEES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP'Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that the medical industry's voluntary program to hold down hospital costs was a distinctly false promise to the American neonle.

title: MARGARET DONAHUE
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (UPI)Margaret Donahue, a former vice president of the Chicago Cubs and the first female executive in major league baseball, died yesterday in a suburban Crystal Lake nursing home. She was 85 years ald.

title: Anton Kuerti, Pianist, In Romantic Program
description: IN RECENT years pianists have started paying a good deal of attention to the music of Alexander Scriabin, but it has been the problematic last works that have been emphasized. The early preludes and etudes have been, by and large, passed over as being too derivative of Schumann and, especially, Chopin.

title: Akron Divided by Heated Abortion Debate
description: AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 28Since this infamous decision, we've killed five million, the Rev. Charles F. Billington declared in a recent sermon to his congregation at the Akron Baptist Temple. He was referring to the 1973 ruling by the United States Supreme Court that liberalized the abortion laws.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 31 (AP)The Ohio High School Athletic Association plans to appeal a Federal judge's decision that girls may not be banned from playing on boys contract sports teams.

title: Builders of Bus Shelters Are in Line for the Bonanza
description: Some of the bestknown and highestpaid legal and publicrelations talent in New York City has been retained in a foursided fight to win a lucrative busshelter franchise from the Board of Estimate.

title: Paul BaduraSkoda Plays Schubert
description: PAUL BADURA-SKODA'S series of three concerts devoted to piano works of Schubert opened last night at the 92d Street Y with three early sonatas and the Grazer Fantasy. The program carried the title The Young Schubert, which can be defended even though there never was anything like an old Schubert (he died at 31). All four works were written when he was between the ages of 20 and 22 and only beginning to find his way in the larger instrumental forms.

title: Technology
description: American domestic communications satellite systems for the 1980's are developing along two divergent pathways. One leads to services tailored to large, highvolume customers. The other leads to omnibus services embracing even remote areas generating small amounts of traffic.

title: Goodrich Names Wooldredge
description: William D. Wooldredge has been elected a senior vice president of the B. F. Goodrich Company, Akron, Ohio, and has been appointed a member of the company's management committee, Goodrich announced yesterday. He will be responsible for financial, administrative and communications staffs at the company's Akron headquarters.

title: The 10Course Banquet
description: Though Chinese New Year's purists would insist that on the first day of the Year of the Horse, 4676, nothing but vegetables be eaten, it has become a custom to have a 10course banquet.

title: Howard Elects Early Retirement
description: The American Can Company announced yesterday that Harry S. Howard Jr., vice chairman of the board and chairman of the management executive committee, has elected early retirement at the age of 60, effective today. He will continue as director and will act as a consultant to the company. He joined American can in 1968, when it acquired the Butterick Company, of which he had been.fpresident.

title: Robbery Victim, 82, Does Police Work To Get GOods Back
description: An 82-year-old Bronx man who said he could not wait for the police to find the burglars who had cleaned out his apartment did the detective work himself and came up with information that resulted in seven arrests.

title: CRIMEPLAGUED BUS TO GET POLICE DETAIL
description: MAPLEWOOD, Jan. 31The Newark police will resume a practice of riding the No. 107 Transport of New Jersey bus between Maplewood and New York in an effort to curb robberies and assaults. The police will be in uniform and plainclothes.

title: Events Today
description: BOYS IN COMPANY C, directed by Sidney J. Furls; starring Stan Shaw and Andrew Stevens, at Loews State 2, Oroheum, Bay and other theaters.

title: New York's Attrition Game Is Over
description: The principal actors in New York City's financial crisis have been advising State Comptroller Levitt how he can help by using the many billions of dollars in his custody that belong td the pension systems of New York State employees. First, Mayor Koch urged him to buy city bonds. The Mayor has now modified this by urging the Federal Government to guarantee the bonds, a sensible precaution. Senator Proxmire has raised his voice to say that Mr. Levitt needs no Federal guarantees; New York's would suffice. Mr. Levitt takes no advice on this issue. He has adopted an unassailable motto for handling other people's money: Safety First. The member of this trio who now most needs advice is not getting it. That person is Mayor Koch, who needs to be told more precisely by his aides how New York City intends to balance its budget. All other help depends on that balance.

title: SYLVIA COZZENS, 76, AGENT AND WIFE OF THE AUTHOR
description: Sylvia Bernice Baumgarten Cozzens, literary agent . and the wife of James Gould Cozzens, the author, died Monday of cancer in Stuart, Fla. She was 76 years old.

The question began: On March 15, 1976, you told the Chicago Council on Foreign. Relations that the American people have hid their fill of covert manipulation.

title: TV: Joanne Woodward, 40, Sweet and Running
description: THIS IS MY QUEST, shouts that soppy inspirational ballad from Man of La Mancha, putting its calculating finger on one of the more durable devices in popular dramatizations. Never under- estimate the developmental poWer of quest. From overcoming every conceivable type of handicap to achieving all sorts of honors in sports or whatever, the quest has proved singularly useful.

description: Many players clutch rooks to their breasts as though the outcome of the game depended exclusively on their never losing the exchange. Yet there are situations where a positional exchange sacrifice makes good sense.

title: HOTEL IS SHUT IN TEST OF PROSTITUTION LAW
description: - A new state law aimed at fighting the use of sleazy hotels for prostitution has been- upheld in its first court test after a year's battle by community groups on Manhattan's. Upper West Side.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, FEURUARY 1, 1978

title: DISCOVERIES
description: In Texas, the spurs may, jingle, jangle, but in New York, it's differentalways. The jinglejangling here may be due to something just introduced a little bell attached to a pretty ribbon, and meant to be pinned to the inside of one's dress, although no one says it can't be worn outside, inside a pant hem, or wherever one wishes. The bells are particular fun for discotheque dancing, but,they, might liven up an otherwise staid dinner party, if you have the courage. The discobelles are at Serendipity, 225 East 60th Street, and on the main floor at Bloomingdale's, in the jewelry and the new Lace Shop. Prices go from $3.98 to $6.98. Still to come are ringbelles and toebelles.

title: Rebuilding of Palmer Square Is Planned in Princeton
description: PRINCETON, Jan. 31Plans for a $10 million expansion of Palmer Square, a combined retail, office and apartment district in the center of town, were announced today by officials of Palmer Square Inc., whose major stockholder Princeton University.

title: Egyptians and Israelis Renew Talks In Cairo on Sinai Military Issues
description: CAIRO, Jan. 31Egyptian and Israeli military delegations returned to the negotiating table here today in the first formal contacts between the two countries since the breakdown of political talks in Jerusalem 13 days ago.

title: A Penniless Heir Fears For His Record Collection

title: Notes on People
description: To draw attention to Government spending that he considers to be fleecing the taxpayers. Senator William Proxmire likes to give what he calls Golden Fleece of the Month awards. This month's award went yesterday to the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, which Mr. Proxmire, a Wisconsin Democrat, said spent $2 million on a project to develop a police car so loaded with gadgets that it ended up as an earthbound spaceship on wheels. The car would have provided policemen with eyelevel readouts of computer terminals and something called voicedigital transceivers, Mr. Proxmire said. A spokesman for the law enforcement agency called Mr. Proxmire feckless for his criticism, and said it was all an exercise in futility because the police supercar program had ended 10 months ago.

title: A Farm Program for All Seasons
description: Federal agricultural policy has traditionally served only farmers, raising their incomes at the expense other taxpayers and consumers. The Secretary of Agriculture, Bob Bergland, argues, correctly, that a policy designed to even out year-to-year fluctuations in commodity prices would serve the longterm interests both farmers and consumers, and help to protect the world against famine. If this new approach is to work, however, the Carter Administration should soon breathe life into the centerpiece of its program, the domestic grain reserve.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: MANY FACTORS are involved in the time required to prepare any dish, be it a simple dinner or an elaborate dish, such as coulibiac, which may require as many as six different preparations combined in one single presentation. It helps enormously, of course, if you know how to cut and slice and chop efficiently. But the proper tools or equipment are a great aid in any form of hasty cooking. A dull knife can hinder a cook as much as a cluttered work surface which is the bane of professional. As you work you should clean and rid your immediate work area of unnecessary ingredients and any other nonessentials, You should also plan ahead, determine the ingredients to be used and decide the order in which they should logically be cleaned and otherwise made ready for cooking.

title: Electronic Music From Quebec
description: IT'S always interesting to hear what experimental musicians from cities other than New York and countries other than the United States are up to. But it can't really be said that the music made Tuesday night at Experimental Intermedia Foun- dation Loft at 224 Centre Street by G.I.M.E.L., the Groupe d'Interpretation de Musique Electroacoustique, an electronicmusic ensemble associated with the Laval University School of Music in Quebec, was very rewarding. Part of the problem was technical. The G.I.M.EL. people are on tour and brought with them a sound system designed for auditoriums that could only be throttled back so far. As a result the music sounded harsher than might have under other circumstances.

title: Court Denies U.S. Move to Speed Antitrust Suit Against A.T.&T,

title: Screen: 'Coma,' Hospital Mystery:Snooping in the O.R.
description: "COMA" is a hospital thriller that has the manner of a cool, brisk night nurse. It does what must be done and moves on before you can really see what it looks like. The film, adapted and directed by Michael Crichton, himself a doctor, is based on the best-selling novel by Robin Cook, who is also a doctor. It's the kind of story that, after you've seen "Coma," you might suspect a couple of waggish surgeons of having cooked up in the operating room while removing a brain tumor.One can only hope the surgeons would be more efficient in cleaning up after the brain tumor than they've been in tidying up the plausibility questions that remain after the movie. Plausibility is not always important, but in a film as bereft of distinctive style and wit as "Coma," it helps to believe in something. It can even help if one is offended. The aftereffect of "Coma" is a catlike yawn, benign and bored.The movie is about the Nancy Drew-like adventure faced by pretty, plucky Dr. Susan Wheeler (Genevieve Bujold), a resident surgeon at Boston Memorial Hospital, after her best friend suffers irreparable brain damage in the course of a minor operation. Against the advice of her lover, handsome, hearty Dr. Mark Bellows (Michael Douglas), a young surgeon on the make for money and position, pretty, plucky Dr. Susan Wheeler initiates her own investigation and discovers that in the last year, something like a dozen other patients, all young and in good health, have met similar fates.It soon becomes apparent to pretty, plucky Dr. Susan Wheeler that there is a conspiracy afoot. All of the fatal operations have been performed in the very same operating room, a fact that handsome, hearty Dr. Mark Bellows dismisses as the merest coincidence. Even gruff, kindly old Dr. George Harris (Richard Widmark), the hospital's avuncular head, refuses to listen to her suspicions. What can a pretty, plucky girl do?Well, the last thing she ever thinks about in this movie is going to the police. Instead, like Nancy Drew, she snoops around alone in the hospital basement and up its air shafts. She receives a promise of vital information from a hospital maintenance engineer and then is a witness to his not quite accidential electrocution. Still pretty plucky Dr. Susan Wheeler pushes on and on, tempting fate and, more dangerously, our patience.In his first film as a director, "West-world," Mr. Crichton made very efficient use of some Disneyland-like robots. "Coma" is the kind of movie that turns real-life actors into robot-like functions of the story. Miss Bujold, Mr. Douglas and Mr. Widmark, as well as Rip Torn, Elizabeth Ashley and a stunningly beautiful actress named Lois Chiles, are as mechanical as dolls whose expressions are controlled by a computer's console."Coma," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some mildly vulgar language and some fleeting nudity in a sequence in which a lot of bodies, which are in a state of suspended animation, appear to be sleeping in fancy, Danish-modern hammocks.

title: Screen: 'Company C':Five in Vietnam
description: ACCORDING to a recent ad, "The Boys in Company C" are "the craziest group of men this country ever sent off to war." Here's why: Dave Bisbee is a hippie who says, when he is drafted into the Marines, "I guess that's my karma coming out," and who is seldom without his guitar. Vinnie Fazio is a fast-talking ladies' man from Brooklyn. Alvin Foster is a sensitive type, and he keeps the journal upon which the movie is supposedly based. Billy Ray Pike is an even more sensitive type, because he worries about having left his young sweetheart pregnant and later winds up hooked on drugs in Vietnam. And Tyrone Washington is a former ghetto dope dealer who turns out to have astounding leadership abilities, plus the soul of a philosopher and a heart of gold."You may want to forget the war, but you'll never forget the Boys in Company C," this same ad continues. One reason you won't forget them is that they're already so familiar. In fact, they are so stereotypical, and hence so constricted, that they don't seem to have any feelings of consequence about what they do or what happens to them. This amounts to a failure to take any stand on Vietnam, something that a more slapdash movie might be able to pass off as mere irresponsibility. But "The Boys in Company C" is, in every other respect, as calculating as can be. As a film about heroism, it is chiefly remarkable for its gutlessness.The mood is a carefully balanced one: sure, there are mines in the rice paddies and there's murder in the air, but there is also a spirit of cute camaraderie. In addition, there are a madcap ballgame finale out of "M*A*S*H," tidy where-are-they-now? closing credits out of "American Graffiti," and an odd clarity of purpose that, under the war's confusing circumstances, is out of the blue.The movie is so determined to create instant heroes that it must have its instant villains too; in this case, there are corrupt South Vietnamese officials and excessively gung-ho Marine officers to be blamed. Less visible, but also under indictment, are drugs, the Vietcong and American racism. But there's no real evidence of the troubled American political climate of 1967, which is when the story takes place. As far as the screenplay is concerned, this might as well be World War II.An opening sequence, which typifies the film's teasing tactics, introduces the five protagonists and establishes them as wildly different from one another, then robs them of all eccentricities as soon as they hop into uniform and have their heads shaved. Next thing we know, they're in boot camp, being told things like "You see that guy next to you? You think he's a $%/& or a *)%/ or a &!!/)? I don't care, cause he's gonna save your $%/$%&!* life some day!" Next thing after that, the boys have shaped up and shipped out, each one retaining only one-note remnants of his original nature.The cast is made up of new young actors, all of whose performances are eclipsed by the cheap ironies of the screenplay (recruit accidentally discovering a body bag: "Hey, I got it, you sleep in it! It's a lightweight sleeping bag!") and by the banality of their roles. The wise guy, Vinnie Fazio, is particularly grating, but the actor who plays him (Michael Lembeck) seems to be doing exactly what's expected of him. James Whitmore Jr., who plays a reasonable officer to Scott Hylands's fanatic, gives the only performance with even a trace of the unexpected. But the actor likely to make the biggest splash is Stan Shaw. As the black recruit, Mr. Shaw is handsome and more than competent, and the character he plays is wonderful in a way that only movie characters can ever be.In fact, it's hard to recall anyone on the screen who has demonstrated such unremitting nobility, such unmitigated righteousness, in recent years. And it's hard to imagine a less appropriate occasion on which those qualities might reappear.

One of them is sleep, has given way to a sales pitch that promotes the waterbed for a comfortable night's sleepwarm in the winter, cool in the summer. That's all.

title: A Stone Unturned on Korea
description: Congress can draw only partial satisfaction from the news that South Korea will permit Tongsun Park testify before the House Ethics Committee investigating Korean bribes and favors to members of Congress. It a welcome, if grudging and belated, sign of cooperation from Seoul. But it is not the end of the matter. Mr. Park can advance the committee's inquiry into those lobbying efforts he himself engaged in. But there ample reason to believe that similar efforts were conducted by others, notably Kim Dong Jo, a former Ambassador from Seoul. The committee has insisted that he, too, be made available for questioning, but South Korea continues obdurately to refuse to let him testify.

title: Our Satellites and Theirs
description: The fiery plunge to earth of a Soviet military satellite, carrying a nuclear reactor, has now ignited a debate over what, if anything, should be done to prevent a recurrence. American space officials tend to minimize the dangers of orbiting reactors. Military planners cite the incident as proof that the Russians are leading in the military uses of space and urge a catchup effort that could send still more reactors skyward. Environmentalists, meanwhile, demand international safeguards. And President Carter proposes a ban on atomic material earthorbit, at least until there is better protection against accidental contamination of the environment.

title: Carter Fund Repays $3,500 for Airplanes In 1976 Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  President Carter's campaign fund has reimbursed a dozen companies and individuals more than $3,500 for airplanes chartered by him and Mrs. Carter in 1975 and 1976.

Officially organized lectures, exhibitions and television broadcasts will illustrate the dangers of alcoholism and effects of tobacco, the Bulgarian press agency reported.

He was the voungest of three brothers who won French boxing championships in the late 1940's, capturing France's featherweight crown in 1946 and the European title in 1948.

description: NEWARK, Feb. 1Playboy Entreprises nc., suffering multimilliondollar losses n its hotel and club operations internaionally, is counting heavily on a $75 milion gambling casino hotel at Atlantic City to push up its profits , officials said today.

description: The Treasury sold $3 billion of 8 percent sevenyear notes yesterday at small premium to produce a yield to investors of 7.88 percent. title: Backgammon:
description: Despite the great complexity and subtlety of strategy in backgammon, the actual rules of the game are simple and easily stated. However, situations can arise where misinter- retation is possible. The diagrammed position, taken from the Amateur Backgammon Championship last week in Las Vegas, Nev., illustrates one such case. X, behind 5 to 3 in a 7point match, had already doubled and begun to bear off. The outcome of the match hinged on X's avoiding being hit. By bearing off safely, X would win not only the game but also a probable gammon, thus winning the match 7 to 5. On the other hand, if X were hit he could easily lose both game and match.

In fact, the German Government's statistics office now has announced that real gross national product increased by only 2.4 percent last year. .

Atherton Jr., ended two weeks of efforts to gain an IsraeliEgyptian accord to a declaration of principles to clear the path for talks on an overall peace settlement. But his attempts were snagged by continuing differences between the two countries over the issue of selfdetermination for Palestinian Arabs. description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (AP)Don Williams scored 23 points and Dave Batton 21 as fourthranked Notre beat La Salle, 9590, tonight for the Irish's eighth consecutive victory.

title: BERGLAND SEES EXPORT CUT AS RESULT OF FARM STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)Agrlculture Secretary Bob Bergland said today that a farmers strike could damage the nation's livestock industry and curtail wheat and soybean exports for 1979.

title: Boycotts Ended, Chavez Union Focuses on Contracts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1Statistics from the California Agricultural Labor Relations Board indicate that one of the chief reasons Cesar Chavez and his United Farm Workers formally ended their national boycotts of nonunion lettuce, table grapes and wine was to be able to focus attention on servicing contracts now in hand and on negotiating new ones.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
New York City Is Asked to Detail Its Need for Aid
description: ALBANY, Feb. 1The chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee said today that he did not believe New York State can lock itself into recurring aid of the type the Koch administration was seeking.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
Police Press Search For 3 Missing Boys In Jamaica Bay Area
description: Three boys were reported to have disappeared through broken ice in Jamaica Bay yesterday, and the police and the Coast Guard searched for them until 8:15 P.M.

title: New Leyland Plan Would Cut 12,500 Jobs
description: STONELEIGH, England, Feb. 1BrItish Leyland, in what may be the last chance to save Britain's ability to produce cars for the mass market, outlined today a retrenchment plan that calls for cutting at least 12,500 jobs this year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in The Times on Monday that restitution pledges and payments obtained to date by the office of Charles J. Hynes, the special New York State prosecutor for nursing homes, totaled $25 million. The actual total announced by Mr. Hynes was nearly $5 million.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Two events this weekend are of special interest to students of architecture: Cooper Hewitt Museum will sponsor tour Saturday morning of three prominent buildingsThe Gatehouse at Greenwood Cemetery, designed by the fatherson architectural firm of Richard Upjohn and Richard M. Upjohn; Grace Church in Lower Manhattan and St. Patrick's Cathedral, bot hdesigned by James Renwick. Robert Jensen, an architectural historian, will lead the tour. A bus will leave from 2 East 91st Street at 9 A.M. and return at 1 P.M. Tour fee is $15; phone reservations should be made in advance by calling 8606868.

title: West Germany and the U.S. Agree On Major International Trade
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)  Otto Landsdorff, West Germany's Economic Minister, met here today with Robert S. Strauss, United States trade negotiator, and later said the two countries agreed on major international trade questions.

title: Books of The Times
description: THERE were moments  or should I say sentences?when I felt complete identity with Paul Berlin, the American soldier in Vietn.am who experiences the events of Tim O'Brien's new novel.

title: Senate Confirms Ambassadors To Poland, Gabon and Portugal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (Reuters) The Senate today confirmed William E. Schaufele as Ambassador to Poland, Arthur Tienken as Ambassador to Gabon and Richard J. Bloomfield as Ambassador to Portugal.

title: Market Place
description: This week's announcement by Weeden & Company, the nation's leading third market dealer, that it would probably abandon its traditional business because of shrinking profitability has again focused attention on the continuing turmoil in the securities business.

title: Family Money: How Many Papers Do You Really Need?
description: THERE'S one in every household a dresser drawer or filing cabinet that Is really a magpie's nest of canceled checks, receipted bills, dogeared tax returns, yellowing correspondence, washing machine warranties, accident reports and all the other paper that must be shoved out of sight before the company comes.

title: Heavy January Snowfall Sent Big Retailers Sales To Lowest in 17 Months
description: The 15inch snowfall that blanketed the metropolitan area over an entire weekend last month severely affected retail business in New York City, inflicting the worst monthly showing on the city's largest retailers in 17 months.

title: Metals Futures Are Mixed While Traders Await the Resuts of the I.M.F. Gold Auction
description: Precious metals futures prices closed mixed yesterday as traders awaited the results of the monthly gold auction by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Advertising; Alternatives to the Postal Service; What's Up, Doc?; Ziff Goes Fishing
description: As postage costs continue their upward surge with no end in sight, major users of the United States Postal Service are looking for and finding alternatives to the Government's delivery system.

title: Saving Soap Slivers Before They Go Down the Drain
description: Only recently did I convince my children that soapsliver saving is central to my psychic balance.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE VOIDS JERSEY'S TUITION AID
description: NEWARK, Feb. 1A Federal District Court judge struck down as unconstitutional today a section of the state incometax law that pdrmits parents of children attending nonpublic schools to take a $1,000 deduction on gross income for each child.

title: Bridge:
description: Some of the most interesting problems in the game- revolve around entries, and the solutions can be quite unexpected.

title: Those Creeping Israeli Settlements
description: Every day now brings disturbing new evidence that Israel is planting new settlements, and more settlers old settlements, on the disputed West Bank of the Jordan, whose future will be a central issue in any genuine peace negotiation. The merits of these territorial ambitions can be argued in terms of Biblical justice, Zionist doctrine, international law or Israeli politics. But the stealthy conduct of the policy, particularly at this sensitive time in the Middle East, seems indefensible.

title: Total Value of New York Property Expected to Decline Again in 1978
description: The total value of taxable real property in New York City will decline in 1978 for the third year in a row, officials of the city's Finance Department predicted yesterday.

title: Slide of Dollar Concerns Oil Nations
description: GENEVA, Feb. 1 (Reuters)Oil-exporting nations meeting here are concerned at the effect of the falling value of the dollar on oil prices, the head of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today. The OPEC secretarygeneral, Ali Jaidah of Qatar said the five countriesSaudi Arabia, Kuwait, Iraq, Iran and Venezueladid not discuss measures to combat the effect of the dollar's slide, but we are concerned about the situation. Saudi Arabia recently revived the idea of linking oil prices with a basket of international currencies. The ministers here were expected to look at the proposal during their talks.

title: STREETLIGHT PACTS ASSAILED BY GOLDIN
description: Saying that the city's 25 years of contracts with the Broadway Maintenance Corporation smelled to high heaven, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday that the company had been able to submit low bids to keep its streetlight repair monopoly because it knew it would not have to do all the work.

title: Notes on People
description: This week, Billy Graham is conducting one of his crusades for Christ in that seeming citadel of sin, Las Vegas, Nev., but he has oeen careful not to cast any stones. The evangelist opened his fiveday series of services by calling Las Vegas a nice place to visit and said the true picture of Las Vegas showed it was not merely a city of casinos.

title: U.S. LABOR SECRETARY BARS, DROPPING AIDES
description: The United States Secretary of Labor, Ray Marshall, said yesterday that he knew of no reason to suspend five of his subordinates who Representative Elizabeth Holtzman has charged were directly responsible for favorable treatment of the B'nai Torah Institute of Brooklyn. and for a whitewash of charges against it.

title: Mrs. Moser Retains Downhill Title
description: GARMISCHPARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Feb. 1To nobody's surprise, Annemarie Proell Moser of Austria won the women's downhill race at the world Alpine skiing championships today. To everybody's surprise, especially her own, Irene Epple of West Germany was second.

title: Chairman Is Named For Scouting Drive
description: Robert H. Anderson, head of a New York consulting firm, has been named general chairman of a $2 million fund drive to support Scouting in New York, Darrell D. Eichoff, president of the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America has announced.

title: DISTILLATE OIL STOCKS FELL 7.9 MILLION BARRELS 1NWEEK
description: Supplies for distillate oil fell sharply to 219.8 million barrels in the week ended Jan. 27, from 227.7 million preceding week, according to the latest weekly supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: How to Preserve Paper: Start With a Little Loving Care
description: pAPER is fragile, dispensable and sneezed at. The height of disdain may have been reached by a 16thcentury Italian count who preferred parchment and scorned books made of paperstains on his paper pages indicated he used slices of sausages for bookmarks.

title: Manhattan Plaza: SmallaTovvn Neighbors in a Blase City
description: At Manhattan Plaza, men and women who have spent many years in New York City attuning their senses to be wary of sudden overtures of affability are going through culture shock as they learn the pleasures of greeting neighbors and helping one another.

title: Georgia DoctorOfficial Testifies Against Treatment With Laetrile
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 1 (UPI)  A state health official testified today against Representative Larry P. McDonald, a Georgia Democrat and physician who is the target of a $6 million medical negligence suit, for treating one of his cancer patients with laetrile. The patient died.

title: News Summary
description: Middle East peace efforts adjourned in Cairo, focusing attention on President Anwar elSadat's scheduled talks with President Carter at Camp David, Md., this weekend. The American intermediary in the Mideast, Assistant Secretary of State Alfred L. Atherton Jr., ended two weeks of efforts to gain an IsraeliEgyptian accord to a declaration of principles to clear the path for talks on an overall peace settlement. But his attempts were snagged by continuing differences between the two countries over the issue of selfdetermination for Palestinian Arabs. Meanwhile, Israeli and Egyptian military experts ended a second round of talks aimed at working out a technical accord for the return of occupied Sinai to Egyptian control. [Page Al, Col. 6.]

title: Police in South Jamaica Begin a Crackdown on Drugs
description: The police in South Jamaica, Queens, said yesterday that they had started to crack down on smalltime drug pushers and addicts, But they acknowledged that the drive would at most keep drug sales at a minimum or stop them for just a while.

title: Volcker, Fearing Complacency, Urges Renewed Fight on Inflation
description: Paul A. Volcker, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, called yesterday for renewed efforts to combat inflation and suggested that the American public was being lulled into complacency about the continuing increase in living costs.

title: CARTER, IN TV TALK, ASKS CANAL BACKING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  President Carter appealed directly to the American people tonight to support the ratification of the Panama Canal treaties, which he described as being in the highest national interest of the United States.

title: Washington &
description: The Carter policy of encouraging wage and price deceleration in order to fight inflation may get its first serious challenge when postal workers contracts come up for negotiation this year. Page D3.

title: Federal Suit Asks Textile Makers To Buy Back Tris-Treated Fabric
description: The Federal Government filed a complaint against seven major fabric makers yesterday seeking to have them repurchase all children's clothing treated with Tris, a chemical flame retardant suspected of beine a cancerproducinp agent

title: Time to Stop Towing the Barges
description: The Federal Government spends about $400 million each year to maintain 15,000 miles of inland waterways and to build more of them. Yet barge operators who use the waterways ride for free. Now, barges may at last begin to pull their own weight. The Senate is about vote on a bill, supported by the White House, that would levy charges on waterway users:

title: Levitt Opposes Carey Racing Plan
description: ALBANY. Feb. 1State Comptroller Arthur Levitt said today that he was opposed to Governor Carey's suggestion to cut New York Slate's tax on parimutuel bets at thoroughbred race tracks.

title: McCall's Your Place Coming Off Presses
description: The first copies of Your Place, a new monthly magazine from the McCall Publishing Company, are coming off the presses, each with 132 pages and including about 54 pagesof advertising. The issue will be on sale Feb. 28 and on that date McCall's will start about $200,000 worth of promotion.

title: Jewish Scholars Reassessing Historical Jesus
description: After centuries of relative silence by Jews on the subject of Jesus, including periods when the mention of the name was rare or even forbidden, some Jewish scholars, have recently stepped up efforts to reclaim the firstcentury figure as an exemplary, deeply religious Jew deserving of a high place in Jewish history.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: SelfStyled Pornographer Says He Has Changed, but Not Into a Traditional Christian
description: Right away, Larry Flynt wants to warn people who have heard about his spiritual experience: Don't get the wrong idea. Larry Flynt still can't stand organized religion, and explicit sex is still the cornerstone of his Hustler magazine.

title: Van Allen Recalls How Radiation S.stamped Explorer 1's Detector
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1Twenty years after Explorer 1 was thrust into orbit inaugurating the American space prograss, veterans of that historic mission met here today to review the past and look to the future.

title: That Was Another Country
description: TIJUANA, MexicoMost Americans think of Tijuana as a small, garish tourist town across the border from California. Those of a certain age may remember it as an attraction for Navy men on liberty from San Diego in or just, after World War II. It was seedy border strip then, a place for sin, population about 50,000.

title: Chairman Is Named For Scouting Drive
description: Robert H. Anderson, head of a New York consulting firm, has been named general chairman of a $2 million fund drive to support Scouting in New York, Darrell D. Eichoff, president of the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America has announced.

title: Mistrial in Bubba Smith Suit
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 1 (AP)A mistrial was declared in Bubba Smith's $2.5 million damage suit against the National Football League after a jury reported today that it was unable to reach a verdict. The former defensive end for the Baltimore Colts contended that his career was ruined when he struck a sideline marker and injured a knee during a 1972 exhibition game here. Smith will have to file his suit again.

title: Rutgers Registers 15th, WhipsW.Virginia, 8061
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.; Feb. 1Rutgers overcame a performance in the first half against West Virginia tonight be fore a subdued crowd of 5,133, then rallied with a strong secondhalf defense and triumphed, 80.61, in an Eastern. Eight League game at the Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: U.S. EFFORT FAILS
description: CAIRO, Feb. 1Two Middle East peace efforts were adjourned here today, and attention turned to President Anwar elSadat's projected talks with President Carter at Camp David this weekend.

title: Australia Leads in Cricket
description: ADELAIDE. Australia, Feb. 1 (Reuters)Australia moved neardr to winning the deciding fifth cricket test against India today, despite a secondinnings collapse in which their last six wickets went down for only 84 runs. The Australians were all out for 256, but that still left India needing 493 for victory. By the close, the Indians were 101 for two.

title: I.R.S. Ruling Is Due On Homestead Rebates
description: TRENTON, Feb. 1If you are uncertain about how to handle your New Jersey homestead rebates on your income tax returns, don't feel bad. The Internal Revenue Service does not have all the answers yet and is scheduled to come out with a clarifying ruling soon.

title: EXPENNSYLVANIA SPEAKER LOSES PLEA ON CONVICTION
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (AP)A Federal appeals court today upheld the obstruction-of-justice conviction of Herbert Fineman, former Pennsylvania House speaker.

title: ForeignPolicy Buffs Celebrate 60 Years of Wrestling With Isolationism
description: One of the few things on which the far right and far left agree is that American foreign policy is essentially the product of a handful of powerful men with interlocking ties to the proper corporations, foundations, and universities.

title: U.S., Surprised by Reports of 3 Israeli Outposts on West Bank, Asks for Clarification
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The Carter Administration, caught unawares by reports of three new Israeli military outposts on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River, sought clarification from Israel today on whether the camps would be transformed into civilian settlements, in apparent disregard of repeated statements of concern by Washington.

title: Uratlp
description: NOEEva. A longtime resident of New York City, died Tuesday, January 31st, in Chevy Chase, Maryland. She was 98 years old In lieu of flowers, friends may make contributions to the Scholarship Fund of the Art Students League, 215 West 57 St, NY 10019.

title: Bonn Defense Minister Moves to Resign Over Spying
description: BONN, Feb. 1Defense Minister Georg Leber, who for more than a month has withstood a storm of criticism over the Infiltration of his ministry by East German spies and the illegal use of eavesdropping devices by defense officials, offered his resignation today.

title: A.T.&T.  PROFIT ROSE 17% DURING 1977 TO $4.54 BILLION
description: Operating Revenues Climbed 11.2% to $36.5 BillionRise in Demand for Services Held Impetus

title: About NewYork
description: Down from the Sheepshead Bay ele vated station, on the top floor of building that sags, lives this man Schwartz with milk cases crammed with decades of letter writing and complaining about how he has been cheated through life by all sorts of people.

title: Columbia Pictures And Begelman End Talks on His Role
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1Alan J. Hirschfield, president of Columbia Pictures Industries, and David Begelman, president of Columbia's motion picture and television operations, concluded two days of meetings here today amid rising controversy over some of Mr. Begelman's financial transactions.

title: CENTRAL VALLEY DATA POINT TO A DEFICIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1An extensive audit of the Central Valley Project in California by the Department of the In. terior disclosed today that unless rates the project now charges for Federally supplied electricity and irrigation water are raised, it will incur a deficit of nearly AR billion in the next 20 years.

title: Hargrove Bowles Jr. Weds Marion Schober in South
description: Marion Deziree Kemp Schober and Hargrove Bowles Jr., both of Greensboro, N.C., were married there yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Joseph Mullins performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. EFFORT FAILS
description: CAIRO, Feb. 1Two Middle East peace efforts were adjourned here today, and attention turned to President Anwar elSadat's projected talks with President Carter at Camp David this weekend.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
$35 Million McGuire Contracts
description: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N.J., Feb. 1 (AP)Contracts totaling more than $35 million were awarded by the procurement office here last year, the Air Force said yesterday. It made 32,810 awards totaling $15 million to small businesses. About $9.7 million was spent in New Jersey, $2.3 million in Pennsylvania, $1.2 million in New York and the rest in other states. Of the $17.2 million awarded to large businesses, $7.7 million was spent in New Jersey, $875,000 in New York, $2.8 million in Pennsylvania and the rest in other states.

title: GOING OUT  Guide
description: A LIFE An exhibition of over 135 items, including first editions, manuscripts, letters, photographs and drawings, from the John Masefield Collection of Columbia University's Rare Book and Manuscript Library will be on view from tomorrow through March 3 at the Low Memorial Library, near 116th Street and Broadway. The exhibitionsaluting the centenary of the Britishpoet laureate's birth, then moves to Butler Library on the Morningside Heights campus, where it will run from March 9 until June 28. Viewing hours are weekdays f1om 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. There is no charge.

title: Washington &
description: WASHINGTONThe contracts 01 postal and construction workers dominate the collective bargaining schedule this year at a time when the Carter Administration is trying a new anti-inflation program already denounced by organized labor as a step toward wage and price controls.

title: Design Notebook
description: IAM NOT a ceiling snob. High or low, it's all one to me. As a house holder, I prefer ceilings that don't leak or fall in. As a practicing critic of art, I feel obliged to lie flat on the floor and stare up at any ceiling that has paintings on it. Beyond that, I never thought about ceilings at all until I came to live here and found out to what an extent the psychic equilibrium of the New Yorker is governed by the height of his ceiling.

title: CARTER, IN TV TALK, ASKS CANAL BACKING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  President Carter appealed directly to the American people tonight to support the ratification of the Panama Canal treaties, which he described as being in the highest national interest of the United States.

title: Dr. Janet Weaver, 44
description: Dr. Janet Weaver, educator, psychologist and former director of the National Child Research Center in Washington, died Tuesday at Raritan Valley Hospital in Greenbrook, N.J. She was 44 years old and lived in Rahway, N.J.

title: Little Mo Rejoins Giants As Defense Coordinator
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 1The last time Dick Modzelewski was Giant was the last time the Giants were in the National Football League playoffs.

title: Drug That Speeds Kepone From Body Reported Found
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 1Researchers at the Medical College of Virginia said today, that they had, found a drug that hastened the elimination of the perticide ???? from the body. The discovery could have implications for persons exposed to other Pesticides and to toxic chemicals.

title: Poisoning Charges Dropped Against 2 Nurses
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1 (UPI)The Government today dropped all charges against two Filipino nurses who were granted a new trial on their conviction for poisoning patients at a Veterans Administration hospital.

title: BYRON J. CRONIN
description: Byron J. Cronin, who retired in 1973 as corporate vice president in charge of perishables for the Grand Union Company, the supermarket chain, of Elmwood Park, N.J., died Monday in Pascack Valley Hospital, Westwood, N.J. He was 70 years old and lived at 88 Wanamaker Avenue, Oradell, N.J.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in The Times on Monday that restitution pledges and payments obtained to date by the office of Charles J. Hynes, the special New York State prosecutor for nursing homes, totaled $25 million. The actual total announced by Mr. Hynes was nearly $5 million.

title: A.M.C. Is Considering Affiliation To Improve Financial Condition
description: SOUTHFIELD, Mich. Feb. 1  The American Motors Corporation, smallest of the four major domestic automakers, is likely to affiliate itself or merge with another company as part of an effort to improve its financial condition and remain in the car business, shareholders of the company were told here today.

title: SENATE GROUP TRIES TO REACH A DECISION ON PRICING OF GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The Senate delegation to the energy conference has begun what may be a final push to resolve the issue of natural gas pricing, which has proved a major stumbling block in efforts to pass energy legislation.

title: New Year Cleanup in Chinese Homes
description: BETWEEN the 24th day of the 12th month of the Chinese calendar, which was yesterday, and New Year's Day, the first day of the Year of the Horse, which is next Tuesday, most of us who indulge in such things will be thinking about the banquets we might be eating.

title: Some Poisoned Israeli Oranges Discovered in Europe
description: TEE, AVIV, Feb. 1Some Israeligrown oranges injected with mercury have turned up in West Germany and the Netherlands since Friday, and a letter bearing the name of a hitherto unknown Arab group said its members had contaminated the fruit to sabotage the Israeli economy.

title: Disks: The Liszt Faust Symphony
description: 1pROBABLY no literary work of the 19th century stirred the Romantic composers as irresistibly as Goethe's Faust, with its strains of diabolical mischief and heroic striving. In whole or in part, it inspired vocal and orchestral settings by Berlioz, Boito, Gounod, Liszt, Mahler, Mussorgsky, Wagner, Schubert, Schumann and Wolf, among others.

title: Rhodesia Talks in Malta End With Some Progress
description: VALLETTA, Malta, Feb. 1The negotiations on the future of Rhodesia ended today without firm agreements but with both sides reporting progress toward a teasefire.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Feb. 1, 1929

title: Uganda Says Amin Acts to Remove Bad Elements From Secret Police
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 1 (Retiters)President Idi Amin of Uganda has shuffled the State Research Bureau, his main secret police force, to remove bad elements, the Uganda radio repotted today.

title: Rise in Total U .S. Arms Sales Seen Despite Curb Set for Fiscal 1978
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  President Carter imposed an $8.6 billion ceiling today on sales of arms to nonallied countries for the 1978 fiscal year, an 8 percent cut from 1977. But White House officials acknowledged that the total value of American military sales to all nations for this fiscal year was likely to rise above $13 billion, almost $2 billion more than in the last year.

title: The Durable Miss Steber
description: ELEANOR STEBER has always been famous for her singing of Mozart, and it was the music of that composer that opened her latest New York recital. This was an appearance at the Juilliard Theater Tuesday night as a member of the school's faculty.

title: GOAL STRIKE PERILS OHIO ELECTRIC POWER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1In its ninth Peek, a. strike by 160,000 coal miners that had stirred little concern outside Appalachia has suddenly.come within days or weeks, depending, on the weather, of creating a disruptive regional curtailment of coalfired electric Dower.

title: HOWARD H. M'CLINTIC JR.
description: Howard H. McClintic Jr., a retired vice president of the McClintic Marshall Company, Pittsburgh, died of a heart attack in his home at Gulf Stream, Fla., Monday. He was 80 years old.

title: TV: Taxi!!!'  as a Social Crucible
description: THE OTHER NIGHT on NBC's The First 50 YearsA Closer Look, Part II, one of those superficial scrapbooks devoted to uroadcasting's past, Orson Welles recalled some of the typical techniques of television's early days. One, the product of. low budgets and cramped studios, was the use of extreme close- upsactors faces against nondescript dark backgrounds. With surprisingly few modifications, this approach can still work extremely well, as can be seen on Taxi!!! which also happens to be on NBC, tonight at 10 o'clock.

description: Beatips

description: To the Editor:

title: Brooke Explains Tough Stand on New York
description: WASHINGTONI fight in Congress all the time for programs for poor people, says Senator Edward W. Brooke, the liberal Republican from Massachusetts. And for urban rehabilitation, too, according to his record.

title: How Sweet It Is...
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Wis.., Feb.,I 1 (AP)'We had a heck of a time getting the kids out of herb last night, said Lloyd Groves, a janitor Stockbridge High School,I today. They were milling around, hollering and yelling.

title: Scotland Awaits More Snow
description: INVERNESS, Scotland, Feb. 1 (Reuters) Helicopters began dropping fodder to starving cattle and sheep in northern Scotland today after the heaviest snowfalls in 30 years. Conditions eased but road and rail links were still cut and more snow was expected tonight. So far the blizzards have taken five lives.

title: HARRISON FORMAN, 74, WAR REPORTER, DIES
description: Harrison Forman, an aviator, explorer, photographer and war correspondent, died of a heart ailment at midnight Tuesday in his home at 40 Central Park South. He was 74.

title: Home Improvement
description: When lamps won't light or bulbs . begin to flicker here's what to do.

title: Avon Products Net Up 19% in Quarter To $1.52 a Share
description: Avon Products, a large maker of cosmetics, frangrances and costume jewelry, reported yesterday fourthquarter net earnings of $88.2 minion, or $1.52 share, up 19 percent on sales of $598.5 million. Foreign currency translations unfavorably affected earnings by 14 cents a share, against 29 cents a year earlier.

title: Carey Assessed $572.33 in Taxes Because of Trips by His Children
description: ALBANY, Feb. 1Governor Carey was today assessed $572.33 in additional back state and city income taxes for free trips by his _children on state aircraft in 1975 and 1976. But Mr. Carey said he continued, to question whether he should have to pay.

title: Hers
description: ii WOULD like to live my life in quiet, without being bothered by children, by churches, by schools, says a dashing young man with a mustache. An older man, who appears to be in his mid50's, declares in bitter tones, I moved to this community with the assurance that I would not be plagued with children.

title: Deaths
description: SHRYERMarvin. The entire staff and trainees of the Manhattan Occupational Training Center mourn the loss of their esteemed colleague and teacher. Deepest condolences to his mother and family.

title: Louis Esposito, in Clearwater, Fla.; Daughter in Coma for 37 Years
description: HILLSIDE, III., Feb. 1 (UPI)Louis Esposito, who for the last 37 years devoted his life to caring for a daughter who fell into the world's longest known coma, died of a lung tumor Saturday at Clearwater, Fla. He was 69 years old.

title: Deaths
description: GRABAUErnestine (nee Kohn). Of Houston, Texas, formerly of Jersey City, beloved wife of the late Robert, survived by many nieces and nephews. Graveside services will be held at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, N.J. on Friday February 3rd, 1978 at 11 A.M. For further information kindly call Gutterman-MusicantKreitzman 212-794-8900.

title: 21 Injured as Chemical Explosion Causes $1.5 Million Loss on Coast
description: HUNTINGTON PARK, Calif., Feb. 1 (AKTwentyone persons, including 17 firemen, were injured in a chemical plant explosion that shattered windows and sent toxic fumes into the air, the authorities said today.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Now that the New York Rangers front office is exploring the possibility of importing Soviet hockey players, it also should consider hiring a Soviet hockey coach, at least as an adviser. The logical choice would be Anatoly Tarasov, who has been to Soviet hockey what Paul Brown has been to pro football. Many people in the National Hockey League believe that it has only three coaches with stature as strategistsScotty Bowman of the Montreal Canadiens, Fred Shero the Philadelphia Flyers (a disciple of Anatoly Tarasov) and

title: Briton Arrives for Belize Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (Reuters)Foreign Afairs Minister of State Edward Rowlands of Britain arrived here today for talks with Foreign Minister Adolfo Molina Orantes of Guatemala on their longstanding dispute over the British colony of Belize, The two men last met here in July, amid mounting fears of border war between Guatemala and Belize, formerly known as British Honduras.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the West Coast's largest operator of department stores, yesterday increased its Dec. 12 negotiating bid of $36 a share for Marshall Field & Company to a formal exchange offer amounting to about $42 a share in cash and stock. The total cost to acquire the Chicagobased department store chain would amount to about $380 million.

title: New York City Is Asked to Detail Its Need for Aid
description: ALBANY, Feb. 1The chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee said today that he did not believe New York State can lock itself into recurring aid of the type the Koch administration was seeking.

title: Timing of Carter's Speech on TV Questioned
description: President Carter's address last night on the Panama Canal .treaty proposals was inauspiciously timed for television. As a result of being carried live by ABC and NBC but not by CBS, the President's fireside chat did not make optimum use of the medium and was probably the least watched of any President's address to the nation in the last two decades.

title: New Construction Spending Up
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI)New construction spending, adjusted for inflation, gained 1.4 percent in December to reach a total of $170.7 billion for 1977, a 16 percent increase above the previous year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Rise in T otal U.S.  Arms Sales Seen Despite Curb Set for Fiscal 1978
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  President Carter imposed an $8.6 billion ceiling today on sales of arms to nonallied countries for the 1978 fiscal year, an 8 percent cut from 1977. But White House officials acknowledged that the total value of American military sales to all nations for this fiscal year was likely to rise above $13 billion, almost $2 billion more than in the last year.

title: Greyhound Increases Offer for Verex to $30
description: In a move to diversify further, the Greyhound Corporation yesterday reached tentative terms to offer shareholders of the Velex Corporation, a leading mortgage insurer, $30 a share or some $100 million in cashfor their 3.36 million shares.

title: U.S. SUES TO RECOVER PENSION FUND LOSSES IN TEAMSTERS PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The Department of Labor filed suit today in an effort to force Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and 18 others to repay losses resulting from allegedly imprudent loans made by the Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Pension Fund since 1975.

title: Orders and Sales Up To Best in 9 Months For Manufacturers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)Business improved substantially for the nation's manufacturers in December as both new orders and sales registered their biggest gains in nine months, the Commerce Department said today. Moreover, it said the backlog of orders increased by the largest amount in more than three years.

title: Insanity Ruling in Murder Case
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 1 (AP)A Mahwah man has been ruled not guilty by reason of insanity in the Election Day stabbing death of his crippled father. The defendant, William Gordon, 26 years old, was committed to Greystone Park State Hospital on Tuesday after the threeday. nonjury trial here before a Superior Court judge, Alfred DeSchiaffo.

title: PANEL HEARS A PROPOSAL TO MOVE CRIME VICTIMS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)A House panel on aging today heard a novel approach to stopping crimes against low-income elderly people in inner cities by using Federal funds to move the victims elsewhere.

title: STEVEN HILL
description: STOCKHOLM, Feb. 1 (AP)  Steven Hill, a former Texas Western University basketball star who was playing professionally in Sweden, was killed in a car accident in a suburb today, the police reported. A woman companion seated next toMr. Hill was fatally injured.

title: Soviet Buys More U.S. Grain For Delivery During This Year
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)The Soviet Union has bought an additional 600,000 metric tons of United States grain for delivery this year, the Agriculture Department announced today.
