title: Movie: Invasion Of the Hubcap Saucers
description: "STARSHIP INVASIONS" appears to have been made early enough to borrow from "Star Wars" but too soon to borrow more than a vague U.F.O. angle from "Close Encounters of the Third Kind," on a budget that might better have been used to supply hot dogs for a small picnic. The flying saucers look like hubcaps, the spacelings' bodysuits are baggy and the Christopher Lee part isn't even properly played by Christopher Lee.Mr. Lee does appear in the film, playing an extraterrestrial from a planet whose sun is about to explode, and he scouts Earth as a possible new home for his dislocated people. But Mr. Lee's people do not speak, except in voice-over; this, plus some black costumes with pointy hoods, is supposed to indicate that they come from somewhere other than B-movieville. Wherever they're from, they should have stayed there.Information about the earthlings is scanty, and it all seems to come from magazine covers. Professor Duncan, played wearily by Robert Vaughn, is evidently a Very Famous U.F.O. Expert, because we glimpse his picture on the cover of People magazine one day. And the star wars, which are cheesily staged and should be of no interest even to the most avid science-fiction buffs, generate a mysterious wave of despondency on earth. "Suicide Epidemic!" screams a fake cover of Time, which depicts a bleeding wrist. As the subhead adds, "Will There Be a Tomorrow?""Starship Invasions" is full of outmoded plexiglass props that look as though they've been remaindered at Bloomingdale's, and cardboard sets that are painfully underdecorated. The movie's only truly futuristic touches are in its exterior shots, which are so grainy they make the air look even muddier than it actually is."Starship Invasions" is rated PG (Parental Guidance Suggested) because one scene features a recreation center stocked with cuties from outer space. No recreation takes place and, in any event, the cuties aren't all that cute.

title: New Encounters of the Schuller Kind
description: When Pierre Boulez became music director of the New York Philharmonic in 1971, he instituted Prospective Encounters, concerts devoted to 20thcentury music in informal surroundings at low prices. Composers could use them to discuss their creationsand answer questions from the audience. Although Mr. Boulez did not conduct all the Encounters, his pervasive spirit attracted the young and openminded. So when he gave up the music directorship of the Philharmonic at the end of last season, the question was would the Encounters be continued.

title: Film: Reiner Directs Winkler
description: THERE is one very funny moment in Carl Reiner's "The One and Only," which otherwise stars Henry Winkler as an egocentric, young, would-be actor who wants to become a Broadway star in the 1950's.The funny moment stars Herv Villechaize, whom you probably remember as the evil midget in "The Man With the Golden Gun." This time Mr. Villechaize, who is 3 feet 11 inches tall, plays a good guy, or at least as good a guy as his character's licentiousness allows.Milton (Mr. Villechaize) is a part-time wrestler and a full-time Romeo and, in the one and only funny moment in the new movie, he is mysteriously smitten with a timid, square, middle-aged, Midwestern housewife. She sits primly on a sofa, hands in lap, attending to her husband's clichs. Milton sits next to her, smiling up at her in a way intended to be sweet but actually the expression of rampant sexuality. He inches closer to her. She inches away. Suddenly he slips his tiny wicked hand onto her lap. She screams andthat more or less is that.What? That doesn't sound especially funny? Well, it is funny and in the context of the rest of "The One and Only," it's something of a privileged moment. Mr. Villechaize is a remarkably gifted comic actor who just happens to be smaller than most. He has a fine appreciation for the ridiculous and possesses a slack-jawed leer that would tone up any French farce.He also tones up "The One and Only," which opens today at three theaters. "The One and Only" is a far cry from French farce and any other kind of farce, being instead an attempt to make a heart-warming comedy about a fellow who, in the film's own terms, is an arrogant boob.When we first meet Mr. Winkler's Andy Schmidt, he seems to be a comparatively elderly undergraduate at a midwestern university where he successfully courts another undergraduate, a woman named Mary Crawford (Kim Darby), who looks old enough to be a tenured professor of physics, by talking to celery stalks, singing (badly) in public places and telling her how great he is.Some forms of egotism can be extremely funnyI think especially of Oscar Jaffe's in "Twentieth Century"if only because we know that the egotism, though infinitely elastic, is a fragile skin enclosing a gigantic inferiority complex. At any moment it might pop. There are no such self-deceptions and no dangers in "The One and Only." Mr. Winkler's Andy Schmidt is all brass, which means, I assume, that we are meant to like him for what he appears to be, which is noisy and untalented.Mr. Reiner, who once directed a hilariously vulgar film called "Where's Poppa," subsequently found God (and great popular success) with "Oh, God." "The One and Only" is more of that sort of safe, schmalzy comedy, but fatally lacking the presence of someone like the great George Burns.Steve Gordon's screenplay, which shows us how Andy Schmidt accidentally becomes a professional wrestling star called the Lover, a sort of combination of Gorgeous George and Liberace, plays with bad taste but never really lets it triumph, which was one of the reasons why "Where's Poppa" succeeded. "The One and Only" makes some mildly bigoted homosexual jokes, but even these can be supported as part of the picture of a bygone era.Mr. Winkler's performance alternates between the coy and the cute, which is monotonous and never as endearing as Mr. Villechaize's random leers. Miss Darby seems miscast and Gene Saks is nicely rude as the foul-mouthed fellow who promotes Andy Schmidt to sleazy stardom."The One and Only," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), talks dirty but its heart is as pure as a biodegradable detergent.

description: NEWARK, Feb. 2Dr. Mel Huden returned to California today after his appointment as interim president of Essex County. College here was withdrawn 24 hours before he was to take office

title: U.S. Postal Service Deficit $688 Million in Fiscal 1977
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI)The Postal Service said today that it ran $687.7 million in the red last fiscal year, as against $1.176 billion the year before, and that it delivered on time 95 percent of the first class mail that could be delivered overnight.

title: Nassau and Suffolk Seek Federal Aid For Storm Damage
description: The Nassau and Suffolk County Executives said yesterday that damage from the recent storms on Long Island totaled at least $35.6 million and that they had asked Governor Carey to designate the Island a disaster area.

title: Philharmonic: Martha Argerich Is Mozart Pianist
description: ARTHUR HONEGGER, like Paul Hindemith, had a high reputation in his day, and it was reputation that dropped sharply after his death. We do not hear much of Honegger's music these days, and the Symphony No. 2, which Rafael Kubelik conducted at last night's New York. Philharmonic concert, was almost a novelty. Yet there was a time when it was a repertory ,item, when such Frenchoriented conductors as Serge Koussevitzky, and Charles Munch were constantly prograMming it.

title: Cities Say Plan to Target U.S. Aid Might Shut Out Some of the Poor
description: SEATTLERainier Valley is the graceful name for a not-so-glamorous section of Seattle. It is a long, narrow urban corridor between hills that is home for many of Seattle's poorblacks, Chicanos, Asians, whites. Many of its streets have no sidewalks or even drainage.

title: Clearing the Job Rights Thicket
description: Even a few years ago, the thought would have sounded lunatic: too many Federal civil rights agencies working against job discrimination? It had taken advocates equal employment opportunity decades to eke out an executive order here, part of a statute there. They took their gains the only way possible, piecemeal. But then civil rights gains accelerated; the inconceivable is now fact. There are some 40 separate Federal equal employment laws and regulations; they are administered by different agencies. The result is fragmentation and frustration that burden employees and employers alike. Any day now, the Carter Administration is expected propose a major reorganization remedy. It is a sensible plan and it is needed.

title: Planned Parenthood's New Head Takes a Fighting Stand
description: Faye Wattleton, the new presidentdesignate of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, said here yesterday that she was putting the world on notice that the traditionally lowkeyed organization was going to become more aggressive in the battle for abortion rights.

title: Russi Retires as Skier
description: GARMISCHPARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Feb. 2 (UPI)Bernhard Russi of Switzerland, a former Olympic downhill gold medalist, announced his retirement from competitive skiing today. Russi, 29 years old, won the world downhill title in 1970 and the Olympic gold medal two years later.

title: Sadat Comes for Help
description: CAIRO, Feb. 2President Anwar elSadat arrives tomorrow in Washington to pursue the latest phase of what he has sometimes called his electricshock strategy for peace negotiations between the Arabs and Israel. He left Cairo today on a tour that will take him to eight countries, but his primary target is the United States.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Califano Rules Three States Lag On Plans for College Integration
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Joseph A. Califano Jr., said today that Georgia and Virginia had failed to present adequate plans to eliminate racial segregation in their state colleges and universities.

title: OTTO H. SALTZGAVER
description: KEOKUK, Iowa, Feb. 2 (UPI)Otto H. (Jack) Saltzgaver, a reserve infielder for the New York Yankees and Pittsburgh Pirates during the 1930's and 1940's, died yesterday at a Keokuk hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Taiwan to Strengthen Army
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 2 (Reuters)Taiwan plans to modernize its army of 500,000 and resist appeasement towards Communism, the Cabinet said in its annual administrative report: The Cabinet saidthe Government would bo,pst the strength of Taiwan's defense and vigorously develop the ordnance industry, and manufacture new weaponry to continue modernizing the Chinese armed forces.

title: Billy Graham's Latest Crusade: Preaching Gospel in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb, 2The Rev. Billy Graham started an evangelistic crusade here last night, declaring from the elevated platform of the Convention Center that he did not come to condemn Las Vegas but to preach the gospel of salvation.

description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2David Begelman's lawyer here released today 10-year-old document signed by Judy Garland that he says answers allegations about Mr. Begelman's handling of theactress's finances contained in an article in the current issues of New York and New West magazines.

title: Patricia Hearst Takes Appeal to High Court
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI)Lawyers for Patricia Hearst, making .final effort to keep her from returning to prison, asked the Supreme Court today to overturn her 1976 conviction for bank robbery.

description: DOMINATING this weekend's television schedule are two of those trick based on fact dramatizations, a new British series Theater to succeed the bloodbath of I, Claudius, and an early valentine from ABC to itself on the occasion of the company's 25th anniversary.

title: Rebels in the Philippines Free Korean Employed by U.S. Company
description: MANILA, Feb. 2 (Reuters)Filipino Moslem rebels released a South Korean technician tonight after they had held him hostage for 15 days until they received a ransom payment, his American employers said.

title: Stenmark Easy Victor in Giant Slalom
description: GARMISCH  PARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Feb. 2Ingemar Stenmark answered his last few critics those who said he could not win pressure raceby sweeping to an easy victory today in the men's giant slalom at the worlti championships of Alpine skiing

title: Koch Names James Brigham Jr., An ExBeame Aide, Budget Chief
description: A 44-year-old tormer banker was appointed New York City's Budget Director yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: U.S. Figure for Jersey's Jobless Is Expected to Top State's Figure
description: TRENTON, Feb. 2A Federal official said today that New Jersey's unemployment figures for January, calculated on a new basis, will be even higher than had been reported.

title: Prosecution of Police In Biko Case Withheld
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 2 (UPI)The Attorney General of eastern district of Cape Province said today that he would not prosecute policemen involved in the arrest and detention of the black leader Steve Biko, who died in a Pretoria prison cell Sept. 12.

title: Transit System Apologizes To Riders With a Free Trip
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 (AP)The troubled Bay Area Rapid Transit district gave free rides to all corners today to atone for weeks of jammed cars and breakdowns.

title: Screen: 'Hero Ain't Nothin' But A Sandwich'
description: WHEN WE FIRST meet Benjie (Larry B. Scott), a 13-year-old boy who lives in the Watts ghetto, he appears to be a happy child. Even though he's poor, his father has long since left his mother (Cicely Tyson) and his mother's lover (Paul Winfield) is a formidable disciplinarian, Benjie's spirits are still high.In no time at all, though, Benjie has become a heroin addict, a development for which the screenplay lays too much groundwork and Ralph Nelson's soft-pedaling direction lays none at all. This is a tragic tale told by film makers who don't seem able to believe that such things are really possible.As its title perhaps indicates, "A Hero Ain't Nothin' But a Sandwich," which opens today at the Embassy I and Columbia I Theaters, is a movie that spells out everything but never manages to be entirely lucid. The boy's drug problem is hashed over endlessly, and it takes enough up-and-down turns to sustain a full-length movie, but neither its cause nor its resolution is well enough defined to make the story plausible. However, Mr. Scott is a winning young actor, able to charm and fast-talk his way through the fuzziest situations.Although Mr. Winfield and Miss Tyson have performed together often, they are not, at least in this instance, an ideally matched pair. Mr. Winfield, as a maintenance man struggling valiantly to provide the boy with a surrogate father, is tough and persuasive, so much so that it's hard to see why Benjie can't take more comfort in his presence. Miss Tyson, on the other hand, is paper-thin; the boy's mother might just have well been played by Donna Reed.One measure of Mr. Nelson's confused approach to his material is the sequence that shows Benjie undergoing drug withdrawal at a clinic; Mr. Nelson's montage of sepia-toned stills, prettily scored, clashes crazily with the tortured expressions on the boy's face.Another measure is the film's presentation of George Washington Carver Junior High School, where the only two teachers we meet are the harshly opposite Cohen (David Groh) and Nigeria (Glynn Turman). Nigeria is shown to be a smart, stimulating teacher of black history; he is also shown to be a headstrong and slightly unreasonable character who has managed, a little puzzlingly, to raise the best-adjusted son in town. Mr. Winfield seems so much more helpful a role model, even as a stepfather, that it's hard to understand why the boys' fates should diverge so drastically."A Hero Ain't Nothin' But a Sandwich" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") because of its subject and because it contains a good deal of harsh language.

title: Broadway
description: UNIVERSAL PICTURES will produce The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas, and while major motionpicture companies have been involved in financing plays and musicals before, this apparently will be the first time that one has gotten involved in the actual production. The Best Little Whorehouse, which is more or less based on something that happened in Texas a few years ago, is about the fight to close down a madam's establishment in a small town. The townspeople want it open; a television commentator wants shut, and finally the Governor comes in and closes it. The musical will open at the Entermedia Theater on East 12th Street on April 9.

title: EXASSOCIATE HIRED BY CONSUMER CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2S. John Byington, chairman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission, hired a former associate last year as a $150-a-day consultant to study the way consumer lawsuits have raised insurance costs for manufacturers.

title: THAIS TO NORMALIZE CAMBODIAN RELATIONS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 2Foreign Minister Uppadit Pachariyangkun returned today from a fourday visit to Phnom Penh and said that Thailand and Cambodia had agreed to restore friendly relations and exchange ambassadors as soon as possible.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times on Tuesday, dealing with penalties for possession of marijuana under the proposed new Federal Criminal Code, stated incorrectly that 150 grams is equal to about half an ounce. The equivalent is 5.25 ounces.

title: Woodcock,  U.S.  Aide in China,Calls Absence of Full Ties an  Absurdity'
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  Leonard Woodcock, who represents the United States in Peking, has returned for a visit, saying that he has no quarrel with President Carter's decision to postpone. any decision regarding further moves on China. But Mr. Woodcock is convinced that it is an absurdity not to have full diplomatic relations.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
NASA Plans to Guide Skylab to Earth
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)Skylab, the largest manmade object in orbit, is moving back toward earth faster than expected and the National Aeronautics and Space Adminis-tration is considering a plan to avoid scattering pieces of the station over the earth as a Soviet satellite did last week, according to an agency official.

title: Shah's Visit to India Stirs Protest
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 2 (Reuters)Students clashed with policemen wielding canes today in a noisy demonstration against the Shah of Iran, who was arriving for a fcurday visit. About 60 Iranian and several hundred Indian students took part in the demonstration as the Shah's motorcade passed from the airport to the Presidential Palace. Several students were detained.

title: Publishing: The Day Of The Spinoff
description: LOOKING at the bookshelves, these days, it's hard to tell which came first, the novel or the movie or television tiein. A miniindustry has been generated of books based on television shows, most often on miniseries. There are novel- izations derived from programs that were once loosely derived from novels. Books have become show biz, and show biz has discovered books.

title: Bankruptcy Step Planned by Hospital Linked to 5 Deaths
description: Riverdell Hospital in Oradell will file today for reogranization under Chapter XI of the Federal bankruptcy laws, .the hospital's counsel said last night..

title: 1,000 Political Pilgrims Take Chamber of Commerce Train to Capital
description: ABOARD THE CONGRESSIONAL SPECIAL, en route to Washington, Feb. 2Mystery fans have their Orient Express. Lovers of New Jersey politics take the annual Chamber of Commerce train to Washington.

title: Radioactive Material Recovered
description: CARTERSVILLE, Ga., Feb. 3 (UPI)A pickup truck carrying radioactive material was recovered this morning several blocks from where it was stolen last night, the police said. Authorities were inspecting the truck to determine whether anyone had tampered with the radioactive material. The office said the truck was owned by Industrial Inspection Industries Inc. of North Canton, Ohio.

title: Carolinan Is Given Life After Juror Changes Mind
description: DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 2 (AP)Jurors were unable to agree on a new sentence for a man they had earlier condemned to death, only to have one juror change her vote when the man collapsed on hearing his fate. The judge said today that he was forced by law to give the man life in prison.

title: Someone's in the Kitchen With Nijinsky
description: Wacky names are almost as much at a premium in dance as they are in rock music, but there is a certain mad logic in The Nijinsky Suicide Health Club, the title of David Woodberry's newest dance, which may be seen at the Kitchen

title: Auctions
description: HISTORY has told us about Paul Revere's ride to Lexington, Mass., in 1775. But there was an earlier ride that the silversmithpatriot made to New York City to report to the Sons of Liberty on the Boston Tea Party. Revere left Boson on Dec. 17, 1773, the day after the dumping of the tea, and returned 10 days later. For the ride he submitted an expense account, totaling 14, to John Hancock, who signed it. That: bill will be. sold at auction at Sotheby Parke Bernet,in New York on April'26.

title: Borg, Laver Advance To Tennis Quarterfinals
description: RICHMOND, Feb.. 2 (UPI)Bjorn Borg overpowered Harold Solomon and won a battle of the baselines, 63, 62, tonight to advance to the quarterfinals of the $175,000 tennis tournament at the Coliseum.

title: Court Won't Free Man Who Refuses To Discuss Bombing
description: A Federal judge refused yesterday to release Pedro Archuleta, a former member of the Episcopal Church's National Commission on Hispanic Affairs, who. was failed six months ago for his refusal to answer a grand jury's questions about.. the 1975 bombing of Fraunces Tavern in lower Manhattan.

title: A House Panel Bars Curb on Abortions In Women's Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2A House subcommittee today rejected, 5 to 3, a measure that would permit employers to withhold pregnancy benefits from employees who had abortions unless the woman's life would be endangered if she gave birth.

title: Touring NeoGothic New York
description: In 1829, Richard Upjohn, carpenter, Walked away from the spires of Britain's West Country toward a new life in America, Apart from the tools of his trade that he no doubt carried with him, Upjohn brought a dedication to the Gothic Revival style in architecture. Settling ultimately as an architect in,New York City, Upjohn was instrumental in spreading the gospel of Gothic Revival here. Tomorrow an expert will be offering one and all a look at a couple of Upjohn'sand James Renwick'smost notable works.

description: TUNIS, Feb. 2A week after the gravest riots in Tunisia since it gained independence from France 22 years ago many here say there may be more trouble.

description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 2 (AP)Dutch and West German officials said today that widespread checks of imports, begun after contaminated Israeli fruit turned up in Dutch and German markets, had yielded two poisoned oranges of nonIsraeli origin.

description: ATLANTA, Feb. 2Enjoying their new role as the leader rather than follower in the National. Hockey League race, the Islanders maintained their 3point margin over the Philadelphia Flyers at the head of the Patrick Division by beating the Atlanta Flames, 52, tonight.

title: Yablonski Killer Testified In Hope of Lesser Sentence
description: MEDIA, Pa. (AP)A former mine union official who refused to testify against W. A. Boyle at his 1974 trial on charges of murdering a rival for the presidency of the United Mine Workers said today that he had changed his mind after being promised a prosecutor's efforts to reduce his sentence.

title: DON FREEMAN DIES; ILLUSTRATOR WAS 69
description: Don Freeman, a noted illustrator and awardwinning author of books for children, died Wednesday in New York of a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: RUSSIANS, IN A SPACE FIRST, REFUEL ENGINES IN ORBIT
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 3 (UPI)Two Soviet astronauts successfully carried out a dangerous and unprecedented outer space refueling of the jet and rocket engines of their orbiting Salyut 6 space laboratory.

title: Deaths
description: LANTZEleanor DeHaven. Widow of Harold D. Lantz. Age 74, formerly of Valatie, N.Y. Died February 1, 1978, at Lancaster, Pa. She is survived by three daughters, Mrs. William C. Blake, of Peconic, N.Y., Mrs. Donald A. McMahon, of Atlanta, Ga, Mrs. Robert C. Fringer, of Newtown, Pa, 16 grandchildren, one great grandchild, tour brothers and one sister. Services for Mrs. Lantz will be held today at Luther Acres Chapel,, Lititz, Pa, at 2:00 P.M. Interment will be Kinderhook, N.Y.

title: Music: Waldman Leads Rieti Concerto Premiere
description: THE MUSIC of Vittorio Rieti has always been Italianate in its clarity and buoyancy, civilized in its telling economyit never outstays its welcome. The latest work from the Egyptianborn Italian composer who has lived in the United States for the last 38 years, follows the style and spirit he has developed and clung to throughout his career. It is Concerto for String Quartet and Orchestra, commissioned in honor of Mr. Rieti's 80th birthday by Musica Aeterna, which gave the premiere of it in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night.

title: Pieces of Satellite Devoid of Radiation Exhibited in Canada

title: Mime: Jim Moore's Street Art
description: JIM MOORE attempted to bring the world of the street mime to SoHo's Robert Freidus Gallery on Wednesday. That he succeeded in part was due to considerable personal magnetism and a real gift that was allowed to assert itself fitfully throughout the program.

title: Seattle Slew to Run; Stud Plans Put Off
description: Seattle Slew's owners decided last night to continue racing the Triple Crown winner instead of retiring him as a breeding stallion.

title: PRICES MOVE DOWN  IN METAL FUTURES
description: The prices of all precious metals futures declined yesterday because of what brokers thought was a probable misreading of the results of the latest International Monetary Fund gold auction.

title: Management
description: The idea that middle managers do not get fired is a myth, according to Albert Porter, professor of business at San Jose State University in California. In fact, experts claim that more and more middle managers are getting fired these days.

title: Music: Beethoven, Two by Four

title: Advertising

That's as dumb as Please don't squeeze the Charmin. We don't like advertising in the first place, and a chap like Qwentin won't make matters better.

title: Italy's Ruling Party Deeply Split On Communist Bid for New Status
description: ROME, Feb. 2The Prime Minister designate, Giulio Andreotti, who is seeking to succeed himself as head of the Rawl government, has suspended his stalled negotiations with the Communists and other parties to await the outcome of a sharp debate within his own party, the Christian Democrats.

title: Denver Radio Personnel Indicted in Ratings Case
description: DENVER (AP)The news director and program director of a Denver radio station were indicted by a grand jury today in connection with the alleged manipulation of local audience ratings.

title: Strike Halts Trains in Portugal
description: LISBON, Feb. 2 (Reuters)Portuguese railway workers went on strike for higher pay today and some 20,000 teachers struck over what they say is the refusal of the Ministry of Education to consult the union on policy matters. The nationalized rail network canceled all trains for the fourhour period of the strike.

title: Byrne Weighs Appeal In Deduction Ruling
description: TRENTON, Feb. 2New Jerseyans with children in parochial schools will have to wait a day or so before being advised what to do in the Federal and state income tax returns.

title: Youth Is Arrested In Student's Killing
description: A 16-year-old high school student who had been sought by the police for nearly a month was arrested last night and charged with stabbing to death a fellow student at John Adams High grhnni in Oueens on Jan. 4.

description: HONOLULU, Feb. 2 (AP)Genp Littaking advantage of fastgreens, putted his way, to a seven-under-par 65 today. and. a One-stroke lead inc the, $250,000 Hawaiian open golf tournament.

title: Bonnies 72, Providence 64
description: OLEAN. N.Y., Feb. 2 (UPI)Nick Urzetta scored 18 points; including 9 during a fiveminute span in the second half, to spark St. Bonavenutre to a 7264 upset over 16thranked Providence tonight.

title: STATE DEPT. AND C.I.A. SPLIT ON ENVOY ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2An order by President Carter giving United States ambassadors around the world authority to supervise all United States Government officers and employees in theircountries has produced widely divergent interpretations by the Central Intelligence Agency and the State Department.

title: Air co Sues BOC in Bid To Undo Share Sale
description: Airco Inc., fighting a takeover by BOC International Ltd., yesterday sued the British industrial gas producer in Wilmington Federal Court in an effort to undo BOC's purchase of 1.8 million Airco shares for $43 a share. The block gives BOC, with Airco stock it already owned, 49 percent of the New Jersey company.

title: Coal Talks Off After Raising Hopes for Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, Feb. 3Negotiators for the United Mine Workers union and the major coal companies failed to reach an expected agreement early today to end the nineweek strike of 160,000 miners in Applachia and the Middle West.

title: 200 Hasidim Crowd Court as Murder Trial Opens
description: More than 200 members of the Hasidic Jewish community packed the courtroom yesterday as a 16-year-old youth went on trial in State Supreme Court in the stabbing death last June of 17-year-old Abraham Goldman of the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

title: Keeping Cool on Ethiopia
description: A thousand Soviet advisers, two thousand Cubans, and hundreds of planes and ships full of military equipment have descended on Ethiopia in recent months. Washington is distressed. President Carter has warned Moscow that its grow. ing military involvement jeopardizes AmericanSoviet cooperation on other issues. Many worry that if thE Soviet Union makes client of the Marxist Leninist Ethiopian Government of Colonel Mengistu, will acquire a base for subversion in Africa and for interference with the crucial Red Sea oil routes. Many worry even more about the growing willingnessand capacityof the Soviet Union to project its military power far from home. These are legitimate concerns. But there can be no reasonable discussion of countermeasures without some perspective about the situation.

title: Soviet Dissidents Say Aid For Families Is Continuing
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 2 (Reuters)A fund to aid dependants of imprisoned Soviet dissidents was reported today to be operating as usual despite a statement by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's Swiss lawyers that assets for the fund had been temporarily frozen.

description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 2 (AP)The Phelps Dodge Corporation, Arizona's biggest copper producer, will spend mcre exploration money this year for energy sources such as coal than for copper, a company spokesman said today.

title: Art Earl Kerkam  Painter's Painter
description: IT is disconcerting that paintings done little more than 15 years ago should seem like relics of a much more distant age. But such is the case with a selectioh of can vases,. most, of them from the 1960's, by the late Barl Kerkam at the Zabriskie Gallery 29 West 57th Street.

title: Mental Health Aide Charges Carey Budgets Much Too Little for Care
description: ALBANY, Feb. 2An advocate of mentalhealth care testified today that the $11.4 million Governor Carey wanted to add to mentalhealtli financing was rather an illusion that would do little to achieve its stated goal of improving community services.

description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa, Feb. 2 (AP)Jerome Whitehead had 25 points and 13 rebounds to lead Marquette to a 7360 victory tonight over Penn State.

title: The U.N. Today
Sports News Briefs
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2Danny Ongais, a former dragracing champion who drove in the Brazilian Grand Prix last Sunday and whose major objective this year Is the Indianapolis 500, earned the pole position today for the 24 Hours of Daytona sportscar endurance race, which begins Saturday.INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2 (AP) Chris Evert officially joined the Los Angeles Strings of, World Team Tennis today to try to raise the lagging team to championship status.LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 2 (AP)Erich Scharer, a 28-year-old Swiss, continued his assault on Mount, Van Hoevenberg's bobsled run today, breaking the track record for the second consecutive day.STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 2 (AP) Jan Hoffman of East Germany, the defending European champion, overcame a faulty landing on a triple loop to retain his singles crown at the European figure skating championships tonight. Second place went to last year's runnerup, Vladimir Kovalev of the Soviet Union, and Robin Cousins of Britain placed third.

title: Columbus Discovers a Center, Lands in Playoffs
description: After years of searching, Columbus High School has finally discovered a big man to play center on the basketball team. As a result, the Explorers from the Bronx have made the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs.

We are talking with Tueart, said Chuck Adams, commenting on a report in Manchester that Tueart was close to signing with the Cosmos and that Manchester City would receive a transfer fee of $485,000.

description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 2 (AP)  The Federal Government is acting to limit the exposure of workers to benzene, a widely used chemical that has been linked to leukemia.

description: The dollar drifted lower against most major currencies in foreign exchange trading here and abroad yesterday as the embattled French franc took another beating, The Associated Press reported.

title: PENTAGON IS SEEKING $56 BILLION INCREASE OVER NEXT FIVE YEARS

Brown, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, urged Congress today to keep the B1 bomber program alive. title: Kenon's 42 Help Spurs Sink Knicks
description: SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 2  Larry Xenon, half of San Antonio's twoman representation on the National Basketball Association's Eastern AllStar squad, played the part to the hilt with 42 points against the New York Knicks tonight as the Spurs raced to a 123113 victory in the Convention Center Arena.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2President Carter told Mayor Koch today that the Administration would support further financial help for New York City once he was certain that all the local parties with an interest in the city's future were also making the maximum effort.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times on Tuesday, dealing with penalties for possession of marijuana under the proposed new Federal Criminal Code, stated incorrectly that 150 grams is equal to about half an ounce. The equivalent is 5.25 ounces.

Many are engaged in reevaluating their own permanent collections, and Mounting exhibitions based on themexhibitions familiar objects that sometimes, oddly enough, bring new sense of discovery.

title: Western Diplomats in. Mogadishu Hear of Major Ethiopian Drive
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Feb. 2 (Reuters) Western diplomats said today that Ethiopia had launched air attacks against Somali forces, signaling a counteroffensive in the Ogaden desert war.

title: CommonLaw Wife of Accused Spy Says Hanoi Holds Son Hostage
description: WASHINGTON (AP)The lawyer for a United States Information Agency official accused of spying for Hanoi said tonight that a son of his client's commonlaw wife was being held hostage in Vietnam.

title: St. Louis Man Is Found Guilty Of Killing Larchmont Officer
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 2 (AP)Anthony Blanks was found guilty tonight of killing a Larchmont N.Y.. police officer. The trial was the second for Mr. Blanks for the crime. His first on the firstdegree murder charge ended in a hung jury last July, when the jury reported it was hopelessly deadlocked.

title: DEVELOPMENT OF OIL OFFSHORE REVAMPED BY HOUSE, 291 TO 91
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The House today passed by a vote of 291 to 91 a bill that would revamp the way in which Federal offshore oil and natural gas reserves are developed.

title: Jewish Leaders Decide Not to Meet Sadat in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 2Leaders of the major American Jewish organizations said today that they had declined to seek an invitation to meet with President Anwar elSadat during the Egyptian leader's visit here starting tomorrow. But some prominent Jews, including several businessmen, are still due to meet with him on Monday.

description: A lawyer who handled a liquorlicense application for two undercover officers seeking to infiltrate organized crime was convicted yesterday of stealing from the officers and trying to defraud the state by lying on the application.

title: Mandel Case Lawyers Win Delay
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 2 (AP)Lawyers for Marvin Mandel, the suspended Governor of Maryland, and his five codefendants have been granted a delay until March 2 for filing briefs with the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The six men are appealing their Aug. 23 conviction on mail fraud and racketeering charges in connection with an alleged scheme in which Mr. Mandel accepted favors in return for using his influence.

description: Sewing Bee

title: Contract Accord Is Reported Near In Coal Walkout
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2Negotiators were reported tonight to be nearing agreement on a new contract that could end the nineweek strike of 160,000 coal miners in Appalachia and the Middle West in about 10 days.

title: Bomb Shakes Downtown Beirut For 3d Day Amid Rising Tensions
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 2 (UPI)A bomb today shook downtown Beiruuut for the third time in as many days, raising political tensions in Lebanon. No casualties were reported.

title: EXCHANGE REJECTS CONSOLIDATION PLAN

title: 43 Russian Dissidents Urged for Nobel Prize
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (Reuters)Eleven members of Congress nominated a group of Soviet humanrights advocates today for the 1978 Nobel Peace Prize.

title: A Vital Decision for Waldheim: Filling New U.N. Economic, Development, Post
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 2Diplomats here are waiting curiously for Secretary General Kurt Waldheim's decision on who will fill the new post of director general for economic development, a position created under the United Nations new restructuring program.

title: Notes on People
description: If I had not watched the mirror, would not have believed I could produce such a beautiful creature, Natal- ya Makarova said yesterday, hours after giving birth to her first child, 5pound Andre Michel Karkar. The ballerina, on leave from the American Ballet Theater, had the baby by natural childbirth Wednesday night at the University of California Medical Center in San Francisco, where she lives with her husband, Edward Karkar, an electronics executive. Speaking by telephone yesterday of Andrusha, the Slavic diminutive by which the child will be known, Miss Makarova said, He's small but he has long, long legs, with chestnut hair and blue eyes. The ballerina, who defected from the Kirov ballet company of Leningrad in 1970, has not danced in five months.

title: BILL KENNEDY
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 (UPI)Bill Kennedy, who wrotea Mr. L.A. column for The Los Angeles HeraldExaminer until his retirement several years ago, died of cancer today at Wadsworth Veterans Hospital. He was 64-year-old.

title: The Editorial Notebook Potted Palms and Wilted Roses
description: There was an ecumenical groundbreaking this week for New York City's new Palace Hotel, the 51story, 1,050room tower that Harry Helmsley will build behind the Villard Houses on Madison Avenue. Representatives of city and church (the land and the Villard Houses are owned by the Archbishopric of New York) joined the builder to tout the new luxury hotel that is to rise on the 95-year-old Italianate brownstone block by McKim, Mead and White. The brownstone landmark will be keptafter a lengthy preservation struggleas the hotel's entrance, with some of the period rooms incorporated into the new building's public spaces.

title: At the Movies
description: LISTENING to three of the boys in The Boys in Company C gripe about the hard beds, bugs, heat and fatigue they endured in making their Vietnam War film on location in the Phillippines would have brought a tear to the eye of the toughest veteran of that conflict.

title: Stamford Grand Jury Will Look Into Zoning Practices in Fairfield
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Feb. 2A special Federal grand jury that was empaneled earlier this week to hear evidence of municipal corruption in Stamford will also investigate zoning practices in this town, according to sources close to the inquiry.

The issue is the grounding of pilot. Flights out of Trinidad and Tobago by the airline and by Trinidad and Tobago Air Service are affected.

title: Divorced Fathers: Who Are Happiest
description: In the imperfect world of divorced fatherhood, the socalled halftime father, one who shares child custody equally with his former wife, tends to be happier in his role than his counterpartsthe weekend father and the fulltime father.

title: Lighting Up the Blackout
description: A welcome new report has pinpointed the crucial events that led to the July 13 blackout of New York City and Its suburbs. Instead of listing dozens of human and mechanical failures that might have contributed to the collapse of the system, as previous reports have done, this one focuses on several steps that might have averted complete failure of electrical service. The study was made by Norman M. Clapp, a special consultant to Governor Carey and former chairman of the Wisconsin Public Service Commission, with help from the New York State Public Service Commission. It finds fault not just with Con Edison, everybody's favorite scapegoat, but with other utilities, the state power pool that coordinates transfers of power among utilities, and the Public Service Commission itself. The proposals for reform are not wholly persuasive but the diagnosis of the blackout the most incisive yet.

title: Suppliers and Users Plan Copper Agency
description: GENEVA, Feb. 3Copper producer and consumer nations agreed tonight to establish an intergovernmental agency, where they propose to work together to stabilize the metal's volatile world market.

title: Notes on People
description: Hubert H, Humphrey 3d, a state Senator in Minnesota, had been expected to run for the United States House of Representatives before his father's death last month, but yesterday he announced that he would be a candidate instead for state Attorney General. Political observers regard that as the opening of a drive by the 35-year-old son of the late Senator to run eventually for his father's Senate seat. Mr. Humphrey said his decision had the support of his mother, Muriel Humphrey, who vas appointed last week to succeea her husband. Asked whether Humphrey dynasty was being created, Mr. Humphrey replied: Absolutely not. I think I will have to work hard to live up to the name.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was reported incorrectly in The Times yesterday that Gregory T. Haugan, deputy director of the North- east Corridor rail improvement project, had been dismissed along with the director, Kenneth T. Sawyer. title: Kings Point 78, Hunter 58
description: King's Point's brother combination of Mike and Kevin Ennis combined for 29 points and 20 rebounds last night to lead the Mariners to a 7858 basketball triumph over Hunter College. Hunter's Dennis Britton led all scorers with 24 points. King's Point evened its record at 818 while Hunter fell to 97.

title: Gulielma Fell Alsop, Founded Barnard's Medical Department
description: Dr. Gulielma Fell Alsop, who founded Barnard College's medical department in 1917 and headed it for 35 years, died Jan. 26 in White River Junction, Vt. She was 96 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: GEZINA MEIJER, RETAILER, HEADED A 28STORE CHAIN
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 3 (AP)Gezina Meijer, a Dutch Immigrant who helped pyramid $350 in groceries bought on credit into a 28store Michigan retail chain, died Wednesday while on vacation in Miami Beach, Fla. She was 91 years old and was the former president of Meijer Inc.

Most of the trucks are 1978 models. The recall embraces 17,000 1978model F100, F150 and Bronco light duty trucks and 9,000 1978model F250 and F350 light trucks.

title: Chew on a Dollar, Sleep in a Water Tower
description: In CA, people take courses in Prosperity. They chew on dollar bills (woody in taste) to learn that money is not dirty. Jumping up and down while wildly handclapping is called enthusing and is required. Prosperity costs $250, takes 41 hours over four days, and is available in LA and SF. Graduates lose their hangups about money and can imagine cash piling up in their laps, spilling onto the floor, filling rooms, busting ceilings. They are rewarded by silver Glitter dumped in their hair by Mr. Sunshine, the trainer, at graduation. People hum fiercely into each other's ears, imparting fiscal energy. The poor are not as poor in CA as they are in other parts of the nation but the rich are so very rich, and have bought themselves so many handsome things, that being less than rich makes  one feel bad, dumb.

title: Norman Ives, 54; Graphic Designer And Yale Teacher
description: Norman Seaton Ives, prpfessor of graphic design at the Yale School of Art, died Thursday of lung cancer in St. Raphael's Hospital, New Haven. He was 54 years old.

title: Frederick Kuh, War Reporter, 82
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 3Frederick Kuh, diplomatic correspondent for The Chicago SunTimes who was considered. one of this country's most resourceful reporters in Europe during World War II, died yesterday in Rockville, Md. He was 82 years old.

title: U.S. EASING BARS ON OUTPUT OF UNITED BRANDS BANANAS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP)The Government announced today that it was relaxing some antitrust restrictions on banana production against United Brands, formerly the United Fruit Company, because the company no longer has a monopoly on banana imports to the United States.

title: Publisher to Stay On

title: Treating the Doctor Problem
description: The innercity doctor has become an endangered species in New York City. Over the past decade, every borough except Staten Island has lost physicians; the number in Brooklyn and the Bronx has dropped by more than a quarter. Nearly half of the city's health districts have less than one physician per thousand residents, far below the national average. So there is welcome news indeed from Washington; As many as 50 federally sponsored physicians will be sent to poor neighborhoods New York City this summer.

title: Coal Supplier Found For New Haven Line
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 3Conrail announced today that it had found a new supplier for the 175 to 200 tons of coal it needs daily to operate the New Haven Division's 200 commuter trains and would not have to cut back on service. as extensively as it had exoected.

title: Writings From the Time of Jesus Sought Around World by Scholars
description: DURHAM, N. C.One day a microfilm may arrive from Moscow; the next day a photostat from the Vatican. The third day may bring a typescript from Athens or Jerusalem or Australia. All this is part of a research project into writings from around the time of Jesus.

title: Arrogance Rock Ouintet Carries Forth at Trax
description: A band that calls itself Arrogance ha better be good, and Arrogance, rock quintet from Chapel Hill, N.C., is good. The group isn't quite goon enough, to live up to its billing, but the musicians do not really project much hubris. They are at Trax through tonight, and they seem to have come to play, not to showoff.

The pact includes voluntary wage restraints in exchange for a Government promise to expand democracy.
