title: Despite Strike, Most Farmers Will Reap Full Crop
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 3Lee McGuire, who farms some of the country's most fertile land,',will applaud leaders of the current national strike movement if their calls for sharp cutbacks in production succeed in raising agricultural prices.

title: PlainLanguage Law Facing Amendatory Relegislative Proceeding
description: The revolutionary state law in New York'State requiring apartment leases and Other consumer contracts to be written in plain and simple English is running into trouble even before it can go into effect June 1.

title: Carter's Ratings Surprise Networks
description: Although it was carried by only two networks and faced competition for the national audience from a CBS movie with Joanne Woodward, See How She Runs, President Carter's fireside chat on the Panama Canal treaties Wednesday night drew a larger audience than even the White House had expected.

title: Deaths
description: MILLERSarah Beloved wife of ihe late Isidore, devoted mother of Joseph, Charles, Libby and Jerv. Loving grandmother. Services Wbre held Friday at Gutterman's Lincoln Square Chapel Broadway at 66 St, NYC.

title: David Woodberry in Nijinsky Club
description: David Woodberry's Nijinsky Suicide Health Club has nothing to do with Nijinsky, suicide, or health clubs. Nevertheless, that title does fit the piece, presented Thursday night as the first attraction in a new dance series at the Kitchen Center for Video and Music.

title: Upset by Neighbor's Loud Stereo, Man Shoots 4, Then Kills Himself
description: Apparently ,enraged by loud music coming from the apartment above his, a 45-year-old Kew Gardens, Queens,man shot four of the five people in the apartment yesterday, then returned to his living room and killed himself.

title: New Rochelle Told to Begin Reassessing
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 3Justice Anthony J. Cerrato of State Supreme Court here directed the city of New Rochelle today to reassess all the real property within its boundaries at full market value rather than at a percentage of that value, as it has been doing.

title: ,Senator Case Chides Opponents on Experience Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Senator Clifford P. Case last night chided his young opponents in this year's United States Senate race for failing to have enough respect for experience in office.

title: STOCK MARKET ACTION AROUND THE WORLD
description: STOCK MARKET ACTION AROUND THE WORLD

title: ALBANY REPORT Tax Aid to Counties And Partisan Politics
description: ALBANY DEMOCRATS in the Legislature may argue that declines in county property taxes enables them to hold the line on additional assistance to the counties but Republicans respond that the declines thus far are not enougha point the Democrats will not disputeand in any event, may not actually be declines at all.

title: SHOP TALK A Literary Haven
description: WESTPORT Acustomer's right to privacy is so respected at the Remarkable Book Shop at 177 Main Street here that the sales staff is in structed to avoid all such phrases as, May I help you? when greeting a customer. A simple Hello is recommended, or merely encouraging the visitor to wander until he or she wants assistance. Then there's a brass bell to be rung to bring the staff on.the run.

title: Births.
description: Jane and Arthur Rosenbloom Ionfully announce the birth of their daughter, Maggie Dara, on Jan. 30, 1978.

title: THE GOVERNOR AND HIS COMMISSIONER
description: It was one of those meetings most uncomfortable for a public official. Gov. Brendan Byrne had chosen Essex County Prosecutor Joseph Lordi to head the state's newly created  and highly sensitive  Casino Control Commission, and here were statepolice officials advising him not to make the appointment because, at the very least, could be a major embarrassment. De- spite these warnings, Governor Byrne went ahead and named Lordi anyway. The statepolice response was symptomatic of the whole confused mix of Atlantic City politics, organized crime and law enforcement. They promptly reopened an investigation of Governor Byrne himself.

title: Taiwan: Eager To Plunge Into ColorTV Market
description: TAI PEI, TAIWAN In the last decade, Y.J. Wu has transformed United Electronics from small electronic toy maker into one of Taiwan's 10 largest electronics companies. The field of electronics is almost unlimited, said Mr. Wu, the company's 92-year-old president. You can always develop something new.

title: Space
description: WASHINGTON  The Soviet satellite that crashed into the Canadian tundra.has kicked up an aftershock of concern over the obvious fact that what goes up must come down, even if it might not happen until the year 2578.

title: Long Kepone Cleanup Is Predicted
description: RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 4Although successful effort to detoxify victims of kepone poisoning was announced last week, Virginia's problems with the pesticide will not be solved for several years, state and Federal officials say.

title: John Feeley, Guitarist. In Recital Debut
description: John Feeley, who made his formal New York debut Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, was a 20-yearold engineering student. when he taught himself to play the guitar five years ago. He subsequently dropped engineering and moved from Ireland to New York to pursue music. He is now studying for an M.A. at Queens College.

title: Tensions In Textiles: A Challenge From Asia
description: uring the Industrial Revolution, England was the world's capital of textile manufacture and trade. Then in succeeding waves of industrialization, the textile centers shifted America, then to Japan and now to Hong Kong, South Korea and Taiwan.

title: The Sounds of Silence
description: That Thomas Merton was an extraordinary man no one doubts. Born in France, Jan. 31, 1915, the son of a New Zealand artist and an American mother, he grew up in Flushing and

title: Nixon 72 Fund Still Has $313,715
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI)Richard M. Nixon's 1972 Presidential campaign fund is down to its last $313,715.78, and some of the major figures in the Watergate scandal are claiming it.

title: Lynn Klock Performs On Classical Saxophone
description: The saxophone continues to lead fairly shadowy existence in classical music compared to its ubiquitous presence in band and jazz environments. Even so, there is a surprisingly extensive body of contemporary works for the classical saxophonist to draw on, and, in his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday afternoon, Lynn Klock assembled program that had a considerable amount of expressive variety and sheer musical charm.

title: CARTER TELLS SADAT U.S. TRIES TO ACHIEVE FAIR MIDEAST PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  President Carter and President Anwar elSadat of Egypt opened talks today at Camp David, with Mr. Carter trying to convince the Egyptian .leader of Washington's intentions to press for a fair Middle East settlement but insisting that compromises had to be made by Egypt as well as by Israel.

title: Point of View
description: Substantial parts of the South and midBronx, East New York, Browns= ville and Harlem and East Harlem might be turned into assets of a planned and wellordered citynot by new and massive concrete structures or even by lowrise, lowdensity rebuilding but, rather, by a progressive change of policy and laws concerning redevelopment.

title: The Arrival of Al D'Amato
description: FOR Alfonse M. D'Amato, becoming chief executive of the country's largest town represents the realization of dream. A dream that I've always looked forward to, said, a challenge, a place where I can be happy going further politically.

title: No Rhodesia Settlement Can Ignore Joshua Nkomo
description: VALETTA, Malta  After struggling for more than a quarter of a century to establish a majorityruled Rhodesia, Joshua Nkomo must feel like Moses on the mountaintop, gazing into the Promised Land but fated not to lead his people into it. Majority rule for Rhodesia  or Zimbabwe, as the black nationalists call it  seems near at hand, but Mr. Nkomo is looking on from afar.

title: Ban on LaetrileRich Apricot Seeds To Be Heard by New York Court
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 3The two-year-old controversy between naturalfood dealers and New York State agriculture officials over apricot kernels will get its first judiial test next week in State Supreme Court.

title: SCHOOLS CLEANERS VOTE FOR A WALKOUT
description: School cleaners voted unanimously yes: terday for a strike that could disrupt operations in New York City's 1.1 millionpupil public school system.

title: Realty News.
description: The North Star Reinsurance Corporation has leased the entire 22d floor at 88 Pine Street containing about 18,000 square feet of office space for 15 years at an aggregate rent of more than $3.2 million.

title: Learning at Church to Fix Up Home
description: NEW CASSEL IT'S the buzz of a hand drill, the hum of a sewing machine and the rhythmic beat of hammers, not the sounds of choir practice, that are drifting from the firstlevel meeting room of the Grace Temple Church of God here these Saturday mornings.

title: Rediscovering The Work Ethic
description: GOVERNMENT should encourage the work standard or ethic, not discourage it. In the preoccupation with enormous social programs, many government leaders have forgotten the working man and the abiding genius of this country.

title: Hartford's Agenda: Laws
description: HARTFORD N Wednesday, when Governor Grasso opens the new session of the General Assembly, she will be faced with the prospect of more clangor and serious contention than any Governor of Connecticut has faced in recent memory. Four of the five people in both parties who have openly declared their determination to unseat her as Governor will be among the legislators gathered to hear her. One of them, Lieut. Gov. Robert K. Killian, the leader  of the mutiny In the Governor's Democratic Party. will be at her side.

title: GARDENING
description: SNOWFALL does have its compensations. It forces the housebound gardener outdoors and lets him flex his muscles a bit behind a shovel and ice scraper.

title: CAMERA
description: Even fairly competent photographers often find that the pictures that they wind up with after shooting some ski scenes are disappointing: In some cases the subjects are too dark, in others the skiing figures are so small that you can't tell one person from another, and in still others the mountain scenery and color are obscured by a hazy overcast.

title: A Collector Turns Wheels of History
description: MILFORD ASTEAM engine with a black belly,  brass pipes and wrought;iron grate blows its earpiercing whistle as it chugs and chortles away. A sixhorsepower Foos engine, built in 1910, spits and chokes on its gasoline fuel before it putters into a routine pace, making its brightgreen flywheels .,spin. A 1920 Witte dragsaw, none the worse for wear, sends sawdust in all directions as it eats through a fat tree trunk.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Tennis players talk of fast and slow surfaces. Exactly what do they mean, and which surfaces are which?

title: emanding Guitar Bill For Lynn Gangbar
description: At the tender age of 21, Lynne Gang. bar seems ahle to do anything she wants to technically on the e guitar. The Canacran artist. in her New York debut. Thursday night at the ey2d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. under the auspices of the center for InterAmerican Relations, and in cooperation with the Society of the Classic Guitar, played a de. manding program with the security and presion of an old master.

title: Army 64, Penn State 52
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 4 (AP)Clennie Brundidge and Gary Winton led Army on an 186 gamebreaking stretch in the second half and the Cadets defeated Penn State, 64.52, tonight.

title: Banking's International Face
description: LONDON The City of London, the famous square mile housing the financial capital of the world, seemed just a year ago to be in jeopardy. The pound had recently fallen to $1.55, the British Government had exhausted its market credit and there were signs of a possible exodus of foreign banks. The City's rivals scented an opportunity.

title: Lowell Thomas
description: FOR Lowell Thomas, 1977 was rather a typical year. He lectured, he traveled, he appeared on radio and television. He met with dignitaries like King Hussein; he attended reunions with old comrades, like the men who raided Tokyo in 1942. He looked after his business interests, which consist the list is not complete  of broadcasting, film and newspaper properties; he guarded his seniority as an Alpine skier. He journeyed down the Yangtze gorges, up the slopes of Mount Everest and into the fastness Tibet. Though Lowell Thomas and the News had gone off the air in 1976 after 46 years, the longest run the history of broadcasting, Mr. Thomas did not let time hang heavy on his hands. He wrote some more books. The total now stands at 54. The three published in 1977 include two volumes of autobiography, the latest being So Long Until Tomorrow. And Mr. Thomas got married.

title: THEATER
description: NEW HAVEN STANDING 6 feet 1 inch tall, his thin frame tucked under a thatch of strawcolored hair, Andrei Serban looks like a basketball player and speaks with a Rumanian accent. The night we met he was wearing white peasant blouse under an embroidered sheepskin vest, the whole thing covered by a dark, shaggy wool pancho with sleeves. The upper half of me is Rumania, the lower half Bloomingdale's, he said.

title: Page Ober Fiancee Of Philip A. Picard
description: The engagement of Sylvia Page Ober to Philip Andre Picard has been announced by Robert Barclay Ober of Baltimore and Anne Tillery Ober of Palm Beach, Fla., parents of the bridetobe. Her fianc is the son of Michel Picard of West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mrs. Picard

title: Dancer's Childhood
description: WHAT child has not tried to hoard at least one instant away from marauding time? To quote Agnes de Mille: I remember one night sitting on my chamber pot, alone and saying, shall never forget this moment. And I didn't forget: the candle in its aureole, the feel of the china against my flesh, the overwhelming night silence, the noises small animals.

title: The Region
description: . Gov. Ella Grasso and the Connecticut General Assembly have much to consider when the new legislative session convenes Wednesday, but above all they will consider the political realities. jt, is an election year for the Governorand all 187 Assembly seats, and there will be a budget surplus of a size l'WOrth fighting over.

title: Indoors: Swimming in the City
description: To many New Yorkers, swimming is ,sometking for August, to combine wih a tall, cool drink after riding the subway home. Something to be done outdoors at a country club after a set of tennis or nine holes of golf.

title: Loyola 68, Georgetown 65
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (UPI)Rod Floyd's 22foot jump shot gave Loyola a tie with 50 seconds to play in regulation time tonight and the Ramblers cashed in on free throws to defeat Georgetown. 6865, in overtime.

title: FILM VIEW
description: painters, poets, novelists and filmmakers should avoid talking publicly about their work until some future date when they (and we) have had time get some distance from it. It's too easy for the reporter or critic to strangle the artist with the artist's own words tied in a slipknot. It's of some value, I suppose, to know what the artist intended in his work, and to know what he thinks he has brought off. Yet, quite often the artist is the last person to listen to. Not always, but frequently enough to make selfanalysis a dangerous endeavor.

title: Bud Goode Assesses the Teams
description: Bud Goode of Los Angeles is a statis- tician who began computer studies of professional football teams 15 years ago. Now, 10 National Football League teams use his service. He is the best.

title: LETTER TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Legislator Andrew O'Rourke has distorted the facts in his Jan. 22 article calling for rules changes in the County Legislature.

title: MEMBERS OF THE WEDDING
description: Some of the guests at Frank Narducci's wedding reception last September were family - members and associates of Philadelphia's Angelo Bruno crime family. Atlantic City has traditionally been part of their turf, but as the resort declined, so did the profits to be made there. The legalization of casino gambling, however, opens up lucrative possibilities for organized crime, and some of the guests at the bright yellow tables in the Philadelphia Sheraton's Grand Ballroom may have been celebrating not only a marriage, but also the money they expect to roll in from the action in Atlantic City. Many had made or were arranging significant investments in the New Jersey resort. The celebrants:

title: Outlook for Economy Is Bright
description: THE economy of New Jersey has been through a deep valley. For a decade, nearly every measure of business activity was headed down.

title: ELMER J. TWYMAN
description: Elmer F. Twyman, a retired senior vice president of the Yale and Towne Manufacturing Company, now a subdivision of the Eaton Corporation, died yesterday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 85 years old.

title: SYRIA
description: At the inaugural session of the Syrian People's Council (House of Representatives) on August 18, 1977, President HAFEZ ALASSAD declared the just Arab cause to be the guideline of Syrian policy, aiming at the return of the occupied Arab Territory to Arab Sover- eignty and recovery of the rights of the Palestine Arab People. National unity in Syria is steadily increasing meanwhile, and gaining strength. Syrian parties cooperate together within the framework of the National Progressive Front under the leadership of the Baath Socialist Party. The people in the country participate in the administration of state affairs, through local administrative councils directly elected by them and through a people's .$embly (House. of Representatives) whose members are elected by the country every four years in direct free elections recently held in 1977. Syria collaborates within the United Nations and in international efforts for the establishment of peace, disarmament, and realization of international economic de-

title: Growing Up American
description: NEARLY 40 years ago the French historian Lucien Febre advised all scholars who felt there was little left to chart on the historical map to plunge into the darkness where psychology wrestles with history  they [will] soon get back their appetite for discovery. Historian Philip Greven, who is explicitly concerned with the inner realm of feel- ings and religious experience, has taken the

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THOSE people fortunate enough to own a snowthrower have had plenty of opportunity to use these machines so far this winter, and to discover that when a thrower is used on wet snow or slush, the heavy material often cakes and packs inside the discharge chute.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: Article 4 -- No Title

title: POLITICS
description: THE ISLAND's six members of the House of Representatives are often thought of as peas in a poddifficult to distinguish ideologicallyor at least peas in two pods, one Republican and the other Democratic.

title: Long Autumns And Mr. Mara
description: ARLY one July several years ago, I was huddled in front of the television set at a friend's house watching something billed as the Coaches AllAmerican, which featured the rookie prospects _,the National Fottball League. My. friend's wife came in, loOked at the two of us and snarled, How come they're starting so late this year?

title: Touring Britain In New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN ORMA LYTTON told her group that the mistshrouded landscape was a reflection of the 18th century Englishman's love of nature. But Linda Friedlander said it represented the prevailing attitude toward religion.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: IT would be an exagerration to say that publishers have discovered South Africa this year, but the production of books on that uneasy country is quickening. The most dramatic circumstances surrounded

title: Arkansas 69, Rice 48
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Feb. 4 (AP)Arkansas defeated Rice, 6948, in Southwest Conference game tonight. Ron Brewer scored 17 points as Arkansas raised its record to 91 in the conference and 211 over all.

title: The Gr eatest Enemy of CrossCountry Skiers:
description: Two winters ago, in bitter cold, was skiing crosscountry along a narrow wooded trail in southern Vermont. At a spot where the trail tilted downhill, I prepared to enjoy a long coasting run, I knew how long it would be because a couple of hours earlier I had skied up that same trail.

title: The Critic/Poet
description: RP. BLACKMUR died in 1965, without writing the single fullscale critical work, whether on Henry James, Henry Adams or Dostoyevsky, that would have shown all of his intellectual talents in their final integration. His several volumes of essays, particularly Language as Gesture (1952), remain as evidence of the best close reader among the New Critics. In a more diffuse sense, the image of his power in the literary world still abides, both in the realm of myth or gossip grown old, and in the perhapswaning prestige of literary modernism. Blackmur's judgments and prejudices are still influential, and it is a tribute to his power that his critical authority is still in the process of being overturned.

title: Commodities: The New Era Of Price Stability
description: Wtioith ample worldwide supplies, relative price stability has returned to the markets for basic food and industrial cornmodities, setting the stage for an internanal attempt to make this unusual situation permanent through commodity pacts.

title: A Mix of Tall Tales
description: Howard Frank Mosher's first novel, Disappearances, is an annoying mixture of genres  a puzzling combination of family saga, tall tale and nature reverie focused on the coming of age of a 14-year-old, Vermontraised FrenchCanadian. It is a novel that just can't seem to decide what it is and what it is trying to say. Now novels don't have to be just one thing  in fact, the combination of disparate genres can often produce the most intoxicating fictions but the abrupt changes in tone and direction that riddle Disappearances leave the reader far more befuddled than entranced.

title: Green Leads By 3 Strokes At Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 4 (AP)Hubert Green continued his assault on the Waialae Country Club course today, carding a four-under-par 68 that gave hiin a threestroke lead in the $250,000 Hawaiian open.

title: Military Retirement Changes Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)The system under which military personnel retire after 20 years of service would be changed under recommendations from Presidential commission.

title: Drivers May Get OrganDonor Cards
description: TRENTON EVENTUALLY, the donation of organs and body parts will be as commonplace as donating blood. Dr. Bernard Pollera, director of the Kidney Disease Institute of the New York State Department of Health, was discussing the Anatomical Gift Act and the Uniform Donor Card, which has been enclosed with every New York State driver's license and renewal form since Sept. 1,1976.

title: Canadians Warned: `Easy Times Are Over
description: OTTAWA prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, commenting on the sickly state of the formerly ro bust Canadian economy, warned his countrymen that the easy times are over. Countless Canadians who found their paychecks buying less and less, not to mention nearly a million whose only income came from the Government's unemploymentinsurance program, little needed the warning.

title: Marianne Coleman to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John C. Coleman of Timonium, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marianne Grace Coleman, to Zoltan Adam, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Adam of Lawrenceville, N.J.

title: The Retarded Learn to Live on the Outside
description: MOUNT KISCO SEVEN men and women sit at table in a large, brightly lighted room. One man appears to be in his mid20's. The six others seem considerably older. On the wall before them are three big cardboard clocks. On one, the hands are set at 10:30, coffeebreak time; the other is set at lunch time, and the third is set at 3 o'clock, the time the men and women leave for the day.

title: Former Baby Sitter and 2 Others Seized in Kidnapping of Klein Girl
description: A former baby sitter for Marci Klein, the 11-year-old daughter of the fashion designer Calvin Klein, was seized last night and accused of kidnapping the child on Friday for a $100,000 ransom.

title: Sri Lanka's Government System Changed to Strengthen Presidency
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Feb. 3One of Asia's few surviving democratic reimes today abandoned the Britishstyle parliamentary system it has followed since independence and adopted a presidential system along French lines.

title: Rutgers Defeats UConn, 78-70
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Feb. 4 (AP)Abdel Anderson, James Bailey and Hollis Copeland each scored 17 points tonight and Rutgers won its fifth straight game, defeating Connecticut, 7870.

title: ART
description: MONTCLAIR

title: Chrenstein Asks State to Halt Deferrals of School Aid
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4Senator Manfred Oh renstein, Democrat of Manhattan, recommended this week that New York State close the magic window that allows it to defer payments of most education aid and revenuesharing increases into the future, but also necessitates huge amounts of shortterm borrowing at the state and local levels.

title: Bad News for High Rollers
description: The high rollers of the oil industry came to the New York Hilton Tuesday morning carrying their first bids for oil and gas teases in the Georges Bank fishing grounds. They left emotehanded.

title: Betsey Sherman Fiancee Of Scott Andrew Neslin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Warren B. Lovejoy of Montclair, N.J., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Lovejoy's daughter, Betsey J. Sherman, to Scott Andrew Neslin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Neslin of Elmwood Park, N.J.

title: GARDENING
description: THOSE New Jersey indoor gardeners who have not grown gloxinias could not do better than to begin right now. Just order a few tubers from a favorite catalogue. They will be delivered in early springor as soon as shipping is safeand they will bloom year after year.

title: Debbie Landis, Roy Fischer, Teachers, to Wed June 25
description: Debbie Landis, a firstgrade teacher at the Dalton School, and Roy S. Fischer, a junior high school social science teacher. nlan to be married June 25.

title: A Police Dispute That Lingers On
description: MORE than two years have passed since the name of Alex Wasilewski became synonymous in this town with either candor or galldepending on one's point of view. But the controversy over East Hampton's outcast policeman is, if anything, gathering momentum.

title: The Paradox of the Sex Pistols
description: Even in disarray, the Sex Pistols remain about the most provocative band around. It would certainly be premature to write the valedictory of this most controversial of British punk rock groups, although the components seem for the moment to have blasted off in all directions like some exploding supernovaJohnny Rotten, the lead singer, quitting the band; Malcolm McLaren, the manager, doing ditto; Steve Jones, the guitarist, complaining about the group's frustrations, lack of new material and recordcompany interference; and Sid Vicious, the bass player, overdosing on a flight from Los Angeles to New York after what was, by all accounts, a particularly rabid series of offstage carryingson during the group's first (and last?) American tour.

title: Africa's Economic Showcase
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast African women walk back from markbt with long loaves of French bread balanced on their heads. Restaurants serve imported French food, wine and mineral water. The nation's secondary schools teach the same curriculum as in France.

title: Power Costs to Rise in Upstate Area
description: The 47 municipalities that have been buying cheap hydroelectric power from the New York State Power Authority will begin getting some of their electricity from the authority's higherpriced nuclear plants this year, the trustees of the authority said last week.

title: Ossining's Size Bars It From Getting More Urban Development Aid.
description: OSSINING, N.Y., Feb. 3If this aging Hudson River village were a large city, it would meet the Federal Government's unemployment, jobloss and deterioration yardsticks for additional aid under the 1977 Community Development Act. But because it must meet siigntly allTerm standards in the category of small cities, Ossining has learned to its sorrow that its problems are not serious enough to warrant the additional aid.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Bluebill Hunters Enjoy Connecticut Bonus Season
description: BRANFORD, Conn.Sometime after midnight, the snow that I had driven through the previous day turned to rain, and the wind wailed about the house.

title: Elizabeth: School for All, Day and Night
description: ELIZABETH

title: Headliners
description: Mercy will be on trial, said Natalya Solzhenitsyn, commenting on the case of Aleksandr Ginzburg, an imprisoned Soviet dissident who is expected to be tried soon. Mrs. Solzhenitsyn, the wife of Nobel laureate Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, was joined by other emigres and American political figures, lawyers and writers at a news conference in Nevi Yark last week. They announced formation of two committees, one to press Specifically for Mr. Ginzburg's release, and the other; made up of lawyers from the United States and abroad, to lobby on behalf of all political prisoners in the Soviet Union. According to Mrs, Solzhenitsyn, Mr. Ginzburg, who was arrested a year ago, had distributed $360,000 to the families of more than thousand Soviet politital prisoners. The money came from fund in Switzerland set up by Mr. Solzhenitsyn and financeaby royalties from, The Gulag Archipelago, his book about the Soviet prison camp system.

title: PAUL W. CHRISTENEN
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 5 (AP)Paul W. Christensen, a Cincinnati business, social and civic leader, died Friday while vacationing at Manalpan, Fla.

title: Hope Is Seen in the Legislature for a New York City Employee Residency Bill
description: ALBANYAfter years of being. frozen out by the State Legislature, legislation that would require New Yorke City municipal employees to live in the city expected to get a warmer reception this session, according to Republican and Democratic legislators and their aides.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Wye been hearing quite a bit about elitism these days, much of it stemming from the Washington offices of Senator Claiborne Pell. The National Endowment for the Humanities, he indicates, has been wasting its money supporting intellectuals in projects that do not benefit most of the people. Senator Pell would like a broader base of operations, with moneys disbursed to stale arts groups. Already he has the new heads of the National Endowment for the Humanities and the National Endowment the Arts running scared. Each has promised no letdown quality, but they disavow elitism and murmur comforting phrases in the direction of the important senator.

title: Steven Goldberg Fiance of Sandee Lynn Blechman
description: Sandee Lynn Blechman of Cambridge, Mass., a consultant to the medical assistance division of the Massachusetts Department of Public Welfare, and Steven Howard Goldberg, who expects to graduate in May from the Tufts Medical School, plan to be married May 28 in Chicago.

title: Holy Cross 100, Hofstra 88
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 4 (UPDChris Potter scored 21 points and led Holy Cross to a 10088 victory over Hofstra tonight. The Crusaders led by 6090, with 15 minutes to play in the second half. But Hofstra came back on the shooting of Doug Swanson and Henry Hollingsworth  who combined for 34 pointsto close the gap to 9286 before Holy Cross regained its touch. Holy Cross is now 164 and Hofstra is 515.

title: 2 Companies Challenge Curb on Billboards in Maine
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 4A tough new state law banning all billboards except those on business premises has generated a legal battle that could affect the future of outdoor advertising throughout the nation.

title: Tuning In on the VHFTV Picture
description: THE New Jersey Coalition for Fair Broadcasting has advanced several arguments to support its demand that a commercial VHF television station be based within the state, but none of the coalitions arguments bears close scrutiny.

title: They Look Like Petunias, But They're Not
description: nvision masses of cascading green or bronze foliage covered with a profusion of flowers in glowing shades of pink, blue, white, rose, salmi- on, carmine, lavender, pur ple, even some yellow or orange shades. Some call it Magic Flower, Nut Orchid, Widow's Tears or Glory Flower, but the genuine name is achimenes.

description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Blockbuster. Advertising, publicity, promotion, exploitation, hype  no matter what you call the business of calling the public's attention to books, it's the side of publishing that nowadays engages some of the most inventive minds in the industry. with some of the most fascinating results. Consider, for example, the case of Coma, the novel occupying the No. 1 spot on this week's mass market best seller list. Coma got there thanks to the ingenuity and energy of its author, its paperback publisher and a motion picture producer.

title: Sports Today
description: Iona at Fairfield. 7:30 P.M.; Morgan State at Fairleigh Dickinson, P. P.M.; Vermont at Hofstra, S P.M.; Gannon at St. Francis. 8 P.M.

description: South America, West Indies, Etc.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: FridayFeb. 15Second annual canine art exhibition, Madison Square Garden Arts Center; paintings, sculpture and jewelry by contemporary artists; Edward Keenan, coordinator; 10 A.M.8 P.M. each clay.

title: Whose Ox Is Gored?; Red Smith;  Sports of The Times; Feeling His Oats; Suddenly New Rules; Vida Blue
description: When Charlie Finley sold Vida Blue to the Yankees for $1.5 million and peddled Joe Rudi and Rollie Fingers to the Red Sox for $1 million each, Cincinnati's Bob Howsam was aghast. It's a shame for such thing to happen, said the president of the Reds. I'm concerned about person who comes into baseball and

title: Hope Anne White Wed To Terence Alan Scott
description: Hope Anne White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marc A. White of Ithaca, N.Y., was married yesterday to Terence Alan Scott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Scott of Ithaca, where the bridegroom's father is a professor of agronomy in the College of Agriculture at Cornell University.

title: How Wall Street Rates Westchester Communities
description: WESTCHESTER communities can be compared by variety of standardsschools, shopping, scenery but because most residents are loyal to their home bases, it is hard to get consensus. However, in one field, widely accepted ratings, established by impartial observers, do exist. The ratings are assigned by the two major bondrating servicesMoody's and Standard & Poor'sto the bonds of towns, cities and school districts. These ratings determine how much interest the local governments, and eventually their taxpayers, will have to pay when they borrow. The ratings are also a fascinating guide to just how Wall Street views individual Westchester communities.

title: What's Doing in CARACAS
description: When the Spanish con- quistador Diego de Losada founded Caracas in 1567, he could hardly have picked a more agreeable location. The city lies in a long, green valley separated from the humid coast of the Carib- bean by a range of spectacular mountains. It is about 3,000 feet above sea level and, although close to the Equator, enjoys warm, comfortably dry days and cool nights almost year round.

title: Sports Today; Auto RACING; BASKETBALL; Golf; HOCKEY; SKIING; SOCCER; SQUASH RACQUETS; SWIMMING; THOROUGHBRED RACING; Aqueduct (Queens) Race Track, 1:05 P.M.
description: 24 hours of Daytona, at Daytona .Ha.) International Speedway.

title: GARDENING
description: IF, in spite of good care, your lilacs haven't been thriving in recent years, and you have about decided to give up growing petunias on the Island because they don't do well here, the problem may be air pollution. Both plants are extremely susceptible to damage from certain common air pollutants but perform normally in areas free of the problem.

title: The Energy Strategy of the Heaviest Energy User
description: MIDLAND, Mich.For America's most energyintensive industry, the chemicals, the oil embargo of 1973 was bad dream. For the largest user of energy in the industry, the Dow Chemical Company, it had all the earmarks of a nightmare.

title: Diana Schramm Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Max Schramm of Teaneck, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diana H. Schramm, to Kenneth C. Holtzman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving M. Holtzman of the Bronx. Miss Schramm is a paralegal for Golenbock & Barell in New York, where her fianc is a commodity trader with the CzarnikowRionda Company Inc.

title: The Big Businessmen Who Have Jimmy Carter's Ear
description: WASHINGTONWhen Jimmy Carter, the peanutfarmer populist, first took office, he courted smallbusiness leaders and left his staff to deal with big business. During the last six months, however, the President has done dramatic aboutface.

title: Rangers and Blues End in 22 Tie
description: ST.LOUIS, Feb, 4Sharing a falure syndrome that had burdened each team with a sixgame losing streak,. the New York Rangers and the St. Louis Blues matched miseries tonight do playing to a 22 tie before a orowd of 11,194.

title: A Dangerous Dance for New York
description: New York Citys new Mayor has now assembled government and confirmed that without external help will again face insolvency. The loans of the Federal Government that have kept the city alive since 1975 will be repaid by June 30, but the cash for routine business will then begin to run out. It cannot be borrowed commercially beciuse no one will give credit to a city whose most optimistic budget is at least $1 billion out of balance for each of the next four. years. It will not be easily borrowed in Washington either, because NeW York has.failed, in the threeyear grace period that Congress provided with the last Federal loan, to project credible balanced budget. It is not necessary to, dislike New York to be skeptical about its financial future; and the nation's taxpayers dislike the idea of helping New York.

title: What Is the Good Fight?
description: MICHAEL WALZER'S originality lies in his ability to extend the work of his precursors into new fields. His earlier Revolution the Saints made brilliant use of Max Weber's Protestant ethic thesis to rediscover puritan saints as the first ideologically inspired radical politicians. In Just and Uniust Wars the leeal and moral traditions of the just war theory are extended, refined and applied to the difficult terrain of modern war and terrorism. As an exercise in moral casuistry, it applies moral principles to particular cases.

title: IN BRIEF
description: A good part of the country may have spent last week shoveling snow, but on Wall Street it was business as usual, digesting the latest round of earnings reports from the country's major corporations. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company posted its sixth consecutive quarter of $1-billion-plus earnings. The company with the most stockholders reported that its earnings for the year amounted to $4.54 billion or $6.97 a share, up 18.7 percent from 1976, while revenues climbed 11.2 percent to $36.5 billion. It was a different story at , the United States Steel Corporation. In the December quarter, earnings plunged 89 percent to $9 million or 11t share (only a tax credit saved the company from a loss) and Big Steel was forced twcut its dividend to 40c a share fron144.... Things were no better for the brokerage community right there on the Street. Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner & Smith, parent of the nation's largest brokerage firm announced that fourthquarter profits had tumbled to $7.9 million or 224 a share, off 70 percent from the yearearlier level. The drop at the First Boston Corporation was even steeper95.3 percent, to $409,000 or 34 share, while Paine Webber's net fell 75.6 percent and E. F. Hutton's 40 percent.

title: FOOD StirFry And Enjoy
description: KURA BARN is the name of treeshaded house in Huntington that is a particularly appealing shop for things Oriental, from giftware to food. The owners are Norika and Hisanori Morimoto, both Japanese who were born in Manchuria. They conduct cooking classes, cater dinners and prepare Chinese and Japanese specialties for sale.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking for the Best Horse Racing? Go West
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 4The track announcer, Dave Johnson, intoned the call:

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: CHILDWOLD, by Joyce Carol Oates. (Fawcett, $2.25.) This story of the catastrophe that overtakes lonely eccentric after he falls in love with a 14-year-old member of an impoverished farm family is a typically brilliant yet uneven performance by Joyce Carol Oates. Sometimes it's difficult to tell who's talking, yet in the end, our reviewer Josephine Hendin concluded, it reaches the power and compassion of her admirable novel Them'.

title: Dr. King
description: BRANFORD AFEW minutes after the school meeting started, a 6-year-old asked the teacher: Why are we having school today, when all the other schools have the day off? The teacher replied: Because we thought it was better to celebrate Dr. King's birthday by being here to talk about him than to take a vacation and play all day.

title: A Tale of Two Trials Angers Police Chief
description: HAMDEN IS justice colorblind in Connecticut? That questionor variations of itis at the center of a controversy in the HamdenNew Haven area. Hamden's police chief, John P. Ambrogio, believes the criminaljustice system favors white middleclass youths charged with serious crimes as opposed to poor, black youths similarly charged.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: After running a bookstore on West 87th Street in Manhattan called Murder Ink and concoct ing Murder Ink' a unique ollapodrida of writing and pictures about the crime story past and present that was No. 9 on the trade paperback best seller list last week and is currently No. 16  Dilys Winn believes she's discovered a thing or two about readers who love stories about murder.

title: Bigger Badder
description: EJ. MISHAN, whose 1967 book, The Costs of Economic Growth, was one of the first to alert II the public and the economics profession to the perils of continuous economic and technological advance, tries in The Economic Growth Debate to sum up and assess the dispute over the last decade between progrowth and antigrowth champions.

title: Mista Jumpa Triumphs In Southern Ocean Race
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 4New lightweight racing yachts, exploiting loopholes in the International Offshore Rule for handicapping, dominated the St. Petersburg-to-Fort Lauderdale race that ended here today. The 450mile race is the second event of the annual Southern Ocean Racing Circuit.

title: Asylum From Asylums
description: IN medical school we were taught that the modern physician practices the art of medicine, that our labors would be part science and part humanism. That much is so, but it is not the whole story. In practice today's physician quietly becomes an arbiter and certifier of the human condition  a kind of Hippo- cratic notary public. It is the doctor who signs the sickleave slip, approves workman's compensation, and certifies that rape has taken place. It is the people of medicine, not a judge, a group of peers, or a priest, who pronounce death, approve transsexual operations, and sanctify syphilisfree marriages.

title: Entomologist Develops Technique To Combat Rocky Mountain Fever
description: STONY BROOK, L.I.An entomologist at the State Health Department here says he has met with succ4ss in detling with Rocky Mountain spotted fever by applying variations of some techniques that have already proved successful against other diseases.

title: The Largest Trade Deficit in History: Is it Structural?
description: The word on America's 1977 trade deficit was out last week. A record-shattering deficit had been anticipated for months, and if there was any surprise to the news, it was that the actual amount of red ink in the trade accounts$26.7 billion- was smaller than had been predicted by Government officials.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT,
description: WASHINGTONNearly four years ago, at the height of the Arab oil embargo, the Federal Government had 4.8 billion gasoline rationing coupons printed at a cost of $12 million. The coupons were never usedthey repose today in vault in Pueblo, Colo.nor was a comprehensive plan ever completed.

title: Sporting Gear
description: In karate, Kung Fu and other martial arts, you have a lot of the body to protect,.including the groin area. For a long time now, participants have had to use the same cupstyle protector as baseball, football and hockey players use. That. was fine for straighton blows, but in karate, tor instance, a kick can come from any direction. So there's a special Safe-T-Groin cup of unbreakable plastic, which is curved fit the whole groin area and which blocks wild kicks from any angle. Because it is contoured, it allows freedom of movement and affords overall protection. Its price is $6, and it is available at Frank's Sports Shop, 430 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, and B&L Athletic Supply, 75 Main Street, Port Washington, L.I.

title: Martin Balsam Turns On The Heat in Cold Storage
description: Martin Balsam stroked his grizzled mustache, grinned delightedly and headed for the bright yellow sofa that loomed large even in his kingsize dressing room at the Lyceum Theater. A couple of days ago, this wasn't here, he said, settling himself comfortably and patting a cushion. Must be doing something right.

title: DINING OUT Defining 'Continental'; * Cafe Continental
description: HOW would you define Continental food? glance at the menu at Cafe Continental Manhasset supports my theory that it identical to what most places now call northern Italian. The term Continental has become pass, its vagueness no longer satisfying to a welltraveled public.

title: BLACK VOTE PIVOTAL IN SOUTH BRONX RACE
description: With nine days remaining before special Congressional election in the South Bronx; a closely knitbut frequently nanvoringblack community is emerging as a pivotal factor in a contest among four candidates, all of whom are of Puerto-Rican- extraction, for Herman Badillo's seat in the House of Representatives.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: The American economy is again showing some schizophrenic trends at the midpoint of another severe winter. The adverse weather in many parts of the country, however, may be only partly responsible for the varying character of recent economic conditions, and may prove to be as insignificant in the total picture as it was a year ago.

title: DR. JAMES ANSELL, SERVED THE BRITISH ROYAL FAMILY
description: LONDON, Feb. 4 (AP)Dr. James Ansell, the physician who certified the death of King George VI, died Thursday at his home in Norfolk, eastern England, his family said. fie was 63 years old.

title: Wage-Price Council Urges Delay On Fuel Standards for Trucks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)The Carter Administration's wage and price agency is asking for a delay in carrying out fuel economy standards for light duty trucks and vans.

title: Villanova 59, G. Washington 58
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)A 10foot jump shot by Rory Sparrow with eight seconds in the game gave Villanova a 5958 victory over George Washington. in an Eastern Eight Con- ference game tonight. Daryle Charles had given the Colonials the lead with 28 seconds left on the clock before Sparrow's clincher for Villanova. George Washington is 136, 3.4 in the conference. Villanova is 155 and leads the Eastern Eight with a 70 record.

title: The Politics of the Budget
description: The Council of Economic Advisers last week came up with a cautiously optimistic picture of the economy in the years ahead, and the Government's index of leading economic indicators represented some goon news for the short term.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: This is The Last Sex Manual you will ever have to read not because, as the authors assert, it shows the way to solve the 10 most common sexual complaints, but because it is so breezily simpleminded that it puts the whole genre into hilarious oersoective.

title: Fashion
description: When it's cold in New York, the fashionable folk pull out their boots and leg warmers and pile on layer over layer. In Palm Beach, when the sun shines brightly but the mercury drops to 20 degrees, they wear their fur evening jackets by day and the dogs walk in their upNorth sweaters. In St. Moritz, the rich dress as they always have  in the richest furs in the world  while the really rich dress as they always have  to look poor. In London, they refuse to wear coats: They catch colds and complain a lot  but seem to enjoy it. In Paris, they ignore the cold.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: COLD SPRING HARBORWorks by Sandra Benny Vaux; through Feb. 26; Gallery 63 East, 130 Main St. For hours call 3674635.

title: CRIME
description: In her two previous books Bea Wentworth was a Stat, Senator from Connecticut. Now in DEATH THROUGH THE LOOKING GLASS by Richard Forrest (BobbsMerrill, $7.95), she is the Secretary of the State of the great State of Connecticut. That helpsin more ways than one, for now she can throw some weight around the various state agencies to get information fast. The information is to help her husband, Lyon, solve a murder case.

title: ART
description: BRIDGEPORT

title: Capitals DefeatedTrottier Excels
description: UNIONDALE, LI., Feb. 4Capital punishment, that is what it might be called. For the 15th time the Islanders met the Washington Capitals, and the New Yorkers still have not lost. Tonight's score was 61 at Nassau Coliseum in favor of New York.

title: Rep. Flood Had Secret Ties to Haiti While Pushing U.S. Aid to Duvalier
description: PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 3Representative Daniel J. Flood maintained secret relationship with the Government of this Caribbean nation while pushing foreign aid legislation through Congress, according to letters written by the Pennsylvania Democrat and statements from a former Haitian Government official.

title: Egyptian's Visit Sharpens Issues Steeped in History and Politics
description: JERUSALEM  In what promises to be a decisive week in the EgyptianIsraeli peace negotiations, the sagacity and sincerity of Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel is being questioned. The reason: His . apparent determination to continue Israel's controversial policy of creating settlements on the occupied Arab lands captured during the 1967 war. The question now arises of whether the push for settlements will contribute to the collapse of the peace initiative that only two months ago was wreathed in optimism.

title: Computer Study of N.B.A. Teams
description: The table at the right introduces a computerized teampower rating system developed by The New York Times to evaluate the relative strengths of squads involved in roundrobin league play. In this case, the system has been used to evaluate the 22 teams in the National Basketball Association through games of Dec. 31.

title: INTERVIEW
description: WHITE PLAINS NAFTALI BEZEM is an Israeli artist who spent the last year in Scarsdale, producing what he feels is his major work: triptych 12 feet long and half as high, titled Lion's Gate, depicting the holocaust, or slaughter of Jews by Hitler, and its aftermath.

title: Marenda Perry Sings Rare Vivaldi
description: Nlarenda Perry, accompanied by Warren Wilson at the piano, scored high marks for programmatic enterprise at her song recital Friday night in Alice Tully Hall. Leading off with a rarely heard sacred motet by Vivaldi, the soprano continued with seven largely unfamiliar songs by Schumann. Marietta's Lute Song iron. Korngold's Die Tote Stadt, three ariettas by the 17thcentury composer Andre Campra and ended with a cycle of six songs by Benamin Lees entitled Songs of the Night.

title: POLITICS Resounding Aye For FullValue Tax Assessment
description: OR those politicians in Westchester and elsewhere who fear that advocacy of full-marketvalue reassessments of real estate in their communities is tantamount to political suicide, Morton Baron, Supervisor of the Town of Ramapo in --Rockland County, has. a word or two of reassurance.

title: Joan H. Barnes Affianced To Philip Bemis Pool Jr.
description: Joan Harbeson Barnes, an investment assistant in the personal investment management division of Bankers Trust Company, and Philip Bemis Pool Jr., a commercial loan officer in the national banking division of the Bank of New York, plan to be married in May.

title: ANTIQUES
description: RITA REIF

title: Skating Revival Rolls On
description: JOHN HALTON was roller skating to organ music at his favorite rink on South Kensico Avenue in White Plains the Sunday the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor. The organ stopped and I found out we were at war, he recalls. I hung up my skates and didn't wear them again for 30 years.

title: To Rise Above Space Limitations, You Can Always Add Floors
description: When Donald Benjamin moved into his Beekman Place apartment a year and a half ago, it was because he thought the atea charming, he liked the East River view from his eighth floor apartment and he thought it unlikely to change.

title: FLU PLAN MAY FOCUS ON HIGHRISK GROUP
description: A Federal strategy to combat influenza is expected to have as its goal the immunization of more than twice as many highrisk persons as normally receive vaccine.

title: The Lure of the Money Market Funds
description: Stock prices sank throughout January, and many investment managers now assume that they are headed still lower. Bond prices did much the same thing, and many portfolio strategists think interest rates are going to move higher.

title: The InterArab Struggle for Gaza and the West Bank
description: President Anwar elSadit's visit to Camp David this weekend signals the return of the past: Arabs and Israelis are again at the American court. His grand diplomacy that was to take matters from the superpowers hands came up against the contradiction between Israel and the Palestinians, and the thorny question of Palestine in interArab politics.

title: International Economic Survey
description: GENEVA

title: Article 6 -- No Title
description: IDEAS AND TRENDS Continued

title: Stamford's Growth Industry
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  For years, boosters pointed proudly to Stamford's changing skyline, evidence of a building boom that transformed the quiet commuter town of J.P. Marquand novels into a commercial center of surprising importance. With a population of only 115,000, Stamford is now the headquarters of more Fortune 500 companies than any other city except New York and Chicago.

title: THE MOB GAMBLES ON ATLANTIC
description: Valentino's Restaurant is a bit of transplanted Miami rococo across from the Garden State Race Track in Cherry Hill, N.J. Rock gardens and plastic greenery adorn the dining room, oils of Rudolph Valentino hang on the walls, and after 10 at night, the dance floor vibrates with disco rhythms. It was on such an evening last April that Big Paul Castellano, a thickset capo regime of the Gambino crime family, hunched over a table in conversation with frail, elderly man wearing thicklensed glasses.

title: Columbia Collapses: Penn Wins, 8158
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4It might have been asking too much of the Columbia team to win two in a. row. The Lions, who surprised Princeton, 3836, last night, could have turned the Ivy League race into a chase tonight. Instead, they were routed, 8158, by Penn and the Quakers now have a clear shot at the title.

title: CAVALCADE
description: O.E.C.D.The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the Parisbased agency that studies and coordinates economic policies for its 24 member nationsthe principal industrialized or developed countries, including the United States, Canada, Western Europe and Japan.

title: Mary E. Waesche Wed to T. R. Alessi
description: St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church In Oradell, N. J., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Mary Elizabeth Waesche, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Waesche Jr. of Oradell, to Thomas Richard Alessi, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Alessi, also of Oradell.

title: GRAYPOWER BLUES
description: There was a time (oh, until very recently) when newspaper headlines like these: 'Gray Power Surging in Politics'; Gray Panthers Fighting Society's Treatment of the Elderly'; and (foreboding) Elderly Watch as Get Long Terms  had an effect on me which is probably

title: Katherine Benoit Wed To F. L. Dabney Jr.
description: Katherine Louise Benoit, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hector W. Benoit Jr. of Mission Hills, Kan., was married yesterday to Frederick Lewis Dabney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dabney of South Dartmouth, Mass. The ceremony was performed in St. Agnes Catholic Church at Shawnee Mission, Kan., by the Rev. Anthony Lickteig.

title: For India: New Politics, But Elusive Growth
description: NEW DELHI The Government of Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai has brought basic political changes the months since it has come to power, restoring personal freedom and reversing Indira Gandhi's authoritarian ways. But the economic revolution it hopes to achieve has proved more Milsita.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: Article 5 -- No Title

title: Mixed Parables
description: ILIKE the way W.S. Merwin allows the reader follow the stages of his consciousness. There are, usually, in any one generation four or five different roads of consciousness, with many men and women moving along each. A generous wri?,:x writes about the stages he is going through as he lives them. W.S. Merwin's new book is a collection of prose parables, tiny short stories, fairy tales and prose poems. To quote a typical beginning: A man leading a horse was walking inland from the sea. The horse was loaded with sacks of salt which the man intended sell in the city. The parables touch on the life of writer, and on our lost mood as a country. They reflect the increasing awareness that small primitive tales may tell more than the philosophical essay.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Thirteen months ago California became the first state to enact a right-todie law. Under it, any person can fill out a directive to physicians, to be attested to by two legal witnesses. The form specifies that if the person ever suffers an incurable disease or injury and it is diagnosed as terminal by at least two physicians, the person's life will not be artificially prolonged by medical procedures or equipment.

title: Maria Epple Triumphs In World Giant Slalom
description: GARMISCHPARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Feb, 4Maria Epple of West Germany won the second medal for her family at the world championships of Alpine skiing as she triumphed in the women's giant slalom today. Three days ago, her older sister, Irene, finished second in the downhill.

title: Boston Coll. 114, Fordham 93
description: Ernie Cobb and Michael Bowie combined for 57 points and led Boston College to a 11493 victory over Fordham, last night.

title: Caroline P. Curtis And Robert Melillo Plan April Nuptials
description: Mr. .and Mrs. Todd Porter Curtis of Palm Beach, Fla., and Glen Cove, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Page Curtis, to Robert Anthony Melillo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Melillo of Glen Cove. A wedding in April is planned.

title: Who Should Regulate Hunting and Fishing?
description: AT a recent convention of the State Conservation Council, New York's recreational hunters and fishermen voted overwhelmingly to submit legislation that would transfer the Division of Fish and Wildlife and the closely associated divisions of law enforcement and marine fisheries out of the Department of Envi- tlanmental Conservation to form a new independent agency to be known as the New York Fish and Wildlife Commission.

title: Collector's Item
description: The literature of book collecting, while a large (even corpulent) body of prose, is not distinguished for its beauty or grace. There are of course exceptions.

title: In a Love Affair With Baseball, the Library Is a Rendezvous
description: ITS A little early to start spring training, but it's not too .soon to get''over to the library and start throWing. some bcoks around so Anat yOur data control. will be sharp .enough. to handle those highflying facts when .the season opens.

title: Gil and Angie: A First for TV
description: CBS conducted a dating experiment over the week end, a reckless departure from accepted television practice, that must have shaken the industry clear down to its iconoscope. For its coverage of Roberto Duran's tryst with Esteban Deiesus in Las Vegas, the network took the almost unheardof step of. hiring two professional boxing men who knew what they were talking about_

title: Mideast: Aging Boom, Oil Cutback, Costly Arms
description: ., BEIRUT, LEBANON oom times in the Middle East, with all the phenomenal construction projects that followed the quadrupling of the price of oil in 1973, have begun to ease off to a slower rate of growth, according to Arab economists. Rapid development has run into problems.

title: The Art World Turns to Original Prints as Tax Shelters
description: The flower etching by the wellknown artist Lowell Nesbitt was beautiful, the affluent investor thought. And,the plate from which it had been made, plus the rights to everything produced from the plate, was for sale for $234,000, with only $44,000 cash on the line.

title: Skiing in Klosters: The Stars Have Gone but the Glitter Remains
description: To erase an image takes 20 years, said writer Irwin Shaw as he glanced from the window of his apartment overlooking the little main street of Klosters. Quite inadvertently, Shaw had helped to create the image of Klosters. He shook his head and began one of his large laughs. This town will have to burn to the ground before it loses its jetset image.

title: Deborah Lynn Sampson Fiancee of Mark Reutter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin O. Sampson of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Lynn Sampson, to Mark Douglas Reutter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas L Reutter of Phoenix.

title: The Crisis No One Believes
description: LONDON The following are excerpts from an in- terview with Carmichael C. Pocock, the 57-year-old chairman of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group's committee of man- aging directors. Mr. Pocock, who studied classics and philosophy at Oxford, joined the group in 1946 and became chief exec- utive last year.

title: Lockheed Gets Navy Contract
description: BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 4 (UPI}The Lockheed California Company said yesterday that a $7 million Navy contract received by the company would enable it to initiate a production program for the P3C Orion Update 3, a longrange antisubmarine warfare airplane. The plane is the third in a series of such aircraft developed by Lockheed over a fiveyear period. R. R. Heppe, a Lockheed spokesman, said the new version was scheduled for delivery to the Navy in March 1980.

title: Letter
description: We feel that the following anecdote presents another, more human and accessible side of Vladimir Horowitz, The Grand Eccentric of the Concert Hall (by Helen Epstein, Jan. 8). Finding ourselves in the neighborhood of Mr. Horowitz's brownstone one midnight nine years ago, we and a group of our classmates decided to visit the pianist and express personally our great admiration for his enormous musical gifts. We rang the doorbell and were greeted by Mrs. Horowitz, who showed us in after we told her why we had come. She then went upstairs, returning moments later, followed by Vladimir Horowitz. Although we were strangers who had intruded on his privacy, Mr. Horowitz graciously talked with us about music in general and his piano artistry in particular for about a quarter of an hour. When we told him how much we looked forward to being able to hear him in concert in Chicago, where we were attending college, he told us the date of his next, as yet unannounced, concert there, so that we might get tickets before it was sold out. Needless to say, we treasure the memory of our impromptu meeting with the maestro.

title: Editors Choice
description: ESICI MOS, CHICANOS, INDIANS, by Robert Coles M.D. (AtlanticLittle, Brown, $15.) PRIVILEGED ONES, by Robert Coles M.D. (Atlantic-Little,B rown, $15.) Volumes IV and V of Coles's monumental Children of Crisis series: on the outsiders and the affluent, respectively.

title: Sir Pieter Bisschop Funeral
description: AIKEN, S.C., Feb. 4 (AP)  Funeral services were scheduled today for S'r Pieter Bisschop, former Netherlands cr:nsul in the United States and a retired HollandAmerica Steamship Line official, who died Wednesday. He was 80 years old, and had moved here last December to be with his son.

title: POLITICS
description: HUNDREDS of business leaders, politicians and officeholders (and seekers) rubbed elbows Thursday and Friday in the enforced encounter known as the Chamber of Commerce train trip to Washington.

title: STAMPS
description: SAMUEL A. TOWER

title: Sumner Pingree 3d And Sally Engelhard, Trinity Alumna, Wed;
description: The marriage of Sally Alexandra En-gelhard, daughter of Mrs. CharlesW Engelhard of Far Hills, N.J., and the late Mr, Engelhard, to Sumner Pingree 3d, son of Mr. Pingree Jr. of Sheldon, S.C., and Janet F. Pingree of Hamilton, Mass., took place at moan yesterday.

title: Mary Decker Breaks Her 1,000Yard Record
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4Mary Decker, Houston McTear, Herman Frazier, Eamann Coghlan and a dozen others scored noticeable victories in the 19th annual Times Indoor Games last night, but the sellout crowd of 17,000 in the Forum was notable in its own way, too. In an arena where season ticket- holders habitually walk out early on basketball and hockey games, even when the scores are close, most of the track buffs stayed in their seats right through the end of the program.

title: Gambling on the Boardwalk
description: Looking ahead last year toward the predictable pressure for legal casino gambling in New York State, we registered one major caution: In the experience of Las Vegas and other gambling centers, organized crime follows organized gambling as night follows day. Our misgivings, alas, are nourished by the cover story in today's New York Times Magazine, which reports on the shady figures who are moving in on Atlantic City as that former family resort prepares for the first spin of the wheel. These people are very adept at finding loopholes in the law, using more or less respectable fronts and either buying or scaring off those who get in their way. Wherever they appear, the integrity of government jeopardized.

title: Around the Nation
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 4 (UPI)Two researchers from the University of California have reported that unionizing of fouryear college and university faculties is at its lowest point in a decade and will continue that way until more states pass collective bargaining laws.

title: TV VIEW
description: WASHINGTON Congress has a job to do. It ought to rewriteand significantly updatethe Communications Act of 1934. Believe it or not, what we see on television today is regulated by a 44-year-old law. When written, the law was intended to regulate broadcasting in the public interest, convenience and necessity, whatever those words may have meant in 1934. Your telephone system, too, operates under this law- which mentioned only radio and wire communication. The Act antedated teleVision; coaxial cable, satellites, direct microwave beams, laser beams, fiber optics and a host of other technologies which may change the lives of Americans sweepingly as the Industrial Revolution. The authors of the Act could not anticipate the manner in which three networks would come to dominate broadcasting. Their key aim had been localism. Assignment of frequencies was supposed tailor broadcasting service to the needs of individual communities.

title: The Only Registered Broker in Blue Earth, Minn.
description: BLUE EARTH, Minn.For two decades, Jim Doyle seemed to be everything a small town securities dealer should beexactly the sort of fellow You'd want to handle your money.

title: Chelsea Trio  As a New Hybrid
description: There was a time when 'chamber music meant, to the concertgoing public, the string quartet and not much else. Recent years, however, have seen a proliferation of ensembles made upof diverse instruments and many of these mixed groups seem to be finding receptive audiences, One of the newest of these hybrids, the Chelsea Trio, made its official New York debut Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall with a program devoted to oddities and novelties.

title: The Commodity Futures Man
description: In 1967, the economist Milton Friedman became convinced that the international monetary system was unraveling and that British sterling would be the first major currency to be devalued. He asked a top officer of a Chicago bank to let him sell short $300,000 worth of British pounds and offered to put up savings of $30,000 as cash margin. The officer refused, explaining that banks did not allow individuals to deal foreign exchange.

title: Worlds of Men
description: READERS unfamiliar with German may be unaware that one of the meanings of the word schmuck is jewel. Thus, with its elegant title and despite its consistently foul language this indeed a little gem of a novella. The highly concen- trated action, or inaction, concerns two of life's losers: Mike Levin, a realestate operator who rightly hates his tenants, and Gabor Pelzic, a refugee cab driver who with equal justice loathes his passengers. When Levin and Pelzic simultaneously nose their cars into opposite ends of a dark Montreal alley, each is already so frustrated by life that he refuses to back up to let the other one pass. Levin has a girl he's just picked up in his car, but obstinacy conquers lust and he allows her to leave. Pelzic, as always, is obsessed by schemes to defraud insurance companies  schemes that he too inept and unlucky to carry out successfully.

They discussed the Administration's economic package with Budget Director James T. McIntyre Jr. and Charles L. Schultze, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. Last week, they talked with Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. about an energy program.

title: H.E.W. Team Had To Match Intention With Law
description: WASHINGTON  Drafting regulations to carry out laws passed by Congress is often a cut and dried process. But when the matter involved is as emotional and socially explosive abortion, the process can be delicate as juggling dynamite, Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, was reminded when he testified before the Senate Appropriations Committee last week. He went to talk about his department's $150 billion budget, but all most senators wanted to discuss were the department's new rules for Federal financing of abortions.

But in Europe, and in France particularly, the very idea of profits is now being contested.

Provided that you are not immobilized by a blizzard, provided that you are not standing in lines that recall German prisoners at Stalingrad while you are waiting for a bus or train, provided that your house is in working order when the ice slides in at the doorstep, provided that you are snug in your home with no urgent need to go outwell, with all these provisions, snow can be rather restful.

title: ART VIEW
description: here are artists who specialize in enchantment, and Margaret Israel is one of them. Her work casts a spell of a kind we are not nowadays used to, and many people simply do not know what make of itit is so obviously outside our common experience new art. It teems with objects familiar and unfamiliar. swamps us with a visual melange that is at once irresistible and difficult to keep fixed in the mind. It is almost too exhausting in the sheer number of things it offers us to look at. Not for her the stripped down, cerebral look of so much contemporary art. Sensuous, evocative, full of recognizable images that somehow elude familiar categories of visual experience, her work cannot even be easily classified as painting or sculpture anything else. She is an artist with a hungry eye who commands a range talents that seems to allow her to bring to realization whatever it is that her imagination finds compelling.

title: Flyer's Reflections
description: IN 1979 Charles A. Lindbergh, told by his doctors that he was suffering from terminal cancer, con- tinued his lifetime habit of carefully planning ahead. He phoned his friend William Jovanovich, head of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, asking the publisher to come to the hospital. In the room, in the same plain brown valise Lindbergh had used as his sole luggage during 30 years of flying, was a bulky manuscript con- sisting of memoirs. Lindbergh asked Jovanovich put the manuscript into publishable form after his death. twelve days later the end came. Jovanovich, enlisting the coeditorship of Judith A. Schiff, a Yale archivist set to the task.

title: Food
description: There are many people, no doubt, who believe that mock turtle soup is more literary than real something coined, perhaps, by Lewis Carroll for Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. The fact is that Carroll actually created and named the character Mock Turtle because of the soup which had widespread currency in English kitchens long before Alice came about. It is made with a calf's head  and that's no joke. Calves heads are available at wellsupplied butcher shops in metropolitan areas  and the reason for the name is that the meat of a cooked calf's head has much the same texture as that of turtle in real turtle soup. The ingredients for the dish include the classic spices that provide the flavor of real tle soup. After you have made a kettle of mock turtle soup, you can put it to a marvelous second use, as the base of Lady Curzon's soup. This soup is otherwise almost impossible to make in certain areas of America, where the sale of canned turtle soup is forbidden by law because green turtles are among the endangered species of the world. Lady Curzon was a Chicagoan christened Mary Leiter in 1870. She became the wife of Lord Curzon, the British viceroy to India. As the vicereine, she occupied the most powerful position ever held by any American woman in the British empire. Position aside, it would be sufficient unto the day if she were responsible only for the creation of the soup that bears her name. It is irresistible.

title: Collegiate Sings Durufle Requiem

Philharmonic's Prospective Enco.unters concert, which he did on Friday night in the Great Hall of Cooper Union, Gunther Schuller focused on composers he felt worthy but neglected in New York programs of contemporary music. They included Oily Wilson and Edwin Dugger of the University of California at Berkeley, David Stock of Pittsburgh, William Thomas McKinley of the New England Conservatory of Music in Boston and. title: STAGE VIEW
description: One thing is clear. If our actors are going to improvise, they're a great deal better at inventing gobbledygook than they are at inventing gags. Actually, they don't do badly by the first of the four early Moliere farces that make up Andrei Serban's new and circusy evening, Saanarelle, at the Yale Repertory Theater. The plays, which were developed while Moliere was touring the provinces and learning his trade in direct competition with the exuberantly acrobatic commedia dell'arte, are linked only by the facts that their plots are stock and that a slippery nogood called Sganarelle appears in all of them.

title: Personal History

What it is not, except on the most superficial level, is selfappraising. Nor is leavened by humor. On the contrary, its tone is smug.
