title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sunday, Feb. 5 (AP)--Vietham offered Cambodia a threepoint peace plan today, including .a provision for international supervision of the border area where fighting has raged since last fall, the official Vietnam News Agency said.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: The Industrial Malady Lingers On
description: PARIS The 1970's are turning into a decade of disappointment for the industrialized nations of the West. Persistent inflation, high unemployment and slow growth have produced an economic environment quite different from the great expectations of the 1960's. The decade began with the collapse of the international monetary system and spun out of control with the boom of 73; the increase in oil prices, worldwide inflation, recession and layoffs. The recovery . has begun to lag.

title: Fluorocarbon Ban Could Sink a Floater
description: The polyurethane bubble may be about to burst. The plastic foam, widely used in boat construction and flotation, would be seriously affected if the fluorocarbon ban being considered by three Federal agencies becomes a reality. Styrofoam, another plastic foam commonly used in dock flotation, would not be affected as far as boat manufacturers are concerned.

title: East Germans Set Pace in Lake Placid Sledding
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 4In Polar Region weather that had spectators stamping their feet to keep warm and many competitors running wind sprints in search of warmth, Meinhard Nehmer of East Germany took the lead in the world twoman bobsled chainnionships today.

title: DINING OUT Traditional Fare in a Cozy Setting
description: REDDING SITUATED high on aridge in Redding, the clapboard saltbox that is the Spinning Wheel Tavern is as cozy and homey inside as its unpretentious exterior indicates it might be. The original 18thentury house on the site burned down in 1997, but its successor continues the tradition of a colonial establishmentwith low ceilings, exposed beams and welcomine fireplaces.

title: Advising Venezuela
description: CARACAS, VENEZUELA Shell is busier in Venezuela than before the oil industry was nationalized two years ago. Times change, one adapts to new roles and continues with the business, said Desmond Watkins, president of Shell Venezuela.

title: Margo Melton Has Nuptials
description: Marjorie Linda Melton, an account manager with the Henderson, Roll, Friedlich advertising agency in New York, was married yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church of Greenwich, Conn., to Robert Hurd Nutt, senior vice president of Henderson, Roll, Friedlich. The Rev. Mark R. Pawlowski performed the ceremony.

title: Notre Dame Takes 16th, Routs Davidson, 10076
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 4 (AP)Balanced scoring, led by Dave Batton's 16 points, helped Notre Dame defeat Davidson, 10076, today.

title: Sports Guide; Monday; SOCCER DRAFT; MONDAY NIGHT FOOTBALL (CONT.); Tuesday; THE KNICKS RETURN; Friday; INDOOR TRACK ACTION; Saturday; HANGING TIMES; Sunday; WINNER.TAKES35,000
description: Fans who wonder what goes on when a pro team drafts a college athlete can view all the picking and choosing up close when the North American Soccer League stages its annual draft at the Plaza Hotel. A limited number of seats, all .free, are available in the Baroque Room for the 11:30 A.M.. proceedings. A new team in the league, the Colorado Caribous, will choose the No. 1 player. Representatives of the league's 24 teams will be on telephones, talking to their home cities to discuss drafting strategy. The names of the drafted players will be placed on a board in front.of the room.

title: A Church on Long Island Offers Courses to Save Homeowners .on Building and Repairing Bills
description: NEW CASSEL, L.I.It's the buzz of a hand drill, thg hum of a sewing machine and the rhythmic beat of hammers, not the sounds of choir practice, that are drifting from the firstlevel meeting room of the Grace Temple Church of God here these Saturday mornings.

title: Kentucky 88, Florida 61
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 4 (AP)Kyle Macy scored 30 points tonight and led Kentucky to an 8861 victory over Florida in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: Police Talk
description: ALTHOUGH it passes largely unnoticed by the general public, except in moments of crisis, lively and occasionally bitter debate rages within the American police world over methodology. No matter how the statistics are tabulated - and there is even argument over how that should be done - crime remains a major social irritant and a hot political issue. Every faction among lawenforcers has its own version of what is wrong with the police and what should be done to make them more effective.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: OVERLAND PARK, Kan., Feb. 4 (AP) Mark Roth had three straight strikes in the 10th frame today to win a Professional Bowlers Association $75,000 tournament.

title: Drew to Exhibit Morath Photographs
description: MADISON

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW; The Current Period Of Rediscovery; ADA LOUISE HUXTABLE; ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Now that the tidy tabdos of modernism are gone, the whole of history and esthetic experience respectable again. Architects are charging off all directions; like everyone else, they are search of their origins and identity. Faced with an almost frightening freedom of choice instead of a party line, they have ceased to be evangelists and are attempting to become philosophers. Confusion and revelation have equal time.

title: Public Advocate Cited
description: NORTH.BRUNSWICK. N.J., Feb. 4 (AP) The State Public Advocate, Stanley C. Van Ness. has been commended by the New Jersey Council of Churches for his support of Atlantic City minorities threatened with losing their homes due to casinorelated development. In a resolut tion passed this week, the council said, It is the unequivocal duty of the State to assure that men and women of our very flesh and blood are not cast off this land like so much human debris. The resolution was to be mailed to Govern& Byrne, the State Casino Control Commission, Mr. Van Ness and the City Council of Atlantic City.

title: Noonan's Widow
description: I have a suggestion for Maureen Stapleton. I think she should take her guests out to dinner. Miss Stapleton is now appearing, quite adventurously, in a new John Ford Noonan play, The Club Champion's Widow, as the initial offering director Robert Lewis's acting company at the College of New Rochelle. And as we meet her, she is eagerly awaiting the arrival of a presumably wealthy chap from Louisiana she's met in a supermarket and who's a most likely candidate to replace her late husband, two years gone. The table is laid, the candles are lit.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Read up on fruit tree and grape pruning for the task can begin anytime now. . . Don't delay'on mailing seed orders.. . Check trees and shrubs for limbs and branches that may have been weakened by recent wind and ice storms; prune those that are hazardous.

title: O'Shaughnessy Defeats Buerkle in 1,500; Liguori Takes 3,000
description: New Faces 78 continued'in track and fild last night with impressive victories by Franklin Jacobs, Renaldo (Skeets) Nehemiah and Don Paige in the United States Olympic Invitation meet, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Soviet Concedes Miscalculation
description: MOSCOW Feb. 4 (Reuters)A Soviet scientist conceded today that the Russians, like the Americans, had problems tracking the Cosmos 954 in its final stages and had miscalculated the likely reentry area.

title: A Simple Rite
description: JERSEY CITY

title: GANNETT TAKES OVER WILMINGTON PAPERS
description: WILMINGTON, Del.; Feb. 4The Gannett Company, which already owned more newspapers than any other publishing group in the country, took formal control this weekend of the only two newspapers in Delaware with statewide circulation.

title: Mary Carroll Is Married
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Agnes in Lake Placid, N.Y., yesterday morning Mary Claire Carroll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Carroll of Lake Placid, became the bride of Alan J. Oliver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Oliver of Burlington, Vt. The pastor, the Rev. Philip Allen, officiated. The bride is employed in public relations at the Mount Mansfield Ski Center, Stowe, Vt. Her husband is a television cameraman on the WCAXTV Burlington, Vt., news staff, a CBS affiliate.

title: To Broadway From Glen Cove
description: GLEN COVE IN theater circles, 35 minutes from Broadway may not exactly be out of town, but it's far enough for the company of Look Homeward, Angel, the Broadwaybound musical currently playing at the Northstage Theater Restaurant here.

title: Provincial Struggle Is a Prelude to National Elections This Year and 1979 Referendum
description: MONTREAL Dispersed, discredited and leaderless, the forces arrayed against the Quebec Government's drive make the province a sovereign Frenchspeaking nation have been ineffectual over the past 14 months. Even Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and his Federal Liberal Party Government have been unable to achieve a national concensus an answer to the separatist challenge. But last week there were signs that the Parti Quebecois, which governs Quebec, in for a tougher fight, particularly from the provincial Liberal Party which is about to choose a new leader. The most prob. able choice is Claude Ryan, like Premier Rene Levesque before he entered politics, a respected journalist, but unlike the Premier, one who espouses the Federal cause.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on bill to revise and reform the Criminal Code of the United States, passed, 72 to 15, Jan. 30.

title: Princeton 88, Cornell 50
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 4 (AP)Frank Sowinski scored 25 points tonight and led Princeton to an 8850 victory over Cornell. Princeton led 3328 at the half and pulled away in the second half with a 124 spree. Sowinski scored 17 of his points in the second half.

title: Modern Music Concerts Flourish

description: several years ago, the Plainview School District on Long Island paid $5,000 to Nave the Roper Organization survey the community on its attitudes toward school closings.

title: Jean Farrell Sets Marriage on June 10
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy B. Farrell of Wyomissing, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Frederica Farrah!, to Stephen Joseph Sullivan, a student at the New York University School of Medicine. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Sullivan of Greenwich. Conn.

title: L.I.U. 70, Fairleigh 58
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 4Greg Winston scored 10 of his 15 points in the second half and led Long Island University to a 70.58 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson.

title: The Criteria? Your Needs
description: Take a moment to evaluate your needs. Will you need lessons? All Y's and most clubs offer them. Expect to spend about SIO per hourly ;esson,

title: Sporting Gear
description: Skateboard fanatics, there's no need to moan that winter snows will ruin'your fun. Now there's the Ski Board to make your favorite pastime an all-season sport. Take your skateboard and remove the wheels. Attach a fiberglass Ski Board to the front axle and another to the rear axle, They look like miniature skis, turned up at the front and the rear, but they're much wider. This allows you to razzledazzle down a ski slope much the way you'd maneuver down the street. Ski Boards may even cause you to perfect your regular street technique, since snow is more slippery than asphalt, You'll need pair, with each board costing 517.95. At Scandinavian Ski Shops.

title: LENDER AGREES TO HALT SEX BIAS IN MORTGAGES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI)Utah's largest savings and, loan association has consented to a Federal District Court decree requiring it to use the same financial standards in making mortgage loans and home improvement loans to men, women and married couples.

title: Ethiopian Drive Reported
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Feb. 4 (UPI) Somalia said today that Sovietbacked Ethiopian forces in the Ogaden region have opened a twopronged offensive aimed at slicing through northern Somalia to the sea.

title: EGYPT PERMITS REVIVAL OF A PRENASSER PARTY
description: CAIRO, Feb. 3 (AP)The Wafd Party, the majority faction in Egypt for nearly three decades before being outlawed in 1952, was officially revived today as part of President Anwar elSadat's political liberalization, a Government spokesman said.

title: Joint Bargaining Weighed by Unions For City Workers
description: Leaders of unions representing 250,000 New York City employees are developing plans for joint or coordinated bargaining with the city on an, economic package that would be the basis for all contracts.

title: Paul Schrader
description: People were going to use cabs no matter what we said. And finally we decided to shoot In the streets of Detroit anyway.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 90,000 outlets across the United States.

title: VIETNAMESE PROTEST OUSTER OF U.N. AIDE
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 4 (Reuters)Vietclam protested today the United States expulsion order against its chief delegate to the United Nations, calling it unprecedented in the history of the world body. A statement by the Vietnamese Foreign Ministry said the delegate, Dinh Ba Thi, had been in no way involved in any such activities as the one fabricated by the United States authorities.

title: Texas Rangers Mourn Leader
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 4Half a hundred Texas Rangers gathered here today in an unusual public appearance to pay tribute to one of their fallen colleagues. Cant. James F. Rogers.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: In reply to Dr. Jerome M. Zweig's letter of Jan. 1, I want to commend the judicious policy of Governor Byrne and the officials of the Department of Environmental Protection in regard to fluoridation of water.

title: ART
description: BRIDGEPORT THE impression given by the verbal package around Connecticut Painting, Drawing and Sculpture, 1978 is that the state is an emerging nation long oppressed by the culture of New York. not an Arcady to which New Yorkers aspire, a gracious hereafter obtainable in this life. And like other emerging nations, has its Fidelistas who, in the form of Art Resources of Connecticut, are even now on the march.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4A small but expensive land rush is under way in an exclusive area just north of here, when large numbers of Iranians and Saudi Arabians have been buying some of the Choicest residential property in the nation.

title: Jane A. Fox Engaged To John Riordan 3d
description: Jane Ann Fox, a certified pediatric nurse practitioner, and John William Riordan 3d, a management consultant with Peat Marwick Mitchell & Company, certified public accountants, plan to be married in June.

description: Dr. and Mrs. Ian A. Morrison of New York and Millbrook, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheila Naida Morrison, to Lieut. Bruce Davis Jackson, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Porter Jackson of Houston.

title: South Korea: Racing On Fast Trade Track
description: SEOUL, SOUTH KOREA t 7:30 each morning for 28 days month, Kim Nam Ju, one of South Korea's 143,000 garment workers, leaves his oneroom rented apartment in Seoul's worker district. After a halfhour ride in a crowded bus he arrives at the Taeil garment factory in downtown Seoul.

title: German Caution: Another Drummer
description: WEST BERLIN dependent on imports to meet its energy needs, stands almost alone in havweathered the oil crisis without going into debt. The United States, on the other hand, is running massive trade deficits primarily attributable to oil imports and its dollar is severely battered. Washington and Bonn are obviously marching to the beat of different economic drums and headed for possible conflict.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. Mastering Our Memories.

title: Hail to Thee, Blithe Man! Bird Thou Never Wert!
description: MILL VALLEY, Calif.! have just made the acquaintance, on the TV, of a gray heron named Big Bill. His parents were referred to as Mom and Dad, and I had the luck to meet them before he did. Actually, it's hard to tell Morn from Dad unless you're a heron. They build their nests in the tops of tall trees, but not just for the view. With a wing spread of five feet they need a clearing on the top floor to maneuver.

title: No Girls: No Goalie
description: SARNIA, Ontario, .Jan. 22 (AP) Ten-year-old Michele zmerson sat on the bench yesterday and watched her teammates from Waukegan, ill., lose by 64 to a team from Nickel Centre, On tario in North American silver, stick hockey championship play.

description: 6 A.M., WNYCAM. Cantata No. 30, Bach; Requiem, Schumann.

title: Amadeo Zambon Fills In In Met's 'Trovatore
description: Even in the best of times, tenors can be hard to come by. This season, in particular, a wave of cancetllatdons seems to have left the Metropolitan Opera continually in danger of running short. In addition to reshuffling singers already on its roster, the Met has had to enrage several more tenors than started out with in October.

title: Koch Listens to Bronx at His First Gripe Session
description: Mayor Koch held his first neighborhood gripe session yesterday, listening with his staff to complaints and advice from more than 100 Bronx residents.

title: Charlene R. Crickenberger to Marry June 10
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold P. Crickenberger of Roanoke, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Charlene Rei Crickenberger of Greenwich, Conn., to Timothy P. Handorf, son of Evelyn Polesky of Alexandria, Va., and Dr. William G. Handorf of Killeen, Tex. The wedding is planned for June 10.

title: Andretti Is in High Gear On the Formula 1 Circuit
description: Mario Andretti's quest for the World Driving Championship is moving along quite nicely. After the first two races of the season, he leads the point standings with 12 on a victory in Argentina and a fourthplace finish in Brazil. That gives him a twopoint edge over Niki Lauda of Austria in what is expected to be a tight battle between the two all year.

title: Entries in Specialty Shows Set Records For Weekend Preceding Westminster
description: A spectacular .arry of weekend specialties will precede the 102d edition of the Westminster Kennel Club show to be presented Feb. 13 and 14 in Madison Square Garden. Recordbreaking entries mark these 1978 specialties and, for the first time, a few are being spread over two days to accommodate the large number of dogs in competition.

title: The Wrong Coin for Morocco
description: When in doubt, send arms. Too often that seems to be the watchword of superpower diplomacy. The Carter Administration says it wants to kick the habit, but old temptations die hard. Thus, it is now considering rewarding Morocco's King Hassanfor giving President Sadat's peace efforts their only open support from major Arab stateby selling Morocco two dozen counterinsurgency aircraft and two dozen helicopter gunships. They would be used to help subjugate a territory over which Morocco has no rightful claim and at substantial risk of war with Algeria. The reward would too costly.

title: In Poor Areas, Street Churches Give Cohesion
description: Weekdays, many of the groundfloor commercial spaces along Sutphin Boulevard in Jamaica, Queens, are shuttered or closed off by iron gates. On ,Sundays, however, a lot of the shutters  and the gates are removed, for it is then that the avenue's business boomsin storefront churches.

title: Accounting for Accountants
description: There have been embarrassing moments when irate stockholders and the Securities and Exchange Commission have complained that some of the nation's big accounting firms have done less-than-precise job of reading their clients books. Last week it became clear that some of these firms are unable to get a precise reading on one aiiother's hooks

title: U.S.Decides Not to Match Soviet FirstStrike Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The Carter Administration, in a shift of emphasis from the nuclear strategy of Presidents Nixon and Ford, has downgraded earlier estimates of the threat the Soviet strategic buildup poses and has decided not to match Moscow's move toward a possible _firststrike capability against land based missiles.

title: After Years of Pessimism, Bienstock Is Bullish on New York City
description: The New York City area's chief labor statistician, who came under fire as prophet of decline for the city in 1964 and later, now says he currently tends to be as optimistic about New York City's future as he was pessimistic in the early 1960's.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Klein Shocked by Photos of Him in Phone Booth With Ransom
description: Calvin Klein; who paid a $100,000 ran some Friday for the return of his kid napped 11-year-old daughter, Marci, said yesterday that he was shocked and completely surprised to discover photographs in The Daily News yesterday morning showing him in a phone booth with the money under his arm and later being reunited with the child.

title: Civil Rights Road Has Become More Complicated
description: WASHINGTON  It was almost as if Benjamin Hooks were thankful for the opportunity to protest against South African participation in the Davis Cup tennis finals next month at Vanderbilt University. There will be the biggest demonstrations this country has seen since the 1960's, said Mr. Hooks; the new executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: South Africa: Weakening Of the Foundation
description: JOHANNESBURG Wtauhite South Africans, in an annual ritual at year's end, head for the coast, filling the sunwashed beaches of Natal and the Cape, packing every good hotel and resrant for hundreds of miles. The country seems to be the same prosperous land. But appearances deceive, for the economy is in serious distress.

title: LETTERS
description: Your article, The Selling of the Two Dollar Bill, (Jan. 15), raised the old problem that many Americans consider that much abused denomination of currency to be unlucky. There is now incontrovertible evidence that thisbelief is well founded. For many years $2 bills have circulated widely in Canada. Result: the Canadian $2 bill is now worth about $1.80. If that is not ill luck, I do not know what is.

title: Terror and the Executive Suite
description: COLOGNE, WEST GERMANY Europe has a new and ominous growth industry the wake of terrorist outragesprotecting the businessman. Executives in West Germany joined the targets of ideological violence when Jurgen Ponto, chairman of the Dresdner Bank, was slain by extremists at his home near Frankfurt last July. Then the top spokesman for West German industry, HannsMartin Schleyer, was ambushed here in September and later killed.

title: 4 Boys Killed in Norfolk Fire
description: NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 4 (UPI)Four young brothers died in an early morning fire today in their onestory duplex house. The authorities said the children's parents were not at home when the fire broke out. The victims, all members of the Marsh family, were identified as Gordon, 10; Gerald, 8; Nathan, 4, and Robert, 1.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Dance Theater Workshop, which started out in a loft on 20th Street in 1965 and found a permanent base at the American Theater Laboratory in 1975, begins Seven Winter Dance Events on Thursday. The James Cunningham Acme Company opens the series, followed by Matthew Diamond, a young dancer who studied with Jose Lim6n, Louis Falco and Jennifer Muller; Mel Wong, who works in the Merce Cunningham vein; a group headed by Joan Lombardi, former assistant artistic director of the Paul Sanasardo Dance Company; Obie Awardwinner Ping Chong; Rush Dance Company, which performs a type of narrative dance theater, and a company recently formed by Bertram Ross, who was with the Martha Graham troupe for 25 years. (See Dance)

title: Rhythm on the Rocks
description: A Californiabased wilderness outfit has come up with the ultimate Colorado River expedition: a 14day raft trip to the accompaniment of classical musicplayed live.

description: He is on page 23 of the Cincinnati Reds press guide (on sale for $2.50 at your corner newsstand), and he looks out from under a baseball cap adorned with the big letter C.

title: A Barrier to Nuclear Benefits
description: LONG ISLANDERS know that to reach the continental United States they have to travel through the City of New Yorkunless they take a ferry from Port Jefferson (summer only) or Orient Point (potato trucks preferred).

title: Food and Population: Wary Optimism
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. High up in the Secretariat building, a United Nations official was poring over a collection of statistical charts on food and population when he suddenly asked a visitor, Why can't we all be like the Chinese?He meant that China has in a decade apparently lowered its birth rate more dramatically than any other country, to per thousand of population from 32 per thousand eight , years ago.

title: POLITICS
description: HARTFORD MONG experts it is said that the real measure of a good tune played by a skilled, fullblown group of fifers and drummers is its ability to shake green apples off the trees. So far, of all the robust and stir- ring marches, hymns and ballads that have been heard by the General Assembly in its long search for a state song, only one has really met the testYankee Doodle, as rendered for the state's legislators by the Third Connecticut Regiment of Fife and Drum from East Hampton.

title: Jersey Option, Electronic Trading Cloud City's Status
description: While brokerage firms in New York and the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington grapple with the outlines of a national market system for trading stocks, decigions.are being made at exchanges across the nation that will have a more immediate effect on the lives of many men and women in and around the business.

title: China After Mao: Masked Tension and Unmasked Ills
description: HONG KONG  Radio Peking listeners recently have been surprised to hear newscasters sign off by giving their names. Similarly, the Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, has begun give bylines to correspondents. Not since the Cultural Revolution have individuals been accorded such recognition China.

title: Just a Shot Away From the N.B.A.
description: RED BANK

title: Festival Is Gone, But the Show Goes On
description: HOUGH the American Dance Festival has definitely departed from New London after 30 summers, it has left behind elements of its performing tradition and even one of its staff members.

title: Barons 2, Flyers 2
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 4 (UPI)Walt McKechnie scored two goals in the third period to lift the Cleveland Barons to a 22 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers tonight.

title: An African Dilemma: Using Foreign Experts
description: NAIROBI. KENYA senior planning official in Mozambique, now its third year of independence, was emphatic when asked to name the nation's foremost development need. Foreign experts, foreign teachers and foreign technicians, he declared. Here in Nairobi, Mwai Kibaki, the Kenyan Minister of Finance and Planning, delivered a stinging attack on such help, saying: In the last 20 years, Africa and Asia have been invaded by all kinds of social misfits from overseas whose theories and phony products have been rejected in their own countries.

title: Imbalanced Payments And World Capital Flow
description: Anerab surpluses, thirdworld debt, bulging Japase and West German coffers and a record American deficit are the axes around which the financial world now turns. And, according to most forecasts, the massive imbalances in world trade and the present disequilibrium capital flows, with the possible exception of the Japanese surolus. will change little in the coming year.

title: Morris Cotel, Mark Wait Join Piano Forces
description: Morris Cotel, a composer and pianist who has appeared in New York previously as a solo performerand impressively socame back to Carnegie Recital on Tuesday night with a colleague, Mark Wait, to play 20th-century music for two pianos and piano fourhands. The program for the duo's New York debut consisted of Stravinsky's Concerto for Two Solo Pianos, Debussy's En blanc et noir, Boulez's Structures II and Mr. Cotel's own Sonata for Piano, Four Hands (1966).

title: THEATER A Cultural Explorer in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN STANDING 6 feet 1 inch tall, his thin frame tucked tinder a thatch of strawcolored hair, Andrei Serban looks like a basketball player and speaks, with a Rumanian accent.  - The night we met he was wearing white peasant blouse under an embroidered sheepskin vest, the whole thing covered by a dark, shaggy wool pancho with sleeves.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THOSE people fortunate enough to own a snowthrower have had plenty of opportunity to use these machines so far this winter, and to discover that when a thrower is used on wet snow or slush, the heavy material often cakes and packs inside the discharge chute.

title: If You Go . . .
description: ... Swissair flies to Zurich. Take the train from there; several trains run each day, and they are smooth and on time. Depending on stops, the trip takes about three hours. The fare is $17.40 for the, round trip, second class. You can rent a car in Zurich at the airport, but in Klosters you don't need one. You can walk to everything, except the lift for the ,Madrisa area, and for that there's a red bus that shuttles through town.

title: Politically Troubled Tunisia Sees a Libyan Threat
description: TUNIS, Feb. 4The Tunisian Government is taking military precautions against possible attempts by neighboring Libya to intervene in a power struggle here, according to reliable sources.

title: Latin Curse: Inflation and Staggering Foreign Debt
description: BUENOS AIRES Inflation and indebtedness are the twin curses Latin America. Not the 6 percent inflation the United States lives with but, as in the case of Argentina, 160 percent inflation. Not worrisome yet manageable indebtedness to foreigners but, as in the case of Peru, practically national bankruptcy.

title: CITIZENS BUDGET UNIT SEES BIGGER DEFICITS
description: The Citizens Budget Commission warned again yesterday that New York City budget deficits were likely to be far bigger in coming years than the city has predicted.

title: James Sulkowski Fiance Of Anne I. Auberjonois,
description: The engagement of Anne I. Auberjonois to James M. Sulkowski has been announced by Laura Murat Auberjonois of New York and Fernand Auberjonois of London, parents of the future bride. Her fian6 is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert V. Sulkowski of Canonsburg. Pa.

title: Cynthia Robin Stites Wed to Donald Nagle
description: Cynthia Robin Stites, a legal assistant with the New York law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, was married yesterday to Donald Lowe Nagle, a travel coordinator for AFS (American Field Service) International Scholarships in New York. The Rev. Hugh Livengood performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Westfield, N.J.

title: Divided French Left Gains Hope As Regime's Problems Increase
description: PARIS, Feb. 4The election campaign now under way in France is pitting leftists and rightists against each other along rigid ideological lines rarely seen in Western Europe in recent years.

title: The Foreign Payoff Law Is a Necessity

description: TUNIS The outbreak of violence In Tunisian cities 10 days ago,the worst since the country won its independence from France in the spring of 1956, bared new radical forces in the comparatively liberal society that the President for Life,Habib Bourguiba, thought he had built.

title: Alix Gudefin Engaged to Jean Perrachon
description: The engagement of Mix Gudefin to Jean Perraohon of Philadelphia, son of Mr. and Mrs, Jacques Perrachon of Angouleme, France, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George M. Gudefin of New York.

description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Feb. (AP)---Jack Fleck forged a threeshot lead in blustery weather today in the third round of the Professional Golfers Association national seniors golf championship. The 56-year-old Burbank,

title: Margaret H. Einhorn Is Fiancee of Michael C. Lasky
description: Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Einhorn of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Hattye Einhorn, to Michael Charles Lasky, son of Sylvia Lasky of Bayside, Queens, and the late Robert Lasky.

title: Marchi Demands New York State Council  on Arts, Justify a $5,000 Grant for Pornographic Book
description: ALBANYThe chairman of the New York State Senate Finance Committee demanded yesterday that the State Council an the Arts justify a $5,000 grant to photographer who had used the money to produce what the Senator charged was a patently Dornogranhic book.

title: Lara and Zhivago
description: AUSTERE and comforting, the figure of Lara glides through Boris Pasternak's Doctor Zhivago as an embodiment of humane poise. She is wonderful, this imagined Lara, but now, meeting her reallife model, we may find ourselves on a slightly bumpy descent to reality. for 14 years Olga Ivinskaya was the friend and lover of Pasternak. Some of the Zhivago poems were addressed to her, and she in turn paid for her devotion with two stretches of forced labor in Stalin's'camps. The memoir she wrote in the early 70's of their shared pleasures and sufferings has not, of course, been published in the Soviet Union; it is at once a touching story of human loyalties, still another har. rowing account of literary martydom in the total state, and a somewhat scrambled book. For the truth - a little sad, a little comic - is that the woman who emerges in these pages, especially the early pages, often strikes one as rather silly.

title: The Politics Of Steel: The Workers Are Heard
description: Thousands of workers who lost their jobs in one of the longest and deepest recessions of the world's steel industry found their voices last year. From Ohio to the Ruhr they demanded action from their unions and political leaders. By last fall they were heard, transformed from one more economic casualty to a political force to be reckoned with in the industrialized nations.

title: Kei Takei Offers Light Dances
description: Whatever happens once in a dance is likely to happen again and again, Miss Takei is a choreographic nagger. Yet her nagging, though exasperating, is also eloquent.

title: A Stunning `Macbeth From The RSC
description: LONDON The pride of the English theater at the moment is the Royal Shakespeare Company, and the pride of the Royal Shakespeare Company is its production of Macbeth. In the modern theater

title: CHESS
description: ROBERT BYRNE

title: Les Halles: New Life in an Old Quarter
description: For years I assumed that the legendary passion and enthusiasm of the old Parisian quarters lived on only in the bistro songs of Montmartre. But one gray afternoon a year ago, while I stood on the tiny wroughtiron balcony of hotel on the Rue St.Denis, the world around me suddenly burst into exuberant color.

title: Psyching Out the Group: The Charter Trip as Mobile Sibling Rivalry
description: Members of The Association have assembled at Kennedy Airport for their annual charter trip. The group photograph will reveal each nametagged traveler clutching an Association flight bag in one hand and a Xerox copy of the itinerary in the other. They appear to be a homogeneous lot, with such common denominators as occupation, charitable interest and religious affiliation.

title: China's New Dialectic: Growth
description: HONG KONG Chinese factory workers are beginning to get their first wage raises since the late 1950's. The increases are small, the equivalent only a few dollars a month, and only about half the urban work force will get them. But perhaps more than anything else in China's recent tumultuous past, they dramatize the determination the developmentminded leadership to speed China's emergence as a powerful industrialized nation.

title: Bobick Is Knocked Out By Knoetze in 3d Round
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 4 (Reuters)Kallie Knoetze of South Africa knocked out Duane Bobick, the world's fifthranked heavyweight, in the third round of their fight here tonight.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: IF present national population trends continue, New Jersey is in danger of losing one of its 15 seats in the House of Representatives after the official 1980 Census.

title: Diamonds Are the Man's Best Friend
description: Pierre Arpels flew into town from Paris the other day with a message that may shake the local status-seek ers: The wristwatch he designed in 1949 and named after himself is now the hot watch` among the European elite, he said, hotter even than the Cartier tank watch.

title: Antarctic Laboratories: The Many Uses of Cold
description: The great blanket of ice that covers Antarctica, holding more than 90 percent of the world's fresh water, has now emerged as an invaluable record not only of past events on earth, such as periods of volcanic eruption, but also of extraterrestrial phenomena - ancient rains of meteorites from space and perhaps even the history of solar activity.

title: DINING OUT; A Taste of France in Peapack; *La Champagne
description: NEW JERSEY has long suffered from a shortage of decent French restaurants. Some the places that have claimed to be French really were not, and there always have been a couple that wereand arejust plain bad.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: CRITICS - as anyone who has ever criticized them has ample reason to know - hate to be criticized. Oh, how they hate to be criticized! And what a lot of noise they make when, on rare and wondrous occasions, the unthinkable occurs, and they find themselves temporarily transformed into objects of critical scrutiny. Like the local policeman, who thinks nothing of pulling into a No Parking zone, critics are used to regarding themselves as exempt from the laws they customarily enforce.

title: When I Do It, It's Not Gore, Says Writer Paul Schrader
description: HOLLYWOOD Ahand is chopped off by ceremonial Japanese sword. A cab driver goes berserk and shoots down several people in an outburst of rage. A hand is pushed down the garbage disposal unit of a sink and cut to pieces. These images of violence, vivid and horrifying, seen in,.respectively, The Yakuza, Taxi Driver and Rolling Thunder, are typical of the work of the 31-year-old screenwriter Paul Schrader. Naturally, Mr. Schrader has been accused of exploitation, and an audience at a San Francisco preview loudly booed the handshredding scene in Roiling Thunder. On Friday, MCAUniversal will release his first film as writerdirector, Blue Collar, a movie marked by violence not only in its plot line but also in its actual making. In New York, the film will open at the Rivoli, Trans Lux East 86th Street East theaters.

title: Travel in a Wheelchair: Growing, Yet Always Arduous
description: Like physically and mentally fit people, the disabled like to travel. Despite all the barriers they face they are traveling more than ever and clamoring for facilities they can use easily.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: AVONStudent show, Farmington Valley Arts Center, Avon Park North. Through Feb. 12. Wednesday through Friday 11 A.M. to P.M. Saturday 11 A.M. to 4 P.M., Sunday to 4 P.M. Telephone 6781867.

title: Today Decides Whether England Keeps a Wordsworth Treasure
description: William Wordsworth (17701849) was England's first great romantic poet, worshipper of nature and a worthy successor to Shakespeare and Milton. Hymning daffodils and cuckoos, hailing the rainbow and rose, he adorned the heights of poetic sublimity. As he grew firmer in the cast of Tory orthodoxy and establishea pieties, his poetry delighted parodists who called him Wordswords and Worstworst.

title: A.M.C. Confirms a Rumor
description: We are often asked if our future includes affiliation with another company, Gerald C. Meyers, chief executive officer of the American Motors Corporation, commented in a speech at the annual shareholder's meeting last week. I'm sure you have heard the rumors....The answer to those rumors is yes.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Jamake Highwater, of Black- feet/Cherokee heritage, calls himself the Indian Homer who has written in Anpao an American Indian Odyssey. He almost pulls it off.

title: Marketing in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, KENYA Oil companies in Africa are in an exalted position, high in visibilityand in vulnerability. In East Africa, Shell is a subsidiary of a holding company that dates back to the 1928 partnership of Shell and British Petroleum. In those days, said Gerald Read, chief executive officer for ShellB.P.'s East Africa region, Shell had the marketing organization and B.P. had the oil.

title: The Naticon
description: Tongsun Park, the most soughtafter Congressional witness since John Dean at the Watergate hearings, will testify on Capitol Hill after all about South Korean influencebuying in Washington. His appearance in closed session, scheduled for Feb. 21, should mollify Congressmen who threaten to cut off military aid to Seoul unless Mr. Park tells what he knows. But it is not clear how much of significance Mr. Park has left to say, or if he has, how forthcoming, he will be, especially about the widespread belief that he acted on behalf of the Korean Government in his role as a freespending lobbyist.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY A Test, a Fling-  It's Outdoor Ed
description: HANGING upside down from rope 40 feet off the ground at night in the freezing rain, began to wonder if this is really what education was all about. As a 38-year-old French teacher at Friends Academy in Locust Valley, I had accompanied other groups of ninthgraders on outdoor education trips. But as I swung back and forth in midair, I thought I had gone too far this time in trying to keep up with the kids.

title: OUTLOOK; Will OPEC Drown In a Sea of Oil?; OUTLOOK; The Nuclear Slowdown: Concern and Elation; ANTHONY J. PARISI; Nuclear PowerHow Much, How Soon?
description: he Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has practically terrorized the world since 1973. The cartel's pricing meetings have become almost make-or-break events, routinely preceded by a spiral of frenzied speculation: Will OPEC raise prices this time? How much? What will that do to the economy? Where will it all end?

title: De Kooning: I See the Canvas and I Begin
description: For a famous artist to live as recluse in East Hampton is very neat trickand one about which no novelist and no moviemaker could hope to persuade us. But Willem De Kooning is undeniably a famous artist, and he does undeniably live as a recluse in East Hampton, and there is a legitimate and general curiosity as to why he does it.

It is precisely the assessment the guerrillas have been.trying to spread in Rhodesia itself, with some success.

They may be ,troublesome but they work better than what went beforemonumental exchange crises, with governments pouring out billions to defend fixed rates before yielding, finally, to overwhelming market forces.

Accompanied by Phil Ford, the star of the University of North Carolina basketball team, and Greg Miles, the team's manager, Davis hesitated about leaving. He eventually postponed the trip for one day, and returned to the Tarheel campus.

title: Canada Puts Satellite Recovery Cost at $1 Million

title: Design
description: Needlework and patchwork quilts have dramatically enlivened American homes over the last decade. But few boast the riot of color, the harmony of patterns  both traditional and modern  that Sherlee Lantz, needlework expert and author, has achieved in her New York apartment. Mrs. Lantz has not only devised new patterns for her needlework, but also invented a new stitch, Trianglepoint, which enables her to translate effortlessly the geometric, cubist and opt ical patterns she favors. Throughout the home she shares with her husband, Robert Lantz. the literary and theatrical agent, Mrs. Lantz has played off the old quilts she has collected against her own needlework designs and combined both with robust 17th century English and French country furniture. In front of the fireplace is a rug Mrs. Lantz copied from one that is depicted in one of the celebrated series of 15th century tapestries, The Lady and the Unicorn. It is quite at home with the 19th century Turkish rug on the floor beside it, as is the centuryold quilt on the table (above) with its more

But in 1971 all such fanfare ended for Shen ana competing foreign oil companies (Caltex, Mobil and Getty) as they felt the pressures of rising crude costs, clamor against multinationals and the lengthening shadow of Government controls.

description: WASHINGTONNew York City's new appeal to the Federal. Government for an extension of loan assistance beyond the June 30 cutoff date is being received on Capitol Hill with skepticism, tough scrutiny and some yawns.

title: Mexico Rebuilding Confidence, Aided by Oil
description: MEXICO CITY The Mexican economy is recovering from its most serious crisis in 40 years, but it may be several months before it resumes its traditionally high rate of expansion. Since taking office Dec. 1, 1976, President Jose Lopez Portillo has won back domestic and foreign confidence. Bankers are again willing to lend to Mexico, while businessmen are preparing new investments.

title: Is the Trend to the Democrats Inevitable?
description: DESPITE the loss last November of one seat on the Westchester County Board of Legislators, which gave Republians a 107 edge, county Democrats can expect gains this November in state and Federal elections.

description: This evening at 9 P.M., Channel 13 will present the first hourlong episode in 10part dramatization of Leo Tolstoy's Anna Karenina, with Stuart Wilson, Caroline Langrishe and Robert Swann in major parts and with Nicola Pagett playing the title role. Miss Pagett is best known to publicTV audiences for her portrayal of Elizabeth Bellamy in Upstairs, Downstairs.

title: Competing hi a Tougher World Auto Market; Auto Market
description: WOLFSBURG, WEST GERMANY As s the story is eagerly told at Volkswagen here, the company's chief executive officer, Toni Schmiicker, picks up a car fresh off the assembly line at the end of every work day and drives it home, covered with stickers and chalk marks, through the mists of lower Saxony. If the car, on its way around Ferdinand Porschestrasse, sounds or handles less satisfactorily than Mr. Schmiicker likes, a quality control supervisor will hear about it the next morning.

title: New Metropolitan Sign of Change For Orthodox Church in America
description: SYOSSET, L. I.Shortly after being selected spiritual leader of the millionmember Orthodox Church in America last fall, Metropolitan Theodosius returned to his hometown in Pennsylvania and visited his childhood friends, many of them Roman Catholics. They all wanted to know if I was like a Pope, Metropolitan Theodosius recalls. I had to tell them I am not infallible. I cannot issue papal edicts. I have church boards to answer to I am not a Pope.

title: Good Place for a Prison is...Where?
description: Prison. The word inspires visions of steel bars, gray walls, barbed wire and armed guards isolating hardened convicts from the rest of the world. And indeed, art has imitated reality well, for isolation was the idea behind most of the large, fortresslike penal institutions that the Federal Government and the state have built since the early 1800s.

title: Ravo Thaws Yonkers City Hall
description: YONKERS AT RAVO .drew up the darkgreen shades over the windows, letting daylight stream into the office and play on the waxed surface of a large oval desk. He then walked deliberately toward the door that connected the office of the Yonkers City Manager with that of the Mayor, Angelo R. Martinelli, unbolted it, opened it and said : Good morning, Mayor. Come in anytime.

title: Consumers League:
description: FOR most of the five years that Jayne Southwick Bodo!sky has been associated with the Consumers League of New Jersey, she has lived goodnaturedly with an image as the kid among the board of directors of the 78-year-old organization.

title: Men's Company to Bow At Judson Church
description: The men move across the creamcolored floor, absorbed in the curious ritual of dance. Beyond the stainedglass windows, the sounds of Washington Square Park are muted in the snowy winter afternoon. Inside, soft voice calls out: . Don't let it get set too much. Keep the energy up in the space. And on and on they dance.

description: There was an element of desperation about Anwar elSadat's trip to Washington this weekend and for good reason.

title: U.S. Neutrality Heartens Nicaragua Rebels
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 4By making no gesture of support for President Anastasio Somoza Debayle during his current political crisis, the United States has indirectly encouraged opposition groups to maintain their campaign againstthe longruling dictatorship.

description: LONG BEACH, L.I., Feb. 4 (UPI)The bodies of two persons were found today in the rubble of a Long Beach, L.I., apartment building that burned in predawn fire. authorities said.

description: BUFFALO, Feb. 4 (AP)Nick Galis scored 23 points and led Seton Hall to a 71.62 victory over Canisius tonight.

title: MARKETS
description: The stock market forged a modest advance last week despite a surprise dividend cut by the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker. On Monday, before the unsettling announcement from U. S. Steel, the Dow Jones industrial aver; age moved ahead more than eight points to record its biggest oneday gain of the year.

title: Exotics in the white Mans world
description: The search to uncover the photographic past, currently a pursuit that commands the diverse energies of academic art historians, social historians, museums, galleries, private collectors, and amateur addicts of thrift shops, flea markets and garage sales, comes more and more to resemble  in spirit at least  an archeological expedition. Every new dig into the attic or the dusty archive seems to turn up heretofore unknown pictures worthy of preservation, and every season new names are added to the already crowded annals of photographers who must be recognized as having produced distinctive work. Indeed, like archeology, photography is a field in which the discovery of unknown or littleknown masterworks is still a regular occurrence, which may be one reason for the activity it now generates.

title: The Issues Go Beyond Energy vs. Environment
description: The dilemma over oil and naturalgas exploration the Atlantic Ocean grew more acute last week. Once again, East Coast opponents triumphed over the oilmen, winning a lastminute cancellation of a sale leases in the Georges Bank fishing grounds. Big Oil promptly let out a Big Sigh. This part of the country just seems like it does not want to carry Its share of the energy burden, said Max G. Pitcher, general manager for North American exploration at the Continental Oil Company. When I left Houston for the lease sale, my 12-year-old son said, You're wasting your time, Dad. Now I've got to go back and tell him he was right fora change.

title: GARDENING In the Dead of Winter, Signs of Spring
description: SNOWFALL does haVe its compensations. It forces the housebound gardener outdoors and lets him flex his muscles a bit behind a shovel and ice scraper.

title: The Future's Revenge
description: THE futurist novel seems to be a Faustian bargain: The author sells his soul  and his characters  to purchase omniscience. He surrenders individuality to ideology, loving observation to bleak synthesis. He thinks too much and feels too little. He is interested in seeing only at a distance. The macninery of nis plot is like a factory where nothing handmade or carefully crafted. And for all this effort, all this knowing, the predictions of the futurist novelist are inevitably dire. The more we know about man, the further we can see, the worse things are.

And yet, unless the dancer performs rather than merely executes the steps, the choreography will fail. The most obvious examples are the ballets

title: Sports World Specials
description: For the last three seasons the word on Elliott Maddox has been damaged goods. In 1975, Maddox, then a Yankee and now a Met, injured his right knee when he slipped on the outfield grass at Shea Stadium, where the Yankees played their home games that year. After becoming a free agent this fall and signing with the Mets, Maddox has been working out three or sometimes lout times a week, trying to strengthen his knee so he Can return as the player he was before the injury.

Royal Dutch/ Shell is the archetype of the multinational company. But it has not been analyzed like I.T.T., glamourized like I.B.M., professionally admired like Citibank or vilified like Exxon, the only oil company that is bigger.

title: From Moscow to Murmansk, Not Quite a Consumers Paradise

The intelligence came from piece of highly unusual research: a Muscovite spent hours sitting in saunas at Black Sea resort talking with men from throughout the country.

The officials said the legal specialists faced difficulties because there was no precedent.

The area went into a funk and even the resident ghost, the Man in Gray, rarely came around.

title: Mrs. Humphrey to Take Seat

He was always standing under a palm tree at the edge of a dense jungle, watching over a large group of native workers. There were never sweatstains under the armpits of his white suit.

title: Let Community Development Develop
description: Washburn Wire Products, based in Harlem and one of Manhattan's largest industrial employers, was about to go out of business last year. But the company is alive and well now because it was bought by the Harlem Commonwealth Council, one of nearly fifty unusual Federal experiments called community development cor- porations. The Washburn rescue may be the last of its kind, however; the Administration's new budget has cut development corporation funds in half, to $25.8 million. Though less severe than some had feared, the slash nonetheless shortsighted and oddly inconsistent with other Administration efforts. Full funding should be restored.

title: The U.N. Today
Film: Happy Melange of Peasants and Ex-Parisians Meets to Eat
description: ON THE EVIDENCE of "Cousin, Cousine" and now "Blue Country," Jean-Charles Tacchella's specialty is the madcap crowd scene. By gathering together a band of zanies on an appropriately festive occasion, Mr. Tacchella can tickle his audiences with a disjointed, determinedly fluffy-headed brand of comedy. He can also, by allocating one or two piquant remarks to each character and never allowing anyone to conduct a sustained conversation, create the impression that this is merriment with a message.Mr. Tacchella's messages, upon close inspection, don't amount to much: He offers endless variations on the notions that people must do what makes them happiest, that they don't always live up to their dreams and that they must be forgiven their foibles. But the thematic banality of his films in no way compromises Mr. Tacchella's most useful talent, which is for sleight-of-hand. In "Blue Country," he once again manages to suggest that the lightweight mood of his films bespeaks an inner seriousness. Mr. Tacchella's peculiarly circular gift is for lending ephemeralness and insubstantiality the appearance of virtues.In "Blue Country," the obligatory zanies meet in a rural setting, a breath-takingly beautiful French valley populated by a happy mixture of peasants and ex-Parisians. The peasants have more children than they can keep track of, and long for the luxuries of city living; the Parisians like to bake bread, speak knowingly of their newly acquired goats and talk of the landscape in terms of Corot or Czanne ("No wonder peasants don't buy paintings!" one unreconstructed bourgeoise exclaims).The valley's populace meets gaily and often for communal dinners so appetizing that viewers headed for the 68th Street Playhouse, where the film has opened, would be well advised to arm themselves with bread and pat. At least half of "Blue Country's" appeal is based on its sheer pastoral pleasantness, and on the gusto with which its principals indulge their appetites.As in "Cousin, Cousine," there is a romantic subplot that seems strangely tangential to the film's predominant hustle and bustle. Louise (Brigitte Fossey), an ex-Parisian, meets Mathias (Jacques Serres), a country bachelor, and both are so fiercely independent that they vow not to fall in love. Fall in love they do, though, very picturesquely, and each makes a few sacrifices to accommodate the other. But they never move in together, even after 10 years of courtship, which is the film's rather lumbering way of reminding us that they have retained that fierce independence.Here, as before, Mr. Tacchella seems unable to integrate the romance with all the brouhaha, and it's the romance that suffers. Miss Fossey is unflaggingly radiant and Mr. Series attractively stalwart, yet the director seems unaccountably uneasy when his screenplay leaves him alone with these two very agreeable lovers."Blue Country" is less structurally coherent than "Cousin, Cousine," and its delightful eccentrics seem a little more contrived in their delightfulness. Both films are likely to appeal to the same audience, thoughto viewers who ascribe a certain Gallic cachet to films with the consistency of cotton candy, and who approach with utter fearlessness the prospect of being charmed to death.

title: The Benefits of Unemployment
description: More than four million Americans received unemployment insurance benefits in an average week last year. For most, the insurance functioned as intended, helping people to get along until a new job could be found. But fnr a sithstantial (and probably growing) portion of the unemployed, the . insurance served only as a taxfree cash supplement to already adequate incomes and reason not to look for work. Now, as part of his tax reform package, President Carter proposes to tax the unemployment benefits of those recipients with high incomes.

title: HEADS OF PRECINCTS TO GET MORE POWER
description: New York City's Police Commissioner said yesterday that he was giving precinct commanders greater independence, including the right to put as many of their police officers in plain clothes units as they want to.

title: Few Vie for Jersey School Boards
description: The annual school board elections in New Jersey, which begin tomorrow, have attracted the fewest candidates in the state's history, apparently as a result of apathy caused by the shift of financing from local control to Trenton.

title: RATE RISE EXPECTED IN CREDIT MARKETS
description: The consensus that dominates the credit markets these days holds that interest rates are headed upward in 1978, and the view is practically unanimous. Even so, many are optimistic that there may be a break in the trend during February.

title: Professional FundRaising Efforts For Police Groups Under Inquiry
description: Using techniques that law enforcement officials say sometimes verge on extortion, professional fundraisers hired by at least 20 police and detective benevolent associations during the last three years elicited millions of dollars in contributions from businessmen in the New York metropolitan area.

title: A Bronx Rehabilitation Is Now a Ruined Dream
description: Ten years ago a group of civic-minded people and government officials had a dream: to rehabilitate 20 decayed, partly occupied apartment buildings on two adjacent blocks of the South Bronx.

title: Israel Insists Aim at West Bank Site Is Archeological
description: JERUSALEM, Feb 5The Israeli Government defended today its decision to classify a controversial new community at ancient Shiloh on the occupied West Bank as an archeological dig rather than a new Israeli settlement.

title: 13 Held for Importing Marijuana
description: NEW BERN, N.C., Feb. 5 (AP)Thirteen men were arrested today anti charged with importing and conspiring to import marijuana after the state and Federal authorities seized a shrimp boat and six smaller craft laden with an esti- mated 20 tons of the drug, Don Ashton, a special agent for the Federal Drug Enforcement Agency, said that the men had been unloading about $16 million worth of marijuana from the Lady Ellen onto four smaller boats and two barges when they were arrested on the Neuse River.

title: U.S. Still Seeks Normalization
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (Reuters)The United States hopes that today's recall of the Vietnamese delegate to the United Nations will not affect talks on the normalization of relations between Washington and Hanoi, a State Department spokesman said.

title: Stenmark Captures His 2d Skiing Title
description: GARMISCHPARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany,- Feb. 5Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden closed the world championships of Alpine skiing here today by winning his second gold medal with an elegantly controlled pair of runs in the men's slalom: He won the giant slalom on Thursday.

title: The Buck Stops Here: $22,579 Big A Triple
description: The ninth race, a claimer worth $6,500, lit up the tote board with impressive figures at Aqueduct yesterday. The winner, Swarthmore Stable's Waza Buck, a 6-year-old gelding who had not finished better than fourth in his last 10 races, scored a 23/length triumph and returned $60 to win and set up a $22,579 Triple.

Miss Crespin has had a fine career on the operatic stage, and at her best her huge soprano had a commanding strength and a warmth that made it most appealing.

description: MIAMI, Feb. 5 (Reuters)Prime Minister Menachem Begin says that Israel will not surrender to Egypt's unreasonable demands for withdrawal to borders that prevailed before the 1967 Middle East war and for establishment of a Palestinian state.

title: Hijacker Convicted Second Time
description: SEATTLE, Feb., 5 (AP)Frank Marcoe Sibley Jr. has been convicted for the second time of hijacking a United Airlines airplane flying from Reno to Seattle in 1972 A Federal District Court jury re- turned the verdict Friday after deliberating for nearly a day. Mr. Sibley, who is 48 years old, was convicted of the hijacking and was sentenced to 30 year& in prison several months after he commandeered a Boeing 727 and demanded $2 million in ransom to aid warcrippled children in Vietnam. However, a Federal appellate court ordered a new trial, saying he had not had a proper hearing on his mental competency to stand trial.

title: Congress and Pentagon Face Key Questions on Role for U.S. in NATO
description: Congress and the Defense Department are dealing with two closely related issues that affect the future of the United States role in NATO.

title: Rangers End Slump, 63
description: Walter Tkaczuk had little to say last night, but the frizzyhaired center's work on the ice spoke eloquently as he scored two goals and assisted on two, leading the Rangers to a 6.3 victory over the Colorado Rockies. It was New York's first victory since Jan. 18 after six consecutive losses and one tie.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The Republican National Committee plans to spend $1.75 million this year in an extraordinary effort to elect state legislators around the country. No major party has done this before, and the Democrats have no comparable plans.

The sale, which ilmanne $56 Billion of maturing bills and raise $200 million of additional cash, was scheduled Feb. 10 because the Government securities market will he closed Feb 13.

title: Chairlift Accident Injures Dozen At Hunter Mountain Ski Resort

None of the victims was seriously injured. Seven of them were taken to three hospitals in the area, where they were reported as in fair to good condition.

title: No Moaning At This Bar
description: ACCORDING to a newsmagazine I read in other days, sportswriters are a notoriously sentimental lot. That is how they put it. Notorious. Sentimental. And lot. The same issue reported that if we were to stand any chance against godless, atheistic communism, we would all have to vote for Thomas E. Dewey. Although young, I let my subscription expire.

title: A Vote for the Redwoods.
description: A final skirmish in the long battle to enlarge and protect the Redwood National Park in northern California is about to begin. With the Senate's vote last week in favor of the park expansion bill, the spotlight now shifts to the House Rules Committee. The House version of the measure was bottled up by this committee last year. An affirmative vote now would give the full House its chance to consider the merits of the plan to add 48,000 acres to the park.

title: A Brown Study: I
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5Federal funding for five of California's state mental hospitals will be cut off next week because inspectors found their staff and physical conditions belowminimum standards. That follows similar findings by California licensing officials. They decertified four hospitals for the mentally retarded last fall because patients were going hungry, dirty, without care.

title: Stage: Double Bill of South  African Drama
description: ATHOL FUGARD'S characters are harried by a foreshortened version of fate. It is the State that perpetrates the arbitrariness and unpredictability that in other places is left to life itself. The State Mr. Fugard writes about is South Africa, and the lives he writes about are those of the blacks and the coloreds and the occasional white who tries to share their destiny. Mr. Fugard's gift is to write about people impaled upon an extremity, and to make their humanity all the more vivid and precious because of it. There is hardly a living playwright of the English language who can denounce so strongly while creating so much life.

title: A Former Smoker Gives Neediest Saving of 58 Weeks Since Stopping
description: Breaking a smoking habit more than a year ago has so pleased one donor to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund that she has given the yearly campaign $174.

Once, he was the world's highestsalaried athlete, cashing paychecks of $50,000 every two weeks in season, sending his RollsRoyce on 80mile trips to pick up women friends, buying rounds for everyone in the bar. Only last year, Sanderson earned $214,000 capping remarkable fiveyear stretch in which he grossed more than $2 million.

Mr. Carey and Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingutboth Democrats from Brooklyn  are supposed to be allies, but their ability to work to-gether has often been strained because of a difference of style and frequently a strong difference in political points-of-view.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Are you a badminton player with a desire to improve but without an opponent? Shotball may be a solution. This new game, developed for badminton courts, features small perforated balls that approximate the flight of the feathered shuttlecock. Special racquets, rather loosely strung, come with the game, but the balls can be used with regular badminton racquets too. The balls last longer and cost less than shuttle- cocks and can be used for solo practice. They rebound off a wall, for instance, and can be hit on a bounce (which is allowed in the rules of play). The game can be played indoors or out, even when, there is some breeze, because the ball is less affected by wind than is a shuttlecock. There are three classes of ballswhite for slower indoor play; yellow for faster outdoor play, and a competition model (not yet on the market) for serious badminton plpyrers. The balls cost $1.60 for a set of three, and the game sets range from $7 to $20, directly from Norca Industries, 235 Monte de Lisse, Ville St. Laurent, Mortreal H4TIP5.

title: 'Coup de Grace,' A Film Parable
description: THE TIME is winter, 1919-20, shortly after the end of World War I. The setting is that Baltic territory where the Allies, for a while represented by troops of the defeated Kaiser, waged a desultory campaign against the Bolsheviks who had come to power in Russia. That war, too, was already over but the people fighting it hadn't been told. As the war became Increasingly fragmented, the battles became increasingly violent, bitter and personal.On one of the great Latvian estates near Riga, still comparatively serene in spite of food shortages, disease and defections to the Rod cause, the last act is played out as the kind of domestic drama that comes perilously close to farce. No one quite understands what's happening, but then when they do, they continue to pursue doom not as duty but as conscious choice.Volker Schlondorff's "Coup de Grace," adapted from Marguerite Your-cenar's 1939 novel (published here in 1957), has the form of a violent nightmare now dimly remembered. The film is the recollection of a Prussian officer who participated in specific events from which all pain has long since vanished. What is now remembered is the series of curious occurrences that, in hindsight, appear to have been inevitable."Coup de Grace," which opened yesterday at the Cinema Studio, is an extremely studied, sorrowful movie, photographed in a fine, chilly black and white that has the important effect of removing the story even further away from our emotions. We don't respond to it viscerally. We contemplate it with a certain amount of detachment, which, in this movie era of fast-cutting and obligatory shock, is almost refreshing.I'm not quite sure that I know exactly what Mr. Schlondorff ("Young Torless," "The Lost Honor of Katharina Blum," etc.) and his wife, Margarethe von Trotta, who collaborated on the screenplay and has the leading role, see as the point of the movie, though it's a vivid and haunting experience.The film is, I suppose, a kind of parable about the collapse of one order and the survival of another. It's the story of Sophie (Miss von Trotta), a handsome, strong-willed aristocrat, her younger brother Konrad (Rudiger Kirschstein), and Erich (Matthias Habich), the Prussian officer who commands the White garrison at their country house. Sophie loves Erich, Erich loves (apparently from afar) Konrad, and Konrad, having not much passion for anything, exists passively, to be supported by those around him.Though Sophie loves Erich, her sympathies are with the Reds, a political commitment she doesn't act upon until she learns about Erich's feelings for Konrad. As the campaign against the Bolsheviks collapses, only Erich the true Prussian, maintains some sense of purpose. Life at the great house falls into disorder. The crazy old aunt, who talks French and wears horrendous makeup, presides at formal dinners as artillery shells land in the garden. When the Bolsheviks triumph, only Erich survives to musein voice-over narrationabout the depth of Sophie's love and fury.Does Erich survive to support the later rise of Adolf Hitler? "Coup de Grace" remains at such a distance from its characters that one must make all sorts of assumptions about them, which is the reason it is disturbing without being entirely satisfying."Coup de Grace" raises many questions that it refuses to answer in any easy fashion, which is just the opposite of Mr. Schlondorff's "The Lost Honor of Katharina Blum," a film that had an answer for everything. Since I'm suspicious of answers in art, I much prefer this new film.

title: Teachers Union to Push Bills on Caps and Strikes

After going through innumerable changes on drawing boards and in budget sessions, that series has finally emerged in a patchwork conglomeration called The Originals. It began last Thursday with a halfhour on Mary Cassatt, which is being rerun tonight at 10:30 on Channel 13.

title: The Burns Egg vs. the Miller Chicken
description: Which came first, inflation or unemployment? That question has been answered in such diametrically opposite ways in recent debates over Federal policy that the public must feel more confused than ever. Arthur Burns, the outgoing chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, argues with professorial certainty that inflation generates unemployment by upsetting investment plans.

L, Feb. 6For the third time this winter, major roads in Nassau and Suffolk Counties were closed by the weather today, and motorists who were caught on them had to be rescued by the police. title: Montserrat Caballe Sings Lead In Met's `Adriana Lecouvreuf
description: Like vintage Bette Davis movies, Cilea's Adriana Lecouvreur is an opera the true buff adores, no matter how often he may be told that it is trash. This work does not uplift the spirit, challenge the intellect or shed much light on the human condition, but the score is full of very pretty tunes beautifully written for the voice and the action bristles with enough crafty musical melodrama to raise any audience's blood pressure. If done really well, there's no reason why should not provide a fun evening now and then to counterbalance the deeper messages of Mozart, Verdi or Wagner.

title: News Summary
description: Snow closed schools and businesses in the New York metropolitan region and made all travel hazardous. The snow fell at times at the rate of an inch an hour, and the accumulation late in the day was eight to 12 inches in the city, and more than a foot in New Jersey and Yonkeii. The National Weather Service had predicted the storm would continue into the night, possibly depths of as much as 18 inches in the city, and up to two feet in some New Jersey areas. description: carol Burnett announced yesterday that her CBSTV comedyvariety series would not be back on the air next year because after 11 years and 286 shows, including those that remain to be done this season, I want to be free for a while from the demands of a weekly show. Robert A. Daly, president of the CBS entertainment division; said, We have asked Carol to reconsider her decision and return with her show for a 12th year, but she has remained firm in her position. Miss Burnet said she wanted to make it clear that she was certainly not retiring from television, and added, I will definitely continue my association with CBS by doing a number of specials over a period of years. Since her first CBS season in 1967, Miss Burnett and her supporting players have performed in nearly 1,500 comedy sketches and 500 musical numbers.

title: A Little Help for Consumers

If House mem- bers manage to look beyond the symbols to the substance of the debate, the consumer agency bill should stand a good chance of passage. And once over the House hurdle, the going should be easier; supporters form a majority in the Senate.

title: `Portrait de Manon Revived as Concert

So in 1894, 10 years after Manon's premiere, he came up with a little oneact piece called Le Portrait de Manon, which received one of its rare revivals. in concert form, by Musique a Ia Mode at Hunter College on Sunday afternoon.

title: Pollard, at 84, Reflects On His Days of Glory
description: There are many things one would never suspect about the quiet, old gentleman living in the rambling twostory white stucco corner house in New Rochelle with his wife and German Shepherd dog.

title: New York TeenAge Scientists Emerge on Top in Talent Search
description: Ten teenagers from New York City high schools collected top honors in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search yesterday for projects ranging from a study of the courting habits of fruit flies to a system for a computer-controlled robot.

title: ISRAEL CANCELS PLAY ON STATE TELEVISION
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 6A Government official canceled at the last minute tonighea state television presentation of a play by an Israeli which shows Arab villagers banished from their homes by Israeli forces during the 1948 war of independence.

description: BLOOMSBURG, Pa., Feb. 6 (AP)A bus. carrying 46 girls from a Jewish day school in New York City sideswiped a tractortrailer, then flipped over near here today, injuring 21 of the girls.

Such gatherings, commonplace luring the heydey of jazz lofts a year or two ago, have become somewhat rare now that the lofts are no longer centers of downtown jazz activity.

title: Pop: Robert Fri pp After 3 Years
description: When Robert Fripp finally broke up his King Crimson band in 1974, it and he were firmly established as leading innovators on the London progressiverock scene. Since then Mr. Fripp has pursued a reclusive course as a solo guitarist, collaborating with some of the more interesting figures in experimental rock (Brian Eno, David Bowie), but rarely performing publicly and being extremely guarded in talking to the press.

Blumenthal, the former Assembly majority leader, in return for help in getting a license for a nursing home.

title: SunayanaPerformsKathak, Dances of Northern India
description: The dance of other cultures can seem impenetrable to all but the initiate. The liveliness and pantomimic element of Kathak, the dance of northern India, makes it accessible to the casual viewer although it is a style with rigorous technique and highly shaded nuance. On Sunday at the Alternative Center for International Art, Sunavana. a Kathak dancer from Bombay, presented a solo recital that not only delighted aficionados in the audience, but also drew in those less familiar with the art, ending in a standing ovation. It was an afternoon of pure magic.

title: Thousands of Stranded Motorists Rescued After Abandoning Cars
description: Thousands of motorists and their passengers forced to abandon cars on snowchoked highways were rescued by the police and put up in firehouses, schools, churches and even a factory on Long Island yesterday afternoon and evening.

description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 6 (AP)--- Zandra Montgomery scored 29 points and Cindy Brogdon added 26 to give Tennessee a surprisingly easy 8668 victory over top - ranked Louisiana State in a women's game tonight.

title: Topics
description: A small London firm named Coral Index, Ltd., has developed a line of business that may make New York City's languishing stockbrokers bullish. Coral Index takes bets on the market. The player simply chooses to buy or sell lumps of Dow Jones industrial stocks, composed of 30 leading issues on the New York Stock Exchange. If they go up in a given period, the buyer wins; if they go down, the seller wins. And vice versa. The bookmaker safeguards himself with a point spread, just as America's bookmakers do on sports events around the land.

description: Dick Nolan was appointed head coach of the New Orleans Saints yesterday, replacing Hank Stram who was dismissed last week. Details, page 8.
