description: MOSCOW, Feb. 6 (AP)Two Soviet astronauts jettisoned the unmanned space supply ship Progress 1 from the Salyut 6 space station today, and space officials made preparations to bring the supply ship down to burn up in the earth's atmosphere, Tass reported.

title: Koch, Carey Agree on Aid to City
description: Ending weeks of uncertainty, Governor Carey and Mayor Koch announced yesterday that they had agreed the state budget contained $200 million to help New York City close its budget gap in the coming fiscal year, and that the figure would be an appropriate amount of state aid to the city.

title: BECTON SUES SUN CO. TO BLOCK TAKEOVER
description: Vigorously battling a $293 million takeover attempt, Becton, Dickinson & Company, the big New Jersey hospital supplier, charged the Sun Company in a suit filed here yesterday with making an illegal acquisition and six others with acting in concert and conspiracy.

title: Spain's Andalusians, Beset by Economic Problems, Near Autonomy
description: SEVILLE, Spain  Andalusia, the political tinderbox of Spain, is about to join Catalonia and the Basque provinces in obtaining a provisional autonomy statute from Madrid. The statute will be cause for considerable rejoicing, but also some nervousness.

title: Begelman Resigns  At Columbia Films Amid Controversy
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6David Begelman, the center of a controversy that began with allegations of a coverup involving forgery charges and grew to include questioning of financial practices throughout Hollywood, resigned today as president of the film and television divisions of Columbia Pictures Industries Inc.

title: TV: WCBS Eye On Focuses on Lesbian Couples
description: One of the more visible evolutions in broadcasting attitudes over the last decade has taken place around the reality of homosexuality. For years, that reality simply didn's exist except in the flip putdown of a mincing fag joke. Then, slowly, the homosexual began to be discovered as a convenient dramatic peg. Usually the result, no matter how good the intention, was distorted.

Flood helped Hahnemann Hospital in Philadelphia get favored treatment over 83 other applicants for Federal construction grants in 1975, even though the hospital failed to meet the criteria for these funds, according to officials at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 7 (AP)An earthquake of medium intensity jolted the eastern Turkish province of Van, near the Soviet border, today, causing minor damage but no casualties, the state radio reported.

title: 60 Minute Gourmet
description: THE FIRST anecdote I ever heard about American cooking after I came to this country in 1939 had to do with that hastily made preparation called shrimp, lobster or crab meat Newberg. It is a story I have heard in several versions since then, but basically it concerns a customer named Wenberg who dined often at the old Delmonico's restaurant in Man- hattan during the last quarter or the 19th century. Some say he created a dish with cream and egg yolks and sherry which he offered the chef and which subsequently was listed on menus as seafood Wenberg.

title: Celeste Holm to Star in OneCharacter Play

She will appear in Paris Was Yesterday, adapted from the memoirs of Janet Flanner, whose writings from France have appeared for many years in The New Yorker. The play, adapted and directed by Paul Shyre, will recall Miss Flanner's encounters with such figures as Hemingway, Picasso, Fitzgerald and Gertrude Stein.

description: MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Feb. 7 (UPI)The Villa De Roma Restaurant was destroyed today by fire, the second blaze in six weeks. The police said an arsonist set the fire in December, and they were investigating today's. The restaurant, on Route 541, was valued at $250,000.

description: It was the decade before the Civil War and. Charles Loring Brace was warning New York City's fortunate classes that the unwanted, unwashed and uneducated youngsters who rootlessly roamed the streets had no future but to join the dangerous classes.

title: Private Lives
description: sURPRISE! It was a birthday party, and we therefore behaved like trombones, and the victim was pleased, and the tears fell like dimes, and I looked at the ceiling, which where I always look when the spy business takes me to the vital and dangerous Upper West Side of tne imperial .city. Such high ceilings they nave on the Upper West Side, as if to accommodate eagles or bats. And yet the people who live under these high ceilings do not, on the whole, seem bigger than the people who live elsewhere in New. York, perhaps because they eat so much Chinese food. Considering the housing shortage, maybe we should partition along the perpendicular, or turn all these old buildings on their ears. Turning them on their ears, of course, would block traffic, and that would be good thing, too. Traffic frightens the eagles.

description: THE Mabou Mines, one of our most valuable experimental companies, is, explorative tending the possibilities of theater into the visual arts. In the past, the company's farranging work has included the transformation of Samuel Beckett narrative fragments into impressionistic chamber plays; the eyefilling  cornucopia of Colette in Dressed Like an Egg; The Saint and the Football Players, a sports/art spectacle featuring a forklift ballet and a brass marching band.

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: -

title: DISCOVERIES
description: There are some who say they will absolutely choke if they see hearts and flowers on Valentine's Day, but we can't worry about these jaded sophisticates. The day is meant for sentiment and if sentiment is corny, so be it. So how's this to start out witha heart, lace and flowers all wrapped up in one gift. That's hitting the sentimental jackpot. At Renny, a landscaping concerti naturally involved in flowers, there are some marvelous crochet pillows in old lace, many of them heartshaped, and the idea is to have the pillow delivered to a loved one, with a little corsage attached. All this will set hack the budget about $45, depending on pillow and corsage chosen. The Address is 27 East 62nd Street, and the telephone number is 3715354.

description: The weather has forced the Boston Syraphony Orchestra to cancel tonighfs concert at Carnegie Hall. Announcement of a new playing date will be made in the next few. days, Tickets for tonight's concert ,will be honored on that occasion or may be turned in for a refund at the Cernegie Hall box office (2477459), The orchestra is expected to appear tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall as scheduled.

title: Chess:
description: When I last saw Grandmaster Anatoly Lein, at the 1977 United States championship in Mentor, Ohio, he was uttering the familiar complaint about how hard it is to keep up with the rapid changes in opening theory these days. At most, I go into these competitions half preparedno, not even that, he said.

title: Guider MW
description: FATS CATS Fats Waller, who died in 1993, was one of the great jazz composers and pianists (also organist) of all time, which is reason enough for the Manhattan Theater Club, 321 East 73d Street (47206001 to nay him tribute in his own coin. This honor is in the form of a show, Ain't Misbehavin', that includes a fivemember cast and more than 25 songs he either wrote or made famous. Among the numbers you'll hear are Ain't Misbehavin', Honeysuckle Rose and Keepin Out of Mischief Now.

title: Doherty, Mann Adds Appliances by Waring

Doherty, Mann & Olshan is only now admitting that the Waring Products division of the Dynamics Corpora- tion of America has added the remainder of its appliances to the ones the agency already had. Billings have been estimated by Wells, Rich, Greene, the parent agency, at about $2.5 million.

title: THOMAS J. FITZPATRICK
description: Thomas J. Fitzpatrick, who had served as the legislative representative of the New York City Board of Education and had a career of more than 40 years in the city's school system, died Sunday at the Andover (N.J.) Nursing Home. He was 75 years old.

title: Lebanese and Syrians Battle, for, an Hour, Killing at Least 2, After Exchanging Insults
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 7 Lebanese soldiers clashed with members of the Syrian peacekeeping fore here today as the Syrians sought to set up a new checkpoint near a Lebanese Army barracks. Firing continued for an hour, leaving at least two dead and an unknown number wounded.

title: Last ance for a Gas Compromise
description: For weeks, the. fate. of the Carter energy program.has turned on the outcome of a bitter Congressional stritggle over natural gas. Salate conference committee members, divided.betweery,defenders and opponents of Federal gas price regillation have remained deadlocked despite one compromise initiative, aftei another. Now perhaps for the last time, influential moderates are attempting to bridge the gap. A new plan offered by Senator Henry Jackson does not differ, greatly from a proposal by Senator Bennett Johnston that sank without a ripple in December. But this time there is a now-or-never sense to the negotiations that mayforce tha Senators. to face the consequences of their ideological rigidity. The new Jackson proposal is a perfectly sensible basis for com promise.

description: .WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1978

title: Jersey Shore Battered as Winds Whip Tides 7 Feet Abote Normal
description: MANASQUAN, N.J., Feb, 7Winddriven tides smashed the New Jersey oceanfront from Sandy Hook to Cape May last evening and again this morning, gouging out valuable stretch of beach and causing millions of dollars in damage to homes, boardwalks and resort facilities.

description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 7Ethiopian troops have.stepped Up fighting in what is apparently the start of the longawaited counteroffensive to repulse Somali forces from Ethiopia's Ogaden region.

description: PRAGUE, Feb. 7Czechoslovakia's still highly conservative and isolationist Comtnunist Party and Government appearto be. taking the first hesitant steps toward an opening to the Westa move dictated by a series of preSSing.economic and political problems that have been growing more acute month. by month.

title: Youth Awarded $127. Million
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Feb. 7 (AP)An Orange County Superior Court jury has ordered the Ford Motor Company to pay $127.8 million in damages to a youth who suffered Severe burns over 95 percent of his body when the gas tank of a 1972 Pinto exploded.

description: Tennessee whisky, or its kissin cousin, bourbon, is as Southern as possums, catfish and kudzu, and consuming it should refect the Southern ambiance, That can mean sipping it slow, like stroking an old gray cat in winter, or knocking it back neat with a jolt like summer lightning.

title: STORM EMERGENCIES ISSUED FOR 3 STATES

description: Like everything else,,love isn't what it used be. Nobody seems quite sure what it is these days or where to find it; but with Valentine's Day just ahead, it seems appropriate to explore current sentiments.

description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 7 (AP)George D. Aldrich, a Massachusetts investment banker and a first cousin of the Rockefeller brothers, died here today of kidney failure, the United States Embassy announced. He was 61 years old.

description: Joe Frazier, at the age of 34, is set to make a comeback almost two years after he announced his retirement.

title: Koch Tours 2 Brooklyn Sections, Promises Help, and Gets a Kiss
description: In a whirlwind tour of two Brooklyn neighborhoods, Mayor Koch promised the special assistance of four city departments, called on Governor Carey to grant a special state appropriation and even got a kiss from an angry resident after looking at the flooded apartment building she lived in.

title: Wine Talk
description: Despite the muchpublicized Heublein auction of rare wines held every year in this country, wine auctions are relatively unknown to American wine drinkers. Restrictive liquor laws do much to impede the innovative marketing of wines.in the United States, but even if these laws wererelaxed,there is little likelihood that wine auctions would become much more popular.

title: Cold Weather: Hot Cereal Mornings
description: T'S a hot cereal morning, my mother would whisper, half aloud, half to herself, as she routed us out of bed on the coldest, darkest school mornings in midwinter. It was an announcement that told us more than merely what we were having for breakfast; it was a weather report as well. A firm believer in children eating a solid breakfast before going to school, and a hot one whenever possible, my mother would no more let us out the door without hot cereal on the frostiest mornings than she would let us leave without coats and scarves, boots and mittens.

The Transit Authority expects normal service on all subway lines.

title: Two Seats in the House
description: All New Yorkers have a stake in the special election next Tuesday in which the voters of the South Bronx and the East Side of Manhattan will fill vacancies in the House. of Representatives. The winners will reach Washington in time to participate in this spring's effort bail out the city. They will have a shot at seats on the important Banking and Public Works Cominittees, which will determine the shape of assistance to the city. The winners will also gain a clear advantage in the maneuvering, already begun, for the primary and regular elections for Congressmen later this year.

title: Notes on People
description: ALE KUEHN, a Federal Energy Administration investigator based in Houston, quit his job is disguist last year, enarging that the agency had failed to stop illegal fuel price increases. His explanation of how several corpora- inns and nunviduals profited trom sales of fuel to the Florida Power Company resulted in a Federal investigation that i sstill going on. Now, Mr. Kuehn is the surprised recipient of a $10,000 check from an unidentified Californian who saw. Mr. Kuehn tell his story on the CBSTV's 60 Minutes program. Harry AShmore, the former newspaper ex6cutive rwh'o acted as a gobetween. said of the donor: It is his, hope that this taxexempt gift will help Kuehn further his ambition to take graduate training that will enable him to qualify as a certified public accountant.

Mr. Brezenoff, 40 years old, was program officer of the Ford Foundation's office of government and law. Before joining the foundation in 1971, he was a program adviser for the New York Urban Coalition, and director of.program operations for the city's Human Resources Administration.

description: N THE 1960's, there were Many composers, who attempted .:.to make music reflect political or social concerns. Vietnam, civil rights and campus riots turned up as the subjects of academic cantatas as well as popular songs. description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 7 (UPI)Tom Sheff was released from prison today after serving about two months of a twoyear sentence on a drug conviction, which law officers and the courts had forgotten about. He was freed early by the Parole and Probation Commission.

description: You couldn't get here from there yesterday, and so not too many people tried.

title: Columbia Foreign Legion Striving for Tennis Glory
description: The snow falling outside the Columbia Tennis Center's bubble was as strange to them as the clay courts on which the three new members of the varsity tennis team were playing the other day. For Abil Toubia of Sudan and Greg Dingwell and Andy Caulfield of Australia, all of whom learned to play on grass, it was a time for adjustment

title: NATION'S STEEL OUTPUT INCREASED 2.7% IN WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended Feb. 4 rose to 2.28 million tons, up 2.7 percent from the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry produced 2.22 million tons the week before.

title: Open Interest
Derby Hopefuls Frolic in Florida
description: To get a colt ready for the Kentucky Derby, Woody Stephens told a visitor recently at Hialeah Park in Florida, you've got to be where the weather is right. You can't, get a horse ready in New York.

title: Measure to Expand Redwood Park Sent by Rules Committee to House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)  The House Rules Committee cleared the way today for floor action on a bill to expand Redwoods National Park in California by 30,000 acres. The measure was passed by the Senate last week, 74 to 20.

title: Dividends
Personal Health
description: MILLIONS of Americans, most of them middleaged or older, haye serious and potentially lifethreatening coronary heart disease. One or more of the arteries that supply their hearts have become, encrusted with fatty deposits atherosclerosis) that may impede the flow of blood to that lifesustaining pump.

title: Bill to Ease Taxes for Americans Abroad Would Cost U.S. Millions
description: WASHI.NCITOP.1, Feb. 7Legislatioh to case the impact of the 1976 tax law on overseas taxpayers would cost the Treasury $115 million or more a year, . and more than half of that tax saving would go. to Americans working in the Middle East and Africa, according to a Treasury analysis published today.

title: BONDS DOWN A BIT; NEW ISSUES PRICED
description: Bond prices slipped slightly yesterday and investment hankers priced more than $600 million of new bonds, many of which had been delayed a day because of the heavy snowfall over the Northeast, as the credit markets returned to fullscale operation.

title: The U.N. Today
Ambiance, for Women, Scheduled Next Week
description: A new fashion magazine called Ambiance is in the wings waiting to make its debut next Tuesday in New York and in the rest of the country a week later. Its point of difference is that it will be interested only in the American woman  her life style, fashion and beauty  and the American retail scene.

title: The 3Day Cursillo: Basically a BornAgain Movement for Catholics
description: A Roman Catholic movement that began on the island of Majorca, Spain, has become a social and religious force among Hispanic people, in the United Statesparticularly in the New York area.

title: Lamplight: The Soft Glow Of Yesterday
description: THE OR lamps our ancestors depended on for light are making a comback and taking their place alongside modern appliances the home. Cheaper than candles, more dependable than batteries, they're a godsend when the power fails. They're romantic, too, evoking as they do the aura of more tranquil days.

title: Miss. Barker Joins Racquets
description: PHOENIX, Feb. 8 (AP)Sue Barker was signed by the Phoenix Racquets of World Team Tennis today. The 2I-yearold Briton replaces Chris Evert, who was traded to the Los Angeles Strings last month. Ross Case of Australia, playercoach, will not return to the team, said the owner, Jimmy Walker.

description: HOUSTON, Feb. 8 (AP)Dr. Granville Sawyer, Texas Southern University president, terminated the contracts of seven of the 10 assistant football coaches at the Southwestern Athletic Conference school today in a move to bring spiraling costs under control.

title: JUSTICE DEPT.CHECKS 1975 DASH TESTIMONY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 The Justice Department is looking into Samuel Dash's testimony at a Nevada gaming board hearing as part of its general review of his fitness to be United States Attorney in Philadelphia, according to John Russell, a department spokesman.

title: A Ticket Offer Finds No Takers in Stamford
description: Clairol, the Stamford, Conn., manufacturer of haircare products, stood ready to do battle with the state any of the company's 1,500 employees got a ticket on the way to work for defying a driving ban imposed by Gov. Ella T. Grasso.

title: Cornell Students Get an Elective: Gastronomy, SelfTaught
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 8 How many times have you sat in a fancy restaurant and thought, I could do just as well at home'?

title: Passaic County Jail Conditions Are Deplorable, VanNess Says
description: Stanley C. Van Ness, the State Public Advocate, filed a classaction suit in Federal District Court in Trenton listing 47 conditions at the Passaic County jail in Paterson that he said constituted cruel and unusual punishment and violated the constitutional rights of inmates.

title: 2 MORE BROKERAGES PLAN INSTITUTIONAL RATE RISE
description: Two more brokerage firmsMitchell Hutchins Inc. and Shearson Hayden Stone Inc.have decided to increase their institutional commission rates, following the move announced over the weekend by Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette Inc.

title: 2 Russian Flu Cases in Michigan
description: LANSING, Mich., Feb., 8 (Reuters)Two confirmed cases of Russian flu, the first in the United States outside the Rocky Mountain area, were reportd in Michigan today. State health officials said that the illness had been diagnosed and confirmed in a 19-year-old East Lansing man and a 20-year-old Tecumseh man. Both men contracted the flu last month and have since recovered. Many cases of Russian flu have been reported in Wyoming and Colorado, with a virtual epidemic at the Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs.

title: CARTER AND SADAT END MIDEAST TALKS, VOW PEACE EFFORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  President. Carter and President Anwar clSadat of Egypt concluded their talks here today with pledges to continue efforts to reach a Middle East peace that would provide security for Israel and a solution to the Palestinian problem.

title: 76ers 117, Jazz 104
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb.8 (UPI)Julius Erving had 23 points to lead five Philadelphia players in double figures and carry the 76ers to a 117.104 victory tonight over the New Orleans Jazz.

title: Sugar and Spice, but Not Everything Nice
description: THERE ARE in this world certain childrenyou are either one of them, or their victimwho crop up in every new generation like dandelions to bedevil the grass. They are not evil, perhaps not even calculatedly malicious, and seen from the heights (which is how most adults view children) they aren't even very exceptional. But what do we know? More to the point, what do we remember? There is at least one baby tyrant in everyone's 1..ast  a slab toothed gloater who ruled the class with the moral authority of a person whose socks never slipped down into her shoes. Who knows what miracle glue these children p..)ss'..s?

description: HAMPTON, CONN.

title: Backgammon
description: The Amateur Backgammon Championship recently held in Las Vegas, Nev., drew a recordbreaking 652 players, who competed for $360,000 in prizes. No professional players were permitted to play. Suspense heightened in the last rounds of the tournament, as all the final contestants were unknown and untested.

title: Kodak Cuts Prices, Offers New Cameras
description: The Eastman Kodak Company disclosed yesterday an aggressive marketing strategy for conventional and instant consumer photography, inOoducing four new pocket Instamatic cameras and two new motorized instant cameras with lower prices and more features than their predecessors.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 8Western negotiators are preparing to press for acceptance of a new proposal to obtain independence for SouthWest Africa.

description: BOSTON, Feb. 8 --.ThiS city struggled today to dig out from under the worst snowstorm in its history as the police and National Guard. troops stood by to prevent a recurrence of last night's loot.ing incidents.

title: Futures Prices Dip In Precious Metals; Copper Also Drops
description: A steadier dollar and a 50-cent-anounce drop in London gold bullion prices sent prices of precious metals futures tumbling yesterday in New York.

title: EARNINGS FELL 20% IN 4TH QUARTER; 77 PROFITS UP 14%
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday 20 percent decline in fourthquarter earnings but an increase of 14 percent for all of 1977. These preliminary earnings are both before extraordinary items, according to the unaudited statement.

title: ;Design Notebook
description: IT IS NO wonder that some people Jose their way on the New York ,subway. It is a wonder that any of them find their way. For the city's system of rapid transit, technical marvel that it is, has been for years under the aegis of administrators whose sole purpose, it would seem, has been to deny the public any sense of information about where they are going. It is no exaggeration to say that there is no subway system in the world with a more inadequate and confusing system of signs and maps than New York's.

title: Notes on People
description: IN the long career of 87-year-old actor, Stanley Holloway, perhaps best remembered for his Broadway role as Eliza Doolittles father in My Fair Lady, he has not until now, he says, won a show business award.

title: East German Daily Complains About Questioning After Hijacking
description: EAST BERLIN, Feb. 8 (Reuters)LEast Germany accused West German authorities today of violating international law by what it called their scandalous treatment of airline passengers hijacked to. Frankfurt on Monday.

title: TV: 6Hour King, Drama of Civil Rights Drive
description: ING, a sixhour docudrama being presented by NBCTV in twohour segments on three consecutive nights, begins Sunday at P.M. Already the production is caught up in an unusually blustery swirl of vestedinterest criticism and potential controversy. Written and directed by Abby Mann, whose previous scripts include the film Judge in Nuremberg and television's The MarcusNelson Murders (which gave birth to Kojak') this new project, reportedly costing nearly $5 mullion, traces the life of Martin Luther King Jr. from the 1953 courtship of his future wife, Coretta, to his murder at a Memphis Motel in 1968.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Times yesterday incorrectly reported that President Carter had approved disaster designations for Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island. The President approved declarations of emergency providing Federal help in digging out from Monday's storm, but not the loans and grants that disaster designation would permit.

title: All the Essentialsfor $1,565
description: WHEN IT COMES to decorating a two-and-a-half room apartment, $1,565 can stretch only so far. It could, for instance, buy you a matching pair of Angelo Donghia sofas, or 9-by-12-foot Oriental rug at Sloane's, or perhaps a custombuilt bookcase wall.

title: Drug Used for Gout Found to Cut Deaths From 2d Heart Attacks
description: An international research study has found that an existing drug, Anturane, can more than halve the incidence of sudden deaths from heart attacks among people who have previously had at least one heart attack..

title: The Reluctant Marchioness
description: WOBURN, ENGLAND

title: Piano: Ivan Moravec
description: AS FAR as New Yorkers are concerned, Ivan Moravec is one of those artists better known for their recordings than in live performances. He has made numerous albums for the Connoisseur label, but he has not played in New York since the 1960's, when he appeared twice w:th orchestra and once in recital. The recordings have given him a strong local following. His piano recital in Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Tuesday night had long been sold out. If the recent storm's aftermath kept the actual audience down it was extremely large under the circumstances.

title: Bridge
description: One of New York's brightest stars, 29-year-old Ron Rubin, seems to have been thinking of matters other than bridge in the past month. He recently required a limitedoption seat on the American Stock Exchange, and 10 days ago won second prize in a major backgammon tournament in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Dayan, Visiting New York, Gives Israeli Side of Settlements Issue
description: Some young people want to go and settle down on the landwhat a crime, said the Israeli Foreign Minister, Moshe Dayan, referring in a speech in New York yesterday to a dispute between the United States and. Israel over new Israeli settlements on occupied Arab land.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)President Carter's proposal to overhaul the nation's welfare system survived its first major test today when a special House subcommittee approved the plan basically as the White House designed it.

description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it lost $9.5 million in the fourth quarter of 1977 but showed profit for the full year of $45 million.

title: OSCAR L, CHAPMAN, 81; AIDE TO PRESIDENTS
description: Oscar L. Chapman, a key strategist for the Democratic Party during the Roose-s velt and Truman Administrations and senior official of the Department of the Interior for 20 years, died yesterday Washington, D.C., after a long illness He was 81 years old.

description: If there is glory in the city's recovery from the snow, it is more insectival than romantic.

description: The New Jersey Nets ended a 16game losing streak last night in Piscataway with a 140138 victory over the Indiana Pacers in overtime. Page D18.

description: LOS ANGELESTwo words, confidence and credibility, again provide insight into the waning public popularity of a President.

description: School cleaners and maintenance workers reached a new oneyear agreement yesterday with the Board of Education and custodians, averting a strike.

description: STUDENT orchestras don't always sound studentish. But the Tuesday evening Carnegie Hall concert of the National Orchestral Association did, and thus for all its passing felicities, it must be accounted a failure.

title: Look at It This Way: Snow Isn't That Bad
description: While the snow brings with it myriad woes, there are some good things to be said for it, and among these, said Philip Aampi, New Jersey's Secretary of agriculture, is that snow. is the poor man's fertilizer.

title: Guard Strives to Close Gap in Ranks
description: For the third time In a month, New York National Guard units have been activated to help battle snow and ice. In the latest snowstorm, guardsmen from the 42d (Rainbow) Division have been providing 28 ambulances and drivers Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: Stage: Devil's Disciple Presented in Brooklyn
description: SHAW believed that the best way to hide a weakness was to proclaim it. Accordingly, he announced in his preface to The Devil's Disciple that it was a conventional comic romance whose familiar machinery was simply dressed up with a few unconventional ideas.

title: Somalis Contend Russians Operate Tanks in Ogaden
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Feb. 8 Ethnic Somali insurgents fighting in Ethiopia's Ogaden area said today that Sovietmade helicopters plucked white crews from disabled Sovietmade tanks in a battle two days ago. The insurgents said the tank crews were Soviet and the helicopter missions had been flown to prevent their capture and positive identification.

title: Civil Rights Inside the Capitol
description: Congress is a somewhat special place to work, with employers who come and go at the whim of the electorate and employees who must serve the political as well as the substantive needs of their bosses. But surely Congress is not so special that those who work or want to work there must be denied their civil rights. Yet years after passage of Federal equal employment legislation, Congress's 20,000 workers remain exempt and unprotected. They can still be hired or fired because sex, color or any other prejudice of a legislator. There is no grievance procedure. It is not even clear that Congressional employees share with other citizens the right to bring court challenges against discrimination on the job.

title: 2 Icons Stolen in Greece Recovered in London
description: LONDON, Feb. 8, (Reuters) London art dealer, Richard Temple, said today that the recovery of two valuable Greek icons stolen from museums in Athens and Rhodes was like finding a Michelangelo. He said he had been offered the icons for more than $193,000.

title: `Wonder Drug Doctor Faces Pennsylvania Hearings
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 8 Dr. Peter T. De Marco of Pine Hill, N.J., whose license to practice medicine in New Jersey was revoked permanently last month for causing a hepatitis outbreak by using unsterilized needles and syringes in injecting a socalled wonder drug, faces two hearings here next Wednesday.

title: L.I. Surgery Case May Be Dropped
description: The evidence against three doctors and a nurse who allegedly allowed a medical equipment salesman to help them perform surgery may. be insufficient to warrant their prosecution, the Suffolk County District Attorney said last night.

title: Sleepy South African Enclave Stirs as a Storm Gathers
description: WALVIS BAY, South AfricaWhen people reach for an analogy, they compare this tiny enclave on the Atlantic coast of SouthWest Africa to Hong Kong. But on a blowy weekend after- noon, with whitecaps cresting a grayish sea and sand whipping off the surrounding desert, pelicans diving for fish are the most colorful sight to be seen.

description: CHICAGO,. Feb. 8A Federal district judge criticized the Federal Bureau of Investigation today for not heeding court orders to turn over its files on the surveillance of civilians, politicians and civic organizations and held a Justice Department lawyer and an F.B.I. agent in contembt, of court.

title: Making Sense of Arms Sales
description: The Carter Administration seems headed for a needless confrontation with Congress over arms sales to foreign governments. The Administration has set itself limits for sales that it now seems incapable of meeting. Congress is sure to cry foul. But what matters is not so much whether the United States meets selfimposed standards for virtuous restraint as whether its arms sales exacerbate or reduce the prospects of war. That issue deserves careful consideration by the Congress, as well as by the Administration.

title: Home Beat
description: Have you ever seen a bed in a flower shop? Reiiy, the flower and plant purveyor, has moved from East 62d Street near Second Avenue to East 62d Street off Madison, and the decor of the shop has gone a million miles from au nature to midsummer night's dreamy.

description: WASHINGTONCorporate executives who condone criminal acts by their subordinates could spend up to a year in prison if a littlenoticed provision of the revised Federal criminal code passed by the Senate last week becomes law.

description: Alice Browne of Corona del Mar, Calif., holds the record for that distance in 16:24.61, which she sot at Mission Viejo, Calif., Aug. 22, 1977.

title: Radioactive Material Retrieved
description: MASSILLON, Ohio, Feb. 8 (UPI)  A container filled with radioactive material, stolen from a truck earlier this month or lost, was found today in the Massillon area, the Ohio Highway Patrol reported. The cylinder, containing a mixture of americium and beryllium, was reported missing Jan. 31 from a truck operated by Shelwell Services of Hebron, Ohio. Such cylinders are used at gas wells. Experts from the United Stales Nuclear Regulatory Agency and the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency, joined in the search with state and local authorities.

title: Army Starts Survey On G.I.'s and Unions
description: LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP)The United States Army is paying $12,000 to British social scientist to find out whether American soldiers would like to join unions.

title: NEW &
description: Tuesday is Valentine's Daythe one day when you gotta have heart. Chocolate hearts are given traditionally, but here are a few suggestions for a romantic message that will linger on. A white coffee mug with a red heart handle and a red ceramic doubleheart picture frame, with a dressertop stand, were both found at Hubert des Forges (1193 Lexington Avenue, near 81st Street). The frame, which measures six inches through the center of each heart, is $9; the red rimmed coffee mug is $3.50.

title: House Rejects Consumer Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 The House of Representatives shattered for the foreseeable future a longdeferred consumers goal by voting against a bill to establish a Federal agency to represent their interests. The vote was 227 to 189.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: uUMNY UP Therp is a ventriloquist act that has nothing at all to do with vaudeville's coming into the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (4755120), tonight. It is a play called The Ventriloquist's Wife, a threecharacter thriller written and directed by Charles Ludlam (the Theater of the Ridiculous man), who also is one of its stars.

description: ALBANY, Feb. 8 Governor Carey asked the Legislature today to invest panel of state officials and gubernatorial appointees with sweeping authority to define energy needs and guide decisions on the approval and siting of power plants.

title: Where to Get Super Tubers
description: Today's super tubers, with their extravagant flowers, were developed over the past century from the rather small and plain singleflowered Begonia Boliviens, B. pearcei, and related species.

description: Leonard Silk discusses a study by the staff of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, which concludes that the nation is entering an era of slower economic growth. Page D7.

description: Sunshine and slush raised the spirit of New Yorkers and suburbanites yesterday as snowbanks shrank, darkened and melted, and asphaltsometimes potholesappeared where there had been a blanket of snow since Monday.

title: U.S. Rules on Homestead Rebate
description: NEWARK, Feb. 8 (UPI)New Jersey homeowners who itemize their Federal tax returns must treat their homestead rebates as refunded property taxes, the Internal Revenue Service ruled today.

description: Anthony V. Bouza, deputy chief of the New York City Transit Police Department, sent a gift of $50 to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, and in a letter said:

title: Spring Comes Early for Yankees
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 8 While Yankee Stadium in New York rested under a heavy cover of snow, the Yankees stadium in Fort Lauderdale burst with activity today as an advance contingent of 13 players began working out in an unusually early stage 'f the team's spring camp.

title: State Aides Say Atlantic City Plan Would Evict Poor for Casino Sites
description: TRENTON,Feb. 8  State officials charged today that Atlantic City's new .A500,000 master plan ignored many of the resor' community's poor, whose slum dwellings would be torn down to make room for gambling casinos.

title: Harness Racing Resumes in Area
description: Harness raping resumed last night at Yonkers Raceway and the Meadowlands after two days of snowrelated disruption. Aqueduct, shut down Tuesday and yesterday under its regular winter schedule, plans to reopen today with a program of thoroughbred racing.

title: Oakland Seeks Half Of Giants
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8  The mayors of San Francisco and Oakland held fast to contrary positions today while baseball officials from Commissioner Bowie Kuhn down kept hoping they would agree on something that would let th' Oakland A's move to Denver and avoid a probably disastrous 1978 season here for the A's and San Francisco Giants.

title: BOSTON FIGHTS BACK IN 27INCH SNOWFALL
description: BOSTON, Feb. 8 This city struggled today to dig out from under the worst snowstorm in its, history as the police and National Guard troops stood by to prevent a recurrence of'last night's looting incidents.

title: Vance Urges Congres's Not to Cut Aid to Seoul Over Influence Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance told a Congressional committee today that Congress should not cut off military aid to South Korea to force Seoul. to cooperate with the House ethics committee's investigation of influencebuying by the South Koreans here.

title: Corporation Affairs Commonwealth Oil to Get Help of Coastal States Gas
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, whose troubled refinery in Puerto Rico may force that company to seek protection under Chapter XI of the Federal bankruptcy laws, got a lease on life yesterday. CORCO announced that Houston's Coastal States Gas Corporation had agreed to supply it with all of its feedstock for the next six months on a daily basis.

title: Exports by Interbras Soar, Helping Brazil Pay Oil Bills
description: RIO DE JANEIROA big, new international trading company born of the oil crisis is growing fast in Brazil under the sheltering wings of Petrobras, the state oil monopoly that is the nation's largest corporation and the secondlargest in Latin America, after Petroven, which controls the nationalized Venezuelan oil industry.

title: Austin J. Tobin, Executive Director Of Port Authority for 30 Years, Dies
description: Austin J. Tobin, the autocratic Brooklynborn lawyer who built the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey into the most powerful agency of its kind in the world, died of cancer yesterday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 74 years old.

title: Senate Starts Debate on Panama Pacts With the Outcome Still in Doubt
An Amusement Park Is Holding Auditions at Colleges for Performers
description: PRINCETON, Feb. 8 Singers, dancers and jugglers came out of the cold today at Princeton University for the first of a series of auditions for college students run by Six Flags Great Adventure, the amusement park in Jackson.

title: Bossy Hurt in 54 Loss
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 8From whiteout to blackout went the Islanders tonight. Not only did they lose to the Chicago Black Hawks, 54, after extricating themselves from the mountainous snowdrifts of Long Island and spending seven hours traveling, but they also faced the loss of Mike Bossy, who injured his left shoulder and was taken to the hospital for Xrays.

title: Peruvian Bus Plunge Kills 7
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 8 (AP)At lease seven persons were killed when a bus careened down a 100foot embankment in the Andes and into the Mataro River 100 miles east of Lima, officials said today. Authorities say recovery operations are being hafpered because the river is in flood.

title: Letters
description: To THE HOME SECTION:

title: Carter Gives Congress His Plan for Wider Aid to College Students
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Two million college students from families with annual incomes of $16,000 to $25,000 would automatically be entitled to grants of $250 a year, under the Middle Income College Assistance Act, which President Carter proposed to Congress today.

title: ESSEX CHARTER FIGHT SEEMS TO BE OVER
description: NEWARK, Feb. 7 Advocates of charter reform for Essex County said today that they were not satisfied with the new districting plan adopted by the countys election commission but that they would not further challenge it in the courts.

title: Fair Trial and Free Speech
description: Cases Raise Question of Whether Constitution Has Set Up a Conflict Between Amendments

title: Studs Terkel's Working, A Musical, Due April 27
description: Working, a new show adapted by Stephen Schwartz from Studs Terkel's bestselling book, will join the increasing number of musicals expected to open on Broadway in coming months. title: Home Improvement
description: The heavy snowfalls in many parts of the country tills year have given owners of snowthrowing machines plenty of opportunity to use them and have thus prevented many backachesand even possible heart attacks. title: Personal Beauty
description: WHAT next? For over a decade, the cosmetics companies have been in thrall to the gift-with-purchase promotion. If a customer buys a certain dollar amount of the company's products, she gets something else free. (A second type of hype is purchase-withpurchase. A purchase of makeup or fra- grance entitles the woman to buy something else for less than its usual price.)

title: Newell to Head Spode
description: The election of Peter M, Newell as president of Royal Worcester Spode Inc. was announced yesterday. The company is the United States marketing organization for the British company of the same name, which manufactures English china, porcelain and crystal.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
Books of The Times
description: BUT OF COURSE. That's it! The trouble with thrillers like Black Sunday is that the enemy and the terrorists are one and the same. So it goes without saying that terrorism is evil, and the only moral question that the drama poses is whether the good will be destroyed by the bad. Gerald Seymour's accomplished new thriller, Kingfisher, makes us realize this by turning the tables for a change. Instead of enemy terrorists preying on us or our friends, it is a trio of Russian Jews who hijack an enemy airplane. Protesting the oppression of Soviet Jewry, three wouldbe guerrilla fighters named David, Isaac and Rebecca try first to assassinate a Russian policeman, and then, when their attempt fails and they are in danger of being caught by the KGB, they hijack an Aeroflot Ilyushin jetliner in order to escape to Israel via Western Europe.

title: Olympic Update From Lake Placid
description: Like many people stranded by this week's snowstorm, George Marlin couldn't get his car out of his driveway. And he had to be somewhere. As the ski director of the 1932 Winter Olyr.\llics at Lake Placid, the spry septuagenarian was to be named the honorary chairman of the ski events fo1 the 1980 Winter Olympics at a small ceremony in Lake Placid, where he lives. 'But don't worry about me," hC' told a caller, ''I'll ski over." He eventually agreed to be transported in a friend's fourwheel drive, but as they crunched along the snowplowed roads, he kept saying, You didn't have to pick me up, I could have skied over. Snow snarls the cities, but it's a way of life in Lake Placid, the little Adirondack Mountain village where in two years, on Feb. 13, 1980, the Olympic torch will be lighted for the 12 days of the XIII Winter Games.

title: ExGov. Jones of Louisiana, at 80
description: Sam Houston Jones, the oneterm Louisiana Gogrnor who routed the discredied political machine of the late Huey P. Long from State government in th 1940's, died yesterday in his hometown of Lake Charles, La. He was 80 years old.

title: New Yorkers Finding a Haven in Santa. Fe
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Feb. 2 As Darrellyn Hochman tells it, she and her husband Joel, a psychiatrist, decided one night last year that Los Angeles was simply too far to go for a pastrami sandwich. Something had to be done. And then, three months ago, there it was, tucked away in a downstairs corner off Santa Fe's 350yearold plaza: the Hochmans version, and a faith- ful one at that, of a New York delicatessen.

description: Federal officials yesterday canceled the Feb. 28 elections for members of local governing boards of antipoverty projects to give Mayor Koch time to reorganize the troubled, multimilliondollar citywide program.

He said that this could endanger the accreditation of of at least some of the hospitals.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 A record level of cargo moved in 1977 through a key section of the St. Lawrence Seaway, Secretary of Transportation Brock Adams announced today.

title: Hanoi, Some Say, Has Its Own Quagmire in Fight With Cambodia
description: DANuKOK, Thailand, Feb. 8  An American here spoke the other day of Vietnam's involvement in Cambodia as ,quagmire, a word that gained currency in the 1960's when it became evident that the United States would find it difficult to extricate itself from its involvement in Vietnam. Now, in the late 1970's, Vietnam has brought superior military power to bear against a neighbor that had peen raiding its border regions almost since the end of the war in 1975. And Hanoi finds itself in a situation where has not won a decisive victory and has to consider the application of more force, with the risks that this entails, or try new diplomatic tack.

title: Tokyo Airport Protesters Routed
description: NARITA, Japan, Feb. 8 (Reuters)Po icemen today demolished a 65foot tower RIM to block aircraft and prevent the opening of Tokyo's new international airport next month after routing demonstrators at the end of a 40hour battle. Fighting between more than. 800 riot police men and about the same number of protesters ended last night after four leftwing students who had clung to the upper part of the tower for nearly two days in nearfreezing weather climbed down and surrendered.

title: Pitfalls for a SovietBacked Ethiopian Offensive
description: Fighting and winning a fullscale, Modern war in the Horn of Africa is likely to be far more difficult than the Ethiopians and their Soviet and Cuban allies apparently expeCt as they prepare an offensive against Somalia. Analysts in Washington and at headquarters of the Notrh Atlantic Treaty Organization in Brussels emphasize that, while it is easy to see the military options open to the attackers, carrying out the options another, more serious problem because of the logistical problems inherent in diffi- cult terrain, the absence of roads and the approach of the season known as the little rains.

title: 5 More Koch Aides T old ,` No City Cars

description: A letter from Rita Kaufman of the Bronx, published in this newspaper not long ago, deplored the display of dead deer atop automobiles during the hunting season.

title: Jack Warden to Open In Stages March 19
description: Jack Warden has begun rehearsals for Stages, a new tragicomedy by St uart Ostrow. It will have its premiere March 19 at the Belasco Theater. The play, with a cast of 14 under the direction of Richard Foreman, marks Mr. Warden's first Broadway venture since The Man in the Glass Booth in 1969.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Times yesterday incorrectly reported that President Carter had approved disaster designations for Connecticut. Massachusetts and Rhode Island. The President approved declarations of emergency providing Federal help in digging out from Monday's storm, but not the loans and grants that disaster designation would permit.

title: Preempting the President
description: The most surprising thing about President Carter's rather predictable defense of the Panama Canal treaties last week was the refusal of one of the three major television networks to carry his speech live. In a rare decision, CBS turned down the White House request and showed instead a heavily promoted twohour movie starring Joanne Woodward. ABC and NBC gave their valuable 9 P.M. slots to the President, but CBS waited to carry a replay of the 20minute talk until 11:30 P.M. Whether economic considerations were uppermost in the minds of the CBS executives, as suggested by a White House spokesman, we cannot say. In principle, however, the CBS action seems wholesome.

title: Panama Canal Controversy and Its 75 Year History: Some Questions and Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 The Panama Canal treaties, which the Senate began discussing today are the subject of one of the most emotional political debates in years. Each side has challenged the other's understanding of history and diplomacy.

title: Indictment of a Lawyer In Illegal Adoptions Case Is Issued in Manhattan
description: A lawyer who allegedly operated an interstate network for the sale of babies has been charged in a 192count indictment with conspiracy, perjury, unlawfully placing children for adoption and other crimes, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan announced yesterday.

title: RESPONSE IS GOOD IN CORPORATE BONDS
description: As the winter weather continued to disrupt the normal flow of credit market information, investment bankers offered $605 million of new corporate fixed-income securities yesterday and succeeded in selling almost all of them by late afternoon. Sales apparently were aided by the absence of any bonds for sale next week.

title: Notes on People
description: Orval E, Faubus, the former Governor of Arkansas, and his wife, Elizabeth, said they were terribly upset about how Mrs. Faubus was treated in municipal court in Huntsville, Ark., when she was fined $146.50 for three traffic violations. As they left the courthouse, Carol Whittemore, managing editor of the weekly Madison County Record, tried to take pictures of them. In complaint filed by Mrs. Whittemore, she said that the Faubuses had pulled her hair, slapped her several times and smashed her camera, and so now the Faubuses have been charged by the county prosecutor with thirddegree battery and assault. Mrs. Whittemore is a niece of the newspaper's owner, Alta Faubus, the former wife of the former Governor. He works now as bank teller.

title: Bill Rogers Golf Leader By One Shot

title: `Energy Emergency Is Declared in Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 9 (UPI)Gov. James A. Rhodes toda declared an energy emergency in Ohio and Iced the Federal Government to give utilities and industries permission to burn coal without air pollution control equipment.

title: Jazz: Napoleon in Swing Alley
description: WEST 52d Street, which was once known as Swing Alley when jazz clubs lined it cheek by jowl in the 1930's and 40's, has regained some of its onetime spirit at the only room on the street that still offers musicJoe's Pier 52, 149 West 52d Street. Mary Napoleon, a pianist who was in Gene Krupa's hand and who toured for years with Louis Armstrong's All Stars, is leading a quartet there that has the swing drive and the rollicking, goodtime feeling that was characteristic of many of the groups on the street that seasoned their instrumental jazz with tightly rhythmic singing.

title: Grant Denies Mets Are Up for Sale to Namath Group
description: M. Donald Grant, the New York Mets chairman of the board, said yesterday that he knew of no inclination among the baseball franchise's owners to sell the Mets to a group that would include Joe Namath.

title: Books of The Times
description: IT IS no longer primarily the dog and the frog that we must worry about when steering automobiles along narrow leafy lanes. Now looms the jogger with the hectic flush, Phaidippides reborn, with news, that Anxiety, Obesity and Cholesterol have fallen on the plain of Marathon. And he is evangelical: If you are not yet a runner, writes James F. Fixx at the beginning of his The Complete Book of Running, this book . . . will show you how to become healthier and happier than you even imagined you could be. It will do so no matter how out of shape or fat or old or ungraceful you are, and no matter how many times you have tried other exercise regimens and failed.

title: Criticism Ahead for Carter on Shifts in Rights Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9If it had the choice, the Carter Administration would probably not have bothered to release or even prepare the State Department's survey of humanrights violations in the 105 countries that receive American aid. But Congress has not given the Administration a choice and today's report is sure to set off a debate over apparent shifts in President Carter's policy of promoting civil liberties.

title: Dance: Premiere By Maslow Troupe
description: IT WOULD be wrong to type Sophie Maslow's work as exclusively dance with a social Conscience simply because that is the tradition of modern dance with which she is identified. Miss Maslow's repertory has a wider range.

title: Letters
description: Your Jan. 28 editorial Beyond the Panama Treaties asserts that there in the treaties a provision that would oblige the United States to build any new sealevel canal in Panama and oblige Panama to allow only the United States to build one.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb, 9Vietnam, with support from the Soviet bloc and Cuba, denounced the United States today for having ordered the expulsion of its United Nations delegate on charges. of involvement in an espionage case.

description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Friday, Feb 10 (Reuters)Rhodesia announced today that it was drafting young blacks into the whiteled armed forces in the war against guerrillas fighting for black-majority rule.

description: The Herald Square angels are singing to praise of the prospective rejuvenation of the Hotel McAlpin as apartments. The project is one of the major conversions currently at bay pending City Council action on the renewal of the J51 tax exemption and abatement program.

title: Music: Kubelik Leads Brahms First Symphony
description: IN THE fallout of the snowfall was the wreck of a New York Philharmonic program. Or, more accurately, partly a wreck. Rafael Kubelik was to have conducted the Double Concerto for Two String Or- chestras, Piano and Timpani by Bohuslav Martinu last night. But the snow forced a reduced rehearsal schedule, and instead of the Martinu we had Honegger's Symphony No, 2, repeated from last week. Otherwise the program went as scheduled, with Dvorak's, Othello Overture and the Brahms Symphony No, 1.

title: JAPAN'S EXPORTS UP 22.4% TO $7.3 BILLION IN JANUARY
description: TOKYO, Feb. 9 (AP)Japan's exports in January rose 22.4 percent from a year ago to $7.29 billion, down from December's record $8.1 billion, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. But, adjusted for inflation, exports in January rose to a record high of $8.28 billion, up 8.6 percent from December, the ministry said. Exports to the United States were up 11.2 percent from a year earlier to $1.84 billion. Exports to Western Europe rose 5.5, percent to $1.08 billion. Exports to Southeast Asia were up 33.9 percent to $1.51 billion. Exports to the Middle East rose 20.3 percent to $831.8 million.

They also completed the modernization of sculpture, a process begun by the Constructivists, as well as sowing the seeds of what might be called the mystique of heavy industry.

title: SouthernAfrican Rights
description: CAMDEN, N. political power in Southern Africa IF transferred without a fullscale race war, a comprehensive bill of rightsguaranteed for a transitional period by concerned countries, including the United States  should be an integral feature of the negotiated settlement. The principal danger to the preservation of those rights would he gradual, undramatic erosion, one case at a time, by acts too small or ambiguous to command strong response from the stales guaranteeing the new constitutional order. Too. small, that: is, unless the ambiguities were clarified and the isolated victim's pleas for redress were amplified by a supervisory body possessing the requisite integrity, competence and prestige.

title: Canada to Expel 11 Soviet Aides In Spying Case

title: INIGENERBETTMAN, EXCOLUMNIST, DEAD
description: Iphigene Molorry Bettman, a former columnist for The Cincinnati TimesStar and the moderator of a public affairs radio program on WQXR in New York City after World War II, died of heart failure yesterday at Jewish Hospital in Cincinnati. She was 84 years old and lived in Cincinnati and Petaluma, Calif.

title: Broadway
description: ANEW musical called The Party Girl is supposed to go into rehearsal in April, and it will be as up-to-date and almost right straight out of the headlines as can be. It is about sex, politics and blackmail, and about how a, senator establishes his mistress as the madam of a brothel and then tries to use her and it to make him President. Obviously, this is not The Sound of Music, but not to worry because it does not sound like sleaze, either. The senator does not get to be President, and somewhere near the final curtain his mistress sings A New Beginning, wherein she apparently decides to renounce loose living. She also becomes reconciled with her daughter, who shocked after having discovered the truth about her mother's life.

title: Kodak Profits Rose 2% in 4th Quarter But Fell 1% in Year
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest producer of photographic products, reported yesterday a 2 percent gain in fourth quarter net income and a 1 percent dip for all of last year.

description: SPEAKING of his predilection for late artfor the work that certain artists produce in their later years  Thomas Hardy once remarked: I prefer. late Wagner, as I prefer late Turner. the idiosyncracies of .,each master being more- strongly shown in these strains. When a man not contented with the grounds of his success goes on and on, and tries to achieve the impossible, then he gets profoundly interesting to me.'

The 21game streak equals a record Montreal established. in the 197475 and 197677 seasons.

Kearney, a former supervisor in the Federal Bureau of Investigation, were thrown out yesterday by judge who disclosed at the same time that the Government had named the head of the F.B.I. office here as an unindicted conspirator in the case.

title: Film: On the Auto Front:The Assembly Line
description: "BLUE COLLAR," directed by Paul Schrader and written by him and his brother Leonard, is a film about which you are likely to have very mixed feelings. It is a sort of poor man's "On the Waterfront," a movie that simply  often primitively  describes corruption in a Detroit auto workers' local without ever making the corruption a matter of conscience. Corruption is there. It exists. It's part of the system.This emphasis on inevitability, which is one step away from complete passivity, may be the essential difference between a certain kind of pop culture today and that of the mid-50's when Elia Kazan made his furious, idealized film about crooked locals on New York piers. The Kazan film dramatized one man's fight against corruption and made a hero of a fellow brave enough to testify before a crime commission.At the end of "Blue Collar" we see a man more or less cornered into turning state's evidence. His testimony probably won't do any good. The movie even implies that his decision to testify may make him an unwitting tool of the system. His fate isn't especially tragic. It's a pop tune with a big beat.At least, this is the way I reacted to "Blue Collar," which opens today at three theaters. "Blue Collar" is the first film to be directed by Mr. Schrader, who was one of Hollywood's hottest young writers even before the appearance of "The Yakuza," his first screenplay to be filmed. Since then he has been represented by "Taxi Driver," "Obsession" and "Rolling Thunder," all movies containing a lot of highly cinematic violence and a certain amount of intellectual confusion. Is "Blue Collar" an action film or a meditation upon the American Dream? I suspect it wants to be both though it's not very serious at being either.The movie is at its best in describing the quality of the day-to-day life of its three leading charactersZeke (Richard Pryor), Jerry (Harvey Keitel) and Smokey (Yaphet Kotto), friends who work together on the assembly line at the automobile plant. Zeke, who is married, is irrepressibly rude and in debt to the Internal Revenue Service for claiming six children instead of his actual three. Jerry, also married, also is in debt and works two jobs to make ends meet. Smokey is the sophisticated one. An ex-con and a bachelor, he throws parties that he imagines Playboy would admire. All three work nonstop to afford the material comforts they've been told they deserve. Each in his own way is a very angry man.Where "Blue Collar" starts to go awry is in its melodramatic plotting that has the three friends attempting to rob their union headquarters. Instead of a large amount of cash, they find a ledger that records the details of the union's loan-sharking activities. When they attempt to use this information as blackmail, the results are predictably disastrousfor the friends and for the movie that otherwise shows us a kind of existence seldom accurately depicted on the screen.Everything in the characters' private lives looks right, from the pictures on the walls (and stuck into the corners of mirrors), to their color television sets, plastic slipcovers and bowling costumes. You suspect that each item was bought yesterday on time and will be worn out tomorrow before the payments are completed.The performances are excellent. Mr. Keitel's Jerry is all itchy ignorance, baffled by the circumstances in which he finds himself to do the right thing but having no idea of what that is Mr. Kotto's Smokey appears to be as much a matter of his sheer presence as it is of his cool, self-assured performance.The center of the film, however, is Mr. Pryor who, in "Blue Collar," has a role that for the first time makes use of the wit and fury that distinguish his straight comedy routines. It's a sneakily funny performance right up to the film's angry, freeze-frame ending, which, by this time is a mannerism that almost any film could do without.Mr. Schrader's decision to use that freeze-frame calls attention to the phoniness that haunts the film at other moments. The scene in which a fussy I.R.S. man calls on Mr. Pryor is funny, but do I.R.S. men often make house calls at night? If the television programs that Mr. Keitel's family watches are always black programs, how did something like "Rhoda" become so popular? I'd even question whether the Keitel character, given the probable prejudices of a man in his position, would have two blacks as his only friends.The movie, which is so accurate in other ways, manipulates life to create the sort of idealized, color-balanced reality we are force-fed by television.

The decor is a pleasantly restful and subdued blend of modern and Thai motifs, There is a fairly attractive bar and an atmosphere somewhat More formal and sophisticated than at many of the gaudy Thai restaurants now offering this fiery cuisine.

description: DOES Rudolf Hess's continuing solitary confinement in Spandau Prison after 37 years represent cruel and unusual punishment or is it a necessary reminder of the Nazi holocaust? As man, villain. and symbol, Hess Is potentially a meaningful subject for drama.

description: Ruth L. Spain, a psychiatric social worker and psychotherapist who was longtime activist in the civilrights movement in the United Slates, died Wednesday at University Hospital in New York City following surgery. She was 59 years old and lived on Central Park West.

description: LEEDS, England, Feb. 9 (AP)The Manchester United soccer club agreed today to pay a British record transfer fee of $85,000 to Leeds United for Gordon McQueen, a Scottish international center back.

title: Film: Wajda's Study Of War's Aftermath:No Place to Go
description: ANDRZEJ WAJDA'S 1970 Polish film, "Landscape After Battle," is a movie whose sorrow is sealed off by its beautiful images as if behind thick, protective glass. We see the sorrowits expressions and movementsbut it's so special that it seems silent and remote. How can anyone who was not in the Holocaust begin to comprehend it? Even to attempt to understand it seems an impertinence, as if this would be an invasion of an especially privileged privacy."Landscape After Battle" is based on the autobiographical stories of Tadeusz Borowski, the Polish writer who, having survived Auschwitz and Dachau and the postwar displaced-persons camps, committed suicide in 1951 at the age of 29. That knowledge gives particular poignancy to the Wajda film, which is about a young poet named Tadeusz who goes through this landscape trying to convince himself of the validity of the advice he gives a Jewish girl he loves: "To live, one must forget."Mr. Borowski could not forget, which is why his stories, published here by Penguin in a collection called "This Way to the Gas, Ladies and Gentlemen," comprise one of the most measured, calm and harrowing books about the Holocaust you're ever likely to read. Mr. Borowski was an extraordinary writer. Mr. Wajda, who made "Ashes and Diamonds" and "Kanal," can be an extraordinary film maker, but his style is more lyric and contemplative than the writer's, which is to the film's advantage."Landscape After Battle" is Mr. Wajda's recollection of an idealized Borowski, played with a kind of sweet cynicism by Daniel Olbrychski as a handsome young man who wears spectaclesMr. Wajda seem to belong to that school of film makers that still feels that writers must be identified by the glasses they put on, take off and drop. This is the only unworthy note in the movie, which is a series of vignettes that follows Tadeusz from the day his camp is liberated until he decides to strike out from a benignly mismanaged displaced-persons camp to return to Poland.Because Tadeusz is obsessed with a sense of homeland, which has less to do with conventional nationalism than with mythic roots, there is throughout the film the unstated irony contained in our awareness of what eventually happened to Tadeusz.The landscape of the title is postwar Europe, whose mood is caught in the film's opening sequence, when Mr. Wajda shows us how the prisoners of a concentration camp, at first jubilant with their freedom, come to realize at the end of that first day that they have no place to go but back to the camp."Landscape After Battle"? has no dominant story line. Some of its sequences may mystify those of us not familiar with Polish history or with the spheres of influence that were allocated after the war. Yet it's so beautifully composed, so elegiacal, it compels attention and will be likely to stay in the memory for a very long time. I've no idea why it's taken almost eight years for such a special work to reach us.The film opened yesterday at the Film Forum, where it will be shown tonight through Sunday at 7:45, and again, next week, Thursday through Sunday, at the same time.

title: Some Antiquities Challenged
description: The world's leading collections of antiquities from the Near East are sprinkled with fakes, according to a research paper that Is causing a stir in the museum world.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Town Justice Sebastian Lombardi of Lockport, N.Y., was named as the 30th judge to face removal proceeedings in the statewide ticketfixing scandal. He is charged before a special Court of the Judiciary with 154 counts of official misconduct. Most of the charges involve reducing traffic charges for defendants with special influence. He is also accused of failing to disqualify himself from a case where he was related to the defendant and with trying a case against a man who was involved in a civil suit with Mr. Lombardi's brother.

title: Javits Urges Industrial Powers To Work to Avert a Depression
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Senator Jacob K. Javits called on the United States and other leading industrial countries today to cooperate more closely in economic matters or face the prospect of a world depression in the 197980 period.

title: General Motors Strike Ends
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 9 (AP)Workers at the General Motors Corporation Fisher Body plant in Euclid returned to work today, ending a twoweek strike over working conditions, A spokesman for the United Automobile Workers Local 1045 said the approximately 1,300 workers returned to their jobs beginning with the day shift.

title: Hofstra 101, Wagner 90
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., FKEB. &Henr Hollingsworth scored 38 points as Hofstra rallied to gain a 10190 victory over Wagner tonight. The victory left Hofstra with a 616 record while Wagner, which was led by Steve Johnson with 20 Dolints, fell to 612.

title: 2 Journeys to Take Into Bygone France
description: If it is true that the music of 18thcentury France reflects a bourgeois and aristocratic life and that the literature of the same period reflects the avantgarde side, then a small invasion of French culture this weekend will offer a remarkably complete picture of major era in France's history.

title: The Pop Life
description: TWO British Commonwealth women singers in their 30's have been lying low of late, and both are now picking up their careers. The more dramatic case is Dusty Springfield, who was a might- ily popular singer in Britain in the 1960's, and had some hits here, too. Miss Springfield, who is now 36 years old, has made her first record in four years, called It Begins Again, and contemplating a few selected appearances to promote it.

title: A Young Dancer Vaults Into Fame
description: One of the pleasures of dancegoing is the discovery of new talent, Intermission conversations at the New York State Theaterthe left lobby of the First Ring is likely to provide the most rewarding eavesdroppingoften yield intense analyses of new faces in the back row of the corps de ballet. And Sean Lavery, a tall, blond 21-year-old dancer who joined the New York City Ballet just last spring, has suddenly become everybody's favorite find.

title: Deaths
description: NORMANJulius. Husband of the late Gertrude. Beloved brother of Estelle Rentner and Sid Kellner. Private services were held.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The House today approved its version of the Red-PARIS, Feb. 9 (AP)Roman Polanski, the fugitive film director, said through his French lawyer today that he would not return to the United States to face sentencing for having sex with a 13-yearold girl.

title: Deaths
description: FRANCORosella Costanzo. Devoted mother of Carmela Costanzo, Sebastian Costanzo and Margaret Costanzo. Reposing at Sparaclo & DeMarco Funeral Home, 207 Ave A, NYC until Sat. 9AM. Hours 25 and 7.10.

title: A Comparison: Carter Order and Senate Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9President Carter's Executive Order No. 12036 reorganizing the $6 billion-a-year intelligence complex may be largely replaced by a legislative package such as the one proposed today by, the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: The West Bank Imperatives
description: What now in the Middle East? Egypt and Israel are blaming each other for the impasse in their negotiations and asking the American people and Government throw the weight of their opinion against the terms one side or the other. It is a diplomatic timeout for propaganda that, at the moment, is working for President Sadat. But there is no profit in it for anyone.

title: DISTILLATE OILSUPPLIES OFF BY 7.9 MILLION BARRELS
description: Supplies of distillate oil were down sharply to 211.9 million barrels in the week ended Feb. 3, from 219.8 million barrels in the preceding week, according to the latest weekly supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: S. E. C. LENDS EXPERT TO SENATE FOR STUDY OF TEXTRON BELL UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Securities and Exchange Commission has lent the, Senate Banking Committee an expert from its enforcement division for an investigation of overseas payments by a Textron Inc. subsidiary in connection with the process of confirming G. William Miller as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Jihan Sadat: Also Skilled in the Art of Persuasion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  Jihan Sadat, wife of President Anwar elSadat, is so poised and impeccible in her Paris fashions that one's initial impression is of a women about to pour tea, one who will speak politely And only on safe subjects. Yet the attractive, 43-year-old grandmother an eclectic mixture of Eastern and Western feminism, a woman who advocates birth control and has no time for, as she says, trifling talk.

title: Sadat Sees Callaghan and Schmidt at Start of 6Nation European Tour to Win Support
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Feb. 9President Anwar elSadat of Egypt began a series of consultations with six European leaders today and was told by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt that Western Europe's involvement in the Middle East peaceseeking process should exclude any spectacular intervention.

title: Carter Names Minetti
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  President Carter today designated G. Joseph Minetti as vice chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board. Mr. Minetti, who has served On the board for 28 years, reached the mandatory retirement age of 70 last April but has had his tenure extended through May 1.

title: Bridge:
description: It Takes Some Doing to Get To Tournament in Bermuda

title: Carter Approved TV Surveillance Of U.S. Aide Suspected of Spying
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  President Carter approved covert surveillance by televison of an American official suspected of passing secret documents to Vietnamese Communist intelligence agents sometime last year, Administration officials said today.

title: Sanderson Tries To Get in Shape
description: Derek Sanderson, trying to piake a comeback in the National Hockey League after being disabled by liquor and barbiturates, has been working on program of reconditioning in Canada since Tuesday.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK; MANHATTAN; 43d60th Streets; Upper East Side; Upper West Side; Specials; BRONX; BROOKLYN; STATEN ISLAND; QUEENS; QUEENS (Cont'd); LONG ISLAND; Nassau; Suffolk; LONG ISLAND (Cont'd); ROCKLAND; WESTCHESTER; FAIRFIELD
description: Below 42d Street

title: U.S. Decides to Stall Parley With Moscow On the Indian Ocean
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The United States, annoyea over the Soviet Unions military involvement in the Horn of Africa, is abandoning efforts to achieve quick agreement limiting naval forces in the Indian Ocean.

title: Senate,With Ears Open to Vox Populi, Again Debates Canal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Serrate, continuing consideration of the Panama Canal treaties, debated today the classic question of whether elected officials should be swayed by public opinion.

title: Anne Bancroft Back in Golda
description: Anne Bancroft will resume her role in Golda tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Morosco Theater, 45th Street, west of Broadway. Her bout with flu had caused the cancellation of the show last month. The play will run for 10 performances, closing next Sunday. It will go to Los Angeles in the fall.

title: BENNY GOODMAN'S WIFE, ALICE IL, IS DEAD AT 72
description: Alice H. Goodman, wife of Benny Goodman, died Saturday in a hospital in the island of St. Martin in the Netherlands West Indies after a short illness. She was 72 years old and had residences on St. Martin, in Stamford, Conn., and at 200 East 66th Street in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Rights Report on 105 Lands Is Bleak Except for a Few Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The United States Government reported today some improvement in the observance of human rights in such countries as Iran, South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand, but the overall picture described for Congress again was a bleak one, with rights reportedly violated in all but a few non-Western countries.

title: March 15 Memorial Service Scheduled for Gilbert Highet
description: A memorial service will be conducted March 15 at 4 P.M. for Gilbert Highet, classicist and author, at St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia University campus. Dr. Highet, Anthon Professor Emeritus of Greek and Latin at Columbia, died Jan. 20.

title: The Courtship of Fannie Mae
description: Patricia Harris, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, wants to improve the housing of many poor families in the older cities. A laudable objective, but she has adopted one faulty strategy: She wants to assert control over the Federal National Mortgage Association Fannie Maeto make it invest in innercity mortgages. Fannie Mae, owned by its private stockholders but chartered by Congress in 1968 and now the sixth largest corporation in the country, resists the Housing Department's advances. We hope Fannie Mae's independence will prevail.

title: A Great Issue
description: Why is the United States giving away the Panama Canal?
