Well, the most powerful nation on earth is supposed to be giving in to this blackmail by a poor little pipsqueak domain, with a population about onefourth that of the city of Los Angeles, be- cause of tnreatenect riots and disorders which the police force of Los Angeles alone could wipe out in a week it our own Government were not helping and encouraging Torrijos, Castro and Brezhnev to instigate and build up such riotous forays by their Communist agents!

title: Pavarotti Does a Solo at the Met
description: All 3,800 seats in the Metropolitan Opear House were sold out months ago for the recital that Luciano Pavarotti will give on Sunday afternoon at o'clock. Which means that there are thousands of the tenor's admirers frus- trated in their desire to see him in person. There is a remedy.. The recital will be televised in the Live from Lincoln Center series, presented nationally by the Public Broadcasting Service. Locally it will he seen on WNET (Channel 13) and will be broadcast in stereo on WNCNFM.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: Article 2 -- No Title

title: L.I.R.R. STILL ERRATIC IN STORM AFTERMATH
description: Although commuter rail lines in the rest of the New York metropolitan area offered close-to-normal service yesterday, Long Island Rail Road trains ran sporadically and without schedules, and there was still no service at all east of Speonk and Ronkonkoma. Commuters bound for Manhattan reported delays of as much as three hours.

title: Screen: Of Cars, Sex Money and 'The Betsy':Family Affair
description: MEET the Hardeman family, the oversexed czars of Detroit's most Harold Robbinsy auto empire. They're all descended from Loren Hardeman Sr., a rough-and-tumble First Tycoon played by rough-and-tumble Laurence Olivier. This Hardeman, a.k.a "No. 1," is about 90 years old now, but he is often described as "amazing . . . for his age." Loren Hardeman Jr. (Paul Rudd) was a no-good weakling, so they don't talk much about him any more. They talk even less about his beautiful wife, Sally (Katharine Ross), who used to fool around with her father-in-law. On her wedding night, Sally caught No. 1 fooling around with Roxanne, a French maid, and the spectacle gave her ideas. "I've wanted it to be like that ever since  just once," Sally whispered.Loren 3d (Robert Duvall), who saw quite a primal scene in his day, is a mean-tempered fellow who hates being called Loren 3d. He likes playing a savage game of squash, running the family business, and forsaking his glum wife Alicia (Jane Alexander) for his high-toned English mistress, Lady Bobby (Lesley-Anne Down).But Lady Bobby is not exactly what you'd call a one-man woman, and so she inevitably winds up in the arms of Angelo Perino (Tommy Lee Jones), the hot-blooded Italian racing driver and automotive designer who is in No. 1's employ. Just before she flings herself at Angelo, they drink a toast.Lady Bobby: "To fast cars, and the men who race them."Angelo: "To their women, who wait and worry."Last in line is nubile young Betsy (Kathleen Beller), whose poolside love scene with this same Angelo will get a huge hand, and an even huger giggle, if you go to see "The Betsy" with a properly punchy crowd. Betsy has the movie's finest line, which she delivers while lying on a lounge chair: "I knew it would be like this," she coos. "You're a beautiful child," Angelo coos in reply. "No Mr. Perino, I'm a beautiful woman," she corrects him. "It's my 21st birthday, remember?"The Hardeman's have their incest, their infidelity, their homosexuality and all the rest, and they have another problem so awful that no one ever talks about it: The Betsy, which is being designed by Angelo in great-granddaughter's honor, is going to be a cheap car. Trouble is people don't go to see big-budget adaptations of Harold Robbins stories to find out about cutting costs and getting better mileage; they want to know about luxury and limousines and what Lady Bobby does in her spare time. How can a movie about the invention of something like a Pinto have much of a gloss?"The Betsy" careens recklessly from the 1930's to the 70's and back again, from Hardeman generation to Hardeman generation, in a vain effort to generate the illusion of a storyline. Laurence Olivier doesn't change much over 40 years, and he never seems to have the unscrupulousness of a real magnate, but that hardly matters: What he does have are a roguish Scots accent, a lot of lines like "I'll be horn-swoggled," and a twinkle in his eye, as befits the material.There are some good performances here (such as Edward Hermann's, as a corporate yes-man, Mr. Duvall's and Miss Alexander's), and some terrible ones (Miss Ross is deadly serious, and just awful). But only Olivier manages to play his role and wink at it simultaneously, and his is surely the most sensible approach.For the most part, the director, Daniel Petrie, has a classier cast than he knows what to do with. He also has at his disposal an unwieldy script and the worst set of costumes to be seen in a movie in years. (All the men wear ill-fitting suits, even the zillionaires, and Betsy's yellow ballgown for her birthday party is a lollapalooza. Mr. Petrie, who also directed "Lifeguard" and the television movie "Sybil," regularly dissolves his love scenes into shots of city skylines, and he treats the Hardemans with a reverence they in no way warrant.Mr. Petrie was in no danger of making a good movie out of "The Betsy," but he might easily have made a funnier or more enjoyable smarmy one. Without much of a plot, "The Betsy" often sags, and a movie this frivolous has no business being dull.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Times reported incorrectly yesterday that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance had testified that he hoped South Korea would waive its rights under an international convention to permit Kim Dong Jo, a former South Korean Ambassador in Washington, to testify before the House ethics committee. Mr. Vance told a House subcommittee that the only way that testimony could be obtained from Mr. Kim would be if the South Korean Government were to voluntarily waive the provisions of the international convention. Mr. Vance did not express the hope that. the South Korean Government would do this.

title: Fermilab Director Resigns in Protest Over Lack of Funds
description: Dr. Robert It Wilson, who directed construction of the world's most powerful atom smasher,, a fourmile ring west of Chicago, and since then headed its operations, has carried out his threat to resign on the ground that his project to double the device's energy is grossly underfinanced.

title: Houston: A Promised Land For the Skilled Middle Class
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 8For John and Heidi Lewis, it was the weather. Last winter, when the temperature in Illinois plunged below zero for days at a time and snowdrifts kept the Lewises from getting to work, was the clincher.

title: Some Essential Facts About New York's 'inances
description: New York City's financial condition is frequently shrouded in the complexities of its budget and accounting practices.

title: Jailhouse Lawyer Makes Good
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 9Julius L. Echeles, who said to have few peers among Chicago's criminal lawyers, leaned forward on the desk in his comfortable but unpretentious 35thfloor office.

title: Corporation Affairs Goodyear Purchases CorfoInsa, Chile's Largest Producer of Tires
description: AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 9 (UPI)The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said its new Chilean subsidiary was acquiring CorfoInsa, Chile's biggest tire maker, for $34 million. Goodyear de Chile will operate the facility, which makes tires, vinyl sheeting, automotive batteries and tire cord. CorfoInsa, on the outskirts of Santiago, employs

title: Governor Grasso to Propose Sales Tax Cut
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 9With a projected budget surplus this year of as much as $82 million, Gov. Ella T. Grasso will propose to the General Assembly tomorrow that the state's sales tax be trimmed from 7 to 6.5 percent.

title: BYRNE WIRES CARTER FOR STORMLOSS AID
description: TRENTON, Feb. 9Governor Byrne asked President Carter today for disaster aid to repair storm damage to the state's coastal counties.

title: Lachman to Leave Bloomingdale's
description: In the first top management changes in almost a decade at Bloomingdale's, one of the area's largest department store chains, Lawrence Lachman, chairman and chief executive officer, is to take early retirement May 1 and be succeeded by Marvin S. Traub, who has been president since 1969.

title: Books: Story of a Body Builder
description: ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER. whose massively muscled frame becatne famous in the movie Pumping Iron,, about bodybuilders, has achieved a pre-eminence that should enable him to kick sand in bullies faces on Muscle Beach. He's been six dines Mr. Olympia, twice Mr. Universe and once Mr. World. As he tells us in this autobiography cum exercise bodk, written with Douglas Kent Hall, he's taken on all corners in the body  building world and emerged victorious. When he looks in his mirrorwhich bodybuilders do quite frequently, not out of narcisism, he says, but to check their progresshis mirror tells him, Arnold, you're the beefiest beefcake of them all.

title: Book Brings the Rule of Reason To CorporationPublic Clashes
description: The participants in the National Coal Policy Project say they achieved the remarkable degree of unanimity evident in their report by adopting a set of behavior guidelines collectively known as the Rule of Reason. The stimulus for their groundbreaking approach was a littleknown book bearing just that title and written by a professor of law at New York University named Milton R. Wessel.

title: Site of 1778 Military School to Be Excavated
description: PLUCKEMINExcavation on the site of a relatively littleknown Revolutionary War encampment will begin this spring, based on the thesis by a Staten Island scholar that this central Jersey town was the home of the nation's first military school.

title: Texas Ice Storm Keeps Federal Troops From Flying to Help Out in Connecticut
description: NORWICH, Conn., Feb. 9Although an ice storm in Texas prevented the arrival of more than 600 Federal troops with heavy equipment to help Connecticut dig out from the worst snowstorm in nearly a century, the state seemed today to be makine a auick recovery on its own.

title: Publishing: Coda From James Jones
description: JAMES JONES did not live to see Whistle published, but his editors and friends who have read the novel believe it is his masterpiece. Students of World War II literatureand the book is dedicated to every man who served in that war whether he survived or notare expected to recognize it as a major work that will enhance Jones's reputation as a writer about men at war and under stress in their own country.

title: Longtime Pilot's Airline Offers Service With a Splash
description: ST. CROIX, V.I.Like the waterfowl it is named for, the Grumman A21 Goose is an ungainly bird on land, noisy and thickchested.

title: New Face: Alan Rosenberg
description: Alan Rosenberg's first professional acting job was a small role in a production of Shakespeare's Twelfth Night in Syracuse, One of his heartfelt ambitions is someday to act in Awake and Sing!, Clifford Odets's hymn to hope in the Depressionridden America of the 1930's. But at the moment, Alan Rosenberg is making a name for himself with his memorably realistic portrait of a homosexual drug addict and murder suspect in Thomas Babe's new play, A Prayer for My Daughter, which is at the Public Theater. In his review for The New York Times, Mel Gussow called Mr. Babe's play an original and Mr. Rosenberg a definite discovery.

title: Future of N.A.A.C.P. Is a Cause Of Concern Amon Black Leaders
description: Murmurs of deep concern about the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People are rippling through the leadership of America's black community. Voices are muted now few are willing to speak out openly- but when the leaders come together, as many of them did last Sunday for a preview of the movie on the life of the Rev. Dr. Marlin Luther King Jr., they wring their hands. in quiet anguish.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1978 Canada ordered 11 Soviet diplomats and officials expelled and barred two others from returning. The Government accused them all of plotting to penetrate the security apparatus of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, Canada's equivalent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. It said the Soviet representatives offered a member of the police agency unlimited funds for information on Canadian intelligence methods. [Page Al, Column 5.]

title: Impasse in Senate on Gas Prices Causes 4.85 Fall in Dow to 777.81
description: An impasse in the Senate that developed late Wednesday over natural gas pricing touched off selling in the stock market yesterday to send prices lower after a twoday advance.

title: Agreement Saves Program on TenantRun Buildings
description: A New York City program to rescue slum buildings abandoned by landlords was rescued itself last night after 200 slumarea residents had picketed City Hall earlier in the day to protest what they saw as threats to the program.

title: Deaths
description: land, On February 6, 1978. mer Summit, NJ resident and prominent New York banker. Survived by wife Bette (nee Hoffer), also survived by daughters Mrs Photios Paulson of Franklin Lakes, NJ and Mrs Samuel Johnson of Paoli, Pa , sons J. Meakin , Stuart G. and W. Jarvis Hoffer, 8 grandchildren and a brother Raymond V. Ringler. Memorial service on Friday at United Church of Marco Island, Marco Island, Fla. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the Marco Island Art League Building Fund. RUSSELLMariette. On Feb. 6, 1978, of N.Y.C. and Princeton, N.J. Wife of

title: Excerpts From State Department Reports on the Status of Human Rights Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Following are excerpts from some of the reports on the condition of human rights in 105 nations prepared by the State Department and made public today by the House International Relations Committee and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: Sabres Beat Rangers, 20; Rick Martin Is Injured
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 9Littering the New York goal with 37 shots while Don Edwards, their rookie goalie, kept the Sabres net clean, Buffalo defeated the New York Rangers, 2.0. tonight and extended its winning streak to five gathes and its undefeated streak to eight. Edwards stopped 25 shots for his third shutout of the season.

title: Management
description: Middle managers who have had periodic cost-of-living pay increases but no promotions have suffered more from inflation than the average factory worker or the average top executive, according to David Kraus, a principal of McKinsey & Company, the big man- agementconsulting firm. Mr. Kraus made that point in a recent speech at a meeting of the Conference Board, the research organization.

title: Deaths
description: KETZMichael, F. of Port Washing ton, L.I. on Feb. 8, 1978. Beloved husband of Barbara, loving father of Priscilla Shine of Colorodo Springs and Gerard E. of New York City. Dear brother of Anna Keblish, John and Wesley. Services private. Memorial service to be arranged at latter date. In lieu of flowers donelions to Dartmouth College Hanover, N.H. or Saint Stephens Episcopal Church, Pt. Washington would be greatly appreciated.

title: Canada to Expel 11 Soviet Aides In Spying Case
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 9The Canadian Government today ordered the expulsion of 11 Soviet diplomats and officials and barred two others from returning, accusing them all of plotting to penetrate the security apparatus of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

title: So Strong He Is Overwhelming
description: Unswerving Irving Rudd is in Las Vegas making investments of a sort not usually favored by visitors to that desert oasis. While high rollers from Texas and housewives from Glendale lay money on the bouncing dice or whirring wheel or stuff it into the slots, Irving is investing his time and his lively imagination in the heroic task of building the Muham- mad AliLeon. Spinks promotion into a fight for the heavyweight championship of the world. This is not the sort assignment that a press agent polishes off with one hand tied behind his back, and Irving, sparing no effort, recently turned for assistance to the Studio of Psychic Arts on Paradise Road near the airport.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE VOTES NOT TO RENEW AID TO NEW YORK CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Senate Banking Committee unanimously concluded today that New York City should be able to meet its financing needs and avoid bankruptcy after June 30 without further Federal financial aid, upsetting the city's hopes for speedy Congressional action on its request for help.

title: Syrian and Lebanese Aides Meet As Fighting Continues for 3d Day
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 9Fighting between Syrian peacekeeping troops and Lebanese Christian forces flared today for the third day, prompting urgent meetings between Syrian and Lebanese leaders to find a way to halt the spread of hostilities.

title: New Face: Cristina Raines Adorns Duelist
description: Acting in the moviesit's a dream come true.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE VOTES NOT TO RENEW AID TO NEW YORK CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Senate Banking Committee unanimously concluded today that New York City should be able to meet its financing needs and avoid bankruptcy after June 30 without

title: At the Movies
description: YOU might say, said Joris lvens, that it's adgressed to people who think all Chinese look alike. Mr. Ivens, an extraordinary youthful 80-year-old, was talking about riffs 12hour film exploration of the lives of ordinary people in Communist China, How Yukong Moved the Mountains.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: TV WEEKEND
description: IF length be all, which the networks seem to be suggesting these days, the weekend's biggest production is undoubetdly King (reviewed yesterday). Beginning Sunday at 9 P.M., the sixhour portrait of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., will be spread over three con- secutive evenings on NBC. On ABC, another fearless proponent of eye fatigue, a new series called How The West Was Won is being launched Sunday at 8 with a special threehour premiere. Immediately preceding King on NBC is The Great Wallendas, ,which only runs for two hours but manages in a more modest way to be at least as impressive as its marathon brothers.

title: A.T.&.T., a Fussy Buyer, Bars Linty Towels
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company doesn't buy just any old paper towel. It has a lot of hands to wipe. It buys about 500 million paper towels a year, and when you buy that much of something, you tend to get fussy. A.T.&T. is fussy.

title: Republicans Call on Ethics Panel For Inquiry on Flood and Eilberg
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The House Republican leadership formally asked the ethics committee today to investigate Representatives Daniel J. Flood and Joshua Eilberg, saying that the allegations raised in the news media raise some serious questions which affect every member of Coneress.

title: Snowbound New England Digs OutWith Help From Army
description: BOSTON, Feb. 9The snowwhite plains that cover southern New England sparkled cheerily in the winter sun today, but even from a National Guard helicopter flying high above the icy beauty it was easy to imagine the weeping that must have gone on below.

title: KIDNAPPED FRENCH JUDGE IS FOUND TIED TO A TREE
description: LYONS, France, Feb. 9 (Reuters) A magistrate kidnapped by masked men on Monday was found tied to a tree near here early today.

title: DOCTORS HOLD TALKS ON NEW HEART DRUG
description: Informal groups of doctors were called together at several medical centers here Yesterday to determine how to treat patients who might benefit from a drug, Anturane, that an international study has found could more than halve the inci- dunce of sudden deaths from heart atticks among people who have previously had at least one heart attack.

title: Opposing Sides Agree on Ways To Shift to Coal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  After 13 months of debate and study, a group of leading environmentalists and industrialists announced today that, to their surprise, they had agreed on more than 200 steps that could help the nation shift from oil to coal as a prime source of energy in ways that are both environmentally tolerable and economically sound.

title: Taxi Service for Minority Areas Assailed at Hearing as Inadequate
description: Willie Clowers had taken his young son to a downtown hospital and the visit over, the two were standing outside at night looking for a taxicab to take them home to Harlem. Up the street was another father, a white. man, with his small son, also waiting for a taxi.

title: MEDIAN INCOME CLIMBED BY 7.5% TO $12,686 IN 1976
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9, (UPI)Median income of American households increased 7.5 percent to $12,686 in 1976 for its first gain after two years of inflationand recessioninduced declines, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Deaf Skater Loses Lead and. Drops to 2d
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 9 (AP)Performing to music he has never been able to hear, David Michalowski inspired smiles and cheers after his 2minute program at the United States figure skating championships tonight. He enters. tomorrow night's free-skating segment of the junior men's event in second place.

title: Webster Is Confirmed to 10Year. Term as F.B.I. Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)Judge William H. Webster won Senate confirmation today to a 10year term as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He will succeed Clarence M, Kelley, who is retiring.

title: FED TO REVISE BANK RULES ON OPERATIONS OVERSEAS
description: The Federal Reserve plans to revise the way it examines the foreign operations of the banks it regulates, Paul A. Volcker, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today
Art. Effigies of Humanity
description: THERE is a place in every great city for the hallucinatory likeness: the wax effigy that looks more real than real. Madame Tussaud's in London and the Musee Grevin in Paris have had their public ever since the days of the French Revolution, when freshly severed heads were available in quantity and the waxman worked overtime. Some effigies are more like than others, but when they are really goodas is the case with the wax effigy of Peter the Great in the Hermitage in Leningradthey may well have more to tell us about the great figures of the past than almost any painting or sculpture.

title: Holtzman Shuns Lure of the South
description: An eightfoot snowdrift dominates the backyard of the Ken Holtzman residence in Lincolnshire, Ill., but it doesn't move Holtzman to flee to Florida any sooner than he has to.

title: Niagara Tops L. I.U. by 8079 In Overtime
description: Garry Jordan, a freshman forward, scored 22 points last night to lead Niagara University to an 8079 triumph in overtime against Long Island University at the loser's court in Brooklyn.

title: Some Antiquities Challenged
description: The world's leading collections of antiquities from the Near East are sprinkled with fakes, according to a research paper that Is causing a stir in the museum world.

title: 52 Local Leaders Reject Mine Pact
description: By The Associated Press

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BOSTON, Feb. 9 (UPI)Tomorrow night's National Basketball Association game between the Boston Celtics and the New Orleans Jazz has been postponed because of an extension of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's emergency, driving ban in eastern Massachusetts, team officials said today. The, ban has been in effect since Monday's recordsetting blizzard struck New England.

title: Deaths
description: SPAINRuth. The Medical Staff of The Brookdale Hospital Medical Center extends Its profound sympathy to our colleague, David M. Swain, M.D. on the passing of his beloved wife. We offer our sincere condolences to the bereaved family in their hour of sorrow.

title: jailhouse Lawyer Makes Good
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 9Julius L. Echeles, who said to have few peers among Chicago's criminal lawyers, leaned forward on the desk in his comfortable but unpretentious 35thfloor office.

title: Israeli Tours South Africa As ArmsTrade Furor Grows
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 9Israel's Finance Minister, Simcha Ehrlich is on an official tour of South Africa, the first by an Israeli Cabinet minister, Government officials here described the visit as an attempt to overcome a trade situation in which Israel is importing more from the South Africans than it is selling to them.

title: Defeat for Consumer Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  The 38vote defeat of the consumer agency bill in the House of Representatives last night reflected not only differences in lobbyingbusiness's was effective; the Carter Administration's antisepticbut also, in the View of influential members of the House, some real changes in the national and Congressional mood since the high point of legislative consumerism in the early and mid70's.

title: New Use for Ciba-Geigy Dug Draws Investor Interest
description: The excitement over Anturane, a drug developed for gout but recently found to .have value in the prevention of heart attacks in people who have already had at least one attack, has thrust the CibaGeigy Corporation, the world's largest pharmaceutical producer, into the limelight again.

title: Demonstrations at the Dinosaur Factory
description: SURROUNDED by dinosaur skeletons, with 20foottall Tyrannosaurus rex presiding, a kind of mad tea party scene will take place today at the Museum of Natural History, where crew is working to create the world's biggest dinosaur kit. The project itself, offering behind-the-scenes information on techniques, has been turned into an exhibit, The Making of a Dinosaur.

title: Sports Program In State Sought By Task Force
description: ALBANY, Feb. 9The new task force for sports and physical fitness, appointed by. State Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut, agreed today to introduce legislation that would appropriate funds to develop a statewide policy covering all facets of athletics and physical fitness.

title: Market Place
description: Stocks that offer high yields and loW prices are very popular with investors in today's market. However, investors will find that these attributes can lead to stagnation if the company's ability to squeeze profits from its assets is impaired.

title: Miss Morerod Triumphs
description: MEGEVE, France, Feb. 9 (UPI)Lase Marie Morerod of Switzerland won both legs of a women's giant slalom today but gained only 10 points on Hann Wenzel of Liechtenstein, the leader in the World Cup chase.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERTodd G., of Port Richey, Fla. formerly of Berkeley Heights, NJ on February 9, 1978. Husband of Eleanore Velin Alexander, father of Todd G. Alexander, Jr. and the late Sandra Jean Alexander. Brother of James I. Alexander. Also survived by one grandson. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the service at the Brough Funeral Home, 535 Springfield Avenue, Summit, NJ, Monday at 10AM. Visitation Saturday 79PM, Sunday 2.4 and 79PM. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer society-

title: For Children
description: AN EARLY MUSIC MATINEE, of baroque end renais sance music, the first In a series of Family Concert Programs sponsored by the Hebrew Arts School for Music and Dance, will be Presented at 3 P.M. on Sunday by the Quadro Barocco at the school, 15 West 65th Street, near Lincoln Center. The second contort, A Vist with the Woodwind Quintet, will be given at the school at 3 P.M. on March 5, A series ticket is $1.50 for children and the elderly, and 55 for adults; single admission is SI for chiidten and the elderly, aro $3 for adults. Information: 787-0650.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Times reported incorrectly yesterday that Secretary. of State Cyrus R. Vance had testified that he hoped South Korea would waive its rights under an international convention to permit Kim Dong Jo, a former South Korean Ambassador in Washington, to testify before the House ethics committee. Mr. Vance told a House subcommittee that the only way that testimony could he obtained from Mr. Kim would be if the South Korean Government were to voluntarily waive the provisions of the international convention. Mr. Vance did not express the hope that the South Korean Government would do this.

title: Tristate Planners Back Proposal On LowerIncome Suburb Housing
description: The TriState Regional Planning Cornmission, which reviews applications from metropolitanarea governments for Federal funds for housing, transportation and other regionwide concerns, approved controversial plan yesterday that calls for additional lowincome and moderateincome housing in New York City's suburbs.

title: Herbert Kappler Dies
description: SOLTAU, West Germany, Feb. 9 (Reuters)Herbert Kappler; a_convicted Nazi war criminal, died of stomach cancer here today, six months after- a daring escape from a Rome military hospital. iie was 70 years old.

title: Auctions
description: NOT since the recordbreaking antiquities auction in 1972 of the Cranbrook (Mich.) Acade my of Art collection, have two such extraordinary ancient treasures been offered at public sale here as in next Friday's offering at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street. There is, for intance, an arresting study of the; god Osiris, a sparely carved Egyptian wood carving dating from 1305 to 1080 B.C. that stands 42 inches high, The obsidian eyes are of buining intensity, the cloakNVrapped body. stands imperially erect and its arms hold a crook, and a .flail. This New Kingdom sculpture, a work of the 19th or 20th dynasty, is estimated to fetch $50,000'to $80,000.

title: STP,inF.T.C.Pact, Will Reduce Claims And Pay a Penalty
description: The STP Corporation agreed yesterday to stop making some advertising claims for its motor oil additives, to pay a civil penalty of $500,000 and to pay an additional $200,000 to publicize the settlement under a consent judgment obtained by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Suffolk Medical Unit May Look Into Salesman Case
description: The Suffolk County Medical Society will conduct its own investigation into allegations that an orthopedic salesman was allowed to perform an implant operation at Smithtown General Hospital if the Suffolk County Prosecutor decides to drop criminal charges against the hospital and four of its staff members, the Medical Society's president said yesterday.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Hamlet, Russian style, will provide a novel look tonight at crosscultural perspectives when Fairleigh Dickinson University in Florham ParkMadison, N.J., initiates a free, fourpart lecture and film series, Shakespeare Among the Nations: Exploring National Views of Shakespeare in Film. On hand for the first lecture is Jan Kott, the Polish Shakespearean author and scholar, and following his talk the 1964 Russian version of Hamlet directed by Gregory Kozintsev will he screened. After coffee, there will be an informal discussion with audience participation encouraged. It all begins at 7:30 in Room 11 of the science building at the FlorhamMadison campus. Take the ErieLackawanna Railway from Hoboken. to the Madison or Convent stations, By car, take the Lincoln Tunnel and continue west to Route 3. Take Route 46 to Route 80 and exit at Route 287 South to Madison Avenue; from there it's two miles east to the campus entrance. Information: (201) 3774700.

title: Art People
description: THEIR pants bag, their bellies bulge, their dresses sag, their curlers show. They have flab, moles, wrinkles, varicose veins, thinning hair and drooping shoulders. They are Duane Hanson's lifesize figures of American types, of such hypersimilitude they make real. people seem prettied up: shoppers, sunbathers, busi- nessmen, construction workers, repairmen, porch sitters and players of solitaire. And now a crowd of them29 in allhas come to haunt the fourthfloor galleries of the Whitney Museum (through April 16).

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, Feb. 9,1978

title: Previous Contributors to Neediest Come Through for the 66th Appeal
description: Previous contributors to the annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest cages Fund who live in new Jersey are beihg heard from once again during the current campaign.

title: While Winter Howls, a Fur Collection
description: Virtually the only fashion show that didn't seem incongruous this blizzardy week was Ben Kahn's. Both the audience and the models were wearing furs, while elsewhere on Seventh Avenue muffled spectators were supposed to suspend disbelief and see themselves languishing in summer cottons.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: 10 Major New York Banks (Selected balance sheet items in millions of dollars: Wednesday figures)

title: Pop: Andrea Marcovicci
description: SEVERAL of the singers who have appeared at Reno Sweeney have been able to draw on acting experience to give their singing a fuller dimension that it might otherwise have. Geraldine Fitz- gerald end Martha Schlamme come immediately to mind. But Andrea Marcovicc, who appeared in The Front with Woody Allen and has just f:nished Kings and Desperate Men, has not yet been able to open up her singing performances with her acting background.

title: OPPOSING FACTIONS AGREE ON A SHIFT FROM OIL TO COAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  After 13 months of debate and study, a group of leading environmentalists and industrialists announced today that, to their surprise, they had agreed on more than 200 steps that could help the nation shift from oil to coal as a prime source of energy in ways that are both environmentally tolerable and economically sound.

title: Koch Seeks to Strip School Board of Marty Functions
description: Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo said yesterday that the Koch administration would attempt to take away many of the functions of the New York City Board of Education and transfer these responsibilities to other agencies.

title: U.S. Rights Report on 105 Lands Is Bleak Except for a Few Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The United States Government reported today some improvement in the observance of human rights in such countries as Iran, South Korea, Indonesia. and Thailand, but the overall picture described for Congress again was a bleak one, With rights reportedly violated in all but a few non-Western countries.

title: Rouse Committee Assails Air Force And Pentagon on Computer Project
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 9A Congressional panel has accused the Air Force of gross mismanagement and insipid leadership for not complying with CongresSional order to terminate a computer system.

title: Where the Divorced and Widowed Learn to Cope Again
description: BALT1MORE---With its sunny yellow rooms, its bright posters, and its air of happy disorder, the ,town house on Maryland Avenue is very like a small private girls school. In a way, that is what it ts, although the girls are unmistakably women. and the lesions learned are not from texts or academics, but from one another. This is the Center for Displaced Homemakers, the house that death and divorce have built, and the women who take chance and twist its ornate brass doorknob enter a place of learning where the end of the course of study is a new life.

title: Country Music Invades the City
description: IF your taste in music takes in fast banjo picking, high mountain harmony and footstomping hoedown fiddling, this is your weekend. A great bluegrass group, the Country Gentlemen, is performing in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, along with the seldomseen guitar wizard Northan Blake, who is making his first New York appearance in almost 10 years. Oldtime country music and bluegrass can be heard in two new club settings in New York City in addition to regular locations such as the Lone Star Cafe and O'Lunney's.

title: INTELLIGENCE AGENCY WOULD HAVE A LAW,
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Senate Intelligence Committee today proposed the first staltutory framework for what is believed to be the largest single United States intelligence organization, the publicityshy National Security Agency.

title: New York Countdown: the Governor's Role
description: When Federal officials say, that to qualify for extraordinary Federal aid, New York must do more to help itself, they mean mostly New York State. They want discipline from the city, too, of course; but in proper Federal fashion, President Carter and Congress expect Governor Carey to assume primary responsibility for the city's condition and to put the state's cash and credit on the line. No help necessary financing will be seriously considered in Washington until Mr. Carey offers assurances that the city's fiscal plan is solid and that the state itself is pressed to the prudent limit. So far he has offered neither.

title: Rutgers 74, UMass 62
description: PISCATAWAY, N. J., Feb. 9 (AP)James Bailey and Hollis Copeland scored 22 points each and led Rutgers to a 74.62 victory over the University of Massachusetts in an Eastern Athletic Association basketball game tonight.

title: Control Board Approves Increases Won by New York City's Teachers
description: The Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday approved the restoration of automatic raises for New York City teachers based on length of service.

title: Answers to Weekly Quiz
description: Questions on page 19.

title: Why a Jetliner's 3 Engines Failed Remains Mystery 2 Weeks Later
description: Investigators have been putting in long hours searching for an explanation for the astonishing loss of power by all three engines of a National Airlines jet two weeks ago.

title: FinishedGoods Index Up . In New Inflation Warning
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)New warnings of worsening inflation were signaled today by a Government index that measures prices received by wholesalers.

title: President, in Speech Slips Out of Office
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) President Carter, in a slip of the tongue, referred to himself today as a former President.

title: Two Jazz Performers Mix Well
description: Two performers who are already established individually in the Jazz field Jimmy Rowles, the pianist, and Carol Sloane, the singerare working together this weekend and next at Story Towne, the subterranean room at 41 East 58th Street that was known as Sforyville until a few weeks ago, in a way that suggests that a very appealing jazz duo may be in the process of formation.

title: Vaccine Production Started
description: DETROIT, Feb. 10 (UPI)Parke, Davis & Co. said today that it has started production of a vaccine against the Russian flu and that it would he ready for distribution in about three months, but not before clinical studies of its effects.

title: Sports Today
description: World Series, international race of champions, third in a series, at Riverside (Calif.) International Raceway. (TelevisionChannel 7, 2:30 P.M.)

title: Cuba Announces an Increase In Penalties for Many Crimes
description: HAVANA, Feb. 10 (Reuters)  The Cuban Government has announced harsher penalties for many crimes, making robbery with violence a capital offense and gambling punishable by eight years in fail.

title: Begin's Fund-Raising Trip Ends
description: JERUSALEM, Feb, 10 (Reuters)Prime Minister Begin returned home today from fundraising meetings in Switzerland and said he had reason to expect that peace negotiations between Israel and Egypt would resume. Arriving just an hour-before the start of the Jewish Sabbath, Mr. Begin told reporters: I have to hurry. He made a brief statement before getting into his car for the drive to Jerusalem.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Sherwin Williams Company said yesterday that it expected a loss of about $1.60 a share for 1977, preventing a declaration of cash dividends on wits common shores. Net income from continuing operations of the large diversified paint, coatings and chemicals concern will be about $1 a share while losses and other charges connected with discontinued operations will be about $2.60 a share, it said. Previously, the company had estimated net income would about break even.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Commuter Plane crashes on Coast; 17 Reported Dead
description: RICHLAND, Wash., Feb. 10 (AP)A commuter airplane crashed nosefirst into the ground and exploded in flames shortly after takeoff today. All 17 persons aboard were killed, the authorities said.

title: Deaths
description: STEINJ. Zachary. The Board of DIrectors of Child Study Association of America/WelMel notes with deen sorrow the passing of J. Zachary Stein, founder, former president and friend of WelMet. The Board wishes to express their condolences to the family.

title: A WITNESS DISAPPEARS IN VILLAGE KILLING CASE
description: A- witness scheduled to testify against nihe defendants charged with killing student during an armed rampage through Washington Square Park in 1976 disappeared yesterday, and at least three of the prosecution witnesses were held in Custody to assure their appearance.

title: Boy Sopranos: Having Too Much Fun to Grow Up
description: Whenever Adam Guettel and Robert Sapolsky, a couple of 13-year-olds, leave the Collogiate School together, one or another of their schoolmates is almost cettain to call out: There go the two opera stars.

title: Pretoria's New Opera Plans to Ban Blacks
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 10 (UPI)The administrator of Transvaal proyince said today that Pretoria's planned opera complex would he for whites only.

title: Carter's Plans for Reorganization Giving Way to More Modest Goals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10President Carter's effort to reorganize the Federal Government has been widely regarded as methodical, well planned and stubbornly pursued. But Congressional sources agree that, like some other Presidential projects, it will probably bear fruit more slowly than Mr. Carter wished and be more modest in scope than he once hoped.

title: Israel Moves to Reverse Ban on Controversial Film About Banishing Arabs
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 10The way was opened today to reverse an order canceling the showing of a controversial film depicting the banishment of Arabs by Israeli soldiers during the Middle East war of 1948.

title: Rockport, Mass., Plans to Rebuild Coast Landmark Razed by Storm
description: ROCKPORT, Mass., Feb. 10The sea and the storm destroyed one of New England's most famous landmarks earlier this week, but today town officials here were already making plans to rebuild the 150yearold lobster shack known as Motif #1.

title: James Cunningham Is Appearing With His Acme Dance Company
description: It has elements of dance and elements of theater. But it is not dance theater or theater dance. It is just James Cunningham's Acme Dance Company, which opened Thursday night at the American Theater Laboratory for an engagement through tomorrow.

title: Male Dance Troupe Workmanlike
description: Maledominated dance groups appeared in New York twice this week. San Francisco's Mangrove petformed in New York Monday, . while Thursday night, at the Judson Memorial Church, there was a Concert by the Rudy Perez/Men's Coalition; le company of nine men augmented for this occasion by guest dancers (including two women, cast ix Ieviv,als of older pieces by Mr. Perez).

title: Atlanta's Upward Surge Stalls As Omni Building Complex Falters
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 10For the second time in a year, one of Atlanta's bold new downtown ventures has fallen on financial hard times, again raising serious questions about this key Southern city' s ability to continue its dramatic upward surge on a longterm basis.

title: Television
description: 4:56(2)The Jeanne Parr Show

title: Galiber Acquitted With Two Others Of Fraud Charges
description: State Senator Joseph L. Caliber and two other defendants were acquitted last night on charges of participating in fraudulent scheme to sell a Bronx building to a drug rehabilitation program.

title: Rain and Winds of 90 M.P.H. Lash Southern California
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10The worst storm in 4) years hit southern California early today, deluging Los Angeles with three and a half inches of rain in a few hours and causing widespread destruction and at least seven deaths.

title: Money Supply Fell $1.7 Billion in Week Ended Feb. 1
description: The nation's basic money supply fell $1.7 billion in the week ended Feb. 1, while the broader money supply declined $1.2 billion, the Federal Reserve disclosed yesterday afternoon. The statistics were made public one day later than usual because this week's storms had made data gathering difficult.

title: 2 Floral Parks Separated By a Snowplow in Winter
description: Dressed warmly against the cold, Robert David, a 76-year-old retired printer, heaved a shovelful of snow from a twofoot high pile on his street in Queens onto a bare stretch or street in Floral Park, an abutting village in Nassau County that had plowed its residential areas.

title: Maloney Of Rangers Hurt. Again
description: TORONTO, Feb. 10Dave Maloney, the rugged Ranger defenseman, returned to New York today and may be lost for the season after aggravating torn ligaments in his right knee. Maloney had missed 10 games with the in- jury, incurred in a practice session, had played in Wednesday's game against Minnesoba but was unable to play in last night's 20 loss to the Sabres in Buffalo.

title: George W. Kern, at 79, Executive Of Meat Business Father Founded
description: George W. Kern, a retred meat-packing executive and a past president of the New York Meat Trade Association, died Sunday in Lenox Hill Hospital of heart attack. He was 79 years old.

title: Letter: On Planning for the Region
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1978

title: Treasury Memo Sees New York Losing BidforU.S. LoanExtensiori
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10A Treasury Department memorandum made available tonight estimates that if the House of Representatives voted today it would reject an extension of Federal loan assist ance to New York City, 223 to 204.

title: El rails
description: PINSArnulf, The Board of Directors and the Staff of the Council on Social Work Education notes with sadness the passing of Arnulf Pins, former Executive Director. Dr. Pins was more than a former Staff Member of the Council. Everyone of us knows that we have lost a dear friend and an inspiring leader. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family.

title: OHIO, STILL REELING FROM SNOWSTORMS, FACES POWER LACK
description: COLUMBUS, OhioThe fi4rce- winter blizzard that paralyzed this state two weeks ago has easily cost Ohio's economy some $100 million, state officials here are estimating. And now there is widespread fear that those losses will be compounded shortly unless there is an end soon to the nationwide coal miners strike.

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions

title: A's Deadlock Aids No One In Bay Area
description: SAN FRANCISCO; Feb. 10It is now official: The A's will remain in Oakland in 1978 and the San Francisco Giants will play all their home games in Candlestick Park. What's more, there will be no more negotiation between authorities of the two cities to work out a plan that would allow the A's to move to Denver and to consolidate the baseball market here around the Giants.

title: Putting Men's Fashions Back on the Soft and Narrow
description: After two weeks filled with fashion shows, the message for men is clear: Bigness is out, sedate is in.

title: CORRECTION
description: Sale information for the Art Nouveau and Art Deco auction at Christie, Manson & Woods was given incorrectly in the Auctions column yesterday. The correct date is Feb. 25. The viewing time for the sale, which includes Rookwood pottery, will start next Saturday, and continue from Feb. 21 to Feb. 24.

title: 6 School Bus Crashes Injure 13 in Indiana
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 10 (AP)Seven school buses traveling on Indiana highways in dense fog were involved in six separate crashes today, the authorities said. At least 11 pupils and two adults suffered minor injuries.

title: Family of Kappler, ExSS Colonel, Withholds plans for His Funeral
description: SOLTAU, West Germany, Feb. 10 (UPI) The family of Herbert Kappler, a former Nazi SS colonel, withheld plans for his funeral today to prevent pro- and antiNazi demonstrators from appearing at the rites.

title: Personal Investing
description: The performnce of mutual funds that specialize in gold mining stocks is showing renewed glitter because of the steady rise in the price of gold. Page 34.

title: Absentees, chill Mark Yankees Early Camp
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 10 Ericept for Torn Seaver of the Cincinnati Reds and the traveling shrink of the New York Mets, few of the big honchos were here today as professional baseball opened its first weekend of 1978 in the chilly camp of the World Series champion Yankees.

title: LTV Reports FourthQuarter Loss Of $16.9 Million Against 76 Profit
description: The LTV Corporation, a conglomerate that owns Jones & Laughlin Steel, the Wilson Foods Corporation and Vought aeroskace products, reported yesterday that it lost $16.9 million in the fourth quarter and $38.7 million for all of 1977. In contrast, the company had a net income of $7.3 million, or 50 cents a share, in the 1976 final quarter and $30.7 million, or $2.34 a share, for all of that year.

title: LINCOLN'S BIRTHDAY
description: Lincoln's Birthday will be observed Monday.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Th eWall Saved Sea Bright This Time, but Residents Worry
description: SEA BRIGHT, Feb. 10This sliver of a peninsular coastal village of 2,000 people came through another battle with the violent Atlantic this week with deep bruises, a new awe of ocean fury and strong fears that the sixmile sea wallthe only barrier against inundationwould not withstand another severe battering.

title: Books of The Times
description: Edward and Adeline Waller came to New York from Bermuda Hundred in Tidewater Virginia in 1888. Slavery times were more recent then than World War II is now. Millions of immigrants FATS WALLER. By Maurice Waller and Anthony Calabrese. Foreword by Michael Lipskin. Illustrated. 235 pages. Schirmer. $12.95.

title: Carter's Plans for Reorganization Giving Way to More Modest Goals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10President Carter's effort to reorganize the Federal Government has been widely regarded as methodical, well planned and stubbornly pursued. But Congressional sources agree that, like some other Presidential projects, it will probably bear fruit more slowly than Mr. Carter wished and be more modest in scope than he once hoped.

title: WILLIAM E. IX Sr.
description: William E. Ix Sr., a founder of Frank Ix & Sons, textile manufacturers, 1450 Broadway, died Thursday in his home in Lancaster, Pa., after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A woman from Edison was appointed as the guardian of her comatose mother for the express purpose of removing her from a respirator that has kept her alive for more than a week.

title: CeaseFire in Beirut Ends Quickly:
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 10The fighting began today with sniper fire in the earlymorning hours, and shortly after noon the city resounded to artillery exchanges.

title: SOVIET ASSURES U.S. ETHIOPIANS WILL STOP AT SOMALIA'S BORDER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the Soviet Union had assured the United States that Ethiopia would not invade Somalia if it succeeded in drivingSomali forces out of the Ogaden region of Ethic>. pia.

title: New York Blood Program Is Receiving a TransAtlantic Transfusion
description: On most days, a sleek station wagon containing special equipment heads toward Kennedy International Airport in the late afternoon to pick up hundreds of plastic containers,, packed in ice, that have been transported by jet from Europe. The contents of these containers are rarely examined by customs officials, even though the cargo is precious, because they know that delays could destroy the goods.

title: Jersey Ruling Bars Rises in Rates By Car Insurers Without Approval
description: TRENTON. Feb. 10The State Attorney General ruled today that car insurance companies in New Jersey must not raise their rates without prior approval of the State Insurance Commissioner, finding that may mean lower rates for 700,000 or more automobile owners in the state.

title: Episcopal Diocese Regains Its Church From Dissidents
description: In a court decision yestrderday, the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey gained control over its St. Stephen's Church in Plainfield, many of whose members had broken with the denomination in protest over the ordination of women.

title: ANGRY MINERS BLOCK VOTE ON COAL ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Angry coal miners broke up a formal vote on settling the nineweek coal strike today amid signs that the proposed contract would be rejected and that no settlement could come before March.

title: Snow Diverts Mail Going Abroad From Here to O'Hare and Dulles
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)International mail that normally moves out of John F. Kennedy Airport in New York will temporarily be diverted to Dulles Airport near Washington and O'Hare Airport in Chicago because of winter storms in New York, the Postal Service said today.

title: Bar to Confront Burger Over His Criticism
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 10Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has become the focal point of a growing controversy among his fellow lawyers, some of whom feel strongly that his criticism of sonic aspects of the profession has been more destructive than helpful.

title: Streetcar Named Desire at the Arena
description: 'WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Blanche DuBois and Stanley Kowilski are two of the most titanic characters in the American theater. Their clash in Tennessee Wil- liams's A Streetcar Named Desire is a headon collision of oppositesthe tigermoth of Blanche batting its wings helplessly against the burning voltage of Stanley. Irresistibly, they are drawn to each other and, inevitably, it will be Blanche who will be consumed.

title: Campaign Against Senators
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)The Conservative Caucus announced a campaign today to defeat senators who vote for the Panama Canal treaties.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Feb. 10  Governor Byrne's inaugural raised enough money through the inaugural ball, two fundraising dinners and a luncheon to retire the Governor's primary election debt and pay off most of the money owed by the State Democratic Committee, according to the heat report tried toaav with the Election Law Enforcement Commission.

title: Woodrow Gelman, 62, Publisher And Collector of Nostalgia Items
description: Woodrow Gelman, a publisher and collector, died Thursday of a stroke in Franklin General Hospital, Valley Stream, L. I. He was 62 years old and lived in Malverne. L. I.

title: Deaths
description: KAPLOWArthur on February 10, 1978, of 271 TIllou Rd, South Orange, N.J. beloved husband of Marion (nee Rutkin) devoted father of Nancy John, Susan, & James Kaplow, loving son of Ben & Sarah Kaplow. Funeral from the Suburban Chapel of Philip Apter & Son 1600 Spring. field Ave., Maplewood, N.J. on Sunday February 12th, 1978 at 12 noon. Interment Beth David Memorial Park, Kenilworth, N.J. The period of mourning will be observed at the family residence.

title: SURVEILLANCE ORDER BY CARTER DEFENDED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  President, Carter, without a court warrant, approved , television surveillance of an American official suspected of spying for a foreign, power, Administration officials said today, in an effort to reassert exectitive authority in espionage cases involving national security.

title: To Which New York Might Reply...
description: In the normal course of business, a worried debtor, trying to borrow more than he already owes, explains to his bank that he really has assets against which can safely lend. But New York City is no ordinary debtor, and the Senate of the United States is a most unusual bank. The Senate Banking Committee, oddly, has just told the city that its credit is too good for it qualify for a loan. And the city is left insisting that nobody in his right mind would lend it money and that the United States Government therefore should.

title: High Officials Take Over the SouthWest Africa Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 10The foreign ministers of Britain. France, Canada and West Germany and the United Slates begin talks this weekend on the future of SouthWest Africa, the vast territory that the United Nations calls Namibia.

title: CORRECTION
description: Sale information for the Art Nouveau and Art Deco auction at Christie, Manson & Woods was given incorrectly in the Auctions column yesterday. The. correct date is Feb. 25. The viewing time for the sale, which includes Rookwood pottery, will start next Saturdtiv, and continue from Feb. 21 to Feb. 24.

title: South Africa Reports Border Raid
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Feb. 10 (Reuters)  South African troops crossed into Angola from SouthWest Africa yesterday and killed 18 guerrillas in a hot pursuit operation, the South African military commander here said tonight.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: Article 2 -- No Title

title: How to Capitalize the E in H.E.W.
description: President Carter's budget makes good on his campaign promise to give education the priority it was denied by his Republican predecessors. He rightly emphasizes expanded opportunities for the disadvantaged,:and handicapped as well as a means of giving tuition aid to hardpressed middleincome families. With an overall increase of 18 percent in education spending, the President appears intent on rescuing the most positive aspects of Lyndon Johnson's education program, but with a new concern for educational quality.

title: Elvis the Legend Lives Plays the Palace
description: Elvis the Legend Lives, which currently ensconsed in the Palace Theater, is an inept and witless mess. The only real question after seeing is which of the perpetrators are nave and which are cynically exploitive.

title: Alice B. Toklas Hashish Fudge By William Russo at Top of Gate
description: William Russo is a true man-aboutmusic., Equally at home injazz and classical domains, he is a fanner composeiarranger for .Stan Kenton who has written two books about jazz composition and has also won favor as composer of symphonic and operatic music.

title: SENATE WILL ASSESS ATTACK ON TORRIJOS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (Reuter s)Thel Senate agreed today to hold a rare secret session on Feb. 21 to examine charges that the Panamanian chief of government, Omar Torrijos Herrera, or members of his family have engaged in narcotics traffic to the United States.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A woman from Edison, N.J., who asked that her comatose mother's lifesupport systems be disconnected was named as the 70-year-old woman's guardian.

title: 2 PERSONS KNOWN DEAD AFTER INDIANA EXPLOSION
description: SULLIVAN, Ind., Feb. 10 (AP)Two persons were killed and two others were feared buried in the rubble today after an explosion and fire that shook the courthouse square of this quiet southwestern Indiana community of 4,600 persons.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 (UPI)Don Coryell, who criticized management publicly after his team faltered and missed the playoffs last season, was dismissed today as head coach of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: SURVEY FINDS PUBLIC CRITICAL OF LAWYERS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 10A major survey of the legal profession has found that most people think lawyers charge too much, are slow in getting things done and ignore their clients needs.

title: New York Blood Program Is Receiving a TransAtlantic Transfusion
description: On most days, a sleek station wagon containing special equipment heads toward Kennedy International Airport in the late afternoon to pick up hundreds of plastic containers, packed in ice, that have been transported by jet from Europe. The contents o f these containers are rarely examined by customs officials, even though the cargo is precious, because they know that delays could destroy the goods.

title: Literature From Prisons
description: NEWARKAny person seriously interested in American culture can no longer afford to ignore the literature being created by our convicts. The hundreds of books published by American prisoners and exprisoners since the early 1960's, together with the far larger body of unpublished works, constitute a dynamic creative force redefining our society.

title: Shuffle Along : Reprise of a Hit
description: When Shuffle Along was first produced in 1921, it was a landmark in the history of the New York theaterthe first allblack show, musical or straight, to be presented in .the Broadway area. It also had, along with Blossom Time and the first Irving Berlin Music Box Revue, one of the more memorable musical scores heard that season.

title: Blinky Demanded $100,000 Bonus
description: At a hearing last Thursday before the Pennsylvania Athletic Commission in its Philadelphia offices, Frank (Blinky) Palermo shuffled out of the shadows to apply for a boxing manager's license. Now 73 years old, the fellow who did 10 years in a Federal penitentiary for a crime against boxing talked of how he wanted the license to help the kids at the Montgomery County Boys Club stay out of trouble. Such benevolence, of course, does not require a license. Surely he had another motive. But when Blinky was asked if, as boxing people have whispered for months, he was financially involved with Jimmy Young; the heavyweight contender, Blinky replied under oath, I have no financial interest in no fighter. None. But that triple negative is more suspect than ever now. After having denied Blinky's involvement for three months, Jimmy Young's manager record, Jack Levin, a Philadelphia electricalsupply store owner, testified that Blinky had been present at a meeting in the Hilton Inn near Veterans Stadium last April when $2 million offer. to Jimmy Young for a proposed title fight with Muhammad All was spurned, And spurned mostly by Blinky Palermo, it develops now, according to Bill Caplan, who was in the meeting with Ben Thompson, a California promoter.

title: Dartmouth 56, Cornell 52
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Feb, 10 (AP)Sterling Edmonds scored 27 points and Larry Lawrence sank four foul shots in the last 35 seconds in leading Dartmouth to a 5652 Ivy League victory over Cornell tonight.

title: Pike Will Retire From the House This Year  After Ninth Term Ends
description: Otis G. Pikewho has won nine terms in Congress by twitting his own Democratic Party, a Republican Party that could not defeat him despite a huge enrollment edge in his Long Island district, and just about any other target that came into view, has decided not to seek another term

title: Personal Investing
description: The steady climb in gold bullion prices is putting renewed glitter in the performance of mutual funds that specialize in gold mining shares.

title: March Wheat Up; Soybeans and Corn Post Slight Change
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP)The March wheat contract advanced 3 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade today, as reports of wheat purchases by foreign buyers spurred buying in that pit.

title: CeaseFire in Beirut Ends Quickly:
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 10The fighting began today with sniper fire in the earlymorning hours, and shortly after noon the city resounded to artillery exchanges.

title: Atlanta's Upward Surge Stalls As Omni Building Complex Falters
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 10For the second time in a year, one of Atlanta's bold new downtown ventures has fallen on financial hard times, again raising serious questions about this key Southern city's ability to continue its dramatic upward surge on a longterm basis.

title: E.P.A. Recall of Chrysler Cars
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (Reuters)Then Environmental Protection Agency said today its hearing judge had upheld a decision to recall some. 208,000 1975model Chrysler Corporation, cars because of allegedly defective carburetors. The decision marks the outcome of the first test by a manufacturer of an E.P.A. decision calling for a recall of its product.

title: Search for a Perfect Explosive May Unlock Mysteries
description: DOVER, N.J., Feb. 4The quest by smilitary scientists for a perfect explosive is shedding new light on the strange transformations of matter under enormous pressure, such as that at the center of the earth.

title: Policeman Slain, Suspect Seized
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 (UP1):---A motorcycle policeman was shot to death and a fellow officer was wounded last night as they tried to impound the car. of a speeder wanted on a $1,000 traffic. warrant, the authorities said. Arrested moments after the shooting and held in city jail today on suspicion of murder was Robert Thompson, 34 years old. Patrolman Robert Hooper, 42, died of a gunshot wound in the face. Lieut. Mike Brush suffered a shoulder wound.

title: Why a Jetliner's 3 Engines Failed Remains Mystery 2 Weeks Later
description: Investigators have been putting in long hours searching for an explanation for the astonishing loss of power by all three engines of a National Airlines jet two weeks ago.

title: 6 Barred From Police FundRaising
description: A temporary restraining order was obtained yesterday against six persons who allegedly raised millions of dollars for policemen's organizations by using methods that bordered on extortion. One of the six is Edward J. Kiernan, former president of the New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: Miss Decker ins 1,500Meter Run in 4:13.4.
description: TORONTO, Feb, 10Mary Decker back, and better than ever.

title: EXTRADITION OF CONRAD, QUESTIONED IN MARYLAND
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 10 (AP)New York officials have been told by Acting Gov. Blair Lee 3d of Maryland that he has serious reservations about granting an extradition request for Anthony L. Conrad, former head of the RCA Corporation.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the lest week.

title: Bomb Explodes in Israeli Store
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 10 (AP)A small bomb exploded in the clothing department of a Jerusalem supermarket today, but no injuries or damage were reported, a police spokesman said.

title: The Joy Of Tennis
description: The first article I skipped in this month's magazines was Redbook's report on what 40,000 men told interviewers about their sex lives. This, should add, is the first report on sex lives, individual or collective, that have not read since Kinsey went to work back in the Pleistocene Age. The trouble is, I finally know it all.

title: New York Council to Meet Evenings
description: The New York City Council yesterday voted 21 rule changesa recordand prepared to meet experimentally in the evening so citizens who work during the day could attend the sessions.

title: Deaths
description: APPLEBAUMLeo H., suddenly on February 9th. Adored husband of Pearl Applebaum. Beloved father of Stanley, Dr.Helene Newman, and Mrs.Susan Drachman. Beloved grandfather of Jill Maxine and Meg Dana Newman and Mark and Deborah Drachman. Beloved brother of Mrs.Estelle Harris and Mrs.Selma Grodin. Services and Interment were held on February 10th.

title: McDonald Helps Penn Beat Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 10 (AP)Kevin McDonald scored 36 points, his career high, and Tony Price scored 22 tonight as Penn, the Ivy League leader, defeated Yale, 9678.

title: Relaxation of Spending Curbs Spurs the Saudi Arabian Economy
description: RIYADH, Saudi ArabiaThe pace of Saudi Arabia's economy has been picking up again after lagging early last year, members of the business community here and in Jidda report.

title: Two Jazz Performers Mix Well
description: Two performers who are already established individually in the jazz field Jimmy Rowles, the pianist, and Carol Sloane, the singerare working to- gether this weekend and next at Story Towne, the subterranean room at 41 East 58th Street that was known as Storyville until a few weeks ago, in a way that suggests that a very appealing jazz duo may be in the process of formation.

title: URUGUAY AN PLANE CRASH FATAL TO ALL 31 ON BOARD
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 10 (AP) A Uruguayan Air Force transport on a commercial flight with passengers and mail crashed during an emergency.landing today at the northern city of Artigas. All 31 persons aboard were killed, the air force announced.

title: F. D. Clark of Old New York Family
description: F. Douglas Clark, a private investor and a member of one of New York's oldest families, died yesterday in his home at 344 Wahackme Road in New Canaan, Conn., after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Cilea's Aciriana Lrouvreur, 2; Verdi's OteiIn, 8.

title: Nuclear Weapon Test Postponed
description: YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Feb. 10 (UPI)An underground nuclear weapon test early today was postponed until tomorrow morning because of adverse weather conditions. The device has been planted 2,160 feet below ground at the Nevada Test site.

title: Commodity Spot Price Index Rose To 219.9 From 219.1 Last Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 219.9 from 219.1 last week.

title: Carter, in a Surprise Move, Bars Import Relief for Nuts and Bolts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  President Carter, despite heavy pressure from Congress and the domestic industry to prov,de protection against 5300 million year in imports of nuts and bolts, came doyen today in favor of free trade.

title: Confessions of a Surrogate Housewife
description: NEW HAVENThe rise of feminism in recent years has increased everyone's awareness of women's right to achieve equalemployment oppor- tunities. For some women who have chosen to remain fulltime housewives, however, the effect has been to dimin- ish their feelings of accomplishment and satisfaction in what has become an unpopular style of hfe.

title: Money
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1978

title: HASKINS &
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI)The Securities and Exchange Commission today said Haskins & Sells, one of the nation's largest public accounting firms, had settled an administrative proceeding that included suspensions for three partners and the Philadelphia office.

title: U.S. Said to Feel Israel Must Yield Sinai Settlements and West Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10The Carter Administration has concluded that for Middle East peace efforts to succeed, Israel will have to agree to dismantle its civilian settlements in Sinai eventually and to give up control over the West Bank of the Jordan and Lhe Gaza Strip over a period of years, according to American officials.

title: Around the Nation
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 10 (UPI) Saying that Theodore Robert Bundy may be the most prolific mass murderer in American history, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has placed the name of the escaped kidnapper, who is suspected in 36 sexual slayings, on its list of 10 most wanted fugitives.

title: Players Quit N.B.A. Panel Over ThirdOfficial Delay
description: The National Basketball Players Association notified the league office yesterday that it was withdrawing from their joint committee on violence because of the owners failure to approve the use of three officials in game.

title: Leo Brouwer Offers Guitar Recital
description: Leo Brouwer, the first Cuban musician to be allowed to appear in this country since the Castro regime's ascendancy, gave a guitar recital on Thursday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A Mr. Brouwer. who was born in 1939, has been active for some years in Europe as a recitalist. He also is a composer and the founder of the Experimental Sound Group in Havana, so it was not surprising to find an interest in contemporary music reflected in his program.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: Article 3 -- No Title

title: HOSPITAL COST PLAN PERILED BY DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10A patronage dispute between the Chicago Democratic organization and the Carter Administration appears to have imperiled the President's proposal for curbing increases in hospital costs.

title: Galiber Acquitted With Two Others Of Fraud Charges
description: State Senator Joseph L. Galiber and two other defendants were acquitted last night on charges of participating in fraudulent scheme to sell a Bronx building to a drug rehabilitation program.

title: Rhode Island Still Cut Off
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 10 (AP)Snowcovered Rhode Island was still virtually cut off from the rest of the world today, but a weary Gov. J. .loseph Garrahy said that nonemergency traffic could begin moving again in some parts of the state.

title: Trudeau Hopes Spy Case Will Not Harm Soviet Ties
description: OITAWA, Feb. 10  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott TrMean said today that he expected SovietCanadian relations to go on as before despite a chill caused by the order issued yesterday expelling group of Soviet officials accused of espionage.

title: SOCIOLOGIST CHALLENGES BEATENSPOUSE FIGURES
description: An expert in family violence has challenged assertions made by the authors of a book on wife beating that there are 28 million battered wives and 12 million battered husbands in the United States.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONAn officer of the CBS Technology Center in Stamford, Conn., has invented a- quadraphonic microphone system that will enable radio listeners to tell where performers are on a stage. Benjamin B. Bauer, vice president and general manager of the center, was granted Patent 4,072,821 this week.

title: More Buried Cars Found
description: BOSTON, Feb. 10 (AP)Snowfighting teams found 1,200 to 1,500 more stranded vehicles than they had expected on Route 138 overnight, upsetting the timetable for clearing the major highway arteries south of Boston, the Department of Public Works reported today. However, some owners started retrieving abandoned cars on Route 128.

title: Bethlehem Criticiies Price  Trigger Plan
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's secondlargest steel producer, yesterday joined several other steel companies in criticizing the Carter Administration's reference price plan designed to reduce lowpriced imports of steel.

title: M. S. Handler, a Times Reporter Who Covered World War II, Dies
description: M. S. Handler, a foreign correspondent for news services and The New York Times in Europe for nearly 30 years who also covered the civilrights movement in the United States in the 1960's, died of cardiac failure Thursday night at Parkcrest Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 72 years old and had lived in Santa Barbara since his retirement five years ago.

title: Corporation Earnings Reported for the Latest Quarter
description: For periods ended Dec. 31 unless other. wise Indicated. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) over. thecounter.

title: Notes on People
description: Pope Paul VI told a gathering of about 500 of Rome's priests yesterday that the number of resignations from Roman Catholic priesthood was giving him immense pain. The Pope, ad- dressing himself to the fact that 2,000 to 5,000 clergymen are leaving annually, said: The destiny of the weak ones who have found the force to desert their pledge confounds us and makes us invoke the mercy of God. Statistics distress us, the individual cases disconcert us, the motivations impose on us reverence and compassion but cause us immense pain. The latest figures available from the Vatican are for 1975, when more than 4,000 of the church's 405,000 priests left the clergy.

title: ANGRY MINERS BLOCK VOTE ON COAL ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Angry coal miners broke up a formal vote on settling the nineweek coal strike today amid signs that the proposed contract would be rejected and that no settlement could come before March.

title: Elvis the Legend Lives Plays the Palace
description: Elvis the Legend Lives, which is currently ensconsed in the Palace Theater, is an inept and witless mess. The only real question after seeing is which of the perpetrators are naive and which are cynically exploitive.

title: Major Flu Epidemics in U.S. Linked to Old Viruses, Not Russian Flu
description: The Russian flu virus has been detected in seven states from coast to coast, but the major flutepidemics still reported in some broad areas of the United States appear to be linked to last year's viruses ATexas and AVictoria,

title: Dayan Blames Arab Politics, for Halt in Peace Talks
description: Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel, continuing his tour of the United States, said in New York yesterday that he believed President Anwar elSadat of Egypt had broken off peace talks last month not because they were at an impasse but because the two sides were close to agreement.

title: Make It: Neither a Little Snow...
description: In Manhattan, at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue, there is a giant building on which is engraved a famous guiding principle that sorely needs reappraisal. You may quibble with the whole message, but you may definitely erase with a sand blaster those first two words of the familiar Neither snow nor rain nor heal nor gloom of night stays these couriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds.

title: PublicAffairs TV in New York Is Called Neglectful
description: A study of public-affairs programming on the six New York City commercial television stations has concluded that the programs do not substantially reflect what the stations own surveys have found to be the priority issues in the region.

title: Business Records
description: Friday, Feb. 10, 1978

title: Cost of Cleaning Up After Storm Is Seen as Formidable by Officials
description: Four days after the metropolitan area's worst snowfall in 30 years, public officials yesterday began to calculate the cleanup bill. And the figures were as formidable as the snow.

title: TheWall Saved Sea Bright This Time, but Residents Worry
description: SEA BRIGHT, N.J., Feb. 10This sliver of a peninsular coastal village of 2,000 people came through another battle with the violent Atlantic this week with deep bruises, a new awe of ocean fury and strong fears that the sixmile sea wallthe only barrier against inundationwould not withstand another severe battering.

title: YOUTH FOUND GUILTY OF 25 BRONX DEATHS
description: A Bronx teenager was convicted yes terday of 25 counts of murder for spreading the gasoline used to fire a neighborhood social club in the Morrisania section in October 1976. The fire killed 25 partygoers and injured 24one of the worst fire disasters in the city's history,

title: Canadian Indians Talk of Poisoned Air While OthersWorry About Lost Pipeline
description: YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories. Feb. 7Eddie Drybones is, in sense, a wanted man. Military authorities from Canada's Northern Region Headquarters here went looking for him last week in the frozen wilderness betwen Fort Reliance and Artillery Lake.
