They found his tent, but no one was home, so they left a written warnine.

title: Spokesong, by Stewart Parker, Belfast Drama, at Long Wharf
description: NEW HAVENFrank, the bean poleshaped proprietor of a Belfast bicycle shop, has a vision. Feet are slow, buses keep to a fixed route and taxis are expensive.

title: Kreisky Warns Israel on Support
description: VIENNA. Feb. 10Chancellor Kreisky warned Israel today it was threatened by a process of isolation from the West,

title: Aged in Boarding Homes Are Cheated, Panel Says
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 10The first in a series of nationwide Congressional hearings on boarding homes for senior citizens received testimony today that some unscrupulous owners regularly cheated fixedincome boarders on food and pocketed the difference.

title: Radio
description: 7-8, WNCN. Krakowiak, Chopin; Concertino No. 3; Concertino No. 2, Pcrgolesi; Impromptu in A flat,. Schubert.

title: F.B.I. Gift Supports Alcatraz Park Plans
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10The Na tional Park Service got subtle assistance from the Federal Bureau of Investigation today in its effort to preserve Alcatraz prison buildings as historic structures.

title: Fireman's Fund Elects 2 Directors
description: Shirley Temple Black, the former movie actress and diplomat, and Edwin a Etherington, a past president of the American Stock Exchange, were elected yesterday as directors of the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, a subsidiary of the American Express Company. Mrs. Black has in recent years been the United States Ambassador to Ghana, the State Department's Chief of Protocol and United States representative to the United Nations. Mr. Etherington was president of Wesleyan University from 1966 to 1970.

title: Deaths
description: COHENOr. Morris, CCNY 1912 sorrowfully records the passing of a cherished classmate former President of The Bronx County Medical Society.

description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb.10He looked like Old King Cole but was playing the part of court jester.

description: GLADSTONESylvia. Central Synagogue of Nassau County records with deep sorrow the passing of Sylvia Gladstone, dear devoted member and extends heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family.

title: Vietnamese at U.N. Leaves
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 10Vietnam's chief delegate here, accused by air United States of involvement in espionage, left the country tonight because he said, the United States grossly obstructed his ability to carry out his diplomatic duties.

title: Erving Sidelined With Phlebitis
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 (AP) Julius Erving of the 76ers returned to Philadelphia tonight with a circulation ailment in his left calf. A team spokesman said Erving was suffering from superficial phlebitis and would be admitted to Temple University Hospital.

title: U.S. Trade With Saudis On the Rise
description: RIYADH, Saudi ArabiaAmerican trade with Saudi Arabia is growing by leaps and bounds.

title: Youth Guilty of Causing 25 Deaths In Bronx Social Club Fire in 1976
description: A Bronx teenager was convicted yesterday of 25 counts of murder for spreading the gasoline used to set fire to neighborhood social club in the Morrisania section in October 1976. The fire killed 25 partygoers and injured 24one of the worst fire disasters in the city's history.

title: NOW Mounts New Campaign for E.R.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10The National Organization for Women today announced a major drive to win a Congressional extension of the sevenyear lime limit for ratification of the equal rights amendment.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb., 10 (AP)President Carter declared a major disaster in the state of Massachusetts today,

description: SAILING TODAY

title: WorkingClass Parisians Try to Keep Newly Chic Flats
description: PARIS, Feb, 10Some weeks ago, the residents of 14 Lion SaintPaul Street in Le Marais, a 17thcentury Paris neighborhood, received letters informing them that a realestate agency had bought their building and that they should make their apartments available for visits by the agency's officials.

title: Bridge:
description: If the opponents open the bidding, it is hardly ever right to bid a fourcard suit lacking some encouragement from partner. At a highlevel when vulnerable, a player who takes such action is taking his life in his hands.

title: LEVITT URGES CHANGE IN STATE'S PAYMENTS
description: Warning that the size of New York State's shortterm borrowing subjected to unacceptable risks in the money markets, State Comptroller Arthur Levitt recommended yesterday that the state gradually change its payment schedules to reduce its credit needs.

title: Road Salt: Supplies Short, Locked in Ice
description: In weather like this, business should be great, a spokesman for Cargill Inc., a Minneapolisbased highway salt supplier, said yesterday. Instead, we.face a critical distribution problem because our transportation lines are frozen, literally frozen.

title: Patricia London Is Wed To Arnaud Thieffry
description: Patricia Ann London, executive vice president of the La Bonne Soupe restaurant and its realestate holdings, was married yesterday afternoon to Arnaud Thieffry, president of Ted Lapidus, Fifth Avenue, clothiers. State Supreme Court Justice Martin Evans performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: Ethiopians Call Violence a Revolutionary Necessity
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 10When the United States says Ethiopia is a country where human rights are not respected, we call this a lie, said Alemui Abebe, the Mayor of Addis Ababa.

title: Bar to Confront Burger Over His Criticism
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 10Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has become the focal point of a growing controversy among his fellow lawyers, some of whom feel strongly that his criticism of some aspects of the profession has been more destructive than helpful.

title: The Old Neighborhood
description: I grew up in on Italian neighborhood, by Arthur Avenue and 187th Street. It is, and was then, the Little Italy of the Bronx, with a great indoor market, small shops, cheese of all sorts, fish and crusty bread.

title: Durable Santana: Rock/Jazz/Blues
description: Santana, one of the most durable and dependable rock groups to come out of San Francisco in the latter half of the 1960's, was at the Palladium for two shows this week. The band has undergone a multitude of changes since the 60's, with Carlos Santana, its guitarist and leader, remaining the only constant factor. But Mr. Santana is a strong, personal stylist who knows what he wants from a band and how to get it. He has been more jazzoriented in the last several years than he was in the beginning, but even so it is surprising how little Santana's sound has changed, and how serviceable and contemporary that sound still is.

title: Dollar Mostly Off In Trading Abroad; Price of Gold Gains
description: The dollar lost ground against most major currencies in foreignexchange trading yesterday, while French Government action brought an improvement in the value of the franc, The Associated Press reported.

title: State Weighs Tax To Cover Repairs Of Storm Damage
description: Four days after the metropolitan area's worst snowfall in 30 years, public officials yesterday began to calculate the cleanup bill. And the figures were as formidable as the snow.

title: Army 88, Rochester 44
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 10 (AP)Gary Winton scored 26 points and grabbed seven rebounds as Army's deliberate play and sharp shooting overwhelmed the University of Rochester. 88-44 tonight.

title: Controlling TV  Cameras on Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON--;On Oct. 27, 1977, the House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved radio and television coverage of its floor proceedings, culminating the efforts of numerous Congressmen over 33 years.

title: GOing OUT Guide
description: SIDESHOWS The American Museum of Natural History, 77th Street and Central Park West, has become one of the more popular showplaces in town. In addition to its regular exhibitions, it has become on weekends place to see live entertainment of many kinds.

title: King Scores 31 Points As Nets Down Pistons
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Feb. 10The New Jersey Nets made it two victories in a row tonight by defeating the Detroit Pistons, 117112.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1978

title: Mrs. Grasso Calls for Tax Cuts And City Aid in $2 Billion Budget
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 10Governor Ella T. Grasso today proposed a record, electionyear budget of more than $2 billion, with tax cuts and expanded programs of assistance for new industries and for the hardpressed cities of Connecticut.

title: Shell Oil Forecasts Slackening Imports
description: The current decline in domestic oil production will halt in the 1980's, and this coupled with a much slackened growth in the demand for energy in the United States will result in imports leveling off at 11.3 million barrels a day, according to a projection released yesterday by the Shell Oil Company.

title: World News Briefs
description: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa, Feb. 10 (Reuters)Lawyers worked today on an appeal Of two suspended jail sentences given Winnie Mandela, a black convicted of violating a South African Government banning order.

title: A Hard Job for the New Job Chief
description: Stanley Brezenoff, Mayor Koch's choice as New York City's top employment official, brings to the job a promising record of innovation in training the unskilled. As director of program operations for the city's Human Resources Administration in the 1960's, he managed largescale agency and later, as a Ford Foundation program officer in manpower and welfare policy, he developed small, successful manpower efforts into national programs.

title: Snow and the Russian Flu Vex Coach at St. John's
description: Lou Carnesecca, like most New Yorkers, had problems this week because of the weather. But unlike a lot of other Queens residents, the St. John's basketball coach was troubled by an overzealous Department of Sanitation.

title: U.S. Said to Feel Israel Must Yield Sinai Settlements and West Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10The Carter Administration has concluded that for Middle East peace efforts to succeed, Israel will have to agree to dismantle its civilian settlements in Sinai eventually and to give up control over the West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip over a period of years, according to American officials.

title: BENJAMIN FRANKLIN
description: Benjamin Franklin, who retired in 1964 as vice chairman of the Bronx Borough Taxpayers Association, died Thursday in a Miami Beach hospital after a short illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: 240 Detained in South Africa
description: CAPE TOWN, Feb. 10 (UPI)Justice Minister James T. Kruger said today that at the end of 1977, there were 240 people being detained indefinitely under South Africa's Terrorism Act. He did not give a total figure for detainees held under all of the nation's security legislation. Section six of the Terrorism Act allows the police to jail people until they have replied satisfactorily to all questions.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1978

title: SOVIET ASSURES U.S. ETHIOPIANS WILL STOP AT SOMALIA'S BORDER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the Soviet Union had assured the United States that Ethiopia would not invade Somalia if it succeeded in driving Somali forces out of the Ogaden region of Ethiopia.

title: About Newyork
description: The dreams of San Yan Wong are deliberately limited, he says, as he sees to the platter of squab waiting all nutbrown like toasted dwarf turkeys. Six days a week at the woks are accept. able because he is making the money for the larger dreams of his two children, he says, as his senior chef, Mr, Chao, smiles down on the platter of crisply sweetfried walnuts and moves his cleaver like a knitting needle to make a filigree of meaty ingredients for the Three Pleasure soup.

title: Stocks Drift Lower on Unfavorable Inflation Report
description: The stock market drifted lower yesterday, while a number of individual issues showed sharp price swings reflecting corporate developments.

title: ExBudget Chief Accepts Cut in Severance
description: Melvin N. Lechner, the farmer New York City Budget Director, gave up his fight yesterday and agreed to take 54 days pay as his full and final severance settlement with the city.

title: The Season Peaks With 'Tannhuser'
description: January 3 was an unlucky night at the Metropolitan Opera. At 7 P.M. Martina Arroyo, the Leonora of that evening's II Trovatore performance, reported that she had dislocated her back in the bathtub and would be unable to sing. To make matters worse, the Met was caught without a cover artist to replace her. After a few hurried but fruitless calls to several possible substitutes, Elinor Ross was located and persuaded to perform, even though she had not sung the part in five years and is not currently on the Met's roster.

title: Sports Today

title: U.S. Attorney in California Seeks To Transfer Cases to State Courts

No one could tell how successful it would be in its effort to attract a new kind of studentover 21 years; old, employed, highly motivated.

title: THEATER

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a white ring or mark is left on a finely finished tabletop because a wet glass or damp flowerpot has been standing on it, the damage is in the finish, not in the wood, and it is sometimes possible to remove the white mark without a complete refinishing job. (If the stain is dark, it usually means the dampness is in the wood itself, under the finish.)

title: The Other Worlds Near Disney World
description: Central Florida, with its satellite worlds orbiting Orlando, is currently being promoted by local boosters as the No. 1 visitor destination in the United States, but even if it's true, not all the credit for this newborn magnetism should go to Walt Disney World, Sea World, Circus World and other manmade wonders that seem to be proliferating in the area.

title: Seaport the Focus Of Push for Development
description: It is early afternoon at South Street Seaport, and the bustling activity of the Fulton Fish Market is over for another day. On a corner where packing crates and cardboard cartons have been stacked up along with other refuse from the market, two dozen seagulls fight over who will get the best meal of the day. One bird, a small fish in his mouth, fends off his greedy companions while overhead, two or three hundred of the giant gulls sit perched on the edges of the old buildings, watching the scene below.

title: Orin Grossman, Pianist, In New York Debut
description: Orin Grossman, a product of Harvard and Yale Universities and a piano pupil of Kyriena Siloti. Martin Canin and Richard Goode, made his New York debut Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hail before a capacity audience.

title: Gold Rib Classic
description: When the field started in the first annual Gold Rib Eat, Rod Gilbert got off first, On the plate in front of the Rangers former star were two racks of barbecued ribs looking like twin xylophones. At the opening gong, he ripped the notes C and D off the lowest octave, tore them apart at Csharp. His white teeth flashed, and two bare bones dropped into a bowl beside his plate. Immediately to his left, nerve Filion, the harness horseman, worked on one rib at a time. He held the nosh between finger tips of the left hand as he chewed, discarded the bone with his right. If he seemed to labor in the going, it was understandable. He had spent the morning in a dentist's chair, and it was only French-Canadian spunk that had kept him from scratching. .

title: Chihuahua Award Goes To Ch. Miz Mini Mouse
description: A saucy four-and-a-half-pound black and tan smoothcoated Chihuahua, Ch. Pittore's Miz Mini Mouse, was gaited by her owner, Patricia Kirms of Farmincdale, N.J., to best of breed yesterday at the 13th annual specialty show of the Chihuahua Club of Metropolitan New York.

title: Brakes on Car Insurance
description: It used to be that insurance was a minor cost of owning a car. No more. The average premium now matches oil and gas as an annual auto expense and in some places it can equal half the price off a new car.

title: The Beauty of Williamstown
description: In 1950 Robeit Sterling Clark, connoisseur of art and a Singer sewing machine heir, selected Williamstown, Mass., as  the home for the collection he had been accumulating for almost 40 years. He chose the town because of its setting in the heart of the Berkshires and the presence of Williams College, long linked with his family. Thereby hangs a legend.

title: C. Greer McLane, Soprano, Engaged

title: Beauty Fashion in Fragrance
description: It all started 11 years ago with fashion designer Norman Norell's scent, Norell, tagged as the first great fragrance born in America. Revlon was behind it all because the company felt that the time was right for an American fragrance. But although Revlon expected it to be successful, even they were surprised when, within a year, Norell was rivaling the popularity of Joy. Most beauty-industry people see Norell's success as the turning point in the American perfume business. It was the beginning, some claim, of American ascendance over the established European houses.

title: I.Q. Tests on Trial
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.  Intelligencequotient tests, better known as I.Q. tests, have been around since the turn of this century. The first I.Q. test was developed in France by a psychologist, Alfred Blnef, whose name still is attached to the most widely used child test.

title: Cynics Drive Congressman Back to Home
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11It was after initlpight, and Representative Lloyd Moods was still up, reading letters from ilk constituents. He came upon one scalhing note that said he should not have voted for a Congressional pay increase because he did not work hard enough to deserve one.

Susan M. West Engaged

description: DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 10 (Agence FrancePresseTen supporters of the ruling Senegalese Socialist Party were wounded by gunfire, two of them seriously, in an election meeting clash with an opposition group, the Ministry of Information announced yesterday.

title: Sunday Observer
description: For years I had envied people who took winter vacations as I envied people who had lawyers. It was not simply that they were beautiful, though they were, but also that they were rich. Being rich meant two things to me. You never made a move without calling your lawyer, and you took winter vacations.

description: HUNTINGTON, W.Va., Feb. 11 (AP)Arnold R. Miller said in a telephone interview today that he feared for his .life and I'm not going to present this'contract to the council under condition'g of mob rule, a reference to the presence of demonstrators in Washington. I think my life is clearly in danger if I go to the international headquarters when mob is there.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: One of the key decisions the management of a public company must make in its investor relations program is how to handle earnings forecasts. Most companies look to guiding forecasts made by third parties, usually research analysts at investment brokerage firms; the companies carefully refrain from any public commitment to the numbers that are developed by these third Parties.

title: 3 Debuts Made In Barocco At City Ballet
description: Few ballet companies would ever present during the last weekend of the last week of a repertory season three young dancers in their debuts in celebrated major work. Yet, that is what happened Friday night, when Elise Flagg, Nichol Hlinka and Bart Cook appeared for the first time in George Balanchine's Concerto Barocco with the New York City Ballet. Their performances attested to the company's extraordinary wealth of talent.

Each morning, immediately after homeroon.attendance,silence reigns throughout theschool from 8:30 to 8:45. students andteachers alike settle down with book ormagazine of their choice to participatein Principal Joseph Zajac's Readingfo.r Pleasure progra.m.

title: One Proposal Would Change the Federal Role Altogether.
description: The Federal role in education in the United States has traditionally been a limited one. Washington provides only 10 cents out of every dollar spent on public education at all levels, and what it does spend is usually targeted to specific purposes and populations, such as boosting the reading levels of poor elementary school students.

title: Notes: Skiers Kids Get Y.I.P. Treatment
description: A cottage industry has developed, quietly and unheralded, on the nation's ski slopes, In itself it is not a moneymak er, but it does enable parents of young children who might otherwise stay at home to head for the hills and invest In lift tickets. Their helpmate is the ski area nursery. Todaywith the opening this season of several new children's nurseries at ski centersalmost all resorts have some sort of slopeside sitting service that permits adults to ski away on their own.

So there was keen interest when a team in Florida reported on March 12, 1976, that it had developed a promising experimental vaccine against the potentially deadly venereal disease.

title: BOOKLET ON LESBIAN LOVE ANGERS SOME LEGISLATORS

An investigation was demanded by some, and one suggested that using House pages for the distribution, some of whom are as young as 8 years old, might be a criminal offense.

title: Into the ResourcesRecovery Maze
description: RESOURCE recovery has aroused great interest as an answer to the garbage-dis- posal problem, and Connect- icut can be proud to be a leader. Many municipalities are investing in systems that divert their communities solid wastes away from incinerators and landfills and back into the economic system, where they serve as a replacement for expensive fuels and scarce raw materials. Not only does this new approach to an old problem make economic sense, it is also in accord with the public demand that wasteful throwaway attitudes be reversed.

title: Behind the Philippine Loan
description: The ExportImport Bank's largest transaction has also turned out to be one of its most embarrassing: a $644 million financing package arranged to facilitate a Filipino purchase of a $1.1 billion nuclear power plant from Westinghouse. It led to allegations of multimilliondollar irregular payments by Westinghouse to a company owned by a close friend of  President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines for assistance in obtaining the contract. And it was approved by the bank in spite of a 900 percent increase in the cost of the project while the bank's engineers were evaluating it.

title: ABC's of Title Closings

description: Newport in season is a story by a neoScott Fitzgerald, filled with clipped lawns above private docks, with whitewashed urns overflowing with pink and white geraniums, with straighthaired women in jeans skirts and men in soft white shirts and Breton red pants, their feet bare in boat moccasins, shopping for Mount Gay rum.

title: Selling Jets to Egypt
description: Sophisticated arms often symbolize modernity. A developing country mired in economic and social problems can still evoke a moment of national pride and a sense of progress with a flyover by a squadron of jet fighters. Arms are also symbols of gratitude and confidence. What better way than by bringing home an American commitment to sell him jets can President Sadat show the Egyptian people that, despite the absence of evident progress in bridging the gap with Israel, he and his people have a friend in Washington?

title: What Do They Know How Much It May Storm?; Ideas & Trends Continued; Science Education Medicine

title: White House Motor Pool To Have Smaller Vehicles In Move to Save Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP)The Carter Administration is continuing its war on limousines, The White House motor pool is trading in older cars for smaller vehicles, including Detroit's newest subcompact sedan.

title: TV VIEW
description: Publictelevision station WGBH in Boston specializes in packages of original programming material and acquisitions, all neatly gathered under a serviceable umbrella title. Nova, the series that focuses more or less on science, is one example. World, a new project that will alternate weekly with the revived Advocates, is another. David t. annidg, executive producer, has declared : The goal of World is to. generate awarenessto challenge the way we see things by showing the world as others see it. On the evidence of its first two programs, World would appear to be another those typical television exercises in points well taken and opportunities missed.

title: Toots and the Maytals at N.Y.U.
description: We haven't heard much from Jamaican reggae in recent months, at least in concert. Partly that was for individual reasons rather than because of some cruel shift of fashion: Bob Marley in- jured his foot; Jimmy Cliff remained oddly reclusive. So the appearance Friday night at New York University of Toots and the Maytals, one of the finest and most popular of the Jamaican bands, was a cause for celebration all by itself.

title: Syrians and Lebanese Meet During Truce
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon,Feb. 11Negotiations intensified here today as Lebanese and Syrian officials met to try to resolve the conflict between Syrian peacekeeping troops and Lebanese Christian militia areas.

description: Sara Inglis Hoagland, broadcast syndication assistant of The Christian Science Monitor in Boston, and Durant Adams Hunter of New York, an assistant secretary at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, will be married May 6.

The quality of the candies stocked in the, showeases made the neat little shop success from the minute it opened about two years ago.

title: Expelled Vietnam Aide in Paris
description: PARIS,Feb. 11 (Reuters)Dinh Ba Thi, the Vietnamese representative at the United Nations who was expelled by the United States over a spying incident, arrived here today. He did not indicate how long he would remain in Paris before flying to Hanoi.

title: MORE ARE FOUND SATISFIED WITH LIFE IN THIS COUNTRY
description: The percentage of the American public that is highly satisfied with life in this country has risen from 34 percent in 1974 to 57 percent, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Canines and Art

Admission is free.

title: ANTIQUES

title: ART VIEW
description: When the photographer Edward Steichen died in 1973, only two days before his 94th birthday, he was described on the front page The New York Times as a humanist. One could easily see why. Steichen had been many things in the course of his long and dis tinguished careerpainter, esthete, collector, organizer, graphic designer, commercial artist, military photographer and museum curatorbut from the mid1950's onward, his name and fame had come to be almost universally identified with the success of The Family of Man. This was the mammoth exhibition he organized at the Museum of Modern Art 1955 and that, as both a traveling exhibition and a widely distributed book, bedame the most popular thing of its kind ever assembled. The book version, I believe, continues to be some- thing of a best seller even today.

title: Shocker in 28
description: STORY OF THE EYE can lay claim to being the book from which modern high literary pornography derives  the original to which such as The Story of 0 and The Image pay

title: Will a Robbery Help Aide Get a City Car
description: Three days ago, Mayor Koch told Blanche Bernstein, the Human Resources Commissioner, that she could not have a city car. Miss Bernstein said that she needed the car because she worked late at night and that walking to public transportation from her office would be dangerous.

title: STAGE VIEW; Is the 'Get Whitey Play Obsolete?; WALTER KERR; 'Have black playwrights now surrendered the single note of rage in exchange for a much more complex view of things?; STAGE VIEW; Farewell to 'Get Whitey'?
description: I put a bullet in your master and I freed you, says black man to his brother in Gus Edwards's Black Body Blues, now in repertory with Mr. Edwards's The Offering at the Negro Ensemble Company. Ten years ago that line would have been taken at face value. The master would have been white. he'd have peen directly or indirectly oppressing the play's leading black, and the shot that finally dropped him would have been a shot meant to be heard around the world. If black liberation had to be violent, so be it. The time had come. Whites knew had come and nodded assent, in the theater at least.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Wthether one is flying to Paris or taking the tube to Hoboken, there's always a moment at midtrip that is the point of no return, when the pilot must choose whether to go back or be forever committed to the destination. Something of the same sort happens when one is watching a movie, but it's more mysterious and unpredictable than any ordinary halfway mark, and the decision that is made (when a decision must be made) is always negative. This point-of-no-return in a movie may come in the first five minutes or the last five or at any point in between; though, usually, the longer one watches a film the more one becomes committed to it. Time has been invested. Interest accrues. The most dangerous moments in any movie are those shortly after takeoff.

title: House of Erin Is Victor In Aqueduct Split Stakes
description: Sigmund Sommer's House of Erin and William George's Joyfull Ruler were both held off the early pace and each closed with a rush in the stretch to win the two divisions of the Lucky Draw Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Former Chairman of F.C.C. Agrees to Serve as a Trustee of the Political Arm of Broadcasters Association
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The former chairman of the Federal commission that regulates television and radio has agreed to serve as a trustee of the broadcasting group that distributes industry campaign contributions to political candidates.

Nagler on crime control in New Jersey (Opinion Page, Jan. 15) follow themsual form of American Civil Libertiei Union analysis: Knocic down a fewstraw horses, select few statistics, present them without necessary background.and ignore the overwhelming outcry of the citizens for the government's help in the protection of their life and property.

Produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation, they will feature such accomplished British actors as John Gielgud, Wendy Hiller and Cyril Cusack. The bard will be underwritten in this country by a bank, an insurance company and an oil comnanv.

description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 11Rawly Eastwick, the third of the millionaire pitchers signed this winter by the New  York Yankees, stood in the Florida sunshine and conceded that he was a prime symbol of baseball's bewildering timeshere today and perhaps gone tomorrow.

title: The Ticking Bomb
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The Carter Administration is working along very quietly these days on the creation of a new international political structure for, the control and development of nuclear power and weapons.

title: Dr. Richard Molk Fiance Of Elizabeth S. Herbst
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Frederick Herbst of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Spackman Herbst, to Dr. Richard David Molk, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Molk of West Hempstead, L.I. The wedding is planned for the spring.

title: GARDENING
description: HOREAU called winter that grand old poem, but few gardeners today, except those who are also ski enthusiasts, have any kind words for our season of plant and animal dormancy. Even Shelley was reduced to 0 wind, if winter comes, can spring be far behind?

title: Music: Berman
description: The Cleveland Orchestra, in the city for six concerts, made the first of its appearances Friday night in Carnegie Hall under the direction of Lorin Maazel. The program was Russian, presumably as a compliment to Lazar Berman, the Soviet pianist, who was soloist in Tchaikovsky's Piano Concerto No: 1 in B flat minor. This was preceded by Glinkas Overture to Russian and Ludmilla and followed by Stravinsky's The Rite of Spring.

title: Italian Communist Rank and File Has a Voice, Inner Councils Have the Clout
description: ROME  The Italian Communist Party, No. 2 among the political forces in this restless nation, seemed closer last week to its avowed goal: sharing power in the central Government with No. I, the Christian Democrats. It now appears be a question of semantics, rather than substance, that has be worked out before the Communists will have a peripheral say in how the country is run. Would it have made much difference if they had a more formal role with such minor portfolios as the Post Office and the Merchant Marine?

title: Stealers of Ferrari Took It Underground
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 (AP)Whoever stole Rosendo Cruz's elegant Ferrari more than three years ago decided to go underground with itliterally.

description: 1. Vote on bill to strengthen United States policies on nuclear nonproliferation and to reorganize certain nuclear export functions, passed, 88 to 3, Feb. 7.

title: Segovia50 Years of Concerts. Here
description: Fifty years, one month and four evenings ago, a young Andalusian guitarist named Andres Segovia faced his first New York audience. He knew that his recital was to be the first guitar concert in New York's musical history. He also knew that many or the people in Town Hall that night did not really believe that the guitar was a proper instrument on which to perform the classics.

title: Kathleen Fitzharris Fiancee
description: The engagement of Kathleen Mary Fitzharris to Christopher J. Rohrs, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Rohrs of Somers, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Fitzharris Jr. of Eastchester, N.Y. The wedding will take place June 3.

description: LAWRENCE

title: PRINCE OF THE PAPERBACK LITERATI
description: The critic of Best Sellers magazine, accustomed to sifting through the works of so many Micheners, Baileys and Susanns, was quite startled to sit down one day last year and find before her a novel which, as she noted with trembling indignation, is dedicated to an amoeba. She signed off with warning that she would definitely not give this book to a friend. The critic has my sympathy; best sellers are not supposed to be so odd. And yet, there stands Even Cowgirls Get the Blues high on the sales charts for 1976 and 1977, and, beside it, a companion volume from a few years back, the equally puzzling Another Roadside Attraction. There are nearly two million copies in print of these two books. Almost all of them are in paperback, where the name of Tom Robbins has risen to stand beside those of Pynchon, Brautigan, Vonnegut, Pirsig and Castaneda. Together they form, if not a school, then certainly a breed: the paperback literati. Their readers are found primarily among the generation which thinks nothing of spending $7 or $8 for two to attend a movie, but will not consider paying $10 for a book which will last alifetime]

title: What's Doing in JERUSALEM
description: MANY PULSES Medieval cartographers, contemporaries of the scholastics who racked their brains to determine how many angels could dance on the head of a pin, placed Jerusalem at the center of the world. While they lacked geographic certitude, they have been proved adept at charting the terrain of the emotions.

The members of the faculty, Alumni Association, and the Advisory Council of the Columbia University School of Social Work are deeply saddened by the untimely death In Jerusalem of Arnulf Pins, one of the School's most distinguished graduates, He will be long remembered for his professional - leadership, his outstanding contributions In many fields, and his personal qualities that made him so special to so many of us. We wish to express our sincere condolences to his wife and family.

description: The New York City Police Department has taken measures to prevent any members of the force from selling confidential information in computerized data banks to criminal figures and others.

title: Arizona Setter Triumphs
description: NEWARK, Feb. 11A Gordon setter from Peoria, Ariz., was named best of breed tonight at the Gordon Setter Club of America national specialty show for the third straight year. No other Gordon setter has accomplished this feat. The dog is. Ch. Daron RebeL With a Cause, owned by Darleen Wedeman and handled by Patty Grant. The dog has 22 best-in-show victories, chiefly on the Pacific Coast, and has won the sporting group 95 times.

title: SNOW REMOVAL BIDS SEEN AS PROHIBITIVE
description: The New York City Sanitation Department reports that it could quickly clear the mountains of snow left from the recent storm if it gave five private contractors the goahead on contracts they already hold for snow hauling.

description: Harry Edmund Martinson, the Swedish poet and novelist who shared the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1974 with Eyvind Johnson, his novelist colleague and countryman, died yesterday in Stockholm at the age of 73.

title: Tremors Recorded After Quake
description: GOLDEN, Colo., Feb. 11 (UPI)Geophysicists at the Natioal Earthquake Information Service have recorded two strong tremors they believe were aftershocks of the year's first major quake. They said that the second aftershock was recorded at 7:05 P.M. yesterday and the first earlier in the day. Both occurred in the sparsely populated Kermadec Islands to the South Pacific. No damage or loss of life was expected from either quake.

title: John Blake Fiance Of Harriet Louros
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Louros of Pelham, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Harriet Louros, to John C. Blake, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherwood C. Blake of Wenham, Mass.

title: What Happens. When a Race Driver Drives on the: Highway
description: You have to be a more defensive driver on the road than when you're on the race track. On the race track, we're all professionals, and we all know what we're doing. We're all going in the same direction usually. But on the street, you have to watch everybodyoncoming traffic, side traffic. It's more difficult, more strenuous to me to drive on the highway than on the race track. It's frustrating at times because I'm professional race driver and the other people out there aren't. They just aren't as sharp as I am.

title: Judith Scott, Peter ,Evans Planning to Wed in May

It is Comstock, Ferre & Company, at 263 Main Street, Wethersfield, and it has been dispensing seeds to gardeners and farmers continuously since 1820.

description: The. black smoke billowing from the chemical plant is clearly in violation of environmental law. Who Is to blame? The worker who failed to check a meter? The maintenance crew? The purchasing agent? The design engineer? Or was it the company president?

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: TORCH SONG, by Anne Roiphe. (NAL/Signet, $1.95.) The six years of human bondage of Marjorie Weiss, a Park Avenue girl, after she falls in love with James Morrison, selfstyled writer and outright sadist from Brooklyn. Anne Roiphe, whose fourth novel this is, has a keen eye for details and a sharp ear for talk, but she's never able to make the reader see what Marjorie sees in Jim.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11A study by the American Civil Liberties Union indicates that many employees and executives feel that workplace privacy is matter of considerable importance.

title: Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn Wins Its Battle to Survive, as State Aides Close Nearby Unity
description: Jewish Hospital and Medical Center has won its battle to survive in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn. However, Unity Hospital, a smaller institution about one mile away, will close next month.

title: RHODESIA IS SEVERE IN TERRORISM CASES
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb, 11When the Chief Justice announced the sentence, 15 years at hard labor, Elias Nyamadzwayo looked blankly at the bench. Only as he left the cramped courtroom, barefoot and handcuffed to a black policeman, did the 48-year-old farm laborer offer any reaction. I think ift is too hard, he said.

title: Trying the Joys of Small Town Life With a Summer Rental
description: For five summers my husband and have returned to a small Massachusetts townnot a resortto spend our vacation in someone else's home, The first summer we rented a foursquare Colonial that concealed a delicate interior balcony designed to link a nursing mother to a sick child. The next year we were on the ground floor of a turreted Victorian summer house. Our living room was the original dining room and had double sliding doors and a ceiling of embossed tin. One summer we had harvest of inbedroom sinks, since we had rented a former boarding house.

title: RabbiBrings His Message to Cairo

title: Koch on Residency: A Sound Principle
description: IT has never been any secret that believe that people who work for New York City should live in New York City. This, I believe, is sound principle of government, and as Mayor I intend to try to put that principle into practice.

title: Crufts Show Disrupted
description: LONDON, Feb, 11 (Reuters)A tan and white wirehaired fox terrier named Ted captured the title of supreme champion tonight at Crufts, the world's biggest dog show, but the judging process had a fair share of disruptions.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: WESTERN MINISTERS MEET AT U.N.: The foreign ministers of five Western powers met with the South African Foreign Minister, Roelof F. Botha, left, at the United Nations yesterday. From right: Dr. David Owen of Britain; Cyrus R. Vance of the United States; HansDietrich Genscher of West Germany; Donald C. Jamieson of Canada and Louis de Guiringaud of France. They conferred with Mr. Botha on independence for SouthWest Africa. Page 18.

title: Digressions Along the Nile: A FourthCentury Tourist Visits Egypt
description: Sometime between A.D. 350 and A.D. 371, a Roman staff officer named Ammianus Marcellinus did what many people have been doing recently: he visited Eavot. He seems to have enjoyed the trip, which he recorded in his History. He found Canopusmodern Abukir, on the western edge of the Nile deltato be, for example, a place exceedingly well supplied with good inns, of a most wholesome climate, with refreshing breezes. Anyone might think himself out of our world while he hears the breezes murmuring through the sunny atmosphere. As for sightseeing, he found there are also in this country many things exceedingly worthy of observation.

title: RollerSkating, Once on the Skids, Now Coming Back
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I.The steady drone of wheels can be heard across the country these days in everything from abandoned Quonset huts to converted bowling alleys as rollerskating, virtually a lost art a decade ago, enjoys a renaissance.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The $450,000 Daytona 500, the richest and most prestigious stock car race in the world, will be held next Sunday in Daytona Beach, Fla. The field includes Cale Yarborough, who won last year, and Richard Petty, who has five victories, a record, in this race. Friday's feature.at Daytona is the final of the International Race of Champions, with Yarborough, Petty, Mario Andretti, Johnny Rutherford and five othei drivers.

title: The Nation; In Summary House to Probe Its Own, but How Deeply?; Senate's Ideas On Intelligence; Still No Progress On Natural Gas; And Now, Hollygate; Good Night, Bert
description: Like Calpurnia, the House ethics committee last week displayed its indignation over possibly wayward colleagues by announcing an investigation of two Pennsylvania Democrats, Representatives Daniel J. Flood and Joshua Eilberg.

title: The House Joe Frazier Helped Build
description: The new Madison Square Garden ,orated its 10th anniversary this weekend with Joe Frazier singing instead of smokin. I fought em fair, I fought em square, he sanob before last nights Knick game, I fought em my way. As the former world heavyweight champion contemplated a comeback, perhaps now is All did at his peak. Because of h's smokin style, Joe Frazier burned out too soon. But at his best, Jce Frazier was a glorious gladiator, He was at his best for three years almost to the nightfrom March 4, 1968, when he deflated 242pound Buster Mathis in 11 rounds in the new Garden's first boxing show, to March 8 1971, when he decked Muhammad Ali in the final round of the unanimous 15round decision in the first siege of their fiveyear war.

They are tough, aggressive works that often . stun fortheir boldness as well as for their garishflamboyance, their expressive sloppinessand visual incoherence. Sometimesthey represent imagery of a blatantlysexual nature. Yet these qualities at:eoften not weaknesses in the artist'spaintings but strengths.

title: Court to Hear Censorship Charge By Students at Boston University
description: BOSTON, Feb. 11A longrunning dispute between students and the Boston University president, John R. Silber, to be argued in court Monday in a lawsuit over the university's impoundment of funds for an alternative student newspaper.

title: Bear Mountain Tourney Won by Long Island Skier
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb, 11Michelle Voborill, a 26-year-old construction steel distributor from Centerport, L. I., won the Joseph K. McManus memorial ski jumping tournament today with a jumpoff flight of 158 feet.

title: Business Interests Fighting Back on Regulation
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb, 11Business interests, borrowing a tactic from their foes in consumer movements, are increasingly using taxexempt foundations to fight government regulations and environmental reform.

title: Too Little, Too Late
description: OF the making of many books on the AngloFrench Suez Expedition of 1956 there seems be no end. But at least the latest figure to join selfjustifying procession stretching from Lord Avon (Anthony Eden) through Guy Mollet to Moshe Davan is an author with a difference. In 1956 Jacqueg GeorgesPicot was not a politician or even a soldier but simply general manager of the Suez Canal Company, the AngloFrench condominium whose national. ization at the hands of Gamal Abdel Nasser occasioned the last imperial adventure in modern history.

title: Music in Review
description: Conchita Antufiano, a Mexican soprano who has studied extensively in this country and has done some opera performing here, too, made her New York solo debut. at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night. She appeared in Carnegie Hall's Concert Artists of Mexico series.

title: Ariel PianoFlute Duo Has Debut
description: Because Ariel is such a light and airy spirit, the name seems an especially apt title for a flute and piano team. Susan Hyman and Elizabeth Lane ap- parently .agree. These two young mu- siclans nave performed togetner as tne Ariel Duo since 1974, when they were students at the Manhattan School of Music; on Friday night, they made their formal New York debut in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: MUSIC
description: Pu ACHASE THE Purchase campus of the State University of New York starting to bubble over with student, faculty and guest cul turul events, including dance demonstra tions, lectures, jazz workshops and concerts of every type.

title: Anne Murray Sings at Bottom Line
description: For one reason and another Anne Murray, the Canadian countrypop singer hadn't performed in New York for awhile, so her return Friday night at the Bottom Line attracted a warm and loyal crowd of her followers. They weren't disappointed; Miss Murray was as appealing and gently subtle as ever.

title: Burlington Road Limps Faster
description: ST. PAULIn the mid1960's, when many Western railroads were diversifying and developing their natural resources to offset declining prospects in the rail Industry, the four predecessor roads of Burlington Northern Inc. were begging the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to merge. The regulators consented in early 1970, Just three months before the historic collapse of the PennCentral system.

title: The Creaky. PropertyTax System
description: IMAGINE fixing property values and taxes by picking numbers from a hat. Well, chances are, your taxes wouldn't change much, according to a recent study of New York State property assessments. The accuracy of our assessments, the report declared, does not differ significantly from what might be obtained by lottery.

title: Carter Weighs Pushing States To AssistCities
description: WASHINGTON,Feb. 11The Carter Administration is giving serious consideration to a plan that would reward states that aid their depressed cities and towns while penalizing those that do not by cutting back the revenuesharing funds they get from Washington.

title: Author's Query
description: I am working on a biography of civil rights hero William Henry Johnson (18331918), with emphasis on the period from 1848 when he was a consignee for Henry Box Brown to 1900, when largely through his influence and efforts school discrimination was ended in New York State with passage of the Elsberg Bill. Letters, personal reminiscences and photographs will be welcome..

title: Letter T0 THE EDiT0R

description: College basketball at Madison Square Garden is as healthy as it ever has been as long as the attraction is worth the price of admission. A record crowd of 19,694 filled the Garden yesterday afternoon, lured by the prospect of good teams playing good games.

title: GARDENING
description: THIS is the time of year when houseplants go into their midwinter slump. More often than not it is triggered by the short days and poor light of midwinter combined with either overwatering or underwatering. Another major contributing factor is that of insect infestation, and this seems to be the most difficult to deal with for more indoor eardeners.

title: U.S TO ENTER TALKS IN PARIS ON ECONOMY
description: PARIS, Feb. 11The United States Treasury Secretary, W. Michael Blumenthal, will attempt to resolve differences within the Western alliance over economic policy at unannounced talks with European and Japanese finance ministers here this weekend, according to official sources.

title: Volunteer Firemen Called Out To Cope With Storm Problems
description: DIX HILLS, L.I.In the last month, long Island's 26,000 volunteer firemen have been called out innumerable times, but only rarely were the firefighters asked to fight fires. Instead, since Jan. 13, the firemen have had to cope with an ice storm that knocked down utility wires, a blizzard that shut down much of the Island, a torrential rainstorm that flooded homes and a snowstorm last week that got all the places that the first one missed.

title: Miss Cherry Fiancee Of Timothy Jacquet
description: The engagement of Debra Lynn. Cherry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Cherry of Cleburne, Tex., to Timothy John Jacquet, son of Mr. and Mrs. Constant H. Jacquet Jr. of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents. Plans have been made for a wedding on Aug. 5 in Cleburne.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: HOSE differences between the very rich and you and me that mesmerized F. Scott Fitzgerald, have had their fascination for Btirton Hersh, who absorbed the Kennedy family in his 1972 political biography of Senator Edward Kennedy and has now completed a book on the Mellon family, which William Morrow will publish in May. We ran into Mr. Hersh recently, while he was in town to put the finishing touches on his galleys, and over a drink he talked about those differences and problems of writing about the superwealthy (he estimates the total fortune of the main Mellon heirs as being between three and five billion dollars).

description: ONNECTICUT, fortu c nately, is really way ahead on women's issues, said State Senator Betty Hudson, a leading feminist in the state who will be trying to get some of the most controversial proposals from the International Women's Year Conference through the Legislature this session.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1978

title: Headliners
description: Even the best of jobs can get boring. Not that being a Congressman is necessarily the best job, but it has its rewards. They no longer are enough, however, to entice Representative Otis G. Pike, who announced last week that after 18 years he was giving up his Congressional seat from the First District on eastern Long Island. Mr. Pike's disenchantment had been growing for some time. A full day at the of fice_and a round dinner parties at night, he said. It is a bore, and I am unwilling to do it anymore. He was the 33d member of the present House to announce his retirement after this year. The Long Island Democrat had a penchant for the pungent remark, whether about Congressional ethics codes that he considered too strict or the meager breakfasts offered by the Carter White House. Two years ago, his House Select Committee on Intelligence reported in detail on covert intelligence operations, but it probably will be remembered not so much for what it found but for the fact that the report was prematurely disclosed by Daniel Schorr, the journalist. None of it interests Mr. Pike enough now. He's tired of wasting his time on drivel, a statement released by his office said. He'll get good pension. He'll miss it, but can learn to make his own reservations and balance his own checkbook.

title: Swazi Opposition Leader, a Doctor Arrested Once Again at His Clinic
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 11 (Agence FrancePresse)  The leader of Swaziland's banned opposition party, Dr, Ambrose Zwane, has been arrested at his clinic in the country's second city, Manzini, and taken to a maximum security prison, The Rand Daily Mail reported here yesterday.

title: INTERVIEW
description: LAST summer, rumors suddenly began appearing to the effect that the Prudential Insurance Company might move its corporate headquarters out of Newark, a prospect that shook the business,community and the city government.

title: Science Pure and Impure
description: THE PHYSICISTS is an ambitious book, tells the story of a single field in American science since the Civil War, and it branches outward to cover the history of American science at large; it examines the intrinsic elitism of scientific research and traces the conflict of that elitism with America's democratic traditions.

title: South African to Visit Israel
description: CAPE TOWN, Feb. 11(Agence FrancePressejSouth Africa's Finance Minister, Owen Horwood, will visit Israel later this year, it was announced here today. His Israeli counterpart, Simcha Ehrlich,. has been in South Africa for the last three days and leaves tomorrow at the end of an official visit that included discussions of various economic agreements.

title: This Week the Line Will Present a New FiveYear Plan
description: The last thing the fledgling Consolidated Railroad Corporation needed now was another series of costly winter storms. A severe winter last year cost Conrail $100 million and upset a grand design intended transform the Governmentsponsored railroad into profitmaking private company by 1979. The cost of regrouping after the snowstorm that buried the Northeast last week and the blizzard that paralyzed the Ohio Valley the week before has not been determined, but the expense will again be enormous.

description: ALENTINE'S Day is for lovers, chocolate lovers, and the place to indulge in dark passions is Lazar's Chocolate Chef in

title: Deaths
description: JUVALLHyman, With head lowered we record with sorrow the untimely Passing of Hyman Juvall. His devotion & dedication to the members he served so well contributed much to the effectiveness & success of our union during the decades oast decade. Under his guidance, workers in traditionally underpaid jobs were able to lift themselves out of society's subbasement into the bright sunshine of a better life. The best tribute we can pay to our dear departed Brother is to continue to carry on in his Trade Union faith & committment. Our profound condolences are extended to his beloved wile, Rose and other bereaved emmbers of members of his family.

title: Health Inspectors Find 5 Infractions At Plato's Retreat
description: Plato's Retreat, the Upper West Side social club that caters to its members freewheeling sexual habits, has been cited by the city for healthcode violations involving kitchen, pool and steamroom facilities.

title: Trefoil's Esquire Leads Boxers
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Feb. 11Trefoil's Esquire of Snuffbox was the grand prize futurity winner today at the American Boxer Club's annual speciality show in the National Guard Armory. There were 171 enteries in the futurity. Carolyn C. Spencer of Brroklyn is the owner and breeder of the winner.

title: Sudan Offers Help to Chad
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 11 (Agence PresseFrance)President Gaafar alNumeiry has asked President Felix Maflown of Chad to give him a chance to find a solution to Chad's border dispute with Libya, the newspaper Al Sahafa reported here today. The Sudanese leader made the same request to President AlbertBernard Bongo of Gabon, whom he will succeed as chairman of the Organization of African Unity in July.

title: Tips for Intergalactic Travel: Sturdy Walking Shoes Are a Must
description: Many Americans will be abducted by U.F.O.'s this year, and yet how many of them will be truly prepared? Just seeing 'Close Encounters a few times and reading the saucer magazines can't fully answer those nagging questions about alien encounters. Here, then, are a few of the most common queries about extraterrestrial travel, along with some answers that are, we hope, more downtoearth:

title: Defeat of Protection Agency Was a Semimortal Blow
description: Despite active lobbying, the President's endorsement and a bill modified to meet objections, legislation that would have established a Federal consumers agency failed last week by a 227 to 189 vote in the House. It was the fourth failure in as many Conpresses.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: SOON after I started to teach 16 years ago, I would get up 'on weekdays at 2:30 A.M. to work the 3-to-7-A.M. shift, stocking shelves in the local A.&P. before I went into the classroom to teach. I had to, to pay the rent and eat. I was 37 years'old and had six in the family when I started teaching.

description: The big book on Farrar, Straus and Giroux's fall list is a 1,000page life of Joseph Conrad. The biography by Frederick R. Karl, a professor of English at City College and a lifelong student of Conrad, so impressed the editors of the publishing house that they plan to have copies in reviewer's hands by Labor Day, even though the mariu_script did not arrive at Farrar, Straus until the middle of last month.

Doctors may warn against smoking, overweight and foods high in cholesterol, but following their advice does not insure survival.

description: Springfield, III., is is a city dominated by two realities, the one living, the other dead. Without them Springfield would be another big town out on the prairie, slumbering through the deadening heat of summer, cut off by its. winter snows. But the presence of the state government and the sleeping Abraham Lincoln have combined to make Springfield an enduring attraction.

title: 2 Die, 4 Hurt in Car Crash
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP, N. J., Feb. 11 (AP) Two persons were killed and four persons were injured, one critically, in fourcar accident on Route 70 here today. The dead were identified as Marlene Williams, 42 years old, of Toms River and Alexander Paternoster, 53, of Lakewood. Mr. Paternoster's wife, Josephine, was, admitted in critical condition to Paul Kimball Hospital in Lakewood.

title: Administration Working to Revive a Plan to Allow Presidential Candidates to Pick Own State Committees
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The Carter Administration, rebuffed by the Senate last summer on a proposal to allow Presidential candidate to supersede state party committees and appoint a campaign committee in each state, is working to resurrect the concept in the House.

description: The Cosmos have signed Dennis Touearl, a forward from England, and will announce his acquisition at a press conference tomorrow, according to sources close to the Cosmos.

description: Characterizing the administration of Governor Carey as one of drift and decline, Assemblyman Perry B. Duryea Jr., who is seeking the Republican nomination in next November's gubernatorial election, charged last night that the state bureaucracy had grown by 11,000 employees since Mr. Carey took office.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Back in 1971, Nancy, Friday, read book that blamed women's sexual problems on the influence of their fathers. What about their mothers? she thought to herself. So Miss Friday, whose own father had died when she was years old, decided to write a book on how mothers influence their daughters lives. She wrote a 40page outline and submitted it to her male literary agent, who shoved it into his desk drawer and muttered, What about their fathers?

title: Corruption Charges in Hollywood
description: Hollywood these days is in a state bordering on the melodramatic. On the one hand, its corporate dealings are under scrutiny amid reports by film stars and others of alleged corruption. On the other hand, there is frenetic movement in the ranks of top executives. Last week there were develoments on both fronts.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Spanish Pavillion, the exterior of which simply a huge whitestucco box, is one of mixed bag of Spanish and Portuguese eating places that abound in the NewarkHarrison area, stuck here and there among lightindustry plants and rehabilitated housing. They share a common reliance upon seafood for much of their menus and a tendency to serve vast portions, and Mr. and !Wm Antonio Martinez restaurant Is no exception.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Jerome Roth, oboist of the New York Philharmonic, is a bicyclist. William Blossom, a NYP bass player, is a juggler; and Myor Rosen, the harpist, is a chess fanatic. Nancy Donaruma, one of the NYP cellists, cooks Italian food. Paige Brook, the flutist, sails radiocontrolled model ships..Jim Candido, one the bass players, is a skier. Raymond Sabinsky, in the viola section, plays the classic guitar. Bert Bial, the contrabassoonist, is a photographer. Theodore Podnos, one of the violinists, is a musical historian specializing in early string instruments. Jon Deak, in the bass section, is an outdoors type who goes backpacking, snowshoeing, climbing and camping. Ranier Dilntinis, the horn player, knows everything about gardening.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONA dart board hangs on the office wall of Allan Oakley Hunter, chairman and president of the Federal National Mortgage Association, the nation's largest source of funds to finance housing. All of the darts are neatly clustered in the bull's eye circle.

title: The Books Reveal the Cost Squeeze
description: In an age of mass production and distribution of the lively arts, the Metropolitan Opera is what Arnold Toynbee might have called a fossil of a nowgone musical culturea culture built on a relatively small, elitist audience out front and on cheap labor behind the footlights, backstage and in the pit. Yet, the Met is an increasingly lively fossil these daysand one that promises to stay alive and kicking in the face of the chronic threat to its survival: inflation.

At the same time, Irma Vidal Santaella, chairman of the State Human Rights Appeals Board, lost a court bid to appear on the ballot.

title: Miss Decker Makes It 3Way Race

title: Renegade Tops Afghans

Zuvenda Renegade of Esfahan, the 2-year-old dominomarked house pet of Karen Wagner of York, Pa., was judged to be the best Afghan last night in an entry of 300 at the Afghan Hound Club of America 41st specialty in the Statler Hilton. The winner was handled by Carl Sanders of Houston, and is coowned by his breeder, Karen Usry of Pennington, N. J.

The up-and-corners include Rachel Lampert and Dancers, May O'Donnell Concert Dance Company and the Solomons Company. (See Dance)

title: Feding for the Past Stirs Historic Restoration in the Philippines
description: A tour group composed of American veterans of World War H arrived in the gleaming lobby of the newly renovated Manila Hotel and paused before the familiar twin stairways. Charles M. Swaart, now 69, a combat correspondent during the war, reminisced, Up these stairs we went with fixed bayonets, fighting the Japanese floor to floor. He and most of the touring veterans were wearing the sheer embroidered native shirts called barongs, which suit the tropical temperature, and their wives bloomed in flowered gowns and shell accessories.

title: The Nation

title: 25 REPORTED MISSING IN CALIFORNIA STORM

The very words implied big new theory or big new bucks or even both.

title: The U.N.Today
The Daylight Stretch

Even when the weather isn't cutting capers, there isn't much more a farmer can do except take care of the daily chores and wait.

title: Confidence Less Here Than Abroad
description: American businessmen have less confidence in the economic scene than their counterparts in nine other industrial na tions and regions, according to,a survey by the McGrawHill Publications Company, Only 43.2 percent of American busi- nesSmen answered the survey by saying the outlook was favorable. The highest rates of confidence were expressed in Britain, with 60.1 percent, and West Germany, with 54.2 percent. In Italy, the rate was 54 percent; in France, 52.4 percent; in the Scandinavian countries of Denmark, Norway and Sweden combined, 51.5 percent; in Spain, 50.5 percent; in Japan, 49.6 percent; in Canada, 48.1 percent, and in the Netherlands, 47 percent.

The American record, set in 1974, is 84 days.

When Ford Frick was commissioner, he favored letting the press attend the owners semiannual business meetings, then and now conducted behind closed doors. I guarantee, he told a group of newspapermen, one meeting is all you could take. These guys come in with an agenda prepared advance. title: BOND PRICES STEADY AS TRADING SLACKENS
description: With the Government securities market shut'down for Lincoln's Birthday, corporate and taxexempt bond prices showed little, if any, change from the levels at which they closed. Friday. Trading activity slackened.

title: POPS PRAISES SADAT FOR PEACE EFFORTS
description: ROME, Feb. 13President Anwar elSadat flew home to Egypt tonight after a 70-minute audience with. Pope Paul VI at which he received warm public praise from the Pontiff for working so intenseIy for peace in the Middle East.

title: Hart and Ruskin Share a Concert
description: Alfred Hart, violinist, and Abbott Ruskin, pianist, received equal billing at their Carnegie Recital Hall concert Sunday night. This seemed fair enough considering the program. Mozart, after all, reversed today's conventional ordering by styling his Sonata No. 8 in C for piano and violin. The two instruments also meet as equals in Sonatas by Strauss (Op. 18) and Grieg (No. in G). Only Ysaye's Unaccompanied Sonata No. 4 gave Mr. Hart the spotlight to himself.

title: MercedesBenz to Lift Price of New Cars 3%
description: The price of MercedesBenz passenger cars imported into the United States as of Feb. 13 will increase percent, the company said yesterday.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title

title: Stocks Slip as investors Ponder Coal Impasse and Weak Dollar
description: Stock prices moved modestly lower yesterday. Investor psychology was dampened by the stalemate in coal-contract talks and by pressure on the American dollar in currency markets.

title: Harvard 88, Cornell 81
description: ITHACA, NY., Feb. 13, (AP)Brian Banks's 19 points and Cornell foul trouble helped Harvard post an 88-81 Ivl League victory tonight despite 32 points by the ,Big Reds Mike Davis.

title: Queens Optometrist Slays His Sister, Ailing Mother And Himself, Police Say
description: A Queens optometrist apparently stabbed his mother and sister to death, then killed himself by slashing his wrists and ankles and stabbing himself in tne chest, according to the police.

title: $4.42 BILLION BUDGET PRESENTED BY BYRNE
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13Governor Byrne presented today a $4.423 billion New Jersey state budget for the fiscal year 1979 that begins July 1, saying that it was skimpy but adequate and could be financed without new taxes. He said that if the Legislature approved any new spending programs, it would have to provide the money for them, but indicated that he would veto any major new tax.

title: State Aid Plan for New York City Facing a Fight
description: ALBANY,Feb. 13Details of the $200 Million package of aid to ,New York City agreed upon by Governor Carey and Mayor Koch emerged here today, and legislative aides immediately pounced uponthe political and accounting problems the Dian could create.

description: ALBANY, Feb. 13A small warning flag hoisted by State Controller Arthur Levitt last week, suggesting that New York State's finances were not truly in balance, forced startled aides to Governor Carey today to defend the state budget from attack by someone they had considered an ally.

title: BLUMENTHAL FINDS NO SIGNS THAT BONN WILL SPUR ECONOMY
description: BONN, Feb. 13  Secretary of the Treasury W. Michael Blumenthal met for nearly three hours tonight with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and said afterward that the West Germans had declined to commit themselves, as the United States has urged, to increasing their growth rate to stimulate the world economy.

title: U.S. Panel Finds Lag in Rights in 77
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)The Commission on Civil Rights said today that there was a disturbing lack of economic gains for women and minorities last year despite the Administration's efforts to improve the situation.

title: Revamping to Cut Costs Urged For DayCare System in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13 (AP)New Jersey's costly daycare system is based'on halfbaked concepts and good intentions and needs to be revamped to bring down soaring costs, according to a report by private group.

title: Wagner 97, L.I.U. 94
description: Steve Johnson led Wagner with 24 points in a 9794 overtime victory over Long Island University tonight.

title: Payoffs Inquiry Weighed in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Feb. 13Legislation creating a blueribbon commission to investigate 'the state's farreaching political payoff scandal will be before the State Legislature when it reconvenes here later this week following a recess caused by last week's snowstorm.

title: CoverUpCharged as Nicaragua's  Inquiry Into Slaying Lags
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 12One month after the assassination of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, an outspoken politician and newspaper editor, many questions surrounding the case remain unanswered and many leads provided by witnesses have still to be pursued. Contradictions in the testimony of the alleged killers have also been ignored.

title: NATIONALIST SPLIT DEEPENS IN TALKS OVER RHODESIA
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 13 (Reuters)Two of the nationalist organizations participating In talks on an internal settlement in Rhodesia have demanded that the leader of a third, Bishop Abel Muzorewa, either sign a statement in principle with the rest of the participants tomorrow or withdraw from the talks, sources close to the conference said.

title: JAPAN AND CHINA SET TO SIGN TRADE PACT

title: Bar Votes Down Attempt to Force Burger to Substantiate Criticism
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 13The American Bar Association refused today to endorse the efforts of lawyers who are critical of Chief Justice Warren E. Burger for his adverse comments on the courtroom competence of American attorneys.

title: Train Wreck Kills 5 in Egypt
description: CAIRO, Feb. 13 (AP).A commuter train coming into Cairo during the morning rush hour today smashed into the rear of another train that was halted by track repairs, killing at least five persons and injuring 25, the police said.

title: Recital: Pianism by Paul Schenly
description: Paul Schenly' s piano recital Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall really hit its stride only in the final work, both books of Brahms's Variations on Theme by Paganini, It might have made sense to mi., the repetition of the theme at the beginning of the second book and play both books straight through, without applause after the first. Otherwise, this was a superbly conceived, superbly executed perform. ance.

title: Transportation Grant
description: The Federal Mass Transit Administration has decided to award a $24 million grant to the state's Department of Transportation to reimburse commuter rail and bus lines, it was announced.

description: FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Feb. 13 (AP)  The FMC Corporation's cellophane plant here, which employs more than 1,100 persons, will close by the end of March, company officials announced today.

title: Notes on People
description: On the publication in Britain yesterday of his autobiography, Group Capt, Peter Townsend said that American publishers turned down the book because he refused to include in it the intimate details of his romance. with princess Margaret, which ended 23 years ago. I was not prepared to give any more details of an intimate nature, said Captain Townsend,, now 63 years old and a resident of France married to a Belgian. In his book, Time and Chances, he expresses resentment that his marriage to the sister of Queen Elizabeth II was opposed by the state and Church of England on the ground that he had been married before. The Prime Minister who led the opposition, Captain Townsend pointed out, was Sir Anthony Eden, himself divorced and remarried. He said it was ironic that he is now happily,married; while Margaret is separated from her husband, Antony ArmstrongJones, now Lord Snowden. But infinitely sad, said Captain Townsend, is that the Princess',s marriage, consecrated by the church, is now itself marriage at all.

title: A Wolff Office Is Broken Into Again
description: PORT WASHINGTON, Li., Feb. 13 (AP)For the third time in less than three months, an office of lepresentative Lester L. Wolff, DemocratLiberal of Queens and Nassau County has beenbroken into' Mr. Wolff' office at 156 Main Street here was entered over the weekend but nothing important appeared to have been taken, the police said. The same office was burglarized in December, and $30 was taken and some records were strewn about. Mr. Wolff's Washington office was burglarized Nov. 29.

title: G.A.O. Urges Pentagon Savings By Curbing Occupational Courses
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)The Defense Department could have millions of dollars by being a tougher schoolmaster, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: KOCH AIDE FURIOUS OVER ITGUIRE PLEA
description: New York City's Deputy Mayor for Finance, Philip L. Toia, yesterday described himself as furious at the Police Commissioner's public call for a raise for members of his department. He accused the Commissioner, Robert J. McGuire, of raising false expectations in suggesting that the financially pressed city could afford the increases.

title: ReReforming Social Security
description: It seemed like such a good idea in December: Vote huge payroll tax increases to restore the financial health of the Social Security system but delay imposing them until 1979, and so avoid a major electionyear battle Congress. The chickens, however, have come home to roost sooner than anticipated. Social Security payroll taxes were due to go up this January in any event, and they hatve. These modest increases seem to have sparked anxiety over what will happen when the payroll taxes rise again next year.

title: Experff Say This Winter Approaches 1977's in Severity
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Federal metecirologists today forecast sharply colder weather for the eastern, central and southern parts of the country, and indicated that if their 30day forecast was borne out, this winter, which so far has been warmer than last year's, could end up about as cold.

title: Scientists Talk of Solar Power Stations Aloft and a SuperSubway
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Scientists indulged in a morning and afternoon of thinking big today, discussing such projects as huge orbiting solar power stations and a supersubway system that would carry passengers from coast to coast in less than an hour with an intermediate stop in Dallas.

title: 2,000 in 4 Days Phone On Nuclear Exposure
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)The Defense Nuclear Agency received more than 2,000 telephone calls in four days after setting up a tollfree number to report possible exposure to radiation in nuclear tests in the 1950's and 1960's, officials said today.

description: John F. Royal, who in 1940 became tfie National Broadcasting Company's first vice president in charge of televisipn, died yesterday in New York. He was 91 years old. Mr. Royal, whose career began with NBC radio in 1929, was responsible for bringing to the air many actors, musicians, comedians and other performers, both backstage and on stage.

title: The Conant Vacancy
description: What made James Bryant Conant remarkable was not only that he presided with distinction over Harvard for 20 years, or that he played a key part in the building of the first atom bomb; it was, rather, that he represented a tradition of university leaders who acted on their knowledge that American education is all of piece. Like Charles W. Eliot, who had earlier made Harvard a watchtower over public education, Dr. Conant, who died this week at the age of 84, understood that not even the best of universities could preserve the Jeffersonian concept of an aristocracy of talent unless the public schools provided a durable foundation.

title: The City Is a School, Experience the Teacher
description: The sign at the door of the principal's office of one of New York City's most unusual public schools says simply, Fred, and the man in that office, Frederick J. Koury, feels he is most successful if his students stay away from school.

title: Cuban Exiles Visiting Home Find Identity

'I guess I was just begging to find out if I belonged, if I was really part of that country.

title: From: Jim Crow to Cooperstown
description: Baseball's expanded veterans ccmmittedthe codgers who confer immortality upon old crocks no longer eligible for popular election to the Hall of Fametook its first, run under a new set of rules a fortnight ago and found them., unsatisfactory. When the Baseball Writers Association of America completes its annual vote on retired players who were active in the last 20 years, the 18man veterans committee meets to consider individuals in five other categoriesplayers who packed it in more than two decades age, executives, managers, umpires and blacks who played at least 10 seasons in the Negro leagues before Jackie Robinson broke the color line. Trcuble is, with all those .groups to choose from, the committee may elect only two mennot more than one player from the lilywhite leagues, not more than one from the black leagues, not more than one executive or umpire or manager.
