title: Now, Boat People From Taiwan?
description: Week .after week, the small boats come out of southern Vietnam. Their cargo of desperation is a crosssection of the people. Half are children. The adults are young and old, professionals and peasants, former supporters of the regime of President Nguyen Van Thieu and individuals whose politics are limited to the desire to escape from the steel blanket of totalitarianism spread over their country since liberation. One supposes that they must know the risks. They keep on coming still, in the thousands.

description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Feb. 13 I don't know why it's happening to us, Detect tive Herman Boone said. I guess it's just our turn. Seems like it's always happening to some city or other in this country.

A sevenday festival of Indian and American music, which opened here last night, has brought together nearly three dozen prominent jazz performers from the United States, Western and Eastern Europe and Japan, as well as topflight classical musicians from India.

description: ALBANY, Feb. I3A small warning flag hoisted by State Controller Arthur Levitt last week, suggesting that New York State's finances were not truly in balance. forced startled aides to Governor Carey today to defend the state budget from attack by someone they had considered an ally.

description: You know about the Annie Hall look in fashion. This involves a certain pairing of hats and vests and pants and other meaningless things. More significant on this Valentine's Day, dear hearts, is the Annie Hall look in lovers. Tall women and short men now go together.

description: Marking the start of an academic affiliation with New York University, Hebrew Union CollegeJewish Institute of Religion broke ground officially yesterday at its new site at 1 West Fourth Street, adjacent to the N.Y.U. campus in the Washington Square area.

title: Bar Votes Down Attempt to Force Burger to Substantiate Criticism

title: Turnabout on Horn of Africa
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 13Only three short months ago, United States policymakers were congratulating themselves on developments in the Horn of Africa. The Soviet Union, in siding News Analysis with Ethiopia instead of its old ally Somalia in the Ogaden conflict, had been expelled from its valuable base at the Somali port of Berbera. The United States, in scrupulously avoiding involvement on either side, had simply sat back and won a good oldfashioned coup.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The United States Postal Service, which has been urged by some critics and communications, experts to advance its technology or, face obsolescence, plans to start an electronic message service later this year, Postmaster General Benjamin F. Bailer said in an interview.

title: CITY'S ASPHALT BILL IS TERMED TOO HIGH
description: The city has been paying millions of dollars too much for the asphalt it uses, for potholes and other road repairs, a State Assemblyman charged yesterday. adding that there was a suspicion of collusion between the asphalt supplying companies.

The President used some of those.suggestions, though neither will say exactly what parts of the address reflected her thinking.

description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 13Robert Elmer Kleasen, whose conviction for the 1975 band saw slaying of a Mormon missionary was overturned last week by the state's highest criminal appeals court, has been moved from death row to a local jail as United States attorneys and prose- cutors in Texas and New York continue efforts to keep Mr. Kleasen behind bars.

Jamieson, Canada's Secretary of State for External Affaiis, said here today that, his Government would ask Moscow to pay the costs Involved in the recovery of radioactive debris from Soviet nuclearpowered satellite, which already total more than $1 million.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The United States repeated today that it was opposed to Israeli settlements in occupied Arab territory. The White House press secretary, Jody Powell, said he was issuing the statement reluctantly and with no desire to prolong the argument.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Federal meteorologists today forecast sharply colder weather for the eastern, central and southern parts of the country, and indicated that if their 30day forecast was borne out, this winter, which so far has been warmer than last year's, could end up about as cold.

title: Gloomy City Labor Prospects
description: This year's contract negOtiations with transit workers and municipal employees promise to be far different from the course usually followed in this biennial rite of spring. The workers demand for money is met by the city's plea that it has none. Any lastminute discovery of funds to pay for raises would sink the credibility of the Koch administration. Without money, the workers will not be satisfied.

title: The City Is a School, Experience the Teacher
description: The sign at the door of the principal's office of one of New York Citys most unusual public schools says simply, Fred, and the man in that office, Frederick J. Koury, feels he is most successful if his students stay away from school.

description: A bluejeans price war that began in mid1977 appears to have ended, even thoUgh prices generally have not comeback to their former levels.

title: GUILTY PLEA MADE BY SOUTHERN BELL
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 13 (AP)The Southern Bell Telephone Company, pleaded guilty today to misapplying corporate funds through falsified expense vouchers. The guilty plea on the single count closed out a threeyear legal battle.

title: A Recital Marks Segovia's 50 Golden Guitar Years
description: It is 50 years and a month since Andres Segovia first performed in New York, and not much about that half century has worn as well as the fastidious Spanish guitarist and his art. As an evangelist for his instrument, Mr. Segovia has written a page in music's history, and as a recitalist he has long been in the elite group of artists who do not attract audiences so much as congregations. At Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night, the faithful overflowed onto the stage for Mr. Segovia's goldenjubilee appearance.

title: Weather Service Now Sees Accumulation Of 2 to 4 Inches of Snow in New York City
description: The National Weather Service raised its forecast last night of a new snowstorm to possible accumulations of two to four inches, starting after midnight.

title: Rhodesia Doing Little to Prepare for Black Rule
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 8Jean Worrall, who has long been active in the cause of the governing Rhodesian Front, shook her head as she sipped tea amid the frangipani and bougainvillea blossoms in her garden. I suppose we must accept that majority rule is inevitable, she said. But must we really send our children to multiracial schools?

title: Leonard Silk A Look at the Lackluster State Of Business Confidence in U.S.
description: The greatest riddle facing the stock market, capital goods industries and Washington policy makers today concerns why, with the American economy advancing more strongly than others, unemployment improving and the al- most universal forecast for continued expansion through 1978, the state of business confidence is so low in this country. The stock market itself, drag- The Economic Scene ging along below the 800 level, is on measure of that lack of confidence.

title: Russians Affirm They Would Match U.S. Development of Neutron Bomb
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 13 (Reuters)The Soviet Union said today that it was prepared to produce its own neutron bomb if the West went ahead with its development of the weapon.

description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb 13 (AP)Coach Ed Brown andhis Southern Connecticut State College basketball team still are fuming over a 20 forfeit loss last night at Springfield College.

title: South African Storm Kills Six
description: PIETERMARITZBURG, South Africa, Feb. 13 (Reuters)A sudden storm killed six people and left hundreds homeless here last night, the police said. The 30minute gale ripped off roofs, uprooted trees and downed power lines.

description: Special to The New York TimesTEL AVIV, Feb. 13An icecream vendor appeared on an Israeli television talk snow recently to say that he would convert to Christianity to avoid going to jail for three years.

title: Taxes &
description: The lnternal Revenue Service has redesigned the tax forms that people are grappling with this year, and the changes are making the annual bout with the tax collector a little more palatable. The new forms are shorter, simpler, more logical and even prettier.

The official announcement will be made today. Gerulaitis played for Indiana last year, but the Golden Gaters recently obtained the rights to him.

description: DETROIT, Feb. 13 (AP)Bob Lanier continued his blazing scoring pace tonight, scoring 31 points and grabbing 17 rebounds as the Detroit Pistons snapped the New Jersey Nets threegame National Basketball Association winning streak, 125115.

description: A policeman was shot in the chest by, a gunman standing just a few feet away last night but suffered only flesh wound and was able to remove the bullet himself, according to the police, who said the officer's life had been saved by a lightweight flak vest.

description: CAIRO, Feb. 13 (AP)A commuter train coming into Cairo during the morning rush hour today Smashed into the rear of another train that was halted by track repairs, killing at least five persons and injuring 25, the police said.

With hundreds of new books being published daily, there isn't time to read any of, them anymore. You have to make do with the press releases.

description: LAS ANGELES, Feb. 13 (AP)Charlotte Greenwood,.the comedian noted for her high kick, long legs and gangly mannerisms on stage and in films, died Jan. 18. She was 87 years old.

description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 13 (UPI)The Rev. Daniel C. O'Connell has resigned as president of St. Louis University, effective today. Father O'Connell, 49 years old, declined to give the reason for his action.

title: Inherent Power Again
description: The Inherent powers of a President in national security matters, once so vehemently asserted by Richard M. Nixon, have again been cited by Attorney General Griffin Bell, this time to cover a new form of electronic surveillanceby television. Like ex. ecutive privilege, however, the term inherent power is one that produces rising hackles in Bill of Rights fans.

Eddy Arnold, the singer, and Ed Herlihy, the announcer, served as hosts for a sampling. of material from The Kraft Music Hall of the 1930's and 40's. At one time or another, the program starred Paul Whiteman or Al Jolson, but it probably became most closely associated with Bing Crosby.

description: HARTFORD, Feb. 13Albert Nels Jorgensen, who was president of the University of Connecticut through its period of greatest groWth, died Saturday at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 78 years old.

William Miller, Textron's chairman and President Carter's nominee to replace Arthur F. Burns as Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 13 (UPI)The authorities said today that an overdose of drugs had killed William Brammer, former press aide to Lyndon B. Johnson and author of the political novel The Gay Place.

description: SADDLE BROOK, N.J., Feb. 13Becton, Dickinson and Company, the big New Jersey hospital supplier, held its annual meeting here today before a record 300 persons, many of them company employees, but the widely expected. fireworks over its unwanted takeover by the Sun Company failed to develop.

description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 13A district court judge today denied the request of a Minnneapolis man who wanted his, name changed to a number, saying that it would be an offense to basic human dignity.

It occurred to her one day that doctors wives were a natural market for a new magazine, so she did some market research on the subject.

title: Advice to Japan
description: TOKYO'If a country depends on military might, it does not have to worry about what other countries think about it, But isn't it the principle of the Japanese Constitution to maintain its safety by trusting in the justice and good faith of the peoples of other countries? Why are the Japanese unconcerned about the fact that Japan has come to be disliked by other countries?

title: Criminal Charge Dropped on Use Of Medical Salesman in Surgery
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed criminal charges against the Smithtown LI., General Hospital, three of its doctors and a nurse who were accused of allowing an unlicensed medicalsupply salesman to perform orthopedic surgery on one of its natients in July 1975.

title: Planes for Peace?; WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14Those 200 planes President Carter promised on Valentine's Day to send to Israel, Egypt and Saudi Arabia were not intended as instruments of war but as instruments of peace. They were, in cited, political Valentines. That is the laceembroidered message out of Washington.

title: 2 Developers Open Battle to Build Jersey Meadows Shopping Center
description: SECAUSUS, N.J., Feb. 14Two prominent developers, each seeking permission construct the one mammoth shopping to construct the one mammoth shopping owlands,, formally opened a battle today, with tens of millions of dollars in investment and earnings at stake.

title: Georgia Recreation Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP)The House approved today the creation of a Chattahoochee River national recreation area in Georgia despite complaints about the cost. The House sent the river bill to the Senate by a vote of 273 to 79 despite criticism, mostly from Republicans, that the $73 million authorized for land purchases would be wasted on scenic treasure that seems to have more local than national significance. The money would be spent for acquiring 5,300 acres in enclaves along a 48mile segment of the river from Buford Dam downstream to Peachtree Creek near Atlanta.

title: UNION SAYS OZONE CAUSES ILLNESS ON SOME FLIGHTS
description: Flight attendants of Pan American World Airways contended yesterday that heavy concentrations of ozone, particularly on flights to Tokyo, are still causing illness amone air crews and passengers.

title: Italian A ide Slain; Leftist Extremists Take Responsibility
description: ROME, Feb. 14An Italian official was shot dead this morning on a busy street in a residential section of the city. A leftwing terrorist group, Red Brigades, telephoned the Italian news agency and claimed responsibility.

title: Johannesburg Police Defuse Bomb
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb, 14 (Reuters)Policemen defused a bomb in the base. ment of a central Johannesburg office block today minutes before it was set to explode, a spokesman said. He said a cleaner had discovered the bomb in the basement of a building that houses a bank and other offices.

description: Woman, eternal woman. Age cannot wither her (not if the cosmetics industry has its say) nor custom stale her infinite variety.

They clapped, they stamped, they made her play a third encore.

title: CORRECTIONS

In fact the Environmental Policy Center said it opposed only those recommendations it believed would weaken the 1977 Strip Mine Act and the Clean Air Act and did not oppose a great many others.

description: Amid growing complaints in the nation about increasing inflationary pressures, the Ford Foundation last week approved a $75,000 grant for the Brookings Institution to conduct a onedav seminar in Washineton in April.

title: Luxury Worries
description: We have entered, as the prodigious snows of 78 demonstrate, the era of Luxury Worries. Each new snowfall has brought its accumulation of real worries: cars lost do Boston snowdrifts . . . looting in Providence . . misery in the Midwest. And with such public concerns come private ones: Will it he possible to get home from work? Would the trip really be any worse than another night in the lastchance hotel where the shower handles come off in one's hand? With the black trash bags already piled higher than the gray snow, how long will it be before the sanitation men can beat their plows into garbage trucks?

title: Jackson Is Received in Peking

title: OLDEN D. MILLER, 73, RETIRED EDUCATOR

title: In Defense of Lindsay
description: Most of the public comments about John V. Lindsay's eight years as Mayor ignore the real urban problems that he faced  problems that will not yield to nolitical rhetoric or to the pointing of fingers of blame at past or present officeholders. The fiscal crisis was not created by Robert Wagner, John Lindsay, or Abraham D. Beame, either individually or collectively, and it is grossly unfair to our former Mayors to make them the villains of our urban tragedy.

title: Socialists in France Minimize the Costs Of Economic Plans

That's a lot of money for a bag that won't hold much more than a lipstick and a few cigarettes and a dollar bill or two, but life's too cluttered anyway, and the effect with summer clothes is smash :Ina. Port of Call is at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: A Little Swan Goes a Long Way

These wines appear at the Vintners dinners the company's great hall. , But there is one dinner each year where the Worshipful members are not free to choose every course to complement the wines. For centuries, only the Vintners and the King, or Queen, have had the right to kill the swans on the Thames. To keep that franchise, the Vintners each year do away with one of the birds and serve it at dinner, although not as the main course.

title: Soviets as Pilots, Cubans as Tools
description: It is a neat, and cynical, division of labor: Cuban pilots flying air strikes against Somali forces in the disputed Ogaden region of Ethiopia. while Soviet pilots take their place minding Cuba's air defenses. It is neat be- cause all the aircraft involved are Soviet MIG's, untamiiiar to Moscow's new Ethiopian clients but wellknown to Cubans and Russians. It is cynical because Moscow has evidently decided either that Ethiopia's cause in the Ogaden is not important enough to risk the lives of Soviet pilots, or that Cuban faces in combat look better to Africans than Russian faces. Why else send two contingents of pilots in opposite directions across the seas?

title: In Plain English

The plainlanguage law required that apartment leases and other consumer contracts be written in nontechnical language and- in clear and coherent manner using words with common and everyday meanings. Businesses that did not comply would be subject to classaction suits.

title: Composers Orchestra
description: HE American Composers Orchestra and its conductor, Dennis Russell Davies, presented an exceptionally stimulating program of new music Monday night in Alice Tully Hall. Recently organized to perform the largely neglected orchestral repertory of native composers, the group chose four serious and aurally demanding worksperhaps even too demanding to be thoroughly digested in one sitting.

title: The Theories Behind Ali's Silence
description: LAS VEGAS, Feb. 14For more than a decade, Muhammad All has identified himself as a Black Muslim minister. But lately he has acted more like a Trappist monk. At the weighin today for tomorrow night's title defense against Leon Spinks, the, world heavyweight chamnion never said a word. For more than a month he

title: Private Lives
description: HE WAS DOWN again among the children, in the libidinal compost heap, thinking. about the pork chop problem. The pork chop problem has been described before in this space. It is not the problem of who, on being told to do so, buys the pork chops, or the cornflakes, or the vacuum cleaner bags. Or even who cooks them. It is the problem of who conceives of pork chops or cornflakes as a problem, who imagines the necessity of vacuum cleaner bags. At dinnertime, essence precedes existence. This branch of metaphysics, like the ritual sacrifice of virgins, has been dominated traditionally by women. But not in our braVe new world. In our brave new world, the porkchop problem was his.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: TACOMA, Wash., Feb. 14 (AP)As many as 1,000 salaried positions may be cut from the Weyerhaeuser Company as part of a major shakeup that will occur this year within the lumber and wood products giant, the company announced today.

title: Public vs. Private Weathermen
description: In that trapshooting business called weather forecasting, a long acknowledged edginess that government and private meteorologists feel toward each othersome call it professional jeal- ousytlared into a pulic teua a couple of days ago, but cooled down a bit yesterday with a sober, even generous, statement from the National Weather Service.

title: BOND PRICES SHOW MODERATE DECLINE
description: Bond prices declined moderately yesterday, pushed downward by the weak dollar, the stalemated coal industry talks, and the Federal Home Loan Banks announcement that they are going to raise $1.4 billion of additional cash, an amount larger than expected.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. TO SUE AUTHOR OF C.I.A. BOOK
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that the Department of Justice was preparing to file a civil suit against a former Central Intelligence Agency employee who broke his promise to clear a book about his experiences with the agency before Publication.

title: In SouthWest Africa One Group Leads But Not All Follow

title: Personal Health
description: MARVIN is a diabetic. His life has depended on daily Injections of insulin for the last 24 years, since he was 11 years old. But few would guess he has a serious medical problem, Marvin is a snow and waterskiing enthusiast, a fixerupper of old cars, a trustee in his church. And he hasn't missed day of work in more years than he can remember.

title: Inquiry Set on Grumman Lobbying

title: Souffles: Much More Than a Lot of Hot Air

The success of a souffl- from the French souffler, meaning to breathelies largely with properly beaten egg whites. When brought to a shiny peak, the whites fill with small air bubbles, encouraging the souffld to rise to glorious heights.

description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14The American Bar Association approved today comprehensive new plan fur disciplining, removing and retiring judges who are disabled or unfit for duty, many of whom htive proved to be virtually untouchable in the oast.

description: HELSINKI, Finland, Feb, 14 (AP)The Bank of Finland kept iis foreignexchange windows closed today for the second straight day as the Government considered devaluing the Finnish mark in light of Norway's devaluation of the krone or Friday. Travelers could, however, change foreign currencies at last Friday's rate.

description: Scientists believe they may be close to transforming the common pas hydrogen into a metalone, it is hoped, that could conduct electricity over long distance without resistance.

title: The Jerusalem Artichoke: Maverick Vegetable
description: HAVINZI nothing to do with either Jerusalem or artichokes, the Jerusalem artichoke is a maverick among vegetables. Although it looks like fresh ginger root in its natural state, wnen cooked it resembles the potato. Sliced raw it has the bland icy crispness of a water chestnut and a mild coconut flavor, but once cooked it tastes much like an artichoke.

title: Tourists Back,Virgin Islands Faces New Set of Problems
description: ST CROIX, V. I.After a fiveyear struggle, tourism in the United States. Virgin Islands this winter is recording stunning comeback, surpassing the peak years at the start of the decade.

title: The U.N. Today
Notes on People
description: Sir Richard Bayliss, physician to Queen Elizabeth II, went to Buckingham Palace yesterday to he knighted by his sovereign. Instead, the Queen's physician ordered her to bed, and also confined to bed her husband, Prince Phillip. Both were found to be suffering from influenza. All the Queen's appointments, including a meeting with Prime Minister James Callaghan, were canceled yesterday. Meanwhile, the Queen's son, Prince Charles, heir to the throne, stood in for his mother and knighted Sir Richard on schedule.

title: A Reign Is Ended As Face Shows Stings of Defeat
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 15Like the old bull who, thinking he is still what he once was, lets the young bull gore h'm until it's too late to retaliate, Muhammad Ali had lost the world Sports of The Times championship to Leon Spinks tonight. But now as the exchampion walked slowly from the ring through the crowded aisles of the Hilton Pavilion toward his small upstairs dressing room, people were shouting, Ali, Ali and You're still the greatest. Wearily, he raised his right hand a few inches to acknowledge the chant but he didn't resemble The Greatest. His face, that wonderful face which once was hardly ever marked in a fight, suddenly had seemed stretched and aged as he plodded out for the final round. And now, up close, there were purple bruises above and below his right eye and over the bridge of his nose. His forehead was swollen near his left eye. Blood from his cut lower lip spotted his white satin trunks and his white terrycloth robe.

title: Establishment of Space Colonies Inevitable, Scientists Told
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 151A. foreign affairs specialist, a physicist, a. designer of space stations, a communications specialist and others looked as far out and as far ahead as possible today in assessine the destiny of the human race.

They identified the victim as Walter Simon, who lived in Baltimore. Mr. Simon was working beside a stalled eastbound train.

Mr. Hamilton does not follow any of the current fashions in jazz saxophone. Nor does he quite go to the usual alternativeslavishly copying saxophonists of an earlier day.

title: Case of SelfDefense
description: The American Bar Association's House of Delegates this week sensibly voted down a resolution whose target was Chief Justice Warren Burger. He had aroused some ire by suggesting publicly that many of the nation's lawyers are incompetent when it comes to trying cases in court, Chief Justice Burger's objective seems to be to further specialization among lawyers, and he has cited approvingly the process of specialization among phvsicians.

title: BOND PRICES SLUMP AS RATE RISE LOOMS
description: The credit markets continued to slump yesterday as traders speculated that the nation's basic moneysupply figures, to be released this afternoon, would show a big increase.

title: LEAK FORCES CLOSE OF ALASKA OIL LINE
description: ANCHORAGE, Feb. 15A leak in the $8 billion Alaska oil pipeline that a Federal offioial said was possibly caused by sabotage tonight sent crude oil spewing out; `at the rate of 20 to 80 gallons second, forcing operators to shut it down. They said they could not estimate how long it would take to stop the leak, which was discovered at 2 P.M..today. .

title: Notes on People
description: CLARENCE M. KELLEY, who presided over the Federal Bureau for more than four years, during a period when intensive public and Congressional scrutiny exposed abuses of power by the agency in the past, quietly left office yesterday. Mr. Kelley, who will be replaced by Federal Judge William H. Webster, received tribute at a testimonial dinner in December. His leavetaking yesterday was marked by a small, informal luncheon in the F.B.I.'s executive dining room.

title: Right Wing Seeks to Unseat Rep. Anderson
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., Feb. 15The political right is trying to unseat Representative John B. Anderson, a Republican who demanded the resignation of President Nixon and supports the Panama Canal treaties and public financing of elections.

title: ExSurrogate DiFalco Indicted in Criminal Contempt
description: S. Samuel DiFalco, the former Manhattan Surrogate, has been indicted for .criminal contempt for allegedly telling .d grand jury he could not remember having spoken to a law assistant about ar=zing favorable rulings for clients of his son's law firm.

Hughes Jr. left this city of his birth when he was 21 years old, never lived in the state again and spent the last eight years of his life outside the United States, a probate court jury held here today that the multimillionaire industrialist was. Texan and therefore his estate should pay inheritance taxes here.

title: Grenade Kills 5 in Burma
description: RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 15 (Reuters)Five persons were killed and 17 wounded when a grenade was thrown into a crowd in the northern town of Hsipaw at the weekend, the Government newspaper Hanthawaddy reported today. It attributed the act to an insurgent saboteur.

title: TV: Is The Whale Stupid?
description: THE PROBLEM with most National Geographic specials is a lack of faith in their basic content. The latest example is The Great whales, which can be seen on Channel 13 tonight at 8. Once again, a potentially interesting subject is smothered in inflated prose, superfluous music and drippy sensationalism.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Times incorrectly reported yesterday that Federal legislation imposing restrictions on nuclear exports was before a HouseSenate conference committee to resolve differences over details of implementation. In fact, on Feb. 9 by voice vote the House acceded to the Senate version. The legislation, the Nuclear Nonproliferation Act of 1978, authorizes the Nuclear Regulatory Agency to adopt detailed regulations, in consultation with the State Department and Department of Energy.

description: WARSAW, Feb. 15 (Reuters)Poland's leading newspaper, Zycie Warsawy, has called on Poles to save electricity at home in order to prevent factory stoppages. The daily paper admitted yesterday that failure to produce more power over the last two years had led to an energy crisis.

description: THE name Emery Roth means glass and steel towers to most New York Wilding buffs, and with good reason: The architectural firm of Emery Roth & Sons has designed more than 100 Manhattan skyscrapers since World War II. He believed in masonry buildings covered with Renaissance detailing, and from 1903 through the 1930's, he filled New York with apartment buildings and hotels in his favored mode.

title: Slow Start Toward Economic Salvation

To hold and to increase jobs, the city will have to overcome obstacles to business expansion, sponsor new incentives, cut away regulations, and inspire the cooperation of city agencies. Recognizing the critical need, Mayor Beame created a special deputy mayor for economic development. Mayor Koch not only kept the post but has described it as one of the two most critical in his administration. He said he looked it for New York's salvation. Those were strong words that should have produced an appointee with a strong presence and a clearly articulated set of priorities. But that has not happened and there is no sign that the Mayor is even disturbed.

title: Film: PostVietnam ROrhantic Triangle
description: AGROUP of young men in vari ous stages of casual dress is playing pool. The single overhead light leaves deep shadows on the perimeter of the game to create a feeling of isolation and conspiracy. A man moves to the table, makes his shot, pulls back. As they play, the men argue about Vietnam. Someone says that if he had it all to do over again, he would. He believes in defending his country, he says. The others hoot with laughter. A second man sneers at the first fellow, though he understands the desperate need to justify what happened.

title: Art: Moral Vision In Mannered Style
description: THE ambitions of contemporary Realist painting sometimes seem exorbitant. Is this why the resultwhat we actually see on the canvas before usoften disappoints? Perhaps. Of course, the outsize ambitions of Realism are nothing new: they have been endemic to the Realist enterprise since Courbet launched it on its modern courses more than a century ago. But Courbet enjoyed the great advantagebeyond, that is, the advantage of an enormous talentof coming before the public as an artistic radical, and this is a stance that contemporary Realism is denied by historical circumstance. For us, whatever the degree of its success, Realism is something we experience as a species of revival.

title: Film: 'Ceddo,' a Pageant From Sembene's Africa:Stately Power Struggle
description: AT HIS most engaging, as in films like "Xala" and Mandabi," Ousmane Sembene, the talented Senegalese writer-director, is a sophisticated social satirist who considers the follies of his countrymen with the humanistic appreciation of a Jean Renoir. His heroes are often fools or slightly cracked, self-deluding imitations of the recently departed French colonials. Whatever they are, the Sembene landscape they inhabit is always the same whether urban or rurala land where one culture has been all but squashed by another, yet refuses to die.Mr. Sembene's newest film, "Ceddo," which opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater, is also about cultural continuity and the threat of displacement, but with a major difference. "Ceddo" is a folk tale presented as the kind of pageant you might see enacted at some geographic location made famous by history and now surrounded by souvenir stands. It's not cheap or gaudy, but it's an intensely solemn, slightly awkward procession of handsomely costumed scenes designed to pass on a lot of information as quickly and efficiently as possible.Set in some indefinite time (mostly the late 19th century with bits and pieces of the mid-20th century in it as well), it's the sad, formally told tale of what happens to life in a small rural village after the king becomes a convert to Islam and invites a Muslim teacher, the Imam, into his circle of advisers. As goes the king, so go the nobles. The little Roman Catholic church is quickly abandoned. Only the Ceddo, or common people, who earlier resisted Rome, refuse to follow the king.In the ensuing power struggle, the Ceddo kidnap the king's daughter to force him to meet their demands. The film is composed of meetings of state, of parleys between opposing factions, of trials or strength and cleverness between the loyalists and the rebels, always conducted according to time-honored traditions. Then the ambitious Imam steps in and, through deceit and murder, effectively wipes out an entire people.This is more or less the content of "Ceddo," though the manner is reserved, cool, almost stately. There are no characterizations in the film, only rather grand impersonations. Most of "Ceddo" has been photographed in the sort of medium-long shot from which one might observe an outdoor theatrical. Only twice, in fantasy sequences, does Mr. Sembene allow himself the imaginative film maker's freedom to distort history to achieve some kind of dramatic truth. The rest is picturesque.It is interesting to note that "Ceddo," which takes a very dim view of the Muslim influence in Senegal, has been banned in that country though not, reportedly, because of any religious sensitivity, but because Mr. Sembene insists on spelling "ceddo" with two d's while the Senegalese Government insists it be spelled with one.

description: ALBANY, Feb. 16A threeday conference of 600 leaders and administrators of drugabuse programs ended here today with workers in different treatment programs pledging to consolidate their efforts.

title: What Causes a Seizure and What to Do
description: The more common form of epilepsy, grand mal, is most often the result of unavoidable birth injuries. Its chief characteristic is seizures, or convulsions, which are caused by a disturbance in the way nerve impulses are transmitted.

title: Notre Dame, Georgetown Are Victorious at Garden
description: Notre Dame had. nothing to prove against Fordham, said Digger Phelps, the Irish basketball coach. Why should we beat them by 40 points?

title: REP. FLOOD'S FRIENDS SAID TO AID 2 IN TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16Friends of Representative Daniel J. Flood provided more than $90,000, ostensibly for legal fees and living expenses, to an aide and a friend of the aide while the two were under investigation and indictment on charges of taking bribes, according to sources familiar with the transactions.

title: Brother of Torrijos Is Indicted in U.S. InDrug Smuggling
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UN) Federal grand jury has indicted the brother of the Panamanian leader, Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, oh a charge of heroin trafficking, and United States narcotics agents tried unsuccessfully to arrest him, according to a document released today by the Senate subcommittee on separation of powers.

title: Nets Beat Sonics, 10192, As Williamson. Scores 39
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Feb. 16The New Jersey Nets, trailing by 8 points as the final quarter began, outscored the Seattle SuperSonics by 28 to 11 and went on to a 10192 victory tonight in the Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: Mickey, Teddy and Barbie Hold Court at the Toy Fair
description: If you're already fed up with Mickey Mouse, Teddy Bear and Barbie Doll, this could be a hard year. Each of those toys is celebrating an anniversary: Teddy will be 75, Mickey, 50, and the fashionmad Barbie has now been addMg clothes to her collection for 20 years.

title: Tiger, With Merger in View, Buys A 9.9% Interest in Seaboard World
description: Tiger International Inc., owner of Flying Tiger, the nation's largest scheduled allcargo airliner, said yesterday had bought a minority share in Seaboard World Airlines, the country's second-largest scheduled aircargo service, and was considering a merger.

title: DelBello and Westchester Sheriff Dispute Over Who Should Head Unified Force
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 16Renewing an old battle, Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive, and Thomas J. Delaney, the county sheriff, offered separate plans today to consolidate countywide lawenforcement opera- tions. Each man said he should be in charge of a unified police force.

title: Adelphi 96, So. Connecticut 72
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 16  Bill McGeorge scored 18 points, 14 in the first half to lead Adelphi to a 96.72 victory over Southern Connecticut last night. The Panthers led at halftime 4726.

title: Homageand a Lot More at Crawford Auction
description: Joan Crawford would have loved it. Even when her fans crowded her almost off her feet, she.enjoyed the adulation. About 400 of them got into the auction of her effects at the Plaza Galleries at 406 East 79th Street yesterday, while others stood in the cold clamoring to get in.

title: U.M.W. President a Target of Both Sides
description: WASHINGTON; Feb. 16Both sides in the chaotic coal negotiations now agree that Arnold R. Miller, the president of the United Mine Workers, has been distracting if not disruptive influence on the bumnv efforts to reach a settlement.

title: Power Shuffling Stretches Utilities Coal
description: CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 16In the control room, paper was streaming out of the computer printer. At precisely 11:34 and 52 seconds this morning, the printout showed, the Donald C. Cook nuclear plant on the shore of Lake Michigan was producing 1,047 megawatts of power, a scant three megawatts short of capacity. But at that very moment, 200 miles to the south, the small coalfired generating plant at Breed, Ind., was turning out only 196 megawatts, roughly half of its potential.

title: Rep. Derrick Symbolizes Some of the Problems Carter Faces in Congress
description: AIKEN, S.C.Representative Butler C. Derrick Jr. tells his constituents that President Carter let him down on the Russell Dam, but be also says I'm not ready to sign off on him yet.

title: Carter and Vance Confer With Dayan; Rift Is Played Down
description: By GRAHAM HOVEY special to The New York TimesWASHINGTON, Feb. 16The United States and Israel made a determined public effort today to play down serious differences about Middle East peace strategy as Foreign. Minister Moshe Dayan conferred with President Carter and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance,

title: Patients Option on Laetrile Backed
description: NEWARK, Feb. 16Dr. Edwin H. Albano, president of the State Board of Medical Examiners, said today that while he was personally opposed to laetrile in the treatment of cancer, persons with the disease should have the right to make their own choice.

title: Fire Damages Press Room
description: DES MOINES, Feb. 16(UPI)Fire erupted today in the building of The Des MOINES Register and Tribune just as workers were completing morning editions. The press room was damaged. The district fire chief, Kenneth Hanson, said that the blaze had apparently started when paper dust fell onto a hot press and ignited,

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (Reuters)The State Department reported today that progress had been made in Nicaragua's humanrights record over the past year, but said future American military credits would continue to be linked to the Central American nation's rights performance.

title: Big Hollywood Parties Become Good Business
description: LOS ANGELES  Paramount Pictures threw a $400,000 party for Saturday Night Fever last December. The profit from that party may eventually be $40 million.

title: U.S. MISSION TO SEEK BETTER ETHIOPIA TIES
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 16A highlevel delegation from the United States is expected to arrive here tomorrow to try to improve its relations with Ethiopia. The threeman party is led by David L. Aaron, the Deputy Assistant to the President for national security, who acting as a personal envoy from President Carter.

title: U.S. Jets to Arabs: Legacy of the Kissinger Years
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16In proposing io sell 110 sophisticated warplanes to Egypt and Saudi Arabia, the Carter Administration is fulfilling a commitment that has been implicit in American poi-icy in the Middle East since the 1973 ArabIsraeli war.

title: ExFireman Who Raced Up 85 Flights Faces Review of His Disability Pension
description: A 37-year-old man who won a race up the stairs of the Empire State Building on Wednesday was retired from the Fire Department with back injury four and a half years ago and has been receiving a taxfree disability pension of $11,822 a year, a Fire Department official said yesterday.

title: Roland Hanna s Jazz Quartet Has a Date in Church
description: Since Dave Brubeck broke up his original quartet in 1967 after 17 years and the Modern Jazz Quartet called it quits in 1974 after 22 years, it has seemed that the day of the longlived iazz combo was past, But there are still a couple of jazz combos that trace their Lineage back to the 1950'sArt Blakey's Jazz Messengers, which has been well known for over 20 years, and a group that is just beginning to become known, Sir Roland Hanna's New York Jazz Quartet.

title: Sale of European Airliners Here Endangered by Port Agency Rule
description: A $500 million deal under which Eastern Airlines would purchase European wide body jets is being threatened by dispute over how much use the plans could make of La Guardia Airport.

title: H. B. SUTHERLAND, SERVED IN THE FOREIGN SERVICE
description: Hugh B. Sutherland, a retired Foreign Service officer,. died of canceryesterday at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 68 years old.

title: Detention Center Escapee Arraigned for Bank Theft After Being Recaptured
description: The last of six men who broke out of the former Federal Detention Center on West Street in March 1975 was recaptured late Wednesday and arraigned yesterday on bankrobbery charges.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: A'NOTHER week, another new seriesand the programming . factories grind on. This Sunday's specimen, on NBC at & P.M., is a Jack Webb production called Project U.F.0. a U.F.O., of course, is an unidentified flying object that almost invariably does well in the retinas. That much about the phenoma- non has been clearly identified by producers. The rest is still largely speculation, with details closely linked to imagination and gullibility.

title: POLES CROSS BORDER TO BUY CZECH GOODS
description: CESKY TESIN, CzechoslovakiaEach morning the line of cars winds back up the hill out of sight into the Polish twin village of Cieszyn across the Olse River from this Czech border town. At the footbridge downstream, women with large shopping bags flash their 24hour passes at the border guards and walk across the stone bridge.

title: Computer Gains on Chess Master
description: In 1968, David Levy, a British international chess master, bet a group of computer experts, 1,250 that in the decade that followed no chessplaying computer could beat him. This year, Mr. Levy expects to collect his wager, but is turning out to be a much closer race than many had imagined possible.

title: Corporation Affairs EG?G Board Backs Offer to Buy Company Stock;
description: Directors of EG&G Inc., Wellesley, Mass., a producer of scientific. control systems, have approved the company's offer to purchase one million of its common shares at $20 each. EG&G will buy all shares tendered up to one million if they are tendered by March 10. If more than one million shares are tendered, the company may, at its option. purchase up to a maximum of 1.5 million shares.

title: Pay Benefits From Snowstorm
description: BOSTON, Feb. 16 (AP)Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today signed legislation de. signed to provide benefits to Massachusetts workers who lost pay checks because. of last week's snowstorm. It provides a waiver of the oneweek waiting period for applying for unemployment compensation and affects workers who lost checks because of the Governor's emergency bail on commercial activity and driving.

title: Antiques Show at Garden Tomorrow
description: Three hundred dealers and galleries will be participating in the 34th National Antiques Show, which opens tomorrow in the exposition rotunda of Madison Square Garden, 4 Pennsylvania Plaza.

title: New York Council Picks Panel Heads
description: The. chairmen for the 16 committees of the New York City Council were selected yesterday, but the division of $59,000 in lulus'lump sums in lieu of expenseswas not decided upon.

title: Callaghan to Speak at U.N.
description: LONDON, Feb. 16Prime Minister James Callaghan of Britain will address a special disarmament session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York on June 2, it was announced today. Mr. Callaghan's office also said that he would attend a North Atlantic Treaty Organization meeting in Washington on May 3031. The special session on disarmament will be held from May 23 to June 28.

title: Urban P. Intondi, Managing Editor And Officer of Paulist Press, at 62
description: Urban P. Intondi, managing editor and vice president of Paulist Press, the religious publishing concern at 1865 Broadway, died of cancer Wednesday in New York University Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Jamesburg, N.J., after having lived many years in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: New Face:
description: Richard Kavanaugh isn't likely to forget the circumstances of his Broadway debut. For one thing, he's acting in the highly successful revival of Dracula, the hoary theatrical thriller that has confounded the odds makers by settling into the Martin Beck Theater for what will obviously be a comfortably lone run. For another, Mr. Kavanaugh's role is that of a lunatic whose favorite pastime is catching flies on the wingand eating them. Hamlet, where art thou?

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND

description: The Washington Post's report yesterday of H. R. Haldeman's book, The Ends of Power, took place in spite of elaborate security precautions and upset plans for newspapers and magazines in the United States and abroad to run excerpts of the book beginning next week.

title: Epileptics Join Together To Fight Loneliness and Stigma
description: Every Sunday afternoon they are there, in an East Side hotel suite10 or 15 of them, maybe as many as 20to escape a special kind of loneliness, to play chess or checkers or Scrabble, to talk over problems and give each other moral support.

title: By H.R.Haldeman: The Ends of Power, an Insider's View
description: From the book The Ends of Power. by H. R. Haldeman with Joseph DiMona. to be published by Times Books, Copyright ling by H. R. Haldeman and J. B. Darjoe Inc. high level, there's a lot of commotion, and it takes twentytwo months for anything to happen. .

title: DOLLAR FLUCTUATES IN A BROAD RANGE, SETTINGv RECORD LOWS
description: The dollar took another drubbing yesterday in foreign exchange trading, falling to new lows against the West German mark and Swiss franc after a highly placed United States Treasury official made an ambiguous statement about Washington's commitment to support the American currency,. The Associated Press reported.

title: Learning the Details One at a Time
description: JUNE 17, 1972, a Saturday afternoon in Key Biscayne, Fla. I stretched and yawned. Across the terrace our villa at the Key Biscayne Hotel, Larry Higby, my young deputy, read a book.

title: CRITIC OF KOREA INQUIRY IS CONDEMNED BY O'NEILL
description: Washington, Feb. 16 (UPI)  The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., in an interview released today accused Representative Bruce F. Caputo, Republican of Yonkers, of spying on the sex lives of his fellow Congressmen and of lying about Mr. O'Neill's relations with the South Korean rice merchant Tongsun Park.

description: The cast of characters that dominated boxing, off and on, for nearly two decades has passed into the wings. In its place are new names, new faces as the Bundinis, the various Muhammads, the Dundees step aside. Here is the new lineup:

title: Modest Growth in Money Supply Eases Fears of Higher Interest
description: Showing a much smaller increase than Wall Street expected, the nation's basic money supply rose $900 million in the week ended Feb. 8, alleviating concern that the Federal Reserve might nudge shortterm interest rates higher.

description: ALBANY, Feb. 16In an unusually, early bipartisan agreement, the State Legislature's fiscal leaders announced today that they would support $200 mil lion of state aid to help New York City close its budget gap next year, in a forni similar to Governor Carey's proliosals.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)Bargainers for American Airlines and the Transport Workers Snion reached tentative agreement ona new contract late tonight, averting a strike threatened for one minute efter midnight, an airlines spokesman said. Announcement of the settlement came just minutes before that deadline.

title: Deaths
description: LANERose on Feb 16, beloved Wife of the late Sigmond, loving mother of Bruce, Merge, Stanley and Claire, devoted grandmother of Michael, Rebecca, Douglas, Marcia, William, Janice, Selena and BIM great grandmother of Vanessa, dear sister of Louis, Jules, Irving and Al. Devoted friend of Dolly Benn Epstein. Funeral services at The Riverside, 76th St & Amsterdam Ave, on Feb 19th at 10am. title: Art: Milton Avery And His Friends
description: FOR quite some years now the Borgenicht Gallery, Madison Avenue at 78th Street, has been putting together an annual anthology in which Milton Avery is pitted (by implication) against his mentors, his contemporaries and his rivals. All the shows have been instructive, ana some of them have been of museum standard. This year it is the turn of Milton Avery and His Friends.

Nixon's chief of staff and closest adviser during the first four years of the Nixon Presidency, contends that Mr. Nixon himself initiated the Watergate breakin, participated in the coverup from day one and may have personally erased . 181/2 minutes of damaging dialogue from a critical Watergate tape.

title: PleaBar4ain Ban Adds to C ourt'sWorkin Boulder
description: BOULDER, Colo., Feb. 16Boulder, a halcyon university community, has begun a brave legal experiment. So far, the only agreedon result is that everyone in the local criminal justice system is getting worked to a frazzle.

description: TRENTON, Feb. 16 (AP)George Foley, a promoter who was the owner of the exclusive Smoke Rise development in Morris County, was indicted today by state grand jury on charges of obtaining more than $1 million in loans by fraud.

Mr. Hill has performed here before, but his threeday engagement at the Other End, which closed last night, has attracted special interest because of his recent success.

description: The Board of Estimate yesterday voted a $636,000, 90day contract to a coalition of women's groups to set up neighborhood services for women ranging from medical advice to selfdefense training.

description: At the Hooks Lane School in Fort Lee, a custom that began 20 years ago was continued this year as a gift of $25 was received for the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. A letter from Daniel Gilbert which also included a brief poem said:

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI)  Nineteen persons were injured when a ninecar Amtrak passenger train derailed in northeast Washington last night shortly after it had left Union Station for New York.

description: DETROIT, Feb. 16The Ford Motor Company, the nation's second largest car manufacturer behind the General Motors Corporation, today reported that its earnings in the final quarter of 1977 were more than double those reported in the strikedepressed final quarter of 1976.

description: It is quite possible that if you have a baseball card of Honus Wagner, the Pittsburgh Pirate immortal, lying around in your home you could get up to $3,000 for it. At least, that is what Andrew Heller believes.

title: A Place Where Ali Is Still Champion
description: DEER LAKE, Pa., Feb. 16You travel north on Route 61 from Reading about 32 miles until you come to Deer Lake, and then you slow down. Sculpshill Road is on the left, a macadam road that takes you onequarter of mile up into the woods and to Muhammad Ali's training camp. This is where he honed himself into a fighting machine for the second Ken Norton and the Earnie Shavers fights, among others. This is where he recaptured the greatness he claimed to have a patent on.

He will work in the commissioner's office as executive director of marketing and broadcasting. It's a new postand an important postas the game faces increasing competition from othe sports for the entertainment dollar.

description: Joanne Haldeman says that neither she nor her husband have ever heard a single word from former President or Mrs. Richard M. Nixon concerning Mr. Haldeman's conviction and imprisonment following the Watergate scandal.

title: japan and China Sign 8Year Pact For $20 Billion Industrial Deals
description: TOKYO, Feb. 16Japan and China signed a $20 billion trade pact in Peking today that sets the scene for marked improvements in their diplomatic and politi cal relations and is a welcome economic Plum for Japan.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16Postmastei General Benjamin F. Bailer said today that he would resign to become executive vice president of the U.S. Gypsum Comvans? of Chicago.

title: CHARLES KEITH, MANAGED O'DWYER'S RACE IN 1973
description: Charles Keith, a realestate operator and campaign chairman for Paul O'Dwyer's successful bid for City Council President in 1973, died Wednesday in New York University Hospital after open1 heart surgery. He was 62 years old and lived at 104 East 17th Street.

title: U.S. Moves Against Student Defaults
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16An accelerated effort to track down former students who have not paid their Government guaranteed loans and to recover more than $400 million was announced today by Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health. Education and Welfare.

title: The Pop Life
description: YVONNE ELLIMAN has been a recognizable name on the popmusic scene for most of this decade, first as Mary Magdalene in various Incarnations of Jesus Christ Superstar, then as the artist of some not particularly striking solo albums and, more or less concurrently, as the female voice on Eric Clapton's tours for three and a half years.

title: First Blast Furnace in Space Is Created by Soviet Astronauts
description: MOSCOW , Feb. 16 (AP)Yuri Romanenko and Georgy Grechko, the Soviet astronauts, have melted metals in the first electric blast furnace in outer space, Tass reported today.

title: EXJUDGE'S MURDER SPURS WIDE INQUIRY

title: 2 Areas Seen Unable To Raise Gas Output
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16A Governmentsponsored review committee has concluded that natural gas production cannot be increased in two offshore fields in the Gulf of Mexico that are operated by the Continental Oil Company and the Mobil Oil Company.

title: LEGISLATIVE LEADERS IN ALBANY WILL BACK $200 MILLION FOR CITY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 16In an unusually early bipartisan agreement, the Slate Legislature's fiscal leaders announced today that they would support $200 million of state aid to help New York City close its budget gap next year, in a form similar to Governor Carey's proposals.

title: SCHULTZE DOUBTFUL INTEREST WILL SOAR
description: Charles L. Schultze, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said yesterday that he did not expect interest rates to increase sharply in 1978.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Drops
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on major. United States Railroads during the week ended Feb. 11 totaled an estimated 13.9 billion tonmiles, 5.4 percent below the corresponding week a year ago. Cal- loadings in the same period totaled 366, 489 cars, 11.3 percent below last year. A. continuation of severe weather conditions, particularly in the Northeast, and the coal miners strike were primary causes of the decline, an A.A.R. spokes man said.

title: Merchant, 83, Symbol of Johnstown Pluck

title: Paul Governali, 56 ; Starred in Football A t Columbia in'40 s
description: Paul Governali. an allAmerica halfback at Columbia University in 1942 and professional football player for three seasons, died Wednesday in San Diego after a long illness. Mr. Governali, a professor of physical education at San Diego State University, was 56 years old.

title: Stage: Fourth Dra.cula on the Prowl
description: FOR the Chinese members of our community this is the Year of the Horse. But for theater folks it seems to be the year of the vampire. Not content with the three currently running Draculas, one downtown at the Cherry Lane and two in Midtown, at the Martin Beck and Off Off Broadway at the Troupe Theater, the Equity Library Theater has mountedperhaps raised is the right wordanother.

title: Bourne's Goals Lift Islanders To 54 Victory
description: DENVER, Feb. 16 (AP)Bob Bourne scored two goals in the final minute of the second period tonight and helped the New York Islanders to a 54 National Hockey League victory over the Colorado Rockies.

title: Topics
description: The commodore, long an endangered species of naval officer, appears headed for extinction. The rank borne so proudly by John Paul Jones and Matthew Perry would be eliminated under legislation passed this week by the House of Representatives. In its wake would come bureaucratic hybridthe commodoreadmiral.

title: Television.
description: 6:00(4)Every Penny Counts 6:10(2,7)News .

title: North Stars Top Flyers As Sharpley Scores Twice
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 (UPI) Glen Sharpley scored two goals, including the game winner with 2 minutes 14 seconds to play, tonight and the Minnesota North Stars defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 42.

title: Phone Company Verdict Reversed
description: EASTLAND, Tex., Feb. 16 (AP)The Texas Court of Civil Appeals for the 11th District today reversed a trial jury's finding that the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company illegally wiretapped the telephone of a former executive. James by. Ashley.

title: Senate Approves Instant Registration for Voters; Revised Race Track Bill Is Passed by the Assembly
description: TRENTON, Feb. 16The State Senate approved today a measure that would allow nonregistered voters to cast ballots on election day in New Jersey. It applies only, to general elections, not to primaries. The vote was 21 to 14.

title: ExAide Asserts Nixon RefusedKissinger and Rogers Deny Account
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16H. P,. Haldeman, the White House chief of staff under President Nixon, writes that the Soviet Union made several overtures to the United States in 1969 proposing joint nuclear attack on China's atomic facilities but that Mr. Nixon turned them down.

title: Notes on People
description: A New York City police detective to lead the 120,000 marchers who wend their way up Fifth Avenue this St. Patrick's Day. Fie is James Barney Ferguson, president of the Grand Council of United Emerald Societies, who was elected Grand Marshal of the 216th annual St. Patrick's Day Parade at meeting of 214 presidents and delegates from the organizations that will par. ticipate in the March 17 celebration. The 43-year-old Mr. Ferguson is the first police officer from the ranks to be named Grand Marshal; although several police commissioners have held the honor.

title: Assemblyman Burstein Enters Race for Congress
description: Albert Burstein, majority leader of the State Assembly, announced yesterday his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the Ninth Congressional District, race that could become crowded before the filing deadline.

title: Bronx Man Is Found Unfit To Stand Trial a 2d Time In Separate Slaying Cases
description: A 36-year-old Bronx man who was found incompetent to stand trial for murder five years ago but was subsequently released from a state hospital was again declared incompetent yesterday to stand trial, this time for the alleged slaying of a woman last month.

title: Carter Takes A Risk on Coal
description: President Carter's decision to step intdc the chaotic coal labor negotiations markc the first time since the Lyndon Johnson era in the 1960's that the White House has involved itself so directly in bargain:. ina. But labor experts say he is playing a dangerous game and and puzzled both by the why and the way of his actions. I'm completely perplexed, said one man who has been involved in labor affairs at the national level. You don't pull a President in unless he's got some basis for thinking he can do it I don't believe he understands the vehemence; the chaos in the coal fields.

title: The U.N. Today
Carey Order Allows Flexible Work Hours
description: ALBANY, Feb. 16State employees would be permitted to work flexible schedules of perhaps four 10hour days instead of five eighthour days, under an executive order signed by Governor Carey today. He said such moves had proved beneficial for morale and productivity, according to a study made by Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak.

title: All Couldn't Con Two Judges

We do not yet know the whole Watergate story, and may never know President Nixon feared a Colson role in the breakin and suspected that John Mitchell might also be involved. Flood provided more than $90,000, ostensibly for legal fees and living expenses, to an aide and a friend of the aide while the two were under investigation and indictment on charges of taking bribes, according to sources familiar with the transactions.

title: New Photo Shows Full of Surprises
description: SURROUNDED as we are by Broadway theater, great museums and concerts almost around the clock, New Yorkers and city visitors still ramble out in search of something different on weekend afternoon. Instead of taking the routine cultural pilgrimages this weekend, you can see a number of photography shows that are specially appealing. In fact, the current photo offerings in the city's museums and galleries might encourage you to set aside a full day, even an entire weekend, for gazing into the camera's universe.

title: 177 in Baltimore Left Homeless By Fire Attributed to a Candle
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 16(AP)A lighted candle, used by a child to hunt for ball, was tentatively blamed today for the ninealarm apartment fire that killed a city policeman and left 77 tenants homeless.

title: Where to Sip the Best Hot Chocolate in Town
description: On ti cold and blustery winters weekend day or evening, surely one of the most satisfying drinks is a cup of hot chocolate. There is no drink comparable for bringing a chilled body back to life and instilling a sense of contentment and wellbeing, as weld, as bearing a heartwarming feeling of nosWide. Most of us associate a cup of hot chocolate with the welcome coziness of a warm house, family and Mends and the good times of childhood.

title: The U.N. as Advertising Agency
description: Pity the lowlevel United Nations officials who have the unenviable task, mandated by the General Assembly last December, of publicizing the inalienable rights the Palestinian people. We do, but not for the reason invoked by the representative of Senegal, Medoune Fall, the chairman of a 23member Assembly committee on the subiect. He apparently fears that the 20 nations that voted against the $500,000 advertising campaign will take out their displeasure on any of their citizens who participate, and he has urged the Secretary General, Kurt Waldheim, not to appoint any to the campaign.

title: Macy's Charged With Sex Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)The Labor Department filed suit today against three Macy's department stores in California, alleging wage discrimination against female employees. Complaints were filed in Federal District Courts in San Francisco and Sacramento, The department alleges that many female sales employees have been paid lower wages that male sales employees in the same stores.

title: New York May Get Two New Snowicills Over Long Weekend
description: As residents of .the New York metropolitan area got ready to make the most of the long Washington's Birthday weekend, travelers faCed:the possibility of two new snowfalls, but:the National Weather Service said both.',were expected to lid minor and one might not happen at all.

title: Auctions
description: SOME of the palacequality, pettNgree French furnishings that Henry Ford 2d chose to surround himself with during one or both of his two marriages ,go on view today before their auction late next week at Sotheby Parke- Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street. The more than 100 lots include glittering ormoluencrusted furniture, exquisite gold boxes, colorful porcelains and score of fanciful decorations, treasures that the industrialist selected for his former duplex at the Carlyle Hotel or his mansion in Grosse Pointe, Mich. The sale comes two years . after Mr. Ford's separation from Marie Crisiina Vettore Austin Ford, his second wife, and is the second auction in almost five years to demonstrate Mr. Ford's Francophile taste. Mrs. Ford, however, is seeking to enjoin the sale; a decision is expected today or Tuesday.

title: ExAide Asserts Nixon RefusedKissinger and Rogers Deny Account

title: Behind Israeli Settlements Rift: Issues of Law ancl Emotion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16A debate over the legality of Israel's civilian settlements in occupied Arab territories revolves around complex issues of international TAW But it also appears to mask broader questions of whether, in a final peace assessment, Israel should be expected to. give up all of the increased security and national elbow room it won on the battlefield in ,1967 and the right to some kind of access, if not title, to biblical Palestine.

title: Broadway
description: H ELEN, a musical more or less about Helen of Troy, is supposed to open on Broadway sometime in June. Once, musicals were supposed to open early in the season, but scarcely a producer pays attention to that anymore, and now musicals open almost any time except the middle of summer. Helen began its odyssey last October at the local AMAS Repertory Theater, where Ashton Springer saw it, liked it and decided to get it to Boadway. It is about Helen back in Sparta 17 years after the siege of Troy, when her marriage to Menelaus is slipping, and she is becoming a trifle bored. No, this is not quite the same Helen that Homer was writing about.

title: Music: Igor Oistrakh
description: SOMETHING shocking happened last night at the New York Philharmonic. Igor Oistrakh played an encore. Now, that might not strike you as a cataclysmic event, since the encore is a rather common thing elsewhere in the musical world.

title: A FlingWith Harlem Dancers
description: The world is full of bright new choreographers, it seems, and all of them are waiting for that elusive smile from the establishment. Audiences at Saturday night's Brooklyn College concert by the Dance Theater of Harlem will have a chance to see the work of one of those unknowns. Royston Maldoom, however, is a new face with a difference.

title: Opera: Fredericks in Met's Thais
description: RICHARD FREDRICKS has long been one of the mainstays of the New York City Opera. The baritone, originally from Los Angeles, has a smooth, ingratiating voice, an attractive appearance and an intelligence that informs his acting. It was not surprising that he should be asked to sing with the Metropolitan Opera, and three years ago he was with the company on tour. But it wasn't until Tuesday night that he joined it in its home auditorium, appearing as Athanael in this season's new production of Massenet's Thais.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Current snow conditions notwithstanding, there is a forseeable time when we will be taking to the great outdoors in shorts and hiking boots. At least that's what they believe in Suffern, N.Y., where the fourth annual recreational vehicle and camping show has just opened at Rockland Community College's Field House. You will find homes away from home that run the gamut, from inexpensive canvas tents to a $65,000 motorized shelter described by, the sponsors as a rolling palace. Representatives from Northeast camp grounds wilt be on hand to show pictures of their facilities. And the National Campers and Hikers Association has installed some of its members in a tent city for demonstrations of new gadgets designed to smooth out life in the rough. Hours: noon to 10 P.M. today and tomorrow; noon to 8 P.M., Sunday and Monday. Admission is $2.75 ($1.50 for those younger than 12). From New York, take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to Exit 14B; follow College Road to the campus.

Fries, their daughter, Mrs. Phyllis Mason, and her children Crispin H. Connery and Arden H. Mason. Also surviving are the children of his late daughter, Mrs. Elitzabeth H. Bliss: Edward H. Northrop, Thomas F. Dixon, Roland C. Dixon, Mary Lucinda Dixon and 4hree great grandchildren. His brother, W. Averell Harriman also survives. The front dining room, really the garden floor of a brownstone, is handsome and homey, with a fireplace, dark wood, flowers, candles and a pleasant assortment of bric-a-brac. The back room, an en- closed garden with a center fireplace, is a little less pleasant because it is drafty anda Iiifseedy, much in need of refurbishing.

The audience applauds the Brooklyn Bridge, sneers at a sophisticated Manhattanite and cheers the very streets outside as they appear on the screen. Watching Saturday Night Fever in Bay Ridge is like watching Oklahoma In Tulsa.

Three residents were treated for burns and smoke inhalation. The nearest hydrant, above, was frozen so hoses, top, had to be run down block.

title: Wreckage of Sunken Pilot Boat. Is Discovered With Fifth Body
description: BOSTON, Feb. 17 (AP)The wreckage of the 50foot pilot boat Can Do, with the body of a crew member in its engine room, has been found in 14 feet of water between Tinker's Island and Marblehead Neck. the Coast Guard said today . The crew member was Charles Bucko, a forI mer Coast Guardsman, a spokesman said.

title: 2 Grants. to Honor Black Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI)The National Endowment for the Humanities an nounced today that it was awarding two grants totaling $56,669 for projects commemorating black civil rights pioneer Mary McLeod Bethune, a black pioneer of the civil rights movements. Both grants from the independent federal ,agency will go to the National Council of Negro Women. Mrs. Bethune was named by President. Robsevelt in 1935 as direc tor of the Office of Minority Affairs; I coming the first woman and first blacx to serve as a Presidential adviser.

title: Film: Those Who 'Died' Tell All
description: "Did Harry Houdini really manage to contact his wife from the world beyond, and if so, where was he?" What are "the 14 elements common to the experience related by all those who seem to have died and seen beyond?" When Louisa May Alcott and two relatives claimed that they had seen a little cloud of vapor floating up to heaven when Louisa's sister died, "could all three of them have seen the same optical illusion?" Was Dr. Duncan MacDougal barking up the wrong tree when he found empirical proof that a dog has no soulor that a person does, and it weighs three-quarters of an ounce? Do you know real malarkey when you hear it? What would you consider a fair price for the Brooklyn Bridge?"Beyond and Back," a G-rated documentary about "the death experience," poses most of the above questions. It leaves the viewer equipped to answer only the last two."Would you like to see what it's like to enter that region between life and death?" asks the film's bearded narrator, a serious-looking fellow with glasses, a three-piece suit and a big empty desk in an office lined with hardcover books. "No!" shouted the audience at the RKO Cinerama theater, where "Beyond and Back" was being shown very much out of focus yesterday afternoon.The narrator continued, undaunted. When we go, we will apparently see our own bodies from afar, through a wobbly lens that makes them look as if they were under water. We will see rays of turquoise light. A divine being will beckon to us, and he will be wearing a long white robe with red trimming. Our lives will flash before our eyes, and we will hear oohing and aahing and music of the spheres. Our departed friends and loved ones will welcome us. They will all be smiling, and they will all be blond.

title: West Virginia Miners Hope ACtion At White House Brings Work Soon
description: POINT LICK, W.Va., Feb. 17Charles Rhodes and several of his miner friends who have been on strike for nearly 11 weeks stood around the potbellied stove in a smallroadside shack in this hamlet on Campbell's Creek. Now that the soft coal industry contract negotiations were in the White House, they agreed, they would probably be going back to work in the mines before too long.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article reported incorrectly Tuesday that Edward Harrington, the United States Attorney in Boston, had not acted two years aeo on Feeeral Bureau of Investigation reports alleging political corruption. Mr. Harrington did not take office until last summer.

title: Notes on People
description: Remember those gasoline rationing coupons that the Government spent $10 million to print some years ago? Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger was asked about them at House subcommittee meeting, and he said that, although gasoline rationing was not out of the question, the Government did not intend to use the counons. Have the coupons become part of the biomass program? asked Representative Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, referring to a program in which trash could be burned for energy. Mr. Schlesinger: We are keeping them under control of our anticounterfeit department. Mr. Gore: Why, if we are not going to use them? Mr. Schlesinger: Because they are very similar to dollar bills. Mr. Gore: Can they be used? Mr. Schlesinger (resignedly): They may become part of the biomass program.

title: 3- to 5Inch Snowfall Is Forecast for Today In the Metropolitan Area if Storm Turns
description: The National Weather Service said yesterday that it could be snow and that if a storm coming up from.the Gulf States turned northward. up the Eastern Seaboard, the Metropolitan area could see a significant accumulation.

title: Deaths
description: GREENMary Ann (Seaman) at London, Ontario on Thursday, February 16. 1978. Formerly of Summit, N.J. Surviving daughters Leslie, Cary and Meredith. Funeral and creme tion in London, Ontario.

title: The Uppity House and Federal Judges
description: Whether motivated by mischief or meritwe suspect a mixturethe House of Representatives has done something constructive in passing its version of the new Federal judgeship bill. In the course of authorizing 145 new judicial positions, the House stipulated that the vacancies cannot be filled until the President has published procedures and guidelines for the selection, on the basis of merit of his prospective nominees. one exuberant member hailed the proviso as an unmistakable message to the Senate of the United States that the time for political wheeling and dealing over Federal judgeships is over. It is clearly a slap at a selection system that was nicely described recently by Attorney General Griffin Bell when he recalled how he came be a judge in 1961: I had three friendsa President and two senators.

description: The three Puerto Rican members of the New York City Council yesterday denounced the Koch administration as antiHispanic and antiminority because of what they consider its failure to place Puerto Ricans in key policy jobs.

description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 1711ime Minister Ian D. Smith reported tore progress today in talks on the, structure of the transitional government that will prepare the country for black rule, possihlv within 12 months.

title: About Newyork
description: The Madonna under glass is life sized with a head of human hair, dangling earrings and sad, flat eyes from a past when faith and hope were passions. She is mainly cherished now by shrinking coterie of fine old Italian- born women who say there is nothing like her nor the dolorously lacquered statues of St. Anthony, St. Chiro and the others from the old Sicilian days of Bleecker Street.

title: Colombia Bomb Blast Damages West German Airline's Office
description: BOGOTA, Colombia,Feb. 17 (AP)A bomb blast damaged a hotel office of the West German airline Lufthansa be. fore dawn today. It caused no injuries but routed frightened tourists from their rooms.
