description: It's O.K., I know youre trying. It's a new place. It takes time. Right? A nurse was speaking to a mental patient, in the hall at the Queens Day Treatment Center of the Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center.

title: Kidnapped Italian Is Released After Family Pays $1.1 Million
description: BOLZANO, Italy, Feb. 17 (AP)A kidnapped industrialist, Ander Ammon, was freed,today, hours after his family hand ed his abductors a ransom of about $1.1 million, the police reported.

title: Recital: Elizabeth Parcells Sings
description: Elizabeth Parcells, the soprano who was presented in a Pro Musicis recital at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. on Thursday night has a light, clear voice that is pretty in quality from its high, high top to the lower end of the range, and she has worked it to a flexible state that enables her to negotiate fioratura with ease.

title: Red Sox Sign Burgmeier
description: BOSTON, Feb. 17 (AP)The Boston Red Sox announced today the signing of Tom Burgmeier, former ltlinnesota Twins, lefthanded relief pitcher. He was the tourlh tree agent nirea oy the Red Sox since November. Burgmeier, 34 years old, also pitched for the California Angels and Kansas City. Royals since his major league career started in 1968. Burgmeier's major league wonlost record is 4936; with a 3.61 earnedrun average and 55 saves.

title: Bangor, Me., Family in Temporary Limelight
description: BANGOR, Me., Feb. 17The warm and simple house on a corner lot here that Laura and Robert Murray bought as newlyweds 27 years ago is a Bangor landmark today. It should be faMous for at least a week.

title: Detroit Routs City College
description: DETROIT, Feb. 17 (AP)Kevin Smith, a reserve, scored 24 points in 19 minutes as Detroit defeated City College, 13291, in basketball. Detroit set a school record of 59 field goals. Richard Silvera led City College with 27 points.

title: Thais Returning Refugees to Laos, Sometimes to Official Mistreatment
description: UBON RATCHATHANI, Thailand, Feb. 16For the last three months Thailand has been returning Laotian refugees to Laos, sometimes handing ,them over to the police or soldiers, who mistreat them in sight of Thai officials, the Governor of Ubon Province said in an interview here.

title: CARTER HOPES TALKS PRODUCE COAL PACT WITHIN A DAY OR SO
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17  President Carter reported today that there had been good progress in the stalled coal negotiations and said he hoped for a settlement of the 74day miners strike in the next few hours, or a day or so.

title: Woman From Washington Held By Bangkok in Explosives Case
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 17 (AP)A Washington woman and two Australians I have .been arrested after explosives were found in their hotel room. They said they were members of Ananda Marga,. an In dian religious sect mentioned in connec: tion with the bombing at a meeting of Commonwealth heads of state. in Australia, but they denied the charges against them.

title: Iowa Democrats Angered by Washington's Rules Plan
description: DES MOINES, Feb. 16Iowa Democrats, who gave Jimmy Carter the first leg up toward his party's Presidential nomination two years ago, are smoldering over what many perceive as a selfserving White House attempt to change the rules that permitted an outsider like the former Georgia Governor to gain enough exposure and credibility to win.

title: Affirms Abortion View, in Maine
description: BANGOR,, Me., Feb. 17President Carter. warned tonight that evidence of abuses would lead the Administration to tighten regulations governing the use. of Federal funds for abortions in cases of rape or incest. .

title: U.S. Reports Sharp Increase
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 17The State Department reported another sharp increase in the Cuban military forces in Ethiopia today, estimating the total at over 5,000. This would represent a rise of 2,000 over the previous department estimate, report- ed by Secretary of State Vance at a new; conference a week ago.

title: Books of The Times
description: The Glittering Prizes set me wondering about the difference between good novels and merely entertaining ones. It seems to me that a good novel is more than the sum of its parts, that when you have finished reading it you are moved by the characters to reflect on the subject of character itself. Be- cause they are so convincingly alive in a particular way, the people in good novel inevitably become advertisements for or against an idea, a form of desire, or an attitude toward experience.

title: I R. S. Drops Query On Entertainment For Corporations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Commissioner Jerome Kurtz of the Internal Revenue Service said today that the I.R.S. would not insist on answers to a new question about travel and entertainment expenses on corporate tax returns for 1977.

title: THREE ARE SENTENCED IN CIVIL RIGHTS CASE
description: SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 17A former Texas police officer was sentenced to life in prison today and his wife and sister-inla,w were ordered to serve lesser terms in a landmark case based on violation orphe civil rights of a MexicanAmerican who was killed while he was in the chief's custody.

title: Dollar Extends Slump as Gold Slips
description: LONDON, Feb. 17 (AP)The dollar slumped further today in Europe's nervous foreignexchange markets, while gold slipped marginally. Gold, a traditional hedge in times of economic uncertainty, had hit its highest level since March 1975 in London yesterday.

title: Index of Spot Commodity Prices Up to 220.8 From 219.9 in Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 220.8 from 219.9 last week.

title: Green's Victory Is Of icial,but Mrs. Abzug Is Silent
description: The Board of Elections confirmed yesterday that S. William Green defeated Bella S. Abzug. by 1,161 votes in last Tuesdays special election for Congress on Manhattan's East Side. But Mrs. Abzug still refused to concede that he had won.

description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed two of three prejury counts against Police Inspector Robert H. Johnson, a key police official in the Bronx.

title: All Out for the Empire Games
description: We climbed the fence. Roger and Paul put on their gloves to protect their fingers from the cold steel of the fence, which was about 15 feet high. We jogged toward the football field and climbed a second fence about seven feet high7 We walked along the bleachers and climbed a third fence, also about seven feet high. This led us onto thetrack. Gaining access to the Boys High School field would have been easy if the gates had been left open, but the Board Education was afraid of vandals and had ordered all fields locked after 6,P.M. Since there were no indoor facilities in the Brooklyn areas that were always available, the only way to train on a regular basis was to find a field and hope the fences didn't give out on you or the police didn't haul you off.

title: Bridge:
description: The true safety play, in which the declarer sacrifices a potential overtrick in the interests of improving his prospects of success, is a tricky subject in tournament play.

title: Recognition as a Celebrity Comes Slowly for Spinks
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 17The new world heavyweight champion moved quickly through the Las Vegas Hilton lobby but Leon Spinks was ignored by most people. His face is not that familiar yet. And he's not that big. Unless he smiles, fiasning the gap where his two front teeth are missing, he's not often recognized. But occasionally somebody turned after he passed by in his blue denim leisure suit.

title: Mexico to Release Americans
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 17 (UPI)About 50 more Americans jailed in Mexico are expected to arrive in the United States on March 6, a Department of Justice official has confirmed. This is the secand transfer under the exchange treaty between the United States and Mexico. Some 45 Mexicans imprisoned in this country also will be returned to Mexico.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17World Airways, a charter airline, announced today a proposal for a nofrills, $99 coast-tocoast air fare with minimum restrictions.

description: CAMDEN, Feb. 17Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti, in presenting a recarht 536.7 million budget to the City Council, criti. cized President Carter and Governor Byrne today.

title: Man Is Held in Hunt for Coed Slayer
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Feb. 17 (UPI)Theodore R. Bundy, an escaned prisoner suspected of 36 rapemurders in the West, was held under tight security in a Pensacola jail today while the police rummaged through his vacated room looking for clues that might link him to the slaying of two Tallahassee women students last month.

title: Carter, in New England, Predicts Approval of Mideast Plane Sales
description: CRANSTON, R.I., Feb. 17President Carter predicted at a news conference today that Congress would approve his controversial proposal for the sale of advanced military planes to Saudi Arabia and Egypt as well as Israel, and he insisted that the sale would not disrupt efforts for peace in the area.

title: Munson Is Still an Unhappy Yankee
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 17If there was any doubt that Thurman Munson would play for the Yankees this season, he more or less removed it today, indicating that he would report to the Yankee spring training ramp net week.

title: Petty Is Injured
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17Richard Petty, the most popular stock car drier in history, may have been knocked out of the richest stock car race in history today when he was involved in an accident with a pair of twotime Indianapolis 500 winners, Al Unser and Johnny Rutherford, at Daytona International Speedway.

title: Philadelphia Church Burns
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 (AP)A fireman was injured early today in a fouralarm blaze that destroyed the 70-yearold Triumph Baptist Church in the city's Nicetown section, fire officials said. The fire considerably damaged the adjacent parsonage and forced the evacuation of several homes.

title: Big Charities to Campaign for New Tax Deduction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17A clash over charitable deductions on income tax returns is shaping up between the Carter Administration and some of the country's largest charities.

description: Ricky Free's 16 points led five Columbia scorers in double figures as the Lions defeated Brown, 7570, last night at Levien Gym. The victory lifted the iLons wonlost record to 1110 overall and 72 in the Ivy League. The victory kept them two games behind firstplace Pennsylvania.

The newspaper said he did not want his name used because he did not want to worsen a controversy on the issue.

MANILA, Feb. 17 (AP)Kuo ChieHsiung. of Taiwan posted a courserecord eight-under-par 64 today and took a fourstroke lead after 36 holes in the Philippine open golf tournament. description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP)Personal income of Americans rose 0.3 percent in January, the smallest monthly increase in a year, the Commerce Department said today.

description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 17Cuban military experts in Ethiopia now number about 3,500 and are pouring into the country at a rate of more than 1,000 a month, according to Western sources here.

title: Steel Report Deadline Extended
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI)  The Treasury Department today extended until March 13 the deadline for steel importers to begin filing a special statement in connection with the new steel antidumping program. The Treasury said the Neb. Z1 starting date tor me progruin remained unchanged. The extension was necessary because of administrative problems in distributing the forms to foreign shippers, the department., said.

The ultimate aim is to reduce the need for new generating facilities.

description: DUBLIN, Feb. 17 (Reuters)Don Lauder, a businessman frustrated by an 11dayold strike by Irish telephone engineers, started using three carrier pigeons today to take messages to his factory 60 miles from Dublin.

title: `Shortage S of Nurses Is Cited in 3 Hospital Deaths

description: Gimbel Brothers Inc. announced yesterday a 47 percent increase in earnings fot its first fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31, after incurring losses in the three preceding quarters.

title: Backward Sped the Driver
description: SALAMANCA, N.Y., Feb. 17 (AP)A man was arrested today after driving backward for about 30 miles because of transmission problems. The police said. Anthony R, Lentoloa, 28 years old, of Friendship, was arrested when the police spotted him driving his pickuptype vehicle backward on the Southern Tier Expressway. Mr. Lentoloa, a swimmingpool installer, said transmission trouble prevented the car from going fonvitrd. He was charged with unsafe backing.

title: Atlantic City's First Losers
description: When the voters of New Jersey faced a referendum in 1976 to authorize casino gambling in Atlantic City, two important promises were made: Proponents of the measure pledged to keep the underworld out of the action, and to revitalize the city. No one really expected that criminals could be completely excluded from the casinos. but rejuvenating the depressed resort seemed to outweigh the risk of having a few shady figures around. Unfortunately, the promised rejuvenation seems to be hurting, rather than helping, the very people who are most in need of helpAtlantic City's poor and elderly.

title: Americo Caramuta in Piano Recital
description: Americo Caramuta is a pianist who is more interested in the spirit than the letter of the music he is playing. On Thursday night in his recital in Alice Tully Hall, his first appearance in New York since his debut in 1975, he offered a highly individual program in a highly individual way. He played the first book of preludes by Debussy, Schumann's Impromptus (On. 5) and four of Liszt's Hungarian Rhapsodies. Everywhere there were wide departures from the printed score, and yet many of the performances had a persuasiveness that more literal readings do not produce.

title: Workers Flee Grain EleVator Fire

Officials previously had at- tributed the drop to improving economic conditions and a decline in unemployment. Department spokesmen said in report that 16.1 million people were receiving the stamps last December, up seasonally from the 15.9 million figure for November but down sharply from 17.5 million in December 1976.

title: `1984 Revisited

Futurologists and editorialists are beginning their work, speculating as to the accuracy of Orwell's projected picture of that fated year: How often we hear, how still more frequently we are certain to hear, that easy catch phrase, We might already be living in the world of 1981.'

title: Carter's Mideast Diplomacy
description: President Carter's Middle East policy has been flexible but it has not been inconsistent ('Carter's Long Mideast Ordeal by Stanley Karnow, Jan. 15). The main lines of his position on the ArabIsraeli dispute were clearly defined early in his Presidential campaign, In a position paper on the Middle East, written before the New Hampshire primary, Mr. Carter insisted on Israel's security and the need for the United States to maintain good relations with the Arabs. In addition, he stated that the shape of an ultimate solution will probably involve the recognition of the Palestinian people as a nation. This balance .of emphases was also clearly stated in Mr. Carter's major foreignpolicy address in the middle of the campaign, in which he spoke of both the guaranteed right of Israel to exist and the rights of the Palestinians. Anyone who was surprised by Jimmy Carter's Mideast policy as President had not been paying attention to what he had been

title: Spain's Patron Saint At Home in Santiago
description: Just inside the main door of the Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela stands carved marble column with a deep imprint of four fingers and a thumb at shoulder height. A woman in black steps up and presses her hand into the indentations. Her lips move silently. Millions of pilgrims, completing a long journey to Santiago, have gripped this column in gratitude, wearing away the stone millimeter by millimeter. I press my own hand into the imprint and feel the seamless past. I am, though not a pilgrim, a participant in a rite practiced since the cathedral opened its doors 800 years - ago.

description: MEMPHIS (UPI)Proud Mary, a tugboat with a 73-year-old history that inspired a 1971 hit record, is no longer roltin down the river.

title: IN BRIEF
description: The economic news last week was written in black and white: too much snow and not enough coal. The strike by the United Mine Workers, who produce half the nation's coal, against the Bi- tuminous Coal Operators Association passed the 75day mark with a settlement still out of reach despite the efforts of the Carter Administration. That meant colder, darker homes and offices, shorter business hours and some plant closings in nine eastcentral states where reliance on coal for power is heavy, but other areas are sure to feel the pinch. The Edison Electric Institute, a trade organization, warned of the strike's potentially devastating effects, predicting that they would be substantial and widespread.

title: Fashion
description: Fashion trendsetters started it, stylewise young girls perpetuated it, and now even some of the world's most influential fashion designers advocate it. Mixedup dressing  the combining of several different designers items to achieve one outfit  is one of the new- est, most challenging movements in fashion today. The custom of dressing from head to heels in one designer's clothes is, in two words, old fashioned. One good example of the new, eclectic dressing was worn by Paris designer Kenzo Takada when he received

title: Sipinks Nov Must Cope With Demands of Title
description: After only eight fights as a professional, Leon Spinks is the world's heavyWeight champion. But many boxing people already are wondering he has won the title too soon for his own good, both in and out of the ring.

title: HUGHES PROPERTIES BEING REORGANIZED
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 18 In the months since Howard R. Hughes died, probate court fights have disclosed that his. empire was a creaking, badly administered collection of randomly acquired and unrelated businesses, many of which were losing money.

title: Lowering of the Income Eligibility For Day Care Is Fought in Nassau
description: A diverse collection of community organizations has assembled to contest a recent decision by the Nassau County Department of Social Services that they feel has crippled the county's daycare program.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: SOLDERING is one of the best methods for insuring a solid and permanent electrical connection when joining wires to each other, or when joining wires to terminals on appliances. It is also frequently used for many other metaljoining tasks around the house. However, to insure a strong joint that will hold up it is important that three cautions are observed:

title: A New Head of Steam for the Old Twentieth Century
description: In the 1930's a famous train called the Twentieth. Century covered the distance between New York and Chicago in 16 hours. When our show, On the Twentieth Century, arrives at the St. James to night, the journey will have taken two and a half years.

title: American League: Red Sox to Challenge
description: :Some major. changes should be a net ply's for the Red Sox, who pushed the Yilnkees hard last year. In the starting rotation, Mike Torrez should do better than Ferguson Jenkins did, and the two younger righthanders, Mike Paxton and Bob Stanley, are highly regarded:

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: WHEN officials from New Jersey and other states with heavy welfare expenditures talk about welfare reform, and especially about the Carter Administration's new proposals, their main concern is more Federal help. Lots of it.

title: CHESS
description: Grandmaster Anatoly Lein, a former Russian who now N lives in Cleveland, proved to be a hard man to defeat in the G.H.I. International Tournament in New York.

title: A Talk With Jerry Ford
description: LOS ANGELES,Feb. 18If you want to see a happy man, look at Jerry Ford. The former President, out here addres'sing a religious Congress of the Laity, seems more pleased with life in retirement than he ever did in the Congress or In the White House.

title: John Hay McConnell Weds Diana Wallace
description: Diana Wallace, daughter of Mrs. Barnet Gring Wallace of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Comdr. Joseph W. Wallace Jr., U.S.N., was married yesterday to John Hay McConnell, son of Mrs. Frank J. McConnell of Manhasset, L.J.. and the late Mr. McConnell.

title: Open Space: Color It Green?
description: IN READING the recent biography of Robert Moses, the new bogeyman of urban decay and pollution, was amazed at the courage of our New York City forefathers. To reach Bear Mountain on a summer Sunday, they had to drive their ModelT's to 125th Street, ferry across to Edgewater and then follow local streets north along the Hudson to the green grass and cool lakes at Harriman State Park.

title: The Great Electronic Dictator
description: MOST books on television, by lamenting the evils and perils of what television brings us, tend to confirm our notion that television is just another technological innovation like the telegraph, the telephone, the automobile, or radio  which needs more governmental regulation.

title: National League: The Phillies and Dodgers Aim for an Encore
description: The Phillies dominated the East in thesummer of 1977 with best record it the. league, and the best anywhere this side of Kansas City. But for the second year in a row they lost the playoff, so they are now shooting for their third straight division title and first pennant in 29 seasons.

description: Black History Week Celebration: Nigerian nerves, lectures, folk tales, films, Music; I to 4:20 P.M.; American Museum of Natural History, 79th Street and Central Park West. Voluntary admission contribution museum.)

title: Adelohi 86, C. W. Post 75
description: GARDEN CITY, LI., Feb. 18Gerry Beckles and Gordie McCrae paced Ade1phi to an 86.75 victory over C. W. Post tonight. Beckles had 21 points and McCrae 19,

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: A Montrealbased dance company called Les Ballets Jazz makes its New York debut at the Roundabout this week. Beginning on Tuesday, for a oneweek engagement, Les Ballets Jazz will set out to demonstrate the type of dance implied in its title: formal classical ballet combined with seemingly free improvisation which takes as its inspiration jazz music. The program includes five dances: Jazz Divertissement, series of choreographed exercises set to the music of Harmonium, a young French Canadian group; The Gershwin Song Book by Canadian choreographer Norbert Vesak, takirig off from piano variations of Gershwin; Homage a Duke, choreographed by Richard Jones and dedicated to the late Duke Ellington; Diary, a pas de deuX created by Lynn Raylor, director of a New York group called Dance Collection, and using music by Canadian composer Judith Lander, and Up There, a sixmovement piece by Eva Von Gencsy which is meant to be as abstract as its title.

title: 2 Yachts Dominate Lipton Cup
description: MIAMI, Feb. 18Following the con! clusion of the Lipton Cup race here . today, Mista Jumpa and Williwaw re. mained the dominant yachts of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference.

title: After Christina Onassis
description: Dipping into the rich, creamy nougat of Sidney Sheldon's prose can provide its readers with certain antic fascinations. One of mine is counting the clichs. In this department Sheldon has the consistency of Rod Carew hitting to the opposite field. He can keep it up all day long. Sheldon's women all have eyes that are dark and moist and possess bodies rich with promise. His moguls run international conglomerates that girdle the globe and, when one of them falls into a bottomless crevasse, it echoes throughout financial circles like a shock wave. I checked the time while reading his latest novel, Bloodline, and in the first hour I clocked the master going at 87 per.

title: Chronic Emotional Depression's Role in Poverty
description: WASHINGTON Missed diagnoses in sociology have implications similar to thOse in medicine: incorrect therapy, increased morbidity and continued or in oeressive illness.

title: PEOPLE
description: The announcement of the retirement of corporate chief executive is customarily dry event, more noted for what remains unspoken than for what is actually said. Last week Donald S. MacNaughton, chairman and chief executive of the.Prudential Insurance Company, rang in a change.

title: Burger and the Lawyers Find Each Other Trying
description: The weather was almost springlike in New Orleans last week. Not so the climate of the American Bar Association's 90th annual midwinter meeting.

title: Croup Wants U. S. To Raise Its Quota On Asian Refugees
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 18A citizens committee of Americans called today for the adoption of a longrange program by the United States to admit more Indochinese refugees and to speed their processing.

title: Joseph DeLise 3d to Wed Hilary Brizell in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray J. Brizell of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Brizell, to Joseph DeLise 3d:son of Mr. and Mrs. DeLise Jr. of Manhasset, L.I. The weedding is planned for May.

title: For Tinton Falls, A Ballot Backfire
description: TINTON FALLS WHEN the five polling places in this Monmouth County hamlet opened last Tuesday for a schoolboard election, voters and embarrassed election officials quickly noticed that the names of the four candidates running for three threeyear terms had not been printed on the ballots.

title: The Left, Now Leading in the Polls, Is Committed to Much More Nationalization and Wage Increases
description: PARIS - IS French capitalism at stake in next month's parliamentary elections? It is easy to jump to that conclusion. The leftist opposition alliance of Socialists and Communists, which still enjoys a slight lead in the polls, is committed to nationalizing France's nine biggest privately owned manufacturing companies as well as the remaining private banks and. in the process, to greatly increasing wages.

title: ARMY TRAINING GUARD FOR WAR READINESS
description: FORT STEWART, Ga.The miles of pine forest, the sluggish streams and `broken open country of this post are test bed for a little known but significant effort by the Army.to incorporate National Guard brigades into four active divisions and increase the combat-effectiveness of the Guard.

title: Soviet Launches Another Satellite
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (UPI)The Soviet Union has launched another Cosmos satellite, Tass, the official press agency, said today. The satellite, No. 990 in the series, was launched yesterday in circles the Earth every 101 minutes m an orbit that takes it 497 miles, 434 miles from the Earth at its closest. The satellite carries scientific equipment meant for continuation of space exploration, Tass said. It did not say whether the Cosmos carried a nuclear generator.

title: Albany Says 77 Apple Income Set Record, But Growers Say Rising Costs Cut Profits
description: WEST GHENT, N.Y., Feb. 16Apples grown in New York State produced record high income of $77.4 million last year for the state's farmers, according to reports just issued by the New York Crop Reporting Service.

description: CAIRO, Feb. 18Egypt, outraged over the murder of the editor in chief of the authoritative ,newspaper Al Ahram, Yousef elSebai, is expected to ask that his killers be extradited to face trial in an Egyptian court.

description: The.New York City Police Departnient has dismissed a 34-year-old officer who received more than $65,000 in salary while on sick report for four years and who contended that he was unable to return to work.

title: Why Westchester Survived..
description: THREE times in the last month, Long Island has been devastated by ice and snow while adjacent Westchester County has emerged relatively unscathed. Why? For one thing, the weather was dramatically different. The ice storm of Jan. 13 left a heavier coating on Long Island than on Westchester, causing more damage trees and wires. The snowfalls on Jan. 20 and Feb. 6 were from 6 inches a foot deeper on Long Island and the wind gusts were stronger.

The prosecutor, calling for strict confinement in a place where the prisoner may never again admire his image, has described Reflections as a collection of shopworn reminiscences, tattered homilies and brokendown anecdotes. Harsh words, but sound courtroom tactics require that the defense concede what cannot be denied.

Pupils have to show they can tell time, read a short set of rules for safe kite flying, write a sentence using the word quickly, and otherwise demonstrate their intellectual virtuosity.

Experi- ence has convinced them that any apartment they like will be outrageously overpriced, yet still they hunger for a chance to buy.

title: Many Small N.J. Towns Are Also in Decline

Motorists driving along U.S. 22 New Jersey will pass a string of charming bedroom towns None will have more charm than this picturesque river town whose history is entwined with that of New Jersey, but few will have more troubles, for Phillipsburg, in effect, is a small- scale Newark. And there are dozens of other small New Jersey towns in similar straits  their outer wear still smart looking but their underwear fraying.

The company's president, an agile and eager gentleman named Sid Fry, welcomed me with a ceremonial air that didn't suit him but clearly presaged that Iand few other guestswere about to witness something momentous.

However, prime winter space occasionally becomes available on the spur of the moment, a boon for those who can act fast.

It also includes the Shrine of the Book that houses the Dead Sea Scrolls, the Billy Rose Sculpture Garden and other worksall elements of what is collectively called the Israel Museum.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: WE had just been shopping at Waldbaum's, my wife and I. It was during their evening hours and the store was not very busy. As we pushed our cart past the dairy section, through the frozen foods and into fruits and vegetables, I became aware that a band was playing. .

title: Art Ran in the Family
description: THREE generations of American sculptors in an unbroken line of succession from grandfather to grandson in a single family may seem slightly unAmerican  or, at least, subversive. Yet the Calder family is not without its precedents. In their irrepressible drive toward art, the Calders are outnumbered only by that other American phenomenon, the Peale family of Philadelphia, beginning with the 18thcentury painter, inventor and archeologist, Charles Wilson Peale. Peale, three times married, took to giving his innumerable progeny such encouraging names as Rembrandt, Raphaelle, Rubens or Titian Peale, with a high percentage of success. He also instructed his brother James in the art of painting; James, in turn, encouraged his three daughters. The industrious Peales created America's first artistic dynasty.

title: New York New Music Ensemble Appears at Carnegie Recital Hall
description: There was a new music concert Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, and as is often the case at such events the best piece was by the bestknown composer. But unlike many such events, the whole concert was pretty enjoyable.

title: DIVORCE RATE IN SOVIET SAID TO TRIPLE SINCE 60
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (Reuters)The divorce rate in the Soviet Union has tripled since 1960, mainly because young women, often better educated than their husbands, are in revolt against household drudgery, the journal Literaturnaya Gazeta reports.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThe Labor Department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration has traditionally been one of the most criticized and battered agencies of the Federal Government, with virtually every act greeted with howls of anger from industry and ample helpings of scorn from labor. Lately, however, the howls have subsided to dyspeptic mutters, and the scorn has given way to expressions of praise and admiration.

title: Soviet 1, ,2 In Women's Nordic Race
description: LAHTI, Finland, Feb. 18 (AP)-Zinalda Amosova of the Soviet Union captured he women's 10kilometer crosscountry race and Mathias Buse headed an East German 1, 2 finish on the 70meter jumping hill as the world Nordic ski championships opened today.

title: Design
description: For the Henrys, the 200-year-old house was, in many ways, a dream come true. They had been looking for a place to restore for some time and, in fact, had been eyeing the John Goddard house for a year before it came onto the market. The house, which is named after the man who built it around 1750, was in bad shape. The roof leaked, water had severely damaged the kitchen, and the original layout of the house had been altered to form separate apartments. But the Henrys fell in love with it  or at least with what they sensed it once had been  and they jumped at the chance to restore it when it eventually came up for sale.

title: College Pitcher Stirs Disputes in Japan Over Pro Draft Rule
description: TOKYO, Feb. 18  The adamant refusal of a 22-year-old collegiate pitcher here to sign with the professional baseball team that drafted him has sparked a nationwide legal and sports debate that even reached into Japan's parliamentary chambers this week.

title: REQUIEM FOR RADIO CITY?
description: Producer Lee Guber thinks it would be wonderful to see Liberace drive his RollsRoyce across the vast stage of Radio City Music Hall as the Rockettes highkicked behind him and the Dancing Waters spritzed in colors in back of them. Robert White- head, another producer, wants the hall as an elegant showplace for a series of vaguely envisioned spectaculars. Lewis Rudin of the Association for Better New York and Phyllis Cerf Wagner, who is married to a former Mayor of New York, see the theater as home base for a yearround Las Vegastype show that, says Rudin, we could stop for Christmas, stop for Easter, stop for the Emmies, stop for the Oscars. Ron Delsener feels Radio City would be terrific for rock concerts and wouldn't be at all unhappy if its 6,200 seats were filled every night with shrieking groupies.

title: Big Ditch Debate
description: THE future of the Panama Canal has become the most controversial issue in American foreign policy since the Vietnam War. There is something distinctly odd about this. Only a fraction American trade passes through the waterway. Most Americans have never seen the canal and would probably be hardpressed to locate it on a map. Yet millions of them apparently care passionately about who controls it. A cartoon in The New Yorker captures this anomaly. Two men are standing in a bar, the first saying to the second: What's wrong with me? For thirty years I never gave a thought to the Panama Canal. Now I can't live without it. Three new books address the Canal question. They illuminate it in varying degrees, but none fully explains its prominence.

title: INTERVIEW
description: EUGENE MICHAEL thinks he occupying one of the hottest seats in Fairfield County. The source of the heat is the controversyMr. Michael's word is uproarcaused by the 700page health plan being put forward by the Southwest Connecticut Health Systems Agency, of which he is the executive director. What worries Mr. Michael,  he says, is that some of the controversy may be caused by misconceptions about the plan.

title: Soviet Portrays Itself as Peacemaker in Ethiopia
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18In Washington the Soviet Union is being portrayed as pouring oil on the flames in the Horn of AMca, transporting thousands of Cuban troops and sending In advisers and milltary supplies to help the Marxist regime in Ethiopia.

title: What's Doing in EL PASO and JUAREZ
description: INTERNATIONAL CITY - Lying beneath a pass in the southern end of the Rocky Mountains, El Paso faces Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, from the north side of the Rio Grande at the western edge of Texas. In the early settlement of the region El Paso and Juarez were a single community called El Paso del Norte (Pass of the North), most of which was concentrated on the south side of the river. In 1848, as a result of the Mexican War, the territory north of the river became part of the United States, but for years the business districts of the two cities grew almost as one. The larger population (about 500,000) has remained in Juarez, but El Paso lags only slightly behind (about 400,000), and its cluster of 20story buildings gives it a skyline that towers over its more sprawling and serene Latin neighbor. The forces of urban renewal have also come into play, producing a $20 million Civic Center modern in scope and distinctly Southwestern in design, with a theater shaped somewhat like a huge sombrero and an exhibition hall that has graceful twostory arches reminiscent of adobe construction. The center is one reminder that El Paso, which calls itself the International City, has not forgotten its early heritage.

title: Import Battle: Nuts n Bolts
description: WASHINGTONThe deadline for the decision had arrived. It was Friday,. Feb. 10, and the President was sched, uled to leave by helicopter from the South Lawn at 3 P.M. for a weekend at. Camp David, but not even his closest advisers knew how he would call it.

description: As if to make up for the dearth of new Broadway musicals, there has been spate of recordings that are either based on old musicals or drawn from old musicals. The most innovative of these albums is tne Smithsonian American Music Theater Series, which is attempting to put together original cast albums of musicals from the days before there were such things.

title: GARDENING
description: IS there anything good about snow? As far as plants are concerned, everything. Snow is nature's best insulator, a sort of thermal blan ket. Anything underneath the inches of white is completely protected.

title: African Dissenters
description: NGUGI WA THIONG'0 - the most significant East African writer - has been detained for questioning by the Kenyan police. According to his wife, the police escorted him from his home Limuru, near Nairobi, on December 31, after searching his house and confiscating nearly 100 books. The local police have told her that Ngugi is in good hands, though for more than a week after his arrest, she was given no information about his whereabouts. Although Ngugi is only one of an increasing number of African writer/intellectuals arrested by their governments the past decade (in addition to his literary career, he is also the chairman of the department of literature the University of Nairobi), his case is a particularly depressing one, since this is the first time that the socalled liberal Kenyan Government has arrested one its intellectuals.

title: N.H.L. Helmet Issue: Debate Continues

title: A Return to Punishment
description: AFTER a century during which it was the dominant purpose of the criminaljustice system, rehabilitation is being critically reappraised. Since 1870, when the American Prison Association proclaimed that reformation, not vindictive suffering, should be the purpose of the penal treatment, rehabilitation and its organizational structuresindefinite sentences, treatment programs and release on parolehave dominated the postconviction process.

title: Lefties Have A Certain Tone
description: The study of brain lateralization long ago showed that, unlike righthanded people, some lefthanders have speech centers in their left brain hemispheres only, but many have some speech ability in both. A psychologist has now found that mixed lateralization seems to confer at least one advantage: Such people excel at pitch memory.

title: Unfair Exchanges
description: THIS is one of those rare occasions on which it a pleasure to send up a flare. Many books are written these days about the human plight. Few have as much to teach as this one. Charles E. Lind- blom is Sterling Professor of Economics and Political Science at Yale. His new book is based on relentlessly accumulating evidence that life on this planet is headed for disaster. Politics and Markets is not, however, another examination of the challenges that have by now become familiar, or another clarion call to turn the tide by this means or that. Rather, as Lindblom declares at the start, his book is for those who believe that politics and economics will turn out matter. As such, it is a searching examination of the options before us, the ways in which humanity may collectively cope with the trials ahead.

title: 20 SUSPECTS SEIZED IN ULSTER BOMBING
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 18The police picked up 20 Irish Republican Army suspects in sweeps at dawn today following the killing of at least 12 people in the bombing of a crowded restaurant east of Belfast last night. Among those arrested was Gerry Adams, a former commander of the I.R.A.'s brigade here who was released from prison last fall. The organization's current campaign of violence began three months ago.

title: Frost, Eliot, Thomas, Pound
description: THERE is poetry, and there is the poetry scene. Poetry is highly respectable; the poetry scene isn't. Poets bitching at other poets, rivalries and jealousies, intrigues and connivings, competition in the popularity stakes, the how and the why of some reputations being advanced as others are diminished by malice or calCulated indifference- this is the poetry scene, and a very squalid scene it is, and no wonder that fastidious readers of poetry shudder at it, and pretend it doesn't exist. It does, though; and because every poet there ever was wants to be known and loved by his fellow mortals in his own lifetime, the poetry scene is where the poet lives most the time when he isn't writing poems. A poet's admirers may ignore the poetry scene; the poet himself can't afford to.

title: Beth Israel President Honored
description: Charles H. Silver, president of Beth Israel Medical Center, has been given a gold medallion by the institution for 50 years in its service. Mr. Silver, who is in his 90th year, has been a trustee since 1928 and was executive vice president. for 10 years before becoming president in 1947. Mr. Silver was president of New York City's Board of Education from 1952 to 1961.

title: Television as a Truly Visual Aid
description: Doctors have noted that more and more people are taking responsibility for watching their own health, Women screen themselves for breast cancer, both sexes stain their teeth to see if they are brushing properly, and some even buy home instruments for checking blood pressure. Soon, if three Stanford University ophthalmologists have their way, people may be able to test their eyes at home by watching a televised exam that has been tested at a clinic in Palo Alto, Calif. Its inventors hope soon to try it out by closed circuit in industries and then on a local station in small community.

The President said during stop here that he could not travel to the Pacific area this year, so he had asked the Vice President to make the trip as his representative.

The Civil Part of the court has long been the object of derision by the Brahmins of the bar. It has also been criticized by bar associations. Now it is the focus of criminal investigation into casefixing by District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan.

title: Rowe of Celtics Sidelined
description: BOSTON, Feb. 17 (UPI)-A. Boston Celtics forward, Curtis Rowe, who had been bothered for the three weeks with a sore knee, will be out of action for at least two weeks. Team doctors determined today that Rowe had suffered an irritation of the soft tissue beneath the left kneecap.

title: Hackensack Is Now A Hub for Antiques

Clustered around the intersection of Anderson and Linden Streets, the stores have become the principal antiques center of Hackensack, a historical city first settled in 1640 and where there is now a boom in highrise apartment houses and fashionable stores.

But last week, the deal was dealt a heavy blow.

title: WhiteCollar Crime:
description: CRIME definitely pays, says Lieut. Lester Forst, head of one of the State Police units dealing with whitecollar crime. In dozens interviews with both state and Federal lawenforcement and regulatory officials, lawyers and professors. there were few who volunteered statements as em- phatic as that of Lieutenant Forst, chief of the statewice Organized Crime Investigative Task Force. But their opinion generally was the same: that Connecticut is poorly equipped to fight whitecollar crime and has had no measurable success at it.

title: PrehistoriC Astronomy Was Pretty Good Science

The cult was strong enough to sell out Mr. Harnmill's four sets Friday night and last night at the Other End, which constituted his New York solo debut.

title: Montreal Markets: Gourmet's Guide
description: The old Bonsecours Market on Montreal's waterfront, built in 1845, is an immense building topped with a great gold dome like a bombe mold. On this wintry day the only people in sight, are two elderly men huddled on a window ledge, sharing a tattered blanket. But the blowing snow shapes itself into ghostly shoppers, thronging the busy stalls of yesterday, and under the wail of the wind you can almost hear the calls of vendors and the early morning clatter of carriages on the cobblestones.

title: Band Members Are Convicted
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb 18 (Reuters)Four members of Led Zeppelin, the Brit ish rock group, were convicted yesterday of battery in a concert here last July. title: Soul of a Black Woman
description: THE Rev. Harry Middleton Hyatt, an octogenarian Episcopal priest whose fivevolume classic collection of black myth, Hoodoo, Conjuration, Witchcraft, and Rootwork, more than amply returns an investment of 90 years research and the lion's share of his personal fortune, asked me not long ago what had become of another eccentric collector whom he admired. I think, he reflected for a few seconds, that her first name was Zora. It was an innocent question, made reasonable by the body of confused and often contradictory rumors that make Zora Neale Hurston's own legend as richly curious and as dense as are the black myths she did so much to preserve her cldssic anthropological works, Mules and Men and The Voodoo Gods of Haiti and which stand as compellingly ambiguous metaphorical matrices her fictions.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: MY AUTOBIOGRAPHY, by Charles Chaplin. (Simon & Schuster/Fireside, $4.95.) MY LIFE IN PICTURES, by Charles Chaplin. (Grosset & Dunlap/ Today Press, $7.95.) These two memoirs of the controyprsial genius of the silent screen have been reissued in new paperbound editions scarcely six weeks after his death. In the first, originally published in 1964, the little tramp recalls his triumphs and anguishes from his childhood in the slums of London to his retirement ip Switzerland. The early chapters are moving, the latter sections fascinating yet often shallow and selfjpstifying. There are more than 100 poor-to-fair blackandwhite photographs. Pictures - 319 pages of them - are the raison d'tre of the second volume, first issued in 1975 as a coffeetable book for the fans. Posters, film clips, cartoons, sketches and photographs from Chaplin's own archives span his whole career colorfully but not very analytically; most dwell on the now legendary Hollywood years.

title: Jackson Browne Changes His Tune To Showmanship
description: The qualities that have made Jackson Browne so well-respected are by no means the qualities that have made the current Running on Empty his fastestselling album. Mr. Browne's reputation is that of a sensitive, incisive songwriter, yet only two of this album's 10 songs are nis own compositions. His latest concert performances, especially on his most recent tour of the East, were widely thought to be disappointing, and yet this is a live album, his first. Mr. Browne has never established himself as powerhouse singer, but Running on Empty depends heavily upon his delivery of other people's material. And although he has until now been known as lone wolf who takes things very, very seriously, Mr. Browne is here content to sing, with a great show of camaraderie, about nothing more momentous than the life of a rock-and-roll band on the road.

title: New York Without City Opera? Unthinkable!
description: 0 n the surface, it will look like just another opening night at the New York City Opera. When the spring season opens on Thursday with La Traviata, there will be Violetta, the frail courtesan, feverishly entertaining her demimondein friends and putting the glassware to the test with coloratura outbursts. In fact, however, the City Opera will be entering what could be the most dangerous few months in its 34year history. Both financially and artistically, the City Opera is in such a disturbed and confused state that for the first time . in many years one can hear an ominous old question being asked in musical circles: Does New York really need more than one major opera company?

title: Headliners
description: In the end, Muhammad All could not shake free of his 36 years. He had it over Leon Spinks in weight, reach and without question  talent. But a 36-year-old boxer is an old man, and the hubris of Ali, thinking he could fight a determined 24yearold as though he were the same age, cost him his heavyweight title in a split decision last week. Ali remained the consummate showman almost to the end: He danced in nearly every round, and in the early going he made faces for the crowd. In the late going, the changes in his face were involuntary. There may be more fights ahead for him, but perhaps never as champion. Thus ends an era of a man who was much more than the dominant prizefighter of the postwar period. He was a symbol of black assertiveness since the 1960's. As such he rankled much of ,white America, and not just because he was loud.. In 1964, as Cassius Marcellus Clay Jr., a Christian, he wrested the title from Sonny Liston. Instead of humility, he offered defiance, the news that he had become a Muslim who called himself Ali. It was too much, especially for many sportswriters, some of whom still cannot write his name without putting an a.k.a. after it. He became a symbol to underdeveloped nations around the world with his protest against the Vietnam war in 1967, when h refused to be inducted into the Army. It was no idle gesture. Outraged boxing authorities stripped him of his title even before the courts got around to convicting him of draft evasion. It was not until 1971 that the United States Supreme Court overturned the conviction, and not until 1974 that Ali recovered the heavyweight crown. Throughout, he never doubted his own worth or hesitated over hyperbolic expressions of his selfesteem. I'm fighting for people all over the world, he once said. If I win, people all over the world's going to win. If I lose they're all going to lose. Ali was chastened, even gracious, in defeat last week. But he will soon weary of diffidence. There is not only the lure of becoming the first heavyweight to win the titlethree times, butthe millions to.be added to the $60 million he has earned in almost two deca6s of fighting. He could use the inciney. For all that he has made, he has retained relatively little because of enormous expenses.'A rematch is likely: Leon Spinks, a reallife Rocky, is willing, but he also knows what he is up against. When Ali entered the ring in Las Vegas, Spinks joined in the applause. He recognized a role model; after the fight, he was quick to supply Aliesque doggerel. He's still The Great est,' the new champiqn said. 'But I'm the latest.'

title: The Consensus That Died at Tet
description: It is ten years since Tet, the Vietcong offensive that became the psychologically decisive battle of Vietnam. The occasion has evoked a rush of memoirs and analyses of the war, raising interesting questions about the battle of Tet and about the wisdom and justice of the American venture in Indochina. The most profound consequences of Tet, however, are now plain. No matter who really won the big battle, it exposed a new American consensus: that the price, of rescuing Vietnam from Cominunism had outrun the benefit and should not be paid. It thus destroyed the consensus for containing Cofnmunism almost anywhere our leaders thought necessary, at virtually any price. It destroyed the willingness to let the Presidency manage containment with minimal interference by the public and Congress.

Others insist that only by appointment can disinterested members, protective of the general good; be selected.

title: CRIME
description: Idi Amin, the African dictator who is larger than life, has played a part in various adventure stories . in the last few years. Naturally, his figure is somewhat disguised and the usual disclaimer appears: Any resemblance.. .. But nobody can really disguise an Idi Amin; he is sui generis, the only one of his kind, and as such he is instantly recognizable. Thus the portrait of the black dictator in EXCELLENCY by David Beaty (Morrow, $8.95) is based on one person and one person alone.

title: Literary Francophile
description: WHEN the scholar pauses and takes time off to write his autobiography, what shall he record? How shall he, portray himself? How will, he want to be remembered? What style shall he adopt? What about his work? Out of modesty, his previous books remain in the background. Here, the reader shall meet the man, or more precisely, be introduced to the lover of French literature, a lover with all the expected traits: avidity, joy, ecstasy, jealousy. But the reader is immediately made aware that the Journal of Rehearsals is not really an introduction to la vie privee of Wallace Fowlie. Rather, it is a chiaroscuro presentation of a guarded sort in which the principal star is the French language itself, which was to become his studied and rehearsed approach to life.

title: Doris Sassower Stirs Rights Controversies

Today, while many of her radical proposalstaxdeductible childCare expenses, repeal of the ban on abortions, and expanded work and education opportunities for womenhave become accepted in law in state andFederal jurisdictions, Miss Sas. sower is still raising eyebrows in legal circles with her controversial ideas.  There are still many inequities in our laws that have to be corrected, said Miss Sassower, a nationally known. attorney, writer and champion of human causes, and frankly, it is my greatest happiness to help people, especially women, who are doubly handicapped in our Society, achieve equality.

title: I, Haldeman
description: Nothing involving Watergate seems to go smoothly. Now we have The Washington Post's secondrate,burglary of H. R. Haldeman's memoir of a thirdrate burglary on the eve of its publication by Times Books, a subsidiary of The New York Times. Mr. Haldeman refers to these rival newspapers as one of the four major power centers that seized the sword President Nixon handed them to destroy him. (A hostile Congress, bureaucracy and intelligence community are the other three.) Mr. Haldeman may yet learn from this experience what he seems not to have learned in all that time at the White House and in jail: There can be no effective conspiracy so long as Americans are chaotically competing, fairly and otherwise, for information, influence, power and profit.

Hagan scored the last 8 points for St. Bonaventure and finished with 18 points. Greg Sanders scored 19 points and became the leading career scorer for the Bonnies with 2,075 points.

title: Economy Models Race Indoors
description: ELMSFORD

title: Nastase Finds New. Foe: A Firm Woman Umpire
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 18Ilie Nastase has been playing tennis Allis week on land once occupied by the Agua Caliente Indians. The looale seemed appropriate, for agua caliente means hot water, and the bad boy of tennis has been in it again, up to his racauet.

title: MENTALCARE PLAN PROGRESSING ON L.I.
description: FREEPORT, L.L., At 16 years of age, she is marginally functional, but she learning the alphabet, starting to read words, and her personal hygiene has Mtproved. And that, says a clinical psychologist, is great.

title: The Satisfaction Boom
description: with their lot seems extraordinary. After all, even the great middle class is well advertised these days as believing itself burdened down by onerous taxes, inflation, an omnipresent Federal bureaucracy, the high costs of medical care and college tuition, and the unfair demands of the welfare classes.

title: Hopes for Displaced
description: WESTCHESTER residents concerned about the county's 64,000 displaced homemakers are looking to Washington, where important legisla- tion is pending. Among those concerned is Marguerite Kornfield Davis of Ossining, a leader in the effort for passage of the New York State Displaced Homemakers Act, signed into law last August by Governor Carey.

title: A Woman's Romance With the Wild
description: If you are thinking of canoeing into the wilderness to renew a waning sex life or commence a romantic attachment, don't bother. I once had the same idea: that the mountains and lakes would mean romance, which showed only how little I knew about life in a tent. Maybe some rock climbers (the ones who chuckle sheepishly about their nude ascents) are rugged enough and relish the , hardships enough for a lot of loving in the wilderness, but for me, and the people I have traveled with, an incipient knocking of the knees and the fear ready to drop to the pit of the stomach like stone are always present in enough quantity to inhibit most sexual desires.

title: If You Go...
description: ...to market in Montreal, public transportation is convenient and cheap; the fare for both city buses and the Montreal Metro, one of the cleanest subway systems in the world, is 50 cents. Both give transfers. From Peel Street station, near Dominion Square, in the heart of the city, all of the markets are accessible from the Atwater-Honord-Beaugrand Metro line.

title: Meyer Levin: A Novel and a Talk
description: LET it never be said that Meyer Levin lacked chutzpah. The door cracks open on the first serious bargaining over Middle East real estate in a decade and up walks Mr. Levin with a fat book about how the realestate argument got started in the first place. The Harvest is Mr. Levin's novel about the founding of Israel, plus chunks of Jewish history, folklore and world events that preceded it. What Mr. Levin lacks in literary art he makes up for in ethnic ardor. It works sometimes.

title: Penn State 75, Pitt 68
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 18 (AP)Steve Kuhn scored 19 points, 4 of them in overtime, to help Penn State gain 7568 upset victory over Pittsburgh tonight.

title: Michigan Prosecutor Tests 700Year Rule
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 18. (Reuters)A local prosecutor is challenging a 13thcentury British count ruling, followed by many states as common law, that a criminal defendant cannot be charged with murder if the victim died more than a year and a day after the attack.

title: Georgetown 55, St. Peter's 38
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI)  Al Dutch scored 12 of his 14 points in the second half tonight to help Georgetown gain a 5538 victory over St. Peter's.

title: Carey Is Criticized For Not Submitting 50Cent Fare Plan!
description: In an ongoing battle over aid to mass transit, environmental groups have! accused Governor Carey of reneging on a'promise to submit a plan detailing how to save the 50cent fare in New York City. The Natural Resources Defense Council and other groups earlier this month filed papers in Federal District Court in Manhattan asking Judge Kevin T. Duffy to force the state to file a progress report on masstransit financing.

title: A Boom Is On In OfficeBuilding
description: HACKENSACK AFTER a twoyear slump, the construction of office buildings in northern New Jersey seems to be on the way toward becoming a miniboom. Construction has started or plans have been drafted for nearly a million square feet of office space in the area, which has seen the demand exceed the supply in recent months.

title: Spain to Allow Gambling ,CasinosIn Hopes of Increasing Revenues
description: MADRID, Feb. 18 (UPI)The Government has granted permits for 18 casinos, the first legal gambling in Spain in 54 years, in an effort to bring in more revenue from tourism.

title: Deciding on One Degree Longer
description: Faster is not necessarily better. Reducing the traditional fouryear stretch to earn a bachelor's degree sounded like a good idea when the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education began promoting it in 1971, but a report last week showed that the socalled timeshortened degree has lost favor.

title: Defense Secretary Brown Is ReExamining Its Role in a Nuclear Age
description: WASHINGTON - Without a respectable Navy, alas America, John Paul Jones said in 1776.

description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 18A United States delegation left Ethiopia today after discussions an improving relations.

description: One day Ruth Rosen's telephone will ring and a voice, possibly quizzical and probably blurred with age, will an? nounce: Hello, Ruth, this is Maimie. I want to tell you the end of the story.

title: Caribbean Camping: Sharing Nature With Its Creatures
description: The Caribbean? We'd been there. Camping? We'd done it. Resort vacations? We'd tried them. But not all in one. Here was a chance to combine all threeat a new luxury camping resort billed as a thoughtfully conceived, eco- logically balanced private community of tentcottages perched above the most secluded beach in the U.S. Virgin Islands National Park.

title: Spofford School Guard's Arrest In Rape at Center Draws Criticism
description: A 14-year-old inmate at the Spofford Juvenile Center in the Bronx was raped in a bathroom of the center's school by two other youths while a Board of Education security officer allegedly locked the doors for privacy and walked away, according to the police. The police said that two Spofford boys, aged 13 and 14, were arrested and charged with the rave on Jan. 19.

title: Ohaugnessy Wins 1,000
description: FORT WORTH, Feb. 18 (AP)Niall O'Shaugnessy, Arkansas premier distancejunner, was named outstanding athieta of. the Southwest Conference indoor track and field championships last Pight, but the Houston team captured the title with 93 points.

title: Brazil Declares Computer Independence
description: RIO DE JANEIROAfter months of negotiation with the world's largest computer companies, Brazil has finally decided who will develop a flourishing national market for minicomputers: Brazil itself.

title: Deaths
description: HAAS-Florence. Beloved wife of Dr Joseph, devoted mother of Monroe and Rickle, adored grandmother of Debbi, Lisa and Andrew, dear sister of Milford, George and Marvin Fen ster. Service Sunday, February 19th, 11:30 AM The Riverside', 76th St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Police Officer Kills an Assailant on Upper East Side
description: A decoy police officer shot and killed m assailant on Friday night and woundpd another during a robbery attempt on the Upper East Side, the police reported yesterday.

title: At Least, Koch Has Promises
description: When we last left Ed Koch he was still tied to the railroad tracks, with the Washington express barreling toward him. In the latest cliffhanging episode, a couple of heroes appear in the distance.

title: Classical Nightmare: The Lost Plane Ticket
description: Linda S. and nine of her college classmates were on the way to South America to spend their junior year abroad. At the checkin counter at Kennedy International Airport in New York, where she had been taken by friends, Linda discovered that she did not have her ticket. Although she produced lots of identification and could establish beyond any doubt that she was a bona fide member of a group in which everyone else had a ticket, airline officials said they could not carry her unless she paid $500 to replace hers.

title: Council Fosters World of Dance
description: NOW in its 26th year, the Westchester Dance Council continues to cast a watchful eye on dance activity both within and outside the county. Its work ranges from promoting the public's interest in dance to providing specialized programs for professionals to aiding parents in selecting the proper instruction for their children.

title: Beatrice Kinney Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Sherwood Kinney of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I:, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beatrice Kinney, to Douglas Dwight Broadwater, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Broadwater of Indianapolis. A wedding in June is planned.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: While the nearterm difficulties of the economy, arising principally from the abominable weather, have: been attracting the lion's share of attention, there are a number of deepseated problems that many analysts say should be drawing much closer. scrutiny and concern.

title: Chad ReSumes Ties With Libya
description: LONDON, Feb. 18 (Reuteis)Chad has' agreed to resume normal diploMatic rela tions with Libya, suspended since Feb. 6 after Chad accused Libya of aiding:, rebels in the northern part of Its territory, the Libyan news agency reported today. Chad has also agreed to Withdraw: a complaint against Libya that it lodged with the United Nations Security Council.

title: J. T. Gianis Fiance Of Elizabeth Smith
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edgar P. Smith of Morristown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Pichard Smith, to John Thomas Gianis. Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Gianis of Summit, N.J.

title: Notes: An Arts Center to Celebrate Charles Ives
description: 0 n July 4, 1974, Leonard Bernstein and Michael Tilson Thomas conducted the American Symphony Orchestra in a concert in Danbury devoted to the music of that Connecticut city's most famous musical son, Charles Ives. The oc- casion celebrated the centenary of nis birth, and it drew 7,000 people to the Danbury Fairgrounds, where the concert was held.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY.

title: Office. Art: Buyer, Beware
description: A corporate executive strode purposefully into a Manhattan art gallery not long ago and announced that he was looking for something to adorn his board room. He quickly settled on a group of slightly abstract Japanese prints depict. ine what he took to be annles. It was only after their delivery to his office that he discovered he'd been looking at the prints upside down. The apples turned out to be distaff derrires, and the prints are now hanging in the executive washTOOM.

title: U.S. RABBIS SAY SADAT IS FIRM ON SETTLEMENTS
description: CAIRO, Feb. 18 (AP)A group of American rabbis who met President Anwar el-Sadat today said that he appeared to be disappointed and disheartened at the pace of Middle East peace efforts with Israel.

title: Kathryn Slote Engaged To Gerald M. Kleinbaum
description: Kathryn Wendy Slote and Gerald Myron Kleinbaum, New York lawyers, plan to he married March 26 at the home of the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Slote of Pound Ridge, N. Y., who have announced the engagement.

title: Helen Estill Is Affianced
description: The Rev, and Mrs. Robert Whitridge Estill of Dallas and Quogue, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Haynes Estill, to Stephen William Foote, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Foote of Riverside County, Calif. The wedding is planned for March 28 in St, Michael and All Angels Episcopal Church in Dallas, where the Rev. Mr. Estill is the rector. He also serves as the priestincharge of the Episcopal Church of the Antonement in Quogue in August each year.

title: Flyers 4, Red Wings 2; PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 (UPI)Two goals by Bill Barber within a span of six minutes in the final period today helped the Philadelphia Flyers beat the Detroit Red Wines, 42.
description: The victory helped the Flyers pull to within 4 points of the New York Islanders, who lead the Patrick Division of the National Hockey League.

title: Moving to Plug the Island's
description: THE State of New York has been caught with its navigation law showing, and the exposure could be costly$600,000 a year in fees from boat registrations and about $200,000 a year in Federal aid for boatsafety programs.

title: HISPANICS INFLUENCE ON LOSANGELES GROWS
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19Along Broadway, once the most fashionable shopping boulevard in downtown Los Angeles, there are more brown faces these days than white or black ones. Most of the signs on Broadway are in Spanish, as are most of the songs that blare from, loudspeakers at record shops like the Discotiendas Fiesta.

title: Salami and Cheese Put In a Kosher Sandwich
description: When Representative Elizabeth Holtzman first started investigating complaints about the B'nai Torah Institute's operation of a summer feeding program, a Queens woman telephoned the Lon gresswOman's assistant, Elizabeth Lang, to describe the kosher food she was receiving from the Queens Assistance Program, a B'nai Torah affiliate.

title: Carey's TaxCut Plan and Aid to the Poor
description: The taxreduction program in Governor Carey's proposed budget for fiscal year 197879 . has generated a fundamental debate, the outlines of which are just beginning to emerge, on how best to help the poor in New York State. The issues are not unlike those that have been raised with respect to the taxcut program President Carter proposed to Congress last month. But the New York debate is more accessible to the ordinary citizen because the numbers are more manageable, the personalities involved are closer and, therefore, sharper, and the consequencesplaces like the South Bronx and fluctuations in business activityare more visible here.

title: School District in Brooklyn Plans Classes for Midwinter Recess
description: Most of New York City's one million public school pupils will be on vacation this week as the schools close down for a midwinter recess intended to save fuel costs.

title: Laurie Rotman, Student, Is Married to Allen Levy
description: Laurie Rotman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Rotman of New York, was married yesterday in the Lincoln Synagogue to Allen Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Levy of Montreal. Rabbis Lavy Becker of Montreal and Herschel Cohen, assistant rabbi at the synagogue, performed the ceremony.

title: Sonics 108, Bucks 103
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 19 (AP) Gus Williams scored 23 points, and Wally Walker scored 7 of his 17 points in the last 5:23 to lead the Seattle SuperSonics to a 108103 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks today. Fred Brown had 22 points for the Sonics.,

description: The B'nai Torah Institute, which in five years expanded from a small Brooklyn religious school into a huge, multimilliondollar socialservice agency, is the focus of three Federal investigations into possibly improper relationships between it and senators, representatives and the United States Department of Labor.

description: BLOOMINGTON, Del., Feb. 19Gretchen Spruance of Bloomington captured the United States women's squash racquets championship for the third consecutive year by winning the final today at the Wilmington Country Club by 1 point in a fifth game.

title: A Deal That Divides Rhodesia
description: Ian Smith,. Rhodesia's Prime Minister, has always sought to divide his enemies with sometimes ingenious, always desperate efforts to preserve the domination of Rhodesia's 6.8 million blacks by 263,000 whites. And once again, as so often before, it seems that he has succeeded. This time, however, the fruit of his effort may be civil war.

So formidable was this mountain Lochinvar that he got himsell elected Governor, the first Democratic GoVernoc of Idaho in 26 years, on ar environmentalist platform in a state that is gungho for development. And ther he got reelected with 71 .percent of the vote. He was the unanimous choice his fellow Western, governors for the jot of Secretary of the Interior in the new Carter Administration.

description: DENVER, Feb. 19 (AP)  David Thompson scored 29 points as the Denver Nuggets overcame a Boston rally and defeated the Celtics, 118115, in a National Basketball Association game today.

description: LA CORUNA, Spain, Feb. 19 (Reuters) Fire possibly caused by faulty wiring swept through a wing of General Francisco Franco's former summer home near this northwestern port, officials said today. The medievalstyle home was donated to the Spanish leader in 1938 during the Spanish Civil War.

Dewey Thruway (Interstate 87) to Exit 16, in Harriman. Take Routes 6 and 17 to Monticello and then Route 17B to White Lake. Proceed south on Route 55 to Eldred.

description: Robert Harrison, the creator of Confidential, Whisper and other magazines, died at his office in Manhattan on Friday. He was .73 years old and lived in the Demonic Hotel at 59th Street and Park Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Boxers on Canvas
description: Sculptures and paintings of boxers, including works by LeRoy Neiman and George Bellows, as well as prints by Currier and Ives, go on exhibit Wednesday at the Emily Lowe Gallery at Hofstra University Hempstead, L.I. The show, called The Art of Boxing, draws from the collecton of the late J. Terry Bender, who was director of special collections for Hofstra's library. The show runs through April 1 but will closed Fridays and Saturdays. Admission is free. The hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Mondays and Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. on Tuesdays and Wednesdays, and 1 P.M. to 5 P.M. on Sundays.

title: Sporting Gear
description: As far as table games go, golf has usually taken a back seat to baseball, football, hockey, soccer and basketball, at least in realism. No more. Golf Forreal features tees, fairways, rough, trees, traps and rolling greens made of textured cloth and plastic. The course is the size of a PingPong table. The most realistic touch is the golfer figures, which swing various clubs in sending the ball soaring through the air. The game is valuable as a teaching aid, since the principles a slice, a fade, a draw or a hook can be demonstrated by adjusting a figure's stance and swing. The polyurethane ball rolls on fairways, sticks to slopes and can be putted. The large layout includes four golfer figures, 96 balls and two sets of clubs for $359. There is a small version (tee, green, shooter, five clubi and 24 balls) for $16. Order directly from Snorts Forreal, Osseo. Minn. 55369.

title: A Greasenik's Time for Fun
description: It was just 20 years ago and Fidel Castro was still out in Oriente Province, but his guys were making mischief in Havana to harass the Government of Fulgencio Batista, such as setting off a fire bomb in the clearing house to burn up a weekend's accumulation of bank checks. Here for the auto race? asked the steward on the morning plane from Miami as it landed at Aeropuerto Rancho Boyeros. Better go home. They've kidnapped Fangio and the race is off. It sounded like a joke, but it wasn't. Juan Manuel Fangio of Argentina, five times world champion driver, had been grabbed by. Castro's men on the eve of the Gran Premio de Cuba on the Malecon, the boulevard along Havana's seawall. Racing cars on a public street. a pretty good working definition of criminal negligence, but the Government was determined not to let a lot hairy revolutionaries spoil the show. The race started tardily, but it started.

title: Golf: Morgan Victor As Nicklaus Falters
description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., Feb. 19 If Jack Nicklaus is tied for the lead with a player of relatively limited experience, and no one else is in contention with only four holes to play, and someone is going to blow up, it isn't going to be Nicklaus. Right? Wrong. Gil Morgan, the 31-year-old Oklahoman who has been on the pro tour only five years because he became an optometrist first, proved to be the steadier player under pressure today and won the 52d annual Los Angeles open. He clicked off seven straight pars on the back nine while Nicklaus doublebogeyed the 15th and bogeyed the 16th, and the tournament ended with Morgan at 278, six under par and $40,000 richer; Nicklaus at 280; Forrest Fezler at 283 and no one else under par.

description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 20 (UPI)Kentucky shot 66 percent from the floor and five of its players scored in double figures as the Wildcats defeated Alabama, 9734, tonight in a Southeastern Conference game. Jack Givens led the Wildcats with 22 points and Rick Robey had 18, Reggie King of Alabama was the high scorer with 24.

title: Settlements Debate Opened by Israelis Cabinet Is Divided
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 20Amid signs of divisions within the Israeli Government, the Cabinet began a debate today on the controversial policy concerning Jewish settlement in occupied Arab lands.

title: OHIO OFFICIALS SEEK LINK IN ABORTION CLINIC FIRES
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 20 (AP)Officials are checking for a possible link between the weekend firebombing of a Cleveland abortion clinic and a $200,000 fire at a Columbus abortion clinic last month.

title: Notes on People
description: Betty Smith, press secretary for Senator Muriel Humphrey, said the widow of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey was distressed over reports that she is still in mourning and not functioning in her new duties as a Senator from Minnesota. That hasn't been true since the day she was sworn In, Mrs. Smith said, noting that Mrs. Humphrey has met with reporters, conferred with the Senate leadership and sits on two key committees. She is also the cosponsor of four bills and two amendments to the Panama Canal treaties, which she favors. Senator Humphrey is expected to make her first floor speech in the Panama Canal debate, her spokesman said, and plans this week to reintroduce the HumphreyHawkins full employment bill, the most important piece of unfinished business left by her husband. The debate on the Canal treaties resumed yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: The life master pair championship, which concluded the Greater New York championships at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday, was won by Jim Hilton and Joel Friedberg of New York, who formed an extempore but successful partnership. They both have solid tournament records: Friedberg recently won the national mixedpair title in Atlanta.

title: Iona 70, St. Peter's 57
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 20Freshman center Jeff Ruland scored 23 points and led Iona to a 7057 victory over St. Peter's tonight. Iona (168) led 3423 at the half, but the Peacocks closed to within 4643 with 12:40 remaining in the second half. Iona, however, dominated the rest of the game.

title: Gift to Neediest Aids Weighbors'
description: The inspiring spectacle of how compassionate people working together can do so much for the benefit of humanity was singled out by one contributor to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Koch Retreats From Charge Banks Blackmailed City to Get Deposits
description: Mayor Koch retreated yesterday from his charge, made Sunday, that banks had blackmailed New York City into depositing city funds in interestfree accounts to prevent the closing of bank branches.

title: For New Annie Cast, Rehearsal Could Mean Tomorrow's Success
