description: IAN CAMPBELL

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney. reports that there are indications of recommendations soon on reform proposals on the governance of American corporations. A broad examination has been under way for more than a year by Government agencies and other groups. Page D3.

title: Garden Show Blooms in Poughkeepsie
description: A touch of spring arrives today in Poughkeepsie, some 70 miles north of Times Square, with the opening of a threeday plant and garden show at the MidHudson Civic Center, the newest cultural facility in the Hudson Valley.

title: Precious Metals Up; Dollar Drops Again In Futures Trading
description: The value of the dollar plunged again yesterday and sparked a recovery in .both precious metals and foreign currency futures. On the Comex, gold futures advanced $2.70 to $3.30 an ounce, or twice the losses posted in the previous session.

title: Management
description: Bulletin boards in company offices and factories are being watched more carefully by workers these days. At least that is the indication given by the latest survey of personnel practices conducted by the Bureau of National Affairs, a private publisher and research organization with headquarters in Washington.

title: Film: Rivette's Celine
description: THE riddles and delusions of Jacques Rivette's Cline and Julie Go Boating are much more accessible than the enigmas of his Out One/Spectre. Cline, the later movie, has the dotty Cline and Julie Go Boating was shown at the 1974 New York Film Festival. The following review, written by Nord Sayre on Oct. 8, 1974, has been excerpted. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio, Broadway and 66th Street. logic of dreams, and the characters rational solemnity while talking nonsense does succeed in evoking Lewis Carroll.

title: Cypriot Leader Says He Recognizes Why. Sadat Severed Ties
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 23 (AP)President Spyros Kyprianou of Cyprus said today that he understood the justifiable psychological state that ledPresident Anwar elSadat of Egypt to sever diplomatic relations with his country after the shootout between Cypriot forces and Egyptian commandos at Larnaca airport.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1978

title: A Prudent Defense Budget
description: After a year of elaborate study, managed by Defense Secretary Harold Brown, the Carter Administration has projected its view of the nation's future defense needs. In two lengthy public documentsand two secret ones, leaked by criticsit proposes fundamental changes that are stirring heated controversy. We find the proposals, and Mr. Brown's approach, refreshing and reassuring.

title: Art: An Anthology Of American Nudes
description: THE lack of a solid tradition in the rendering of the nude, while not unique to America, is nevertheless usually treated as such and blamed most often on the country's puritan foundations. Other factors may be invoived, including climate, social history and possibly even economics, but puritanism continues to be the popular explanation, leaving as it does room for delusions of some progress and hopes for more.

title: ALBANY ACTS TO BAR DYSON ROLE IN ADS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23Brushing aside the threat of a veto by Governor Carey, the Democratic controlled Assembly today approved a measure barring the State Commerce. Commissioner, John S. Dyson, from using his voice, signature, name or facemasked or unmaskedin advertisements wooing business to New York State.

title: Books of The Times
description: AT a quick glance, which is what I gave it when it first came my way late last year, Sylvia Tennenbaum's first novel, Rachel, the Rabbi's Wife, appears to be a rather conventionally written story about Net another dissatisfied woman who longs to be independent and creative. Its heroine Rachel Sonnschein, dreams of becoming a famous painter as she begrudgingly goes about. her duties as wife to a Long Island rabbi. So I filed it away for some rainy day when I might be in the mood for a sequel to Marjorie Morningstar.

title: Stan Kenton Makes a Comeback
description: Stan Kenton will bring his orchestra to New York tonight for the first time since he suffered what he refers to as my tragedy last May.

title: U.S. Puts Pressure on Operators To  Accept Less Stringent Coal Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  President Carter told Congressional leaders today that some form of Federal compulsion would be invoked if the increasingly disruptive coal strike was not settled this weekend.

title: Jersey and New York Denied Federal Disaster Aid
description: President Carter yesterday rejected requests by New York and New Jersey for declarations of major disaster that would have cleared the way for millions of dollars in Federal assistance to help pay for damage caused by recent snow, ice and wind storms in the two states.

title: A Brooklyn Family's Long Struggle Ends in Tragedy
description: It was a family that struggled to keep their child, who was blind, deaf and mute all 12 years since birth, with them and developing. And it was a family in which the father, Robert T. Rowe, 48, didn't have a job and glumly had to see his wife working.

title: Bridge:
description: Few New York experts are willing to travel far for a tournament, unless it is a national championship. But several of them break this rule once a year and travel to the Mexican Nationals, which despite the name is a regional tournament according to the standards of the national organization.

title: SPORTS AGENCY WINS RIGHT TO TAKE OVER GARDEN STATE TRACK
description: TRENTON, Feb, 23The State Senate gave final legislative approval today to a state takeover of the Garden State Park race track, and Governor Byrne signed the measure into law a few minutes later.

title: A Fountain of Youth Somewhat Polluted
description: For the 1,800 people living In Clinton, N.J., on the south branch of the Raritan River, it was big news page 1 news. The Dannon yogurt folks, impressed by the youthful appearance of the townspeople of Clinton, were coming to town to shoot a pool of commercials to replace the now famous spots featuring the sprightly ancients in Soviet Georgia.

title: Bill Nero, South Carolina Farmer Born at the End of the Civil War
description: LYNCHBURG, S.C., Feb. 23 (UPI)Bill Nero, who was born six days after Robert F. Lee surrendered at Appomattox, died yesterday.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: New Face: Larry B. Scott, Centered Young Hero
description: Larry B. Scott, who is drawing praise these days as a 13yearold junkie in A Hero.Ain't Nothin but a Sandwich, is especially convincing in the scenes where a look of sublime ecstasy washes over his face after he has taken heroin.

title: A Fight on Flu Planned by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 23The first longterm national policy on flu immunization was announced today by Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. Its goal is to help states more than double the number of persons in highrisk categories who are protected against the disease.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: (millions of dollars) Daily Averages for the weeks ended:

title: Around the Nation
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Feb. 23 (APA state medical examiner, saying he did so with regret, concluded today that Richard Lapchick, a political activist, scratched a racial slur into his own abdomen before reporting to the police that he had been attacked.

title: London Continues Aid
description: LONDON, Feb 23The Chrysler Corporation's British subsidiary has again become a costly dependent, despite the unprecedented 1975 agreement by the British Government to underwrite most of its losses.

title: Concert: Oberon Led by Eve Queler
description: IT HAS been repeated ad infinitum that the only re2son for the neglect of Carl Maria von Weber's Oberon is the inadequacy of tha libretto. Eve Queler and the Opera Orchestra. of New York gave a concert performance of the seldomheard opera lastnight in Carnegie Hall, and cemented the point. The libretto of Oberon is indeed a farrago of nonsense.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Feb. 24, 1978 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Radio
description: 6.9 A.M., WQXR: Bright and Early. George Edwards.

title: Publishing: The Great Perkins
description: THE most respected editor in American literary history in this century, Maxwell Perkins of Charles Scribner's Sons, is finally getting a book he would not have approved in his lifetimea biography of himself. Unlike some of today's editors, who do their main work in the visible watering holes of Manhattan, he was selfeffacing.

title: Further Losses Forecast
description: DETROIT, Feb. 23The Chrysler Corporation today reported a loss on its operations in the fourth quarter of last year amounting to $49.7 million, or 82 cents a share, and said that it expected also to report a deficit for the first quarter of this year.

title: SENATE PANEL APPROVES TAX CREDIT FOR TUITION
description: WASHINGON, Feb. 23 (AP)The Senate Finance Committee today approved legislation that would allow a tax credit of up to $500 a year for each tuitionpaying student in college or vocational, elementary or secondary school.

title: Five Big Events
Dance: The New and Old By Junior Ailey Troupe
description: IT is hard to imagine anyone's not being charmed by the Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble, which is appearing through Sunday at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Directed by Sylvia Waters, the ensemble offers young dancers opportunities to perform works, borrowed from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and it also commissions its own new works.

title: Czechoslovak Dissent Group  Formed
description: VIENNA, Feb. 23 (Reuters)  Nine Czechoslovak dissidents have formed a group to press for the release of three signers of the Charter 77 humanrights manifesto who were arrested in Prague, migr sources said today. In a letter to President Gustav Husak and Prime Minister Lubomir Strougal, the nine asked for information about Vaclav Havel, playwright; Pavel Landovsky, actor, and Jaroslav Kukal, factory worker.

title: Music: Mozart Requiem
description: THE word inexhaustible is often glibly applied to masterpieces, but it certainly pertains to Mozart's Requiem. There are so many unresolved and probably unresolvable questions about the work, which was completed by other hands after his death, that anything approaching a definitive performance is out of the question. A good case could be made, for instance, for presenting the Requiem with the forces appropriate to a service in a small church, which is, what Richard Westenburg did at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night. which was completed by other hands after his death, that anything approaching a definitive performance is out of the question. A good case could be made, for instance, for presenting the Requiem with the forces appropriate to a service in a small church, which is, what Richard Westenburg did at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night.

title: Topics Collision Course
description: Some New York City ambulances have installed police and fire radios to help them get to the scenes of accidents faster. The objective is not merely humane; the hospital whose ambulance arrives first is likely to wind up with the patients and the payments. Ambulance attendants from competing hospitals have reportedly been haggling over victims even as a fire rages. Although the burst competition seems to have caused disarray in the city's 911 emergency ambulance system, it promises to help fill hospital beds. When competing ambulances crash in their rush toward catastrophe, there will be that many more patients availableassuming that anybody remains condition to carry them away.

title: Long Beach Welcomes Plan on Mental Patients
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., Feb. 23For the last eight years, residents of this former resort colony have been complaining about the concentration of released mental patients here, about people who were discharged from the giant state psychiatric hospitals in nearby Suffolk County and who, it is charged, were dumped into the decaying beachfront hotels along Broadway with nothing to call their own but their welfare checks and a daily dose of powerful tranquilizers.

title: Pepsico's Quarter Net Up 17.9%; Earnings for Year Increased 22%
description: Pepsico Inc., currently involved in the $126 million proposed acquisition of Taco Bell, Inc., realized profit increases of 17.9 percent in the fourth quarter and 22 percent for all of last year, setting records, the company reported yesterday. All major lines of business except sporting goods contributed to the increase, with gains in soft drinks particularly pronounced, Donald M. Kendall, chairman, reported.

title: Gem and Mineral Show Opens at Statler Hilton
description: Hundreds of thousands of gems and minerals will be on display and for sale this weekend at the Gem, Mineral and Jewelry Show at the Statler Hilton Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street. Rock hunters can also attend lectures on the cutting and engraving of precious stones.

title: Phil Mahre Takes Giant Slalom Title
description: WILMINGTON, N.Y., Feb. 23Phil Mahre, the star of the United States team, won the national giant slalom championship today, topping Eric Wilson by eightone hundreths of a second. Bill Taylor of Orchard Park, N.Y., was third.

title: 12 Oaks Is Gone With the Wind
description: On an old MtroGoldwynMayer lot in Los Angeles, the house used for exterior views of the Twelve Oaks mansion that belonged to the family of Ashley Wilkes in the film Gone With the Wind is demolished with a tractor. The lot, sold by M.G.M. in 1973, will be the site of a

title: TV STATION EXCHANGE FACES POSSIBLE SNAG
description: A year ago, Mr. Allbritton, under pressure to dispose of WJLA because he also owned The Washington Star, and in need of cash to.keep the deficitridden afternoon newspaper in operation, arranged to exchange WJLA for a station in Oklahoma City.

title: DISTILLATE OIL SUPPLIES OFF 11 MILLION BARRELS IN WEEK
description: Supplies of distillate oil fell by 11.4 million barrels during the week ended Feb. 17, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. As the winter cold continued across the country, distillates used for homeheating oil, dropped to 190.4 million barrels in the latest week from 201.8 million in the week earlier.

title: BILL HINNANT, ACTOR, 42; PLAYED ROLE OF SNOOPY
description: Bill Hinnant, who played Snoopy in the 1967 Off Broadway musical You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown, drowned last Friday while vacationing in the Dominican Republic. He was 42 years old and lived at 240 West 98th Street.

title: Carter Makes Choices On Serveral U.S. Posts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)President Carter announced today that he was nominating H. William Menard, a professor of geology at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La Jolla, Calif., to be director of the Geological Survey. He would succeed Vincent E. McKelvey, who has resigned.

title: 2 RAIL LINES GETTING UPLIFT BY THE STATE
description: TRENTON, Feb. 23The state is buying 10 used locomotives to upgrade the troubleplagued North Jersey Coast Line railroad, used by shore commuters to get to work.

title: Heat Is Turned On for Cardozo Quintet, the Sizzling Queens Champion
description: The city's schools are closed for winter recess this week to conserve fuel, but the heat Was, turned on yesterday in Cardozo High School's gymnasium, enabling the Queens school's basketball team to scrimmage against Holy Cross High and slay hot for the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs.

title: The Pop Life
description: MUSIC may be the universal language, but the languages of songs are not universal at all. In other words, it is only instrumental music that is universal"although here, too, cultural heritages get in the way of truly universal appreciation. But as soon as you add a text to a tune, you limit its complete understanding to those who comprehend the particular language involved.

title: Rangers Win, 62; 3 Goals for Hickey
description: The longsuffering fans of the New York Rangers were treated to one of their club's best games of the National Hockey League season last night in Madison. Square Garden as the Rangers trounced the Chicago Black Hawks, 62.

title: FITZGERALD PHILLIPS, 84; EXPAROLE COMMISSIONER
description: A funeral service will be held today for Fitzgerald Phillips, a member of the old threemember New York City Parole Commission for nearly 18 years and the city's first black Deputy Commissioner of Correction.

title: Iranian Payment Is Minimized
description: G. William Miller, President Carter's nominee to succeed Arthur F. Burns as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said yesterday that despite all the fussing around, there is no evidence that would detract from my being confirmed by the Senate.

title: Newest and biggest Boxing Czar
description: Pound for pound, Jack Prenderville, the new chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, is the biggest. boxing commissioner since James A. Farley Sr. He stands 6 feet 5 and has the heft to pluck up Leon Spinks with one hand and Muhammad All with the other and knock their heads together. Whether he also has the clout to restore New York to its former eminence as the fountainhead of the Sweet Science remains to be seen, but he promised yesterday that he would give it his best shot. This was at lunch in the

title: Business Records
description: Thursday, Feb, 23, 1978

title: McDermott Staff Given Immunity
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI)  A Federal grand jury has granted immunity to present and former employees of J. Ray McDermott Inca in an investigation of the company's alleged foreign payoffs and domestic pricefixing, Federal records showed today.

title: WESTWAY ARCHITECTS SELECTED BY STATE
description: New York State's Department of transportation, moving ahead on the controversial Westway project, has selected an innovative, younger firm of architects and an older, established firm of landscape architects to prepare a design for the $1.16 billion covered highway.

title: Mathilda Hollitscher, Freud's Oldest Child, Was London Resident
description: Mathilda Hollitscher, the oldest of Sigmund Freud's six children, died Monday at her home in London after a long illness. Mrs. Hollitscher was 90 years old.

title: To Be Plain in Texas Is a Fate Norse Than Death
description: DENTON, Tex.  Shirley Cothran Barret wears a gold medallion of the state map around her long neck, and on it a diamond stands for her hometown. Denton is, figuratively, a diamond in the rough, a collection of frame cottages and ranch houses and shopping plazas and college buildings outside of Dallas where Shirley grew up, went to school and got married. In between she went away for a year, to be Miss America of 1975, but when the year was over she came right back more beautiful and poised than ever to where she'd come from, and she settled down. I guess, she says, I'm just smalltown inside.

title: GeddesUllman Advance In Court Tennis Doubles
description: Robin Geddes and E. F. Ulmann of New York gained the semifinal round of the United States amateur court tennis doubles championship by defeating the Philadelphia fatherson team of William T. Vogt and William f. Vogt Jr., 63, 64, 65, yesterday at, the New York Racquet and Tennis Club.

title: Redmen's Day in Court
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 23How much control should American Indians have of their own reservations? How can 19thcentury treaty rights be reconciled with contemporary conditions of state government, land ownership, commercial regulation and legal jurisdiction?

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, Feb, 25 OCEANIC (Home). Left PortauPrInce Feb. 21; du?? 8 A.M. al W. 55th Street.

title: Line Forms as Hamlet Goes on Sale in Peking
description: PEKING, Feb, 23 (Agence FrancePresse)  A hundredyard long line formed outside a Peking bookshop today when a Chinese edition of Shakespeare's Hamlet went on sale.

title: Chinese Party Chiefs Say Nation Is Back to Normal
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 23The Chinese Communist Party's Central Committee concluded a sixday meeting in Peking today with a communiqu stressing that China had retUrned to normal after years of disruption but offering few clues to the gathering's lengthy discussions.

title: Chrysler Says City Has Refused Offer To Check On and Fix Koch's Newport
description: A spokesman for the Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that New York City officials had declined an offer for company engineers to check on and repair Mayor Koch's cityowned 1974 Chrysler Newport, which the Mayor labeled a death trap after the brakes failed.

title: Who's on First, What's on Second: Singles Scene Guide
description: Boy meets girl. boy buys girl a Bloody Mary. Girl asks boy his occupation. Boy asks girl her telephone number. It's all on the East Side of Manhattan, the singles Gold Coast, but part of the scene is on the rocks, and part comes with a twist. Forget, for a moment, familiar First Avenue, the land of the midnight fun, and move on to Second, relaxed and reviving.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSAnne. Beloved wife of Maurice L. Dear sister of Frank and Joseph Kalisch. Loving aunt. Services at BoulevardPark West 115 W. 79th St. Friday at 10 AM.

title: REGENTS VOTE TO GIVE MAYOR BIGGER ROLE IN RUNNING SCHOOLS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23Giving support to Mayor Koch's drive for a stronger role in running the city's schools, the New York State Board of Regents proposed today that the Mayor be given the power to appoint a majority of the members of the city's Board of Education and have the last word on the selection of a school chancellor.

title: 700,000 French Votes Abroad Stir Bitter Election Dispute at Home
description: PARIS, Feb. 23The votes of French citizens living abroad have become the subject of a strong legal challenge by the opposition in the increasingly fierce legislative campaign.

title: Calls for Rules On Residency Rekindle Debate On Old Issue
description: Steven and Denise Yodice live in a small Freeport, L.I., apartment with their 2yearold daughter. For the last few years they have held back on moving to a larger apartment, opting to save enough money for the down payment for a.house somewhere else on the Island.

title: Grumman Jobs and Profits Threatened in F14 Crisis
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Feb. 23For nearly half a century, Grumman. has been a stalwart name in the aerospace field. Its highly regarded products have met the demands of war in aerial combat and the challenge of space in man's flight to the moon.

title: For Children
description: WINTER CARNIVAL, sponsored by the Brownston? Learning and Day Care Center, from 1 to 5 P.M. on Sunday, with three floors filled with fun for children and their parents, including performances by the Clear Light Puppet and Dance Theater, and Tavia the Magician at 1:30 and 3 P.M., also, ethnic foods, a flea market, games, crafts and other entertainment, at 128 West 80th Street (near Columbus Avenue). Puppet show, $1 admission; playroom, SO cents; otherwise, admission to the center is tree. Call 8741341.

title: For the State Library, an Epilogue's a Prologue
description: ALBANYLeonard Di Chiaro and Charles Rothe are checking 25,000 books out of the state library every day this week, but they have no intention of reading any of them.

title: Belgrade Conferees Are Preparing Drafts of Short Final Communique
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb, 23 (Reuters)Western and East European countries at the stalemated conference on EastWest cooperation worked today on their versions of a final declaration for the meeting, but voiced little hope of achieving anything concrete.

title: Hal Borland, Chronicler of the Seasons, Is Dead at 77
description: Hal Borland, writer and naturalist, died late Wednesday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness from emphysema. He was 77 years old.

title: CARL PAUL JENNEWEIN, 87, NEOCLASSICAL SCULPTOR
description: Carl Paul Jennewein, the widely known NeoClassical sculptor whose  work began when he was 13 years old, died Wednesday night in his residence at the Larchmont (N.Y.) Club. He was 87 years old.

title: Bail for Joan Little Is Retained Pending Extradition Appeal
description: Joan Little was allowed to remain free on bail yesterday pending her challenge of Governor Carey's order for her extradition to North Carolina.

title: New Face: Nell Carter
description: NELL CARTER, a short, buxom, bubbling woman with a singing voice that has the raw, penetrating quality of a steeltipped drill, is one of the reasons that Ain't Misbehavin', an evening of Fats Waller's songs at the Manhattan Theater Club, 321 East 73d Street, is such a lively and exhilarating experience.

title: Article 1  No Title
News Summary
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1978

title: Corporation Affairs
description: DALLAS, Feb. 23 (AP)The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest manufacturer of computers, said it filed a patent infringement suit today against the Xerox Corporation, the copier giant.

title: Evangelical Shift to Pluralism
description: LOS ANGELESA major turn toward greater pluralism in the American evangelical boom was signaled here last weekend at a conference as remarkable as was lowkey.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Yonkers Exacta Suspected
description: Officials of the State Racing and Wagering Board are conducting a fullblown investigation into the eighth race at Yonkers Raceway on Feb. 16, a race in which the exacta payoff was a surprisingly low $36.60.

title: Lynn Harrell, Too, Has a Few Musical Friends
description: Some years ago Isaac Stern started a trend by appearing in a series of concerts called Isaac Stern and Friends. The eminent violinist wanted to play more than just the standard repertory and with more than justone collaborator. His friends, of course, were pretty much his peers. The concerts were a brilliant success and have been imitated by other artists since.

title: St. Francis 87, Catholic U. 80
description: Nestor Cora scored 26 points and Alex Vega had 20 as St. Francis College defeated Catholic University, 8780, last night.

title: Canal Accord Foes Begin Senate Drive To Block Approval
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI)Senate opponents of the Panama Canal treaties opened a drive today to thwart ratification of the pacts by attaching several amendments unacceptable to Panama.

title: Narcotics Dealer Says U.S. Agents Pressed Him on Panamanian Aids
description: PANAMA, Feb. 23 (UPI)  A convicted Panamanian narcotics dealer said today that United States narcotics agents had once put pressure on him to implicate Panamanian Government officials in drug trafficking.

title: PRESIDENT PROPOSES MERGER OP PROGRAMS IN FIGHT ON JOB BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  President Carter sent to Congress today a plan to consolidate Federal programs to combat job discrimination.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Columbia Swimmers Lead Met. Championships

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Commissioner Sworn In
description: Mayor Koch swore in Augustus A. Beekman on Wednesday as Fire Commissioner, the second black to hold the position in the department's 113year.history. The Mayor praised the Commissioner's Professional and personal background, adding that guts is one of his most important qualities. Commissioner Beekman succeeds John T. O'Hagan after having served in the department for 31 years

title: Men's Styles: Another Vote for Comfort
description: The design of women's clothes has proceeded. so far in the direction of total comfort that a woman has only herself to blame if she feels constricted. Men, now that's another story. They're a real challenge.

title: Forced Fingerprnting Upheld
description: BOSTON, Feb. 23 (AP)Federal authorities may use as much reasonable force as necessary to fingerprint a suspect or make the person appear in a lineup, the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit has ruled. The appeals court yesterday upheld a ruling by District Court Judge Walter Jay Skinner in the case of Lawrence F. Maguire, 27 years old, of Charlestown.

title: Art: 19thCenturyFrench Printing
description: THE history of the visual arts in France in the second half of the 19th century is so rich and so paradoxical, it is made up of so many separate and diverse elements, that even todayin the second half of the 20th centurywe have not fully charted its complex course.

title: Stage: OHorgan's Tempest
description: IN the 1960's, before he became known as a director of extravagant Broadway shows marked by their  conspicuous consumption, Tom O'Horgan staged plays Off Ott Broadway, mostly at La Mania, with imagination and economy; His production of Paul, Foster's Tom Paine, for example, was an epic on a shoestring.

title: For the State Library, an Epilogue's a Prologue
description: ALBANYLeonard Di, Chino and Charles Rothe are checking 25,000 books out of the state library every day this week, but they have no intention of reading any of them.

title: Broadway
description: Whatever happened to that Gershwin Oh, Kay! revival?

title: Vesco, Fugitive U.S. Financier, Seeking Costa Rican Citizenship
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 23 (AP)Robert Vesco applied for citizenship in this Central American country today, one day after Presidentelect Rodrigo Carazo Odio said the fugitive American financier would have to leave by May 8. Mr. Carazo Odio was elected earlier this month and takes office May 8.

title: Workshop Series Begins At Women's Art Center
description: Workshops in porcelain making this weekend will begin a series of six workshops at the Women's Interart Center, 549 West 52d Street.

title: Monetary Policy Injury Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The White House, pressingthe ndmination of G. William Miller as Federal Reserve Board chairman, is getting assistance from the prsent chairman, Arthur F. Burns, who is warning senators that delay in confirmation is weakening the central bank and hurting the conduct of international monetary policy.

title: Advertising
description: There has been a considerable flap in television and agency circles lately about the drop in the HUT (households or homes using television) levels. It has been enough to cause Lawrence S. Fried, vice president and group supervisor of network negotiations at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, to thoroughly study the matter. And he concludes, We are being misled.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies;

title: Jones Cards a 67, Leads In Florida by Two Shots
description: LAUDERHILL, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP)Grier Jones, who holed a 184yard 5iron shot for an eagle, fired a fiveunderpar 67 today and took a twostroke lead after the opening round of the $225,000 Inverrary Classic, which was played in chilly and windy weather.

title: Press Group Accepts Member
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI)The Standing Committee of Correspondents voted unanimously today to accept the application of Lester Kinsolving of the McNaught Syndicate for membership in the Congressional press galleries. Mr. Kinsolving had submitted a letter with his application agreeing to abide by gallery rules. Last year, the committee found that Mr. Kinsolving had violated the rule against paid promotional activity and would not approve his application because it contained no promise of future compliance with the rules.

title: Calls for Rules On Residency Rekindle Debate On Old Issue
description: Steven and Denise Yodice live in a small Freeport, L.I., apartment with their 2yearold daughter. For the last few years they have held back on moving to a larger apartment, opting to save enough money for the down payment for a house somewhere else on the Island,

title: Restaurants
description: IF there is anything short of spring itself that can lift us out of midwinter doldrums, it is the discovery of a new, charming and deliciously promising restaurant. That, in brief, is a just about perfect description of the twomonthold Restaurant Raphael on 54th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. This small, bright, polished and sophisticated setting, with just 40 seats and a dcor that suggests a French country chateau in miniature, seems destined to become a posh, chic jewel of a place, albeit a jewel with a Tiffany pricetag.

title: Notes on People
description: The Congressional career of Wayne L. Hays, a powerful House Democrat from Ohio, ended in 1976, after allegations that he hired Elizabeth L. Ray as a staff member for the sole purpose of having her as his mistress. He resigned after Democratic leaders forced him out as the chairman of two committees. Mr. Hays has been living in his hometown of Saint Clairsville, and yesterday he announced that he would try a political comeback, seeking a seat in the Ohio Legislature left vacant by the retirement of A. G. Lancione, a veteran of the State House of Representatives. Mr. Lancione said: I think Wayne is asking for a lot of trouble. He's going to be the laughing stock of this area. But Miss Ray, who is in New York studying acting, said, I wish him success.

title: Russian Flu Scarce In New York Area
description: Throughout the metropolitan region the incidence of socalled Russian flu this season has been far from epidemic.

title: 2 Theorize Moon Still Wobbles 800 Years After a Meteor Hit It
description: The moon may still be wobbling front a colossal meteorite impact 800 years I ago.

title: OTB to Offer $1 Triple Box
description: The New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation will introduce to its bettors on Tuesday another exotic betting device, the One Dollar Triple Box, It will be offered for all New York tracks Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga  and all outofstate tracks handled by OTB.

title: Bad Weather Held Gain In Sales by Big Chains To 9.5% During January
description: Severe winter weather and blizzard conditions in much of the country in January held that month's sales among the nation's largest chains to a 9.5 percent gain over the yearearlier month,

title: A 3d Admits Fraud In Deals With U.S. For CheckCasher
description: Robert M. Sparago, a former general counsel of the U.S.N. Company, pleaded guilty in Manattan yesterday to a Federal charge of conspiracy to defraud the Small Business Administration.

title: ExCommunist Upsets Spanish Party With a Book About Its Past
description: MADRID, Feb. 19A 342page memoir bearing the innocuous title Autobiography Federico Snchez has exploded like a delayedaction bomb in the Spanish Communist Party and has thrown its secretary general, Santiago Carrillo, on the defensive.

title: Art: Small Pictures By Julius Bissier
description: TWENTY years ago the waterfront of the little town of Ascona in Italianspeaking Switzerland was one of the most rewarding places to go to in Europe if you liked the company of painters, poets and novelists who might before 1933 have been found on the terrace of the Romanisches Cafe in Berlin, Some of them had really been there. Others were handtailored for the role. Either way, there was much to be heard in at least four languages as the white wine came and went in very small pitchers and the lake steamer lumbered this way and that.

title: State Agency Is Seeking to Lure Commuters to Buses
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, Feb. 23  Faced with a continuinp decline in bus ridership and the cost of millions of dollars in subsidies to keep most New Jersey bus companies operating, the State Department of Transportation took a first step today in an attempt to lure the commuter out of the automobile and into the buses.

title: The Borland Style: The Night
description: Editorial from The New York Times, Dec, 6, 1951

title: Brown Wins 3 Titles in Florida Horse Show
description: OCALA, Fla., Feb. 23Buddy Brown of North Salem, N.Y., one of the mainstays of the United States Equestrian team, did exra duty at the Golden Hills inernational horse show today and won classes in the jumper and hunter divisions.

title: Monetary Policy Injury Seen
description: WASHINGTON., Feb. 23The White House, pressing the non ination of G. William Miller as Federal Reserve Board chairman, k getting assistance from the present chairman, Arthur F. Burns, who is warning senators that delay in confirmation is weakening the central hank and hurting the conduct of international monetary policy.

title: Now Spinks Chases A Champion's Image
description: The heavyweight champion of the world had his picture on the front page again yesterday, this time because he showed up at a discothque.

title: Exploring the World Of the Fulton Market
description: Some came, quite literally, to see the city in a different light. Others, photo buffs, to capture the characters. A few were lured by a sense of history. But none of them bought fish.

title: Nettles, a Contented Yankee, Reports to Camp
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 23Despite early indications to the contrary, maybe everything will be all right in the Yankee family this year. After all, Graig Nettles arrived in camp today and reported that he was happy in general and at peace with George Steinbrenner in particular.

title: Run Dusty Run Retired Because of Leg Injury
description: HIALEAH, FLA., Feb. 23Run Dusty Run, the colt that chased Seattle Slew in last season's Triple Crown series, has run his last race.

title: 2 Theorize. Moon Still Wobbles 800 Years After a Meteor Hit It
description: The moon may still be wobbling from a colossal meteorite impact 800 years ago.

title: A.T. &T. to Revamp Some Departments
description: Responding to an increasingly competitive marketplace, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company disclosed yesterday that it would shortly reorganize those of its departments concerned with customers into groups handling specific markets.

title: About Real Estste Gain in Environmental Interest Is Seen in a  Westchester Area
description: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y.Rugged place, Westchester County. Rocks and boulders fill many of its hilly woods, creating forbidding terrain for construction.

title: PRESIDENT PROPOSES MERGER OF PROGRAMS IN FIGHT ON JOB BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  President Carter sent to Congress today a plan to consolidate Federal programs to combat job discrimination.

title: How to Get There
description: White Plains is reachable by train, every half hour, from Grand Central station and more frequently during rush hours; by car on the Bronx River Parkway or the Cross Westchester Expressway, and by bus from almost anywhere in Westchester because the county seat serves as a transportation hub.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Suffolk County Executive John V.N. Klein vetoed yesterday a resolution to forbid the use of county funds to pay for abortions through Medicaid. The county legislature adopted the resolution Feb. 14.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: QUARK should be mentioned here, I suppose because it's a new halfhour weekly series haying its premiere on NBC tonight at 8 with a special hourlong trip into outer space. Set in the yeat 2222 A.D., the story line centers around Adam Quark, (Richard Benjamin), commander of a starship called the,United Galaxy Sanitation Patrol. Affording an uncanny commentary on the'series itself, Quark's stock in trade is garbage.

title: Assembly Passes Bill to Strengthen Child Visitations
description: ALBANY, Feb, 23In a move designed to put teeth into courtordered childvisitation agreements, the Assembly passed a bill, to give judges the power to withhold alimony from those who refused to allow their former spouses to visit their children.

title: HOUSE AUTHORIZES $1.7 BILLION OUTLAY TO WITTEVEEN FUND
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23By a majority of more than twotoone, the House passed a bill today to authorize a $1.7 billion United States contribution to a $10 billion international fund designed to help countries hardest hit by current oil prices.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: East Is Still East, and West Is West, and...
description: Recent criticism of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. by East Coast journalists shows how difficult it is for Easterners to understand the posthistoric geography of Sacramento, for California is not so much a state of the Union as an imagination that seceded from our reality a long time ago.

title: A FourthGrade Class in Queens Comes Up With $17.22 for Needy
description: Steven Haberman, who is a student in Class 4203 at Public School 164 in Flushing, Queens, asked in a letter to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund:

title: At the Movies
description: HER old friends at the High School of Music and Art, the Professional Children's School and the Manhattan Boroughwide Orchestra will be happy to know that Amy Irving is back in town, no longer merely an obscure fiddler or an Off Off Broadway actress, but a genuine movie star.

title: Bache Cuts Dividend
description: The Bache Group, a major securities firm, announced yesterday it was cutting its quarterly dividends in half to cents, payable March 30 to holders of record March 6. John E. Leslie, chairman, and Harry A. Jacobs Jr., president, said the move was prudent in view of Bache's reduced earnings in the second fiscal quarter. The company recently reported a sharp decline in profits for the period.

title: After a 6Day Meeting, No Hint Is Given on Shifts in Top Posts
description: China's national anthem has been without words since the Cultural Revolution of the late 1960's, when the writer of its lyrics came under attack as a rightist.

title: A.A.U. Entries at Garden
description: 11 A.M.Women's 900Yard Run Trials: Francie Larrieu, Darlene Becklord, Wendy Knudson, Debbie VeHer, Sue Latter.

title: U.S.Soviet Arms Negotiators Meet
description: GENEVA, Feb. 23 (UPT)United States and Soviet negotiators held their 232d meeting today at the current round of the talks on limitation of strategic arms. At the meeting, which lasted two hours and 52 minutes, the negotiators agreed to hold their next session on March 2.

title: U.S. to Aid New York City Budget But Long Loans Still Face Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23New York City officials said today that they had reached agreement with the Federal Government on closing the city's budget gap, but Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said that longterm loan guarantees would still have great difficulty in Congress.

title: Sabres 4, Flyers 0
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 23 (UPI)Danny Gare collected two goals and Don Edwards got his fifth shutout of the season to lead the Buffalo Sabres in a 40 rout of the Philadelphia Flyers tonight. the victory moved the Sabres hack into a tie with the Boston Bruins for first place in the Adams Division.

title: Various Corporations Report Operating Results, Disclosing Their Sales and Earnings Figures
description: For periods ended Dee. 31 unless otherwise indicated. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overthe.counter.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE Friday ANTIQUES IN WESTBURY
description: Treasure Hunting Spree, opening today at the Westbury Music Fair on Long Island, has no pirates in the cast. Instead, the main characters are dealers from eight states who are showing their goods in Westbury's first antiques show, which continues through Sunday. Hours: noon to 10 P.M., today and tomorrow; 11 A.M. to 6 P.M., Sunday. We wanted to bring in new faces dealers who have not shown before on Long Island, say the sponsors, adding, This is definitely not a flea market. Items on sale, ranging in price from double digits into the thou sands, include Tiffany glass, furniture, signed silver, clocks, oil paintings, jewelry, books and dolls. Admission is $2.50. For $2 more, you can have an antique from home appraised. From New York City, take the Long Island Expressway to Exit 40. Information: (516) 8222372.

title: Companies Packaging of Generic Drugs Is Called a Threat to Substitution Law
description: Major pharmaceutical companies are. steadily moving into the marketing of generic drugs, igniting fears among New York State legislative and consumer rep, resentatives that the state's new cheaperdrugs law is about to be undermined and the public deprived of expected cost sayings.

title: U.S. Puts Pressure on Operators To Accept Less Stringent Coal Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  President Carter told Congressional leaders today that some form of Federal compulsion would be invoked if the increasingly disruptive coal strike was not settled this weekend.

title: INDICTMENT PIJLES BENCH IN TYLER CASE
description: An appellate bench hearing an appeal by Justice Andrew R. Tyler on his perjury conviction questioned yesterday whether the justice had actually committed perjury and whether his grand jury testimony, even if false, was pertinent to any investigation.

title: MONEY SUPPEN OFF FOR SECOND WEEK
description: Surprising the money market for the second consecutive week, the Federal Reserve yesterday reported a substantial decline in the nation's money supply.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest. Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Jazz: Dorothy Donegan
description: THE MOST surprising thing about Dorothy Donegan, the pianist who is playing at Jimmy Weston's, 131 East 54th Street, through March 11, is that, in any discussion of great jazz pianists, her name is not apte to be mentioned. In fact, in jazz circles she is scarcely even thought of as a jazz pianist.

title: Dollar Continues Slide Abroad
description: The dollar tumbled against the major currencies of Europe and the yen yesterday despite efforts by several central banks to slow its decline, The Associated Press reported.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article about covering furniture in The Home Section yesterday, Lune en Papier was listed as a source for materials. That store went out of business two weeks ago.

title: Iranian Payment Is Minimized
description: G. William Miller, President Carter's nominee to succeed Arthur F. Burns as chairman of the. Federal Reserve Board, said yesterday that despite all the fussing around, there is no evidence that would detract from my being confirmed by the Senate.

title: Art People
description: THERELL be a new look at the old Executive Mansion in Gracie Square, Mayor Koch's home away, from home (he. spends Mondays through Thursdays there and weekends at his tiny but comfortable pad: in Greenwich Village known as Gracie Mansion South). An, effort is under way to replace what one city official called the Abercrombie & Fitch Colonial look of the big house with a more contemporary ambience, better attuned to the Big Apple's standing as an international cudtural capital.

title: Rock: Yvonne Elliman Appears at Bottom Line
description: YVONNE ELLIMAN'S latest record, Night Flight, sounds more confident and appealing than her previous work. But her appearance Wednesday at the Bottom Line  the first of four shows over two nights at the lower Manhattan rock showcase  was less successful.

title: Josephine Lawrence, 88, Author; Novelist of MiddleClass America
description: Josephine Lawrence, author of 33 novels, incuding the one on which the classic Hollywood film on old age, Make Way for Tomorrow, was based, died at her home at 200 West 15th Street Wednesday of natural causes. She was 88 years old.

title: Governance of U.S Companies: Proposals on Reform Likely Soon
description: For more than a year, there has been a broadscale examination under way by Government agencies and other groups into the governance of American corporations and whether changes are advisable to update the system for The Economic Scene legal, administrative, economic or social reasons. No substantive reform proposals on the second question have yet evolved outside the business world, though there are indications that some recommendations may be forthcoming from various quarters fairly soon.

title: Mets Benin Hunt for Pitching Talent
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23The New York Yankees may be hipdeep in pitchers 250 miles southeast of here, but on this side of Florida's Alligator Alley, in the heart of the spring training belt, Manager Joe Torre said today that the Mets would hoist a help wanted sign when his pitchers reported for work tomorrow morning.

title: Tennis Without Love
description: Once again there are demands to banish South Africa from international sportthis time from the Davis Cup tennis matches between the United States and South Africa, to be played at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, March 1719. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and other groups want the matches canceled and promise a vigorous protest if they are held.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Les Ballets Jazz may be seen at the Roundabout Theater's Stage One, 333 West 23d Street, tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 2. Tickets are $7.95 and $8.95. Information and reservations: 9247100.

title: CARTER LAUDS SANT FOR COURAGEOUS ACT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  President Carter has sent a message to President Anwar elSadat expressing admiration for the courageous decision to send Egyptian commandos to Cyprus last wekend to help free hostages aboard a hijacked airliner. The move resulted in the death of 15 of the Egyptian soldiers and a break in Egypt's relations with Cyprus.

title: GRAIN COMPANY FACES U.S. SAFETY CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Farmers Export Company was accused today of II willful violations of safety standards, at its Galveston, Tex., grain elevator, where an explosion and fire in late December killed 18 workers and injured 21 others.

title: New York and Jersey Denied Federal Disaster Aid
description: President Carter yesterday rejected requests by New York and New Jersey for declarations of major disaster that would have cleared the way for millions of dollars in Federal assistance to help pay for damage caused by recent snow, ice and wind storms in the two states.

title: Troubadour Re turns After 700 Years.
description: The late (very late) Guiraut Riquler is well suited for the posthumous role he will play Sunday night at 8 as master of ceremonies for The Troubadours of 12thCentury Provence at Christ and St. Stephen's Church.

title: NEWCAR SALES ROSE 12% FOR FEB, 1120, HELPED BY WEATHER
description: DETROIT, Feb 23The nation's four major automobile producers reported ;here today a 12 percent increase in domestic newcar sales during the mid February 10day selling period. It was the first report of a yeartoyear sales gain since midNovember.

title: Regents Vote to Give Mayor More Appointive Power
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23Giving support to Mayor Koch's drive for a stronger role in running the city's schools, the New York State Board of Regents proposed today that the Mayor be given the power to appoint a majority of the members of the city's Board of Education and have the last word on the selection of a school chancellor.

title: Bellow Gets Arts Club Medal of Honor
description: Saul Bellow, already more honored than any other living American writer, received another laurel last evening from the National Arts Club in a ceremony at the landmark clubhouse on Cramercy Park.

title: Atherton and Egyptian Aide Meet on Resuming Talks
description: CAIRO, Feb. 23Alfred L. Atherton Jr., the American special envoy, met with Foreign Minister Mohammed Ibrahim Kamel today to discuss Egypt s stand on a proposed declaration of principles that would clear, the way for a resumption of negotiations with Israel.

title: PLAN FOR DEMOCRACY IN BOLIVIA IS IN DOUBT
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 22The cautious plan of President Hugo Banzer Surez's military regime to restore democracy to Bolivia this year, after six years of prosperous but often repressive rule, has undergone substantial changes in recent weeks as the result of strong civilian, and many believe military, pressure.

title: Job Plan Helps Keep Stars in Track
description: Last summer, Stan Vinson was prepared to quit track and field. At the age of 24 with a college degree, the only jobs he could get that would allow him time to train as a worldclass athlete were temporary positions such as janitor and dishwasher.

title: St. John's Triumphs By 7957
description: In a career horn finale for three St. John's seniorsGeorge Johnson, Kevelin Winfree and Paul Berwangert.he Redmen captured their last home game of the season last night by defeating St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, 7957, before 4,055 spectators at Alumni Hall in Hillcrest, Queens.

title: It's Jazz, It's Dance, and It's in Chelsea
description: Jazz dance is one of those amorphous artistic entities that seem to mean all things to all practitioners. There is the original vernacular dance of black hoofers or tap dancers, a vital and rich art form that appears to be slowly dying out. For many, the mention of jazz dance conjures up visions of the slick spins or vitiated shuffles of Broadway musicalcomedy numbers through the years. Others think of the balletic ballroomtap style of Fred Astaire.

title: Dow Edges Up 1.90 on News of Advance in Car Sales
description: An unexpected gain in midFebruary car sales enabled the stock market to stage a late rally yesterday and advance after nine straight declining sessions.

title: After Begelman, Who Will Head Columbia?
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23At a market a halfmile from Columbia Pictures, the woman at the checkout counter is more concerned with finding a 10cent coupon for fabric softener than she is with David Begelmanwhose name she has never heard before. Not many of the electricians, paint salesmen, insurance adjusters, machinists and others who live within the shadow of Columbia can identify, even now, the name of the studio's former president, who allegedly stole $61,008 from the company.

title: U.S. Copper Import Quotas Sought
description: A spokesman for Anierican copper producers said yesterday that the industry would ask the United States Inernational Trade Commission to impose quotas on copper imports here. World oversupply or copper has pushed copper prices to very low levels, hurting American producers. The industry spokesman said details would be released later.

title: Czechoslovaks Fay Coal Miners Well to Keep Them in Perilous Job
description: OSTRAVA, CzechoslovakiaTwice in the last 13 months, explosions and caveins have ripped through mines in this grimy coal district of northern Moravia. Seventynine persons died in the disasters, which were barely reported in the West. and hundreds more were injured.

title: Walter O'Malley Hospitalized
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23 (AP)Walter O'Malley, chairman of the board of the Los Angeles Dodgers, was admitted to Methodist Hospital in Rochester, Minn., today. The 74yearpold O'Malley, who was released from the hospital last Thursday, after abdominal surgery, became ill while flying on the Dodgers' plane from Los Angeles to the team's training site in Vero Beach, Fla.

title: New Toxicwaste Disposal Facility Plans to Open in Newark May 1
description: NEWARK, Feb. 23Plans were announced today for the opening of an industrialwaste detoxification plant here that officials said would be a first small step in easing the state's serious shortage of facilities for the legal and harmless disposal of toxic and chemical industrial discharges.

title: Meany Says Labor Has No Plans for Organizing Drive
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb, 23Organized labor, which is urgently counting on pending labor law revisions to revive its flagging ability to organize workers, has no plans or strategy for a new organizing drive should the revisions be enacted, labor leaders meeting here conceded today.

title: The Problem of Hospitals Flight to Suburbs
description: Much has been made of such aspects of innercity decay as unemployment, abandonment of buildings and the decline in the quality of public education. According to some urban experts, another and more wrenching development has begun to sap center cities and is occurring with very little public awareness. It is the flight of major hospital facilities or functions from core cities to suburban areas.

title: U.S. COURT REFUSES GROSS A NEW TRIAL
description: NEWARK, Feb. 23 (UPI)A Federal judge Thursday refused to grant a new trial to a former state Republican chairman, Nelson G. Gross, who has charged that a United States marshal romanced a female juror during his 1974 campaignabuse trial.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 23 (UPI)A fivehour gun battle between soldiers and antiGovernment demonstrators'. today left numerous people dead and wounded in the eastern city of Masaya, witnesses said.

title: Politics and Poetry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23President Carter has cone to one of those forks in the road where he may have to choose which way he will go. Sometimes, as Robert Frost says, the choice between the road taken and the road not taken makes all the difference.

title: Article 2  No Title
Goldin Urged Not to Enter Primary
description: Signaling a possible bitter struggle over the Democratic nomination for New York State Comptroller, a Democratic legislative leader urged City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday not to challenge the renomination, of State Comptroller Arthur Levitt.

title: People in Sports...
description: The Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League will play without Gerry Cheevers, their goalie, for an indefinite period because of his second major injury of the season. Cheevers sustained torn ligaments in the right knee Tuesday when he was rammed by Colorado's Joe Contint.... Very unfair, Whitey Herzog, manager of the Kansas City Royals, said of the $5,000 fine that Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn reportedly imposed on the California Angels for allegedly. offering Herzog a job. They never tampered with me, Herzog said. Gene Autry, owner of the Angels, said I'm not guilty of a thing.

title: Silent Animated Films On View This Weekend
description: Silent animated films, from the 190620 period, will be shown this weekend at the UP Screen, 814 Broadway (near 12th Street).

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1978

title: Oil Port at Kitimat Barred by Canada
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 23The Canadian Government, in a surprise decision killed today a proposal for a major oil port at Kitimat, British Columbia, for the storage of Alaskan oil to be piped to American refineries in the Middle Western states.

title: ALBANY ACTS TO BAR DYSON ROLE IN ADS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23Brushing aside the threat of a veto by Governor Carey, the Democraticcontrolled Assembly today approved a measure barring. the State. Commerce Commissioner, John S. Dyson, from using his voice, signature, name or facemasked or upmaskedin advertisements wooing business to New York State.

title: Meet Some People Who Love Subways
description: THIS tour's different. It starts with a token. Oh, no, Not a weekend excursion in the pestilential subway, they saythose who haven't met Stan Fischler, Noah Caplin or a couple of other subway nuts. Mr. Fischlerjournalist, author of Uptown, Downtown: A Trip Through Time an New York's Subways and a raconteur of a high orderand Mr. Caplina Metropolitan Transportation Authority analystengineer who once broke the record for the onetoken, allstops subway marathonare among the leaders of a walkandride trip through the subways this Sunday afternoon that could fire the imaginations of the fearful, the uninitiated and the longsuffering cynic alike. Mr. Fischler, for instance; happens to think that what rumbles along underneath us is still the world's best subway system, not the prettiest, but the best: Our expresses, he says, by way of example, are dynamite.

title: Dance: Season's Find
description: WHAT can one say when the discovery of the dance season turns out to be a choreographer in her 60's with an outstanding young dance company in a superb program?

title: Open Interest
description: Open

title: A Fight on Flu Planned by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The first longterm national policy on flu immunization was announced today by Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. Its goal is to help states more than double the number of persons in highrisk categories who are protected against the disease.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article about covering furniture in The Home Section yesterday, Lune en Papier was listed as a source, for materials. That store went out of business two weeks ago.

title: Smith Defends His Rhodesia Plan, Says Guerrillas Will Give Up War
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 23Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that it was absolutely nonsensical to suggest that safeguards for the white minority in Rhodesia included in his agreement with moderate black leaders could be used to perpetuate white rule.

title: Smith Defends His Rhodesia Plan, Says Guerrillas Will Give Up War
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 23Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that it was absolutely nonsensical to suggest that safeguards for the white minority in Rhodesia included in his agreement with moderate black leaders could be used to perpetuate white rule.

title: Judge Considers Reversing Pact On Assigning Teachers by Race
description: A judge in Federal District Court in Brooklyn said yesterday that he was considering an order that could reverse a controversial agreement between the Federal Government and the New York City Board of Education under which teachers have been assigned to schools on the basis of race.

title: Canadiens 5, Barons 1
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 23 (UPI)Steve Shutt recorded the first fourgoal performance of his career and Guy Lafleur made four assists tonight as the Montreal Canadiens extended their record undefeated streak to 28 games with a 51 victory over the Cleveland Barons.

title: LEVITT CHARGES ACT GIVES OIL COMPANIES WINDFALL
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23American oil companies are reaping windfall profits at the direct expense of New York State's highway authorities, State Comptroller Arthur Levitt charged today. He recommended a change in Federal laws to remedy the situation.

title: Ottaway to Buy News Group
description: Ottaway Newspapers Inc., a subsidiary of Dow Jones & Company, agreed yesterday to buy Essex County Newspapers Inc. for $10 million in cash. Essex publishes The Gloucester Daily Times, The Beverly Times, The Newburyport Daily News and The Peabody Times, 11 Massachusetts dailies, and The Hampton (N.H.) Union, a weekly. Also included is a weekly shopper, The Rockingham County (N.H.) Gazette.

title: Jerseyans Who Work in New York Are Staunch Backers of Neediest
description: New Jerseyans who work in New York City have been among the staunchest supporters of the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: WEST GERMAN TERRORISTS RULED COLLECTIVE SUICIDE
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Feb. 23 (AP)Three terrorists died in a collective suicide last Oct. 18 at Stammheim Prison here, a state legislative committee ruled today after a fourmonth investigation.

title: Radio
description: 7.8, WNCN. Sylvia, excerpts, Delibes ; Andante with Variations (K. 501), Mozart ; Zigeunerweisen, Sarasate.

title: Bridge:
description: For players in New York City and Long Island, the world's biggest team contest goes into its second stage this weekend.

title: MOST OF CITY UNIONS ASK JOINT PAY TALKS
description: Unions representing 225,000 New York City municipal employees agreed yesterday, to bargain together with the city for pay increases and other contract improvements despite the withdrawal earlier this week of police officers and firefighters from the coalition. ueiegates rrom ate coalition unions am unanimously accepted the bargainin proposals, including a demand for a substantial wage rise, that had been put forward by the big four unions that were expected to take the lead in the upcoming negotiations.

title: Indians Back Action On Religious Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)Representatives from nine American Indian tribes today endorsed,a resolution that is intended to guarantee them religimis freedom even when. their. ceremonies include animals, sites or substances that otherwise are restricted. The tribes offerdd testimony before the Senate Select Committee on Indian Affairs, which is considering the resolution.

title: Ousted Head of Bonwit Starts New Career
description: John Schumacher, who was ousted last Ootober as chairman of the Bonwit Teller fashion chain, has embarked on a new career as an American marketer of Italian clothes and has also won an initial round against Genesco Inc., which discharged him.

title: BUILDER GETS A YEAR IN WESTCHESTER JAIL
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 24  Oskar Kreisler, a 68yearold builder who misappropriated $48,000 in new home deposits four years ago, was sentenced today to, one year in the Westchester County Jail.

title: ILLEGAL RESIDUES IN FOODS ARE REPORTED TO CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)Officials of the two agencies responsible for making sure that the nation's food supply is safe told Congress today that products were still reaching the consumer with illegal amounts of drugs and other resi dues.

title: Dividends
description: STOCK

title: Gaza Neuman de Vegvar, Headed Producer of Electronics Devices
description: Geza Neuman de Vegvar, former Chairman of the board of DeVar Industries of Englewood, N.J., pioneers in solidstate electroniccontrol devices and manufacr turer of industrial valves, died Wednesday in White Plains Hospital of a neart ailment. He was 56 years old and lived at 20 Cotswold Way, Scarsdale, N.Y;

title: Coldmbia 64, Dartmouth 47
description: HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 24A 234 burst midway through the second half boosted Columbia to a 6447 triumph over Dartmouth tonight for the Lions' sixth straight victory and a 92 wonlost record inthe Ivy League.

title: PACT TO END COAL STRIKE IS ANNOUNCED BIT CARTER; MINERS URGED TO BACK IT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  President Carter announced tonight a proposal for a voluntary settlement of the 81dayold coal strike and urged miners to accept it.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: James Reston's column (Feb. 12) on the control and development of nuclear power and weapons neglects a crucial. political and psychological dimension. Any Carter Administration program to bring more order into its nuclear policies at home and abroad must begin with nuclear disarmament.

title: Police Fence Operation Closes Short of Cash, Not Trade
description: The plate on the door said Push, so visitors to the U.C.C. Company in Richmond Hills, Queens, pushed. What they did not know was that after they entered the office, the doorplate was removed and replaced so their fingerprints could be lifted.

title: UConn 10, Bryant 7
description: STORRS, Conn., Feb. 24 (AP)Chris Kelley scored four goals and had two assists tonight to spark Connecticut to a 107 victory over Bryant in college hockey. Connecticut improved its record to 1010. Bryant, which fell to 1114, got five goals from Jim Grimm.

title: House Delays President's Plan To Raise Fees for Grazing Land
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)The House has delayed for a year a Carter Administration plan to raise Federal grazing land fees for Western ranchers. By a vote of 257 to 47, the House yesterday sent the suspension to the Senate, which is expected to concur.

title: House Unit Backs ExCarter Aide For Agriculture Department Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)P.R. Smith, President Carter's 1976 campaign director in farm areas, was approved unanimously today by the Senate Agriculture Committee as Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Marketing Services.

title: 4 in Burma Get Death Sentences After Convictions in Treason Cases
description: RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 24 (AP) Local courts have sentenced four persons to death and three to life imprisonment in two treason trials.

title: Ouster of McDowell Said to Be Prepared
description: SECAUCUS, Feb. 24  William D. McDowell will reportedly be replaced in the fall as executive director of the. Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission through political maneuvering in Trenton and Jersey City.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Thirteen New Jersey sewage systems are slow in taking action to stop offshore sludge dumping, according to the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Denmark Quits Post As Marketing Chief; Denies City Hall Rift
description: Bernhardt Denmark, the $75,000ayear president of New York City's new BUsiness Marketing Corporation, which aims to bring businesses and jobs to the city, resigned abruptly yesterday, citing unspecified other commitments.

title: Dollar Up Strongly In Tradinz Abroad
description: Rumors of developments in the nationwide United States coal strike helped send the dollar on an uncertain path in foreign exchange trading yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

title: KATHLEEN LOCKHART
description: LOS, ANGELES, Feb. 24 (AP)Kathleen Lockhart, the mother of June Lockhart, the actress, and herself a veteran of more than five decades on the stage and screen; died today. She was 84 years old.

title: Tennessee Is First To Require Seatbelts For Young Children
description: KNOXVILLE, Feb. 24 Tennessee has become the first state in the nation to require the use of automobile restraining devices for children under 4 years old.

title: BIG BOARD SUSPENDS TRADING IN SHARES OF COLUMBIA FILMS
description: The New York Stock Exchange suspended trading in the common stock of Columbia Pictures Industries yesterday to give investors an opportunity to assess the impact of an article in The New York Times Magazine tomorrow that contends the film company was secretly up for sale,

title: Lawyer and 3 Reputed Mobsters Acquitted of TaxEvasion Charges
description: A lawyer and three reputed members of an organizedcrime group called the Purple Gang have been acquitted of taxevasion charges involving an investment in a company that provided vending machines to sell New York State lottery tickets.

title: Phones Ring. for Philharmonic
description: On Thursday night in Avery Fisher Hall, the New York Philharmonic was onstage doing what it is supposed to, making musicin this case, under the direction of Bernard HaitinK. Backstage, administrators and friends of the orchestra and of radio station WQXR were doing what had to be done, raising money for the orchestra in the first Phone Festival that has ever been organized for its benefit.

title: Understanding and Profiting From Ego Defense Mechanisms
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.In his play The Confidential Clerk, T. S. Eliot warns us, If you haven't the strength to impose your own terms upon life, you must accept the terms life offers you.

title: William H. Correale, Helped Write New York City's Building Code
description: William H. Correale, a consultant to the Center for Urban Environmental. Studies at the Polytechnic Institute of New York, died Wednesday in St. Clare's Hospital after a brief Illness. He was. 77 years old and lived at 3440 79th Stree) in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: An AfricaLatin Visit Is Planned by Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)President Carter will visit Venezuela, Brazil, Nigeria and Liberia in a weeklong trip beginning March 28, the White.House announced today.

title: Logib for a LameDuck School Board
description: The New York City Board of Education seems determined to proceed with the appointment of a school chancellor to,take office in June, when Irving Anker, the incumbent, retires. Under normal circumstances, filling a vacancy in the school system's top post wouia indeed be a matter of urgency. But present conditions are not normal: Mr.,Anker's departure coincides with the expiration of the board itself. There is widespread support for Mayor Koch's demand for a more effective voice in managing the school system; he is expected to ask the State Legislature to give him a leading role in the selection of a new board, and the State Board of Regents has voted its support of the required legislative changes. Accordingly, it would be improper and imprudent to deny the next board its most important function naming a professional chief executive.

title: Redskins Hire Beathard As General Manager
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)The Wasbington Redskins completed the reorganization of their front office to day by hiring the former Miami Dolphins' personnel director, Bob Beathard, as general manager and by promoting two scouts who served under the former Redskin coach and general manager. George Allen.

title: Man Killed in Jersey Crash
description: CHERRY HILL, NJ., Feb. 24 (AP)A tractortrailer rammed into the rear of another truck on Interstate 295 here today, killing a North Carolina driver, the state police said. John Heath, 27 years old, of Williamston, N.C., the driver of the tractortrailer, was pronounced dead at the scene of the crash, troopers said. The other driver, John King, 23, of Atglen, Pa., was not injured.

title: Two Dancers From Japan In Tur Seal
description: Eiko and Koma are two Japanese dancers who have enjoyed a growing reputation in the dance underground for the last year. On Thursday night at Japan House, a full house saw them simulate two seals in their bestknown theater piece, Fur Seal. What Eiko, who is the female of the species, and Koma are really presenting is a fable about human existence. The entire image of the hourlong work is an enactment of a mating rite. But it is an image so skillfully and even beautifully developed that it is meant to have greater ramifications than itself.

title: PACT TO END COAL STRIKE IS ANNOUNCED BY CAR TER; MINERS URGED TO BACK IT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  President Carter announced tonight a proposal for a voluntary settlement of the 81dayold coal strike and urged miners to accent it.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24When the history of the peaceful applications of nuclear power is written, the Clinch River project at Oak Ridge, Tenn., may be recalled as the reactor that would not die.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Secretary or State Cyrus R. Vance warned today that the Administration would withdraw its offer to provide 90 warplanes to Israel if Congress blocked a sale of planes to Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

title: Soviet Said to Extend Peru's Arms Debts by a Year
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 23 The Soviet Union has reportedly given Peru, whose decadeold military Government is almost bankrupt, a grace period of one year to.pay back a $60 million arms debt that fell due. in January. Another $60 million credit that was to come due in July also said to be affected.

description: On the whole, Japanese bluechip stocks have held up better than their American counterparts despite what the chairman of an investment fund specializing in Japanese securities concedes is avery bearish set of fundamentals. Page 31.

title: Dance: Smorgasbord, Loft Style
description: The currently popular loftconcert showcase can be a distressingly hitormiss affair. Designed to introduce new talent to a concedely limited audience and. more importantly, to give new choreographers an affordable chance to see their work performed, the loft concert can end up as sheer selfin-. dulgence. That was not the case at a choreographic smorgasbord of works by Patrice Evans, Martha Ferris and Jody Oberfelder presented on Thursday at the Seven Flights Up loft on West 17th Street. It was an engaging evening by virtue of the three women's vital stage presences alone.

title: Man Seized in Bank Robberies
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 24 (AP)A Camden man wanted in connection with two South Jersey bank robberies last year has been apprehended, the Federal Bureau of Investization has announced. William, Council, 28 years old, was arrested yesterday after a vehicle in which he was riding left a parking lot here, the F.B.I. said. He has been charged with the Feb. 18, 1977 armed robbery of tha Atlantic National Bank in Atlantic City and the April 17, 1977 of the bank's branch in Pleasantville.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  President Carter's decision to move into the 81dayold coal strike, in his most farreaching domestic crisis, was a political gamble, and tonight he appeared to have.

title: Alabama Court Stays Execution
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 24 (AP)The State Supreme Court granted a 90day stay of execution today for Donald Thigpen, one of two convicted killers scheduled to die March 10 in the electric chair at Holman Prison. Lawyers for the other condemned man. Johnny Harris. were expected to seek a similar stay on Tuesday. Mr. Thigpen was convicted of killing a farmer after escaping from the prison in 1975. Mr. Harris was sentenced to death for the slaying of a guard in a 1974 riot at the Fountain Correctional Center near Atmore.

title: Clash Between Del Tub and State Senate Intensifies
description: TRENTON, Feb. 24  An unusual controversy between the United States Attorney's office and the State Legislature intensified today when two members of the Senate Judiciary Committee criticized by the Federal prosecutor temporarily withdrew from the committee and charged him with being irresponsible. special to The New York Times

title: Notes on People
description: Henry Ford 2d, legally, separated from his wife Cristina since midDecember, has filed for divorce, according to documents made public yesterday. The auto manufacture filed for divorce in Wayne County Circuit Court in Detroit on Jan. 23, the court documents show. Mrs. Ford asked that the documents be kept secret last Dec. 16, when she requested a legal separation and a court order that her husband maintain her life style. Mr. Ford's divorce claim, filed in response to his wife's request, does not give a reason for the divorce. The Fords were married in 1965 and began living apart in December 1975.

description: BONN, Feb. 24Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, appearing before a parliamentary commission for more than five hours today, testified that no NATO nuclear secrets had been betrayed by an East German spy ring that penetrated the Defense Ministry here.

title: Carter's Political Gamble
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  President Carter's decision to move into the 81dayold coal strike was a political gamble. and tonight he appeared to have won the gamble and reaped the dividends that could eventually enhance his national leadership. Even sympathetic News Analysis Democrats in Congress were conceding late this afternoon that Mr. Carter had made himself politically vulnerable by putting his prestige on the line on behalf of a coal settlement. But with behindthescenes maneuvering, a week of cliffhanger bargaining and the threat of lastminute drastic action to seize the mines, Mr. Carter produced the package he had sought.

description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Feb. 24 (Reuters)England struggled to 172 runs for five wickets at close of play today on the first day of the second cricket test against New Zealand.
