title: Tibetan Spiritual Leader
description: When the Panchen Lama, a traditional spiritual leader of Tibet, showed up for thb Fifth Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference in Peking's Great Hall of the People this week, it was his first public appearance since the Cultural Revolution. In Man in the Neivs 1964 he was stripped of his position as chairman of the election committee for the Tibetan region and charged with onnosine the neonle. the fatherland and socialism. Over the ldst decade there have been unconfirmed reports that he was in a labor camp, that he escaped to. India and that he was studying in Peking.

title: Explosion of Tank Car Kills 5 And Hurts 55 in Tennessee Town
description: WAVERLY, Tenn., Feb. 24 (AP)A ailroad tanker loaded with liquid propane exploded in the heart of this small wn today, and state officials said at east five persons were dead and 55 inured.

title: Remember the Convention Center?
description: Inching its way along like the mastodon it is growing more and more to resemble, New York's convention center now seems to be stalled between the last contending sitesthe 34th Street railyards and the 44th Street piers. The welcome word from a City Hall that has been too leisurely about economic development that the decision on what to build where will be made in 45 days.

title: Thomas C. Peightal, A Surgeon 63 Years At Roosevelt, Dead
description: Dr. Thomas Christian Peightal, a prominent surgeon and gynecologist who served at Roosevelt Hospital for 63 years, died Wednesday in his home at 125 East 72d Street in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: Siberians Match Hardiness and Hardship
description: NOVOSIBIRSK, U.S.S.R.  In this Siberian city, the Soviet Union's fourth largest, at the center of the world's biggest and richest lode of natural resources, there is no meat in the stores. The supply is so short that a form of rationing is in effect.

title: VOYAGER PLATFORM JAMS AND MAY IMPAIR MISSION
description: The platform holding most of the scientific instruments of Voyager 1, the spacecraft headed for Jupiter and Saturn, has apparently jammed in such a way as to impair mission operations, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration reported yesterday.

description: RESCUED IN THE NIGHT: A firefighter leads a woman down a ladder from a highrise apartriierit building near Rush Street in Chicago on Thursday night after fire routed 220 residents Sixteen persons were reported injured in the blaze. The cause is not yet known.

title: Senate Group Backs $1.3 Billion Increase InGrants to Students
description: WASHINGTON, Feb.24 (UPI)  The Senate Human Resources Committee, today approved a $1.3 billion increase In grants for higher education that generally follows President Carter's request.

title: A Full Stomach Alone Does Not Make a Man Free
description: A rebuttal to a familiar argument that the U.S. should respect nations where certain political, niceties are sacrif iced, and certain libertarian corners are cut, in order to ensure maximum economic growth.

title: Study of Questionable Payments Accents Involvement of Officers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24According to a study of the bribes, kickbacks, payoffs and other questionable. payments disclosed by scores of nationally known corporations, at least some officers or directors of companies involved either directly sanctioned the payments or knew about them in more than half the instances.

title: United Press International
description: TRAIN DERAILS IN SOUTH CAROLINA: The scene at Florence, S.C., where 20 cars or a 43car Auto Train, with 503 passengers, derailed as it approached the station. The accident apparently was caused by a broken axle. Dozens of passengers were treated at a nearby hospital and were released.

title: Complete Ban on TV Ads for Children Is Suggested
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The staff of the Federal Trade Commission has recommended that the regulatory agency consider banning all television advertising that is directed to an audience of very young children.

title: O'Malley Still HoSpitalized
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., Feb, 24 (AP)Walter O'Malley, chairman of. the board of the Los Angeles Dodgers, remained in satisfactory condition today..in Methodist Hospital. The 74yearold O'Malley underwent'abdominal surgery here. Feb. 5and was released eight days ago. He was readmitted ThursdaY after he developed a fever during flight from Los Angeles to the Dodgers' training camp in Vero Beach, Fla.

title: Some Miners Denounce Coercion And Doubt Pact Will Be Approved
description: Down in the soft coal country, the men who have stayed away from their mines for. 81 days viewed President Carter's announcement of a voluntary settlentent of their strike with a mixture of relief. puzzlement. skepticism and anger.

title: An InwardLooking Nation
description: There was a time when foreign policy was king. For a generation after World War II, Americans told Mr. Gallup that foreign policy was their major concern. Presidential candidates argued about Moscow, Peking, even Quemoy and Matsu. Money poured into university research centers for the study of Communism, underdeveloped countries and nuclear strategy. Newspapers opened expensive overseas bureaus and foreign leaders appeared on the covers of news magazines.

title: Consumer Notes Homeowners Urged to Watch FuelOil Deliveries
description: With homeheating oil selling for about 50 cents a gallon  almost double what it was a few years ago  the State Division of Consumer Affairs urges homeowners to make sure that their oil man is delivering the amount for which they are being charged.

title: Japanese Slaughter 1,000 Dolphins
description: TOKYO, Feb. 24 (UPI)Japanese fishermen clubbed and stabbed to death about 1,000 dolphins yesterday and today with the approval of a provincial government.

title: Fire on Cannery Row Ruins 8 Businesses
description: MONTEREY, Calif. Feb 24. (Reuters) The Steinbeck Theater and seven restaurants and shops along Cannery Row, immortalized in John Steinbeck's novel of the same name, were destroyed early today in a fire that caused an estimated $2 million dollars in damage.

title: Vietnamese Chief Tells Indians Of Effort to End Cambodian Fight
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 24 (Reuters)Prime Minister Pham Van Dong of Vietnam told the vIndian Parliament today. that Hanoi was doing all it could for a fair and rcaspnable settlement of its border conflint with Cambodia.

title: Cabaret: Lainie Kazan at Playboy
description: The Playroom of the Playboy Club, 5 East 59th Street, has been renamed Lainie's Room in honor of Lainie Kaian and, by no coincidence whatever, Miss Kazan is playing there.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, anus. sorgsky's Boris Godunov, 21 Donlzettl's LaFavorite, 8:30.

title: Dodge Trucks, Honda Motorcycles Recalled for Checks on Safety
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 24 (AP)Recalls of 118,000 Honda motorcycles and 20,000 Dodge light trucks were reported today by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Yonkers Council Strips Mayor of Legislative Powers
description: YONKERS, Feb. 24Angelo R. Martinelli, a Republican who was reelected Mayor last November, suffered a setback last night when a coalition of Republicans and Democrats stripped him and his majority leader in the Council of their legislative powers.

title: Seoul Critics Assail OneMan Rule
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 24Critics of the South Korean Government appealed to President Park Chung Hee today to end his oneman political control and dissolve the National Assembly:

title: BRZEZINSKI ASSERTS THAT SOVIET GENERAL LEADS ETHIOPIA UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The White House said today that a Soviet general was now directing some of Ethiopia's armed forces in their effort to drive Somali forces from the Ogaden region of eastern Ethiopia.

title: A New Survey of TeenAge Sex With TeenAgers Asking the Questions
description: New York teenagers are more likely to be sexually active if they live in singleparent household than if they live in an intact family.

title: Traviata With Mariana Niculescu
description: ln prospect, the New York City Opera appeared to have the ingredients of a triumphant beginning Thursday night, when the springportion of its season opened. The production,by no means new, but still one or tne; company's stronger efforts, was Traviata, in Frank Corsaro's dramatically crafty staging. And the Violetta was Mariana Niculescu, the Rumanian soprano who made her City Opera debut last fall in this same work to some fairly spectacular notices.

title: KENNETH N. STEWART
description: Kenneth N. Stewart, a reporter, editor, journalism teacher and a journalism critic, died Wednesday in a convalescent home in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 76 years old and liVed in Menlo Park.

title: Helena Rubenstein Moves
description: There's a new kid on the block that the neighbors are already buzzing about the sophisticated, beautiful new tenant who moved into the building at 300 Park AVenue yesterday.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONResearchers at Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N. J., have invented a metal alloy that is expected to lead to a substantial reduction in the cost of telephone receivers. Uses are also foreseen in loudspeakers, speedometers and other equipment requiring magnetic properties.

title: Penn Beats Brown, 9175, To Keep Ivy League Lead
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 (AP)Keven McDonald scored 21 pionts tonight to lead the University of Pennsylvania to a 9175 triumph over Brunt. The victory gave Penn a 101 wonlost record in the Ivy League and kept the Quakers one game In front of Columbia in the race for the league title. Both Penn ana Columbia have three games left to play.

title: Letters: On Tuition Tax Credits
description: To the Editor: Tuition tax credits for the middle class are not the electionyear handout The Times editorial of Feb. 13 would lead us to believe.

title: Infighting and Scandals Break Out In Intelligence Agency of France
description: PARIS, Feb. 24Infighting and scandals have broken out in France's intelligence agency, provoking calls for a reoreanization of the service.

title: Cornell 78, Harvard 76
description: CAMBRIDGE; Mass., Feb. 24 (AP)Charlie Brown scored with three seconds left to give Cornell a 7876 victory over Harvard tonight.

title: State's Probate Law To Undergo Changes
description: TRENTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)Governor Byrne signed legislation today revising New Jersey's laws on estates and wills.

title: Deadline Extended On T V Station Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Joe L. Allbritton, owner of Washington Star Communications, and the Combined Communications Corporation of Phoenix agreed last night to extend their contract deadline for the sale of station WJLATV here. II was extended until the Federal Communications Commission decides whether to authorize the sale to Comcinbed, but not beyond March 3.

title: Attacker of Policeman Gets a Year
description: Two Transit Authority policemen who had said they were upset when charges against a man who attacked one of them with a bayonet were reduced, said yesterday that they were satisfied after the man receivd the maximum sentence of one var for th thirddegre assault.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it projected that its total capital spending could reach $5 billion a Year by the early 1980's.

title: People and Business
description: James F. Towey, chairman and chief executive officer of the Olin Corporation, announced that he had recommended to the board of directors that he be succeeded as chief executive by John M. Henske, Olin's president, at the company's annual meeting April 27.

title: Horowitz Recital Live On Radio, Taped for PBS
description: Vladimir Horowitz's. piano recital at the White House tomorrow at 4 P.M. will be broadcast live on WNYCFM. A videotape will be telecast by the Public Broadcasting Service at 10 P.M.

title: Porter's 29 Assists Set Record
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J, Feb. 24People offended by Randy Newman's satirical look at the undersized in his song Short People have to love Kevin Porter and Calvin Murphy.

title: A Handful of Diamond's Dances
description: The late Doris Humphrey, one of the great theoreticians of modern dance, once warned young choreographers, All dances are too long. Her warning might be heeded by Matthew Diamond, who offered a program of three works Thursday night at the American Theater Laboratory under the overall title of A Handful of Diamond's. However long they lasted by the clock, theatrically all three meandered, and the two with narrative content positively dawdled.

title: Report Says Carey Budget Items Could Rise in Cost
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24 A report prepared by a private accounting firm for the United States Treasury asserts that some of the programs Governor Carey has proposed in his budget for the coming year may cost more later, and implies that this could hinder New York State's ability to help New York City in the following years.

title: A BILL SIGNED BY CARTER EXPANDS WILDERNESS AREA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)President Carter signed into law today legislation designating 1.3 million acres of Federal lands as 13 new wilderness areas and expanding four existing areas. Ten Western states are affected.

title: Rural Women, With Stories to Tell, Gather in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Mary Jane. Fate, member of the Athabascan Indian tribe, traveled from the village of Baan 0 Yeel Con on the banks of the Yukon River. Unita Blackwell came from Mayersville, Miss., where, as Mayor, she works out of her trailer. Elana Mikels of Wolf Creek, Ore., drove across the country, visiting members of a group she calls her older women's network along the way.

title: Energy Miracle Needed. Official Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)Nuclear power is a hasbeen and the United States needs a miracle of energy discoveries in order to sustain economic growth, a Carter Administration official said today.

title: U.S. Shipment of Israeli Oranges Is Found Clear of Contamination
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)A shipment of Israeli oranges, spotchecked because some of the fruit sold in Europe was contaminated, has been found free of mercury and cleared for sale in the United States, the Government reported today.

title: In Ogaden War, Exaggeration as a Weapon
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 24If, as the adage goes, the first casualty of war is truth, then the information that has been officially released about the fighting in the Ogaden region of Ethiopia amounts to multiple slaughter.

title: ELIAS GOLDBERG DIES AT 91; PAINTED SCENES OF CITY
description: Elias Goldberg, who painted impressionistic landscapes of New York almost all his artistic life, died Wednesday at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged at 120 West 106th Street. He was 91 years old.

title: viletti Is Queried as Confirmation Hearings Open
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Benjamin R. Civiletti moved serenely and unruffled through the start of his confirmation hearings as Deputy Attorney General today in the face of Republican strategy designed to make the inquiry a test of the Carter Department of Justice.

title: China Calls Meeting With All Minorities, The First Since 1964
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 24In what appeared to be an effort to rally groups outside the Communist Party structure, such as intellectuals, minority groups and overseas Chinese, China today convened the unitedfront organization that proclaimed the establishment of Communist China in 1949 and served as the country's first parliament.

title: Brooks Chamberlin Weds Angela L. Leefe in London
description: Angela L. Leefe, daughter of Peter Leefe of London and the late Mrs. Leefe, was married yesterday to Brooks T. Chamberlin of Darien, Conn., son of Mrs. Theodore L. Chamberlin of West Hartford, Conn., and the late Dr. Chamberlin.

title: Miceli Reported Talking To Bergen Grand Jury About Organized Crime
description: HACKENSACK, Feb. 24  Frank Miceli, a reputed underworld leader in North Jersey, began testifying today before a Ber gen County grand jury investigating ganized crime after reportedly being,. threatened with jailing over his initial refusal to answer questions, according to informed sources.

title: Brezhnev Claims U.S. Is Blocking Improved Ties
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 24Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, said today that improved relations with the United States were blocked by all kinds of obstacles and indirectly called on Congress to be more constructive.

title: Temple 81, St. Francis 67
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 (AP)Tim Claxton scored 27 points and Marty Stahurski had 24 to lead Temple to an 8167 victory tonight over St. Francis College of Brooklyn.

title: She Makes Her Point By Living in a Tepee
description: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich.When the most severe blizzard in the state's history struck northern Michigan recently, it struck June Soper's home especially hard.

title: U.S. INDUSTRIES NET ADVANCES SHARPLY
description: Profits of U.S. Industries rebounded sharply in last year's fourth quarter from the depressed yearearlier level, the conglomerate reported yesterday. Earnings for all of 1977 rose 52.7 percent from a year earlier.

title: Horowitz Recital Live On Radio, Taped for PBS
description: Vladimir Horowitz's. piano recital at the White House tomorrow at 4 P.M. will be broadcast live on WNYCFM. A videotape will be telecast by the Public Broadcasting Service at 10 P.M.

title: Minorities in H.U.D. Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)The Department of Housing and Urban Development said Thursday that 28 percent of all of its executives and managers were members of minority groups. The depratment said that since Patricia Roberts Harris, who is black, became its Secretary 13 months ago, minority members in the policymaking level increased by 8.8 percent.

title: 24 Arrested in Raid on AfterHours Club Called Hangout for Pimps and Prostitutes
description: The police raided a midtown afterhours club yesterday that they said was patronized by pimps and prostitutes, arresting 24 persons on charges including gambling. drug and liquor violations.were crowded into the storefront club when 20 police officers rushed inside at 6 A.M.

title: 16 Injured in Chicago Fire
description: CHICAGO, Feb, 24 (AP)Sixteen persons were injured in a fire that routed about 220 residents, from a highrise apartment building near the Rush Street night club area last night. Fourteen of the iniured were hospitalized, including a 6monthold infant who was in good condition, Three persons were in critical condition. The fire broke out in an elevator shaft and spread quickly up the shaft, the authorities said.

title: Suarez Ousts Economic Aide In Rift Over Austerity Program
description: MADRID, Feb. 24 (Reuters)Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez Gonzalez accepted the resignation of his economic minister, Enrique Fuentes Quintana, today and realigned his Cabinet to bring it more into line with his centerright views.

title: Nassau's Policemen Win 24.5% Raises
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 24Nassau County said today it had accepted an arbitrated contract settlement with the county Patrolmen's Benevolent Association that will raise salaries by 24.5 percent.

title: Money
description: Prime rate: 1. Discount rate: 6, Broker call loan rate: 7.

title: Carnation Faces Tax Action
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)Internal Revenue Service agents proposed increasing the Carnation Company's Federal taxes by morq than $400,000 because of alleged faulty reporting of both legal arid questionable payments, Federal records showed today. Carnation disclosed the potential tax liability in a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Dorsey Captures Ski Title
description: WILMINGTON, N.Y., Feb. 24The winner and still champion: That was the distinction earned by Becky Dorsey of Wenham, Mass., today as she topped a field of 53 in the national giant slalom championship on Whiteface Mountain.

title: Coal Operators a Loosely Knit Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)Besides being one party to a labor dispute that produced the nation's longest continuous coal strike, just what is the Bituminous Coal Operators Association?

title: News Summary
description: The Administration will not sell Israel 90 advanced warplanes if Congress blocks the sale of American fighter planes to Egypt or Saudi Arabia, according to Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance. He told the House Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations that the proposed sales are a package and will be dealt with as a package. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: A Different RaceTrack Script
description: HIALEAH, Fla., Feb. 24A 28yearold groom named Larry Demeritte had peeled an orange and was feeding in quarters to Silver Series; the favorite for tomorrow's $118,750 Widener Handicap. When one of the slices fell the ground, the 4yearold gray colt leaned his head under the webbing at the front of his stall and retrieved it with the efficiency of a vacuum cleaner. Demeritte, a Bahamian with a slight British accent, watched in satisfaction as his favorite horse slowly ate the oranee. He won't eat the seeds, the groom said. He spits 'em.out. See that? See how he spit that seed out? He's smart horse.

title: Settlement Hopes In Coal Strike Spur Broad Stock Gains
description: Rising hopes for a settlement of the coal strike and an easing of Wall Street's interestrate jitters helped to send stock prices higher yesterday in a broadbased rally.

title: Oldest HumanLike Footprints Believed Found in African Ash.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24What may be the oldest humanlike footprints, a series of tracks three and a half million years old, embossed on the bottom of an African watering hole, were reported here today by their discoverer, Dr. Mary D. Leakev.

title: Personal Investing
description: Taro Yamada, executive vice president of Yamaichi International (America), a major Japanese brokerage firm here, is a man who likes his statistics neat. Ask him how the Japanese Dow Jones average is going and he says, Amazingly strong. One second, please.

title: Lee R. Sable Is Married To Hugh Freund, Lawyer
description: Lee R. Sable, daughter of Constance R. Sable of Nashua, N.H., and Arthur J. Sable of Boulder, Colo., was married yesterday afternoon to Hugh Freund, son of Mrs. Mortimer Berko witz Jr. of New York and S. E. Freund of St. Louis. State Supreme Court Justice. Hyman Barshay performed the ceremony at the River Club.

title: INTERVIEW Champion of the Arts
description: 6 6 D LIKE to dispel the mystique of the Arts Council, Barbara Furst,. chairman of the State Council on the Arts, said. We're a public body, and we want to establish a greater visibility with arts groups statewide so that we can learn who they are and try to be helpful to them.

title: Daniel James, First Black to Be a Full General, Dies
description: Daniel (Chappie) James Jr., a former commander of the North American Air Defense Command who was the first black'to rise to the rank of fourstar general, died of a heart attack yesterday in Colorado Sorings. He was 58 years old.

title: Koch Says the City Will Repave Whole Blocks to. Erase Potholes
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that, as a result of recent storms, potholes in the streets had become so deep and so numerous that rather than fill each pothole separately, the city would repave some blocks entirely.

title: Watts Schedules Schubert Celebration
description: Andre Watts will appear in eight concerts. in four weeks at Alice Tully Hall next season as part of a personal Celebration of Schubert commemorating the 150th anniversary of the composer's death. The cycle will come toward the end of an eightmonth American tour by the pianist devoted to Schubert's music.

title: Rutgers Routs Pitt, Wins League Title
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.. Feb. 25 (AP)Rutgers scored the first 9 points and went on to defeat Pitt, 8768, tonight. The victory gave Rutgers a 215 record and earned the Scarlet Knights the Eastern Athletic Association regular season title. Villanova and Rutgers are 73 in the league, but the Knights will be topseeded in next weekend's tournament on the basis of a better overall record.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY The Reluctant Snowthrower
description: MY SNOWBLOWER loves warm weather. It is never happier than in July and August, standing by the pool and soaking in the summer sun. At these times, it is the soul of cooperation and amiability.

title: What's Doing in FORT LAUDERDALE
description: THE NAME IS THE GAME - Fort Lauderdale, the bustling resort 25 miles north of Miami on Florida's Gold Coast, has many claims to fameand with typical Florida flair, it has affixed title to just about every one of them.

title: The Only Way To Run a Railroad
description: GREENWICH WHEN he was a boy growing up in St. Louis, Elliot K. Ludington would sneak away from his family to ride the trains in the nearest railyards. Mv father's plant was a block from the levy and I used to go down there and ride the switch engines, the little cars in the yards that went to and from the big locomotives, he said. I can remember going to the plant with my father and winding up on a switch engine in Selville, Ill.

title: Amy Beth Peterman Is Engaged to Mark Schneider
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ira H. Peterman of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Beth Peterman, to Mark Harris Schneider, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Schneider of Hewlett Harbor, L. I. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Columbia Swimmers Win Met Title Again
description: Columbia captured its fourth consecutive metropolitan swimming title last night at Alumni Hall pool at St. John's University. The Lions won the threeday event with a 543 points, followed by St. John's with 417 and Monmouth College with 382.

title: Vermeer. Aristotle. Nero. Seneca. Kissinger.
description: BRUSSELSVermeer's astronomer holds his hand extended toward globe in a gesture of proof that is et the same time an act of hope. Like him, sometimes, at the close of wearisome day of international conferences, I extend my exhausted hand toward my books in the hope of catching hold of some life preserver.

description: PURCHASE

title: Fashion and Desi  n THE PERETTI OBSESSION
description: For almost a decade, former model Elsa Peretti has been designing highly original, sensuous and sometimes macabre jewelry that has become a runaway best seller. Now her talent has taken a more ambitious turn, offering fresh insights into the woman behind the artist  and the private vision behind the art.

title: The World; In Summary; The Mideast: All Movement Is Up in the Air; Rhodesia's Uneasy Transition Period; How Much Does Chile Know?; Peking Says It With Music; The Evolution Of Devolution
description: Alfred L. Atherton, the United States special envoy to the Middle East, who hadbeen home for consultations, was back on his beat last week, shuttling between Israel and Egypt in search of agreement on the principles of a peace settlement. In Jerusalem; Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan said the Israelis had reviewed the Egyptian proposals conveyed by Mr. Atherton and the important thing is that there is a continuation of negotiations. Mohammed Ibrahim Kamel, Mr. Dayan's Egyptian counterpart, made a similar nonstatement in Cairo after a later meeting with Mr. Atherton.

title: UConn 57. Manhattan 54
description: STORRS, Conn., Feb. 25 (AP)A layup by Jim Abromaitis with a minute left and two free throws by Dennis Wolff with one second remaining tonight gave Connecticut a 5754 victory over Manhattan. Each team's record is now 11-4.

title: Withdrawal Of American Forces Still a Sticky Issue
description: WASHINGTON  Perhaps the most spirited defense of the planned withdrawal of United States troops from South Korea was delivered last summer by the United States Ambassador to Seoul, Richard L. Sneider. He spoke with some heat to reporters accompanying Defense Secretary Harold Brown on a visit Seoul.

H: Raskin, former assistant editor, of the editorial page of The New York Times and a labor expert, will join the National News Council on Wednesday as chief staff officer on freedom of the press and ethical issues. The council, a nonprofit organization, was set up five years ago as a watchdog on news organizations.

description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 25 (UPI)Jack Givens scored 18 points today and led Kentucky to a 6857 victory over Tennessee. The victory clinched at least a share of the Southeastern Conference championship for Kentucky.

description: WESTPORT THE upstairs wing of Dr. Dana Raphael's home used to contain the bedrooms of her three children. Now it is the headquarters of the Human Lactation center Ltd., an international foundation that studies infant feeding practices throughout the

title: Limited Plan for Coal Leasing On Federal Land is Announced
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)Interior Secretary Cecil D. Andrus today announced an agreement that would allow him to resume limited leasing of coal deposits on Federal land in the West. The leasing has been blocked by a lawsuit since last September.

title: MergingIs It A Better Way?
description: NEW JERSEY'S municipalities could save their taxpayers untold millions of dollars in taxes each year if local officials had the wisdom, imagination and will to fully explore the values of regionalizing services.

description: Apart from its nearterm economic impact, admittedly considerable in some industries and areas of the country, the lengthy coal strike of 197778 will have some profound and lasting effects noon major national issues.

title: Elizabeth Gildan, a Student, Fiancee of Mark Desnoyers
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Gildan of North Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Gildan, to Mark Reid Desnoyers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Desnoyers Jr. of Watchung, N J.

description: Wit, wisdom, learning and the glow of a rare personality: How does I.F. Stone manage to get all that into one magazine article (I.F. Stone Interviews I.F. Stone at Seventy: Izzy on Izzy Jan. 22), and with such ease and style? Dazzling!

title: A Victory for Dissident Shareholders
description: Dissident shareholders won a quiet victory last week as the Securities and Exchange Commission decided to be less tolerant of companies that exclude minority shareholder proposals from their proxy materials. The decision was unanimous, although chairman Harold Williams expressed misgivings that the commission might be opening up Pandora's Box.

title: Americans Buy in Britain
description: LONDONEveryone, it seems, wants to buy a house. or apartment in Britain these days, and if possible in London. The real estate market here is now finding it impossible to cope with deniand from overseas buyers, who are now competing with one another rathenthan the British to buy the biggest, best and most expensive property.

description: UNIONDALE, LI., Feb. 25 After scoring many of his goals this season with his instantaneous scoop shot, seemed inappropriate for Mike Bossy to set a National Hockey League rookie scoring record off a skate deflection.

Michael Said, and they put .tO . use with shameless exuberance any .handy musical or dramatic materials that to suit their needs.

description: WILMINGTON, N.Y., Feb. 25The marvelous Mahres, The twinbrother skiers from White Pass, Wash., gave an outstanding exhibition today by dominating the national men's slalom championship on Whiteface Mountain.

title: The Realpolitik Of Foreign Aid

It was laudable gesture, but the results were not likely to encourage other agency heads to repeat the experiment.

title: At Home: Fighting the Enemy Within
description: YOU work at home? Oh, you're so lucky! This what everyone says, but how would they know when they haven't tried it? How could they guess that I suffer more from distractions out here in the country than St. Anthony did in the desert?

description: MIDDLETOWN MANY PEOPLE think that college students lose touch with the everyday problems of the outside world when they become immersed in a self-contained, relatively homogeneous campus environment. But some of us do care about relating to the communities in which we live.

description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., Feb. 25 (AP)Earl Anthony became professional bowling's leading career moneywinner today when he captured the $15,000 first nrize in a $100.000 tournament

title: India Giving Vietnam a $50 Million Credit to Rebuild
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 25Indian officials said today that after two days of talks with Prime Minister Pham Van Dong of Vietnam, they had agreed to offer deirelopmentt assistance and to help in his country's postwar reconstruction. -

title: 1845 Organ to Be In Tune With Times
description: SAG HARBOR LAST spring when the pastor of the Sag Harbor Presbyterian Church summoned his congregation to an organ recital, he apologized to the gathering for what it was about to hear.

title: Experts Ask If Suburbs Really Need Costly Sewers
description: BAY SHORE, L.I.There was a time, only a few years ago, when sewers were being proclaimed as an absolute neces sity for the suburbs, just as it was argued that they were vital forurban sanitation. Now the experts aren't so sure.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: The Museum of Modern Art opens its fourth annual Perspectives on French Cinema on Thursday. The series includes nine feature films, a number of which are currently in their Paris firstrun, and two programs of shorts. Opening night features Bertrand Tavernier's Spoiled Children, about the relationship between middleaged director/screenwriter and younger woman. Mr. Tavernier will introduce his film, as will other filmmakers later on in the series, which runs through March 14. (See Film)

title: Casino School Draws Flood of Students
description: ATLANTIC CITY MORE than 1,200 prospective dealers and croupiers have registered throughout the state for classes that they hope will lead to jobs when the first gambling casino opens here later this Par

title: Army 66, Navy 62
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 25 (UPI)Clutch foul shooting by Matt Brown and Pat Harris in the final minute today helped Army to a 66-62 victory over Navy

title: THE SURPRISE PICNIC
description: The sensibility behind this wordless outing is not so much nostalgia as tasteful antiquarianism. Goodall's Mother and Sister Cat are impeccably turned out in long dresses and sunbonnets; Brother Cat is jaunty in an Eton collar and jacket. Their miniadventure unfolds via alternating full and halfwidth pages: Turn one panel and the rock on which the cats have spread their picnic lunch is transformed into a giant tortoise. Turn another and a gust of wind takes Mama Cat and her parasol flying. Too often, though, Goodall fails to coordinate the surprises, and the halfpage overleaf serves no real purpose. This reduces the format to a gimmick, perhaps, but it's one that very young children respond to.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: WALTER JACKSON BATE'S biography of Samuel Johnson appeared on nearly every yearend list of the best books of 1977. In a poll of the members of the National Book Critics Circle, the national critics and reviewers association, it was by far the most popular book of the year, and it went on to win the N.B.C.C.'s award for general nonfiction. Even People magazine, the national gossip weekly, has featured Bate, complete with pipe, in his booklined Harvard study. Is this another instance nostalgia, a neoVictorian reaction to the Romantic barbarities of the 1960's? Does it express a longing for a central cultural authority, a dangerous regressive craving for the literary law and order of a bygone Tory age? I don't think so.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: IN THESE days of commercial products that seem to be of little value except as the insides of carefully selected packages and namespackaging and names designed to attract, excite, titilate and to make us buywe should be aware of the modest research of Prof. Hershey Friedman of Montclair State College and one of his students, William S. Dipole Jr.

title: Arkansas 84. T.C.U. 42
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Feb. 25 (AP) Ron Brewer scored 23 points and led Arkansas to an 84.42 victory over Texas Christian tonight in the first round of the Southwest Conference tournament., The victory gave Arkansas a 272 record and moved the Razorbacks into the quarterfinal round against Southern Methodist Thursday night at Houston.

title: Correction
description: Ann Douglas in her review of The Protestant Temperament(Feb. 5) referred to a book by Alan Heimert using the title of a book by Perry Miller. The title of the Heimert book is Religion and the American Mind.

title: John McKeen, ExPfizer Chairman
description: John. E. McKeen, who rose from painterto chairman of the board during a 42year career with Pfizer Inc., died in his sleep on Thursday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 74 years old.

title: New York Mortgage Taxes Rise
description: New York City's mortgage and transfer tax collections, are up by more than 20. percent because of a sharp increase in real estate market activity, Harry S. Tishelman, the Finance Commissioner, reported. During the seven-onth period ended last Jan. 31, the city took in $30.2 million in such taxes, a 23.5 percent increase over the same period a year ago.

title: TV VIEW
description: JOHN J. O'CONNOR

title: Promise and Peril of Offshore Oil
description: The last legal obstacle to longdelayed oil and gas exploration in the Baltimore Canyon area off the coast or New Jersey has been removed  but doubts about possible environmental damage remain unresolved. More than 18 Months ago the Federal Government leased exploration and development rights to the oil and gas companies. A lawsuit filed by local officials and en- vironmentalists blocked the project. Initially, a Federal judge. canceled the leases because environmental protections were a charade. But that decision was overturned on appeal, and last week, by refusing to hear the case, the Supreme Court ended the impasse.

title: Arizin, Pollard, Hagan Among 5 Elected to Hall
description: Four forwards who starred in the National Basketball Association in the 1940's and 1950's and a referee who worked for 30 years in high school, college and professional games were elected yesterday to the Naismith Baskeball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass.

title: This Week Will Be Pivotal in U.S.Korea Relations
description: WASHINGTON  Tongsun Park's threeweek stand on Capitol Hill may prove to be one of the most anticlimactic events of the year.

title: John Foster, Allen and Eleanor
description: A Biography of Eleanor, Allen and John Foster Dulles and Their Family Network.

title: Diane C. Goss Plans Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Carpenter Goss of Westport, Conn., and Block Island, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Catherine Goss, to Karr Winslow Farrell Jr. of Marblehead, Mass. An August wedding is planned.

title: `Teaching Toys For Children
description: Y OU'RE a boy. You can't play here, the 4-year-old girl said in an effort to reduce the crowding around the dollhouse. When he is playing ball tomorrow, do you think you might want to play too? her teacher asked. The response was positive. Then how would you feel if he said you couldn't play ball because you're a girl? The boy was quickly invited back.

title: James Jones: The Last Novel
description: SAGA PONACK TO help him remember the past that dominated his creative life for 30 years, James Jones kept picture of Company F of the 27th Infantry near the typewriter in the attic studio of his farmhouse here. Neatly penciled over the chests of the men smil: big outside Schofield Barracks in in November 1941 are the abbreviations W.I.A., K.I.A. or Tr (for wounded in action, killed in action and transferred). Few of the chests, including James Jones's, are unmarked.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Our schools are teaching a lie in every history class in New Jersey. There is no democracy in the Hackensack Meadowlands!

title: Machine Tools: Uproar Over A Bottleneck
description: CINCINNATIIve got a bonfire going, and those guys want to standardize buckets. Frank Daley, director of manufacturing development for the General Motors Corporation, was venting his frustration over a favorite whipping boy of American industry, the machine tool business.

title: New NATO Arms to Challenge Soviet Lead in Tanks
description: The Soviet Union's longestablished tank superiority in Central Europe is about to be challenged by an armory of new weapons developed by the United States and NATO allies.

title: Herman Kahn Revisited
description: CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.The path to Herman Kahn's office at the Hudson Institute is labyrinthine. There are enough sharp turns to make the most intrepid visitor feel like the.tnythi. cal Minotaur. Mr. Kahn's conversation is much the same. He speaks in mazes, enveloping nis ustener wan wails of ideas, throwing open tempting new avenues with each new sentence. But there is always an exit, and of course it leads to hispoint.

title: AMICHAI PAGLIN, ADVISER OF BEGIN ON TERRORISM
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 25 (UPI)Amichai Paglin, an adviser to Prime Minister Menahem Begin on enemy terrorism, died today of injuries suffered in a car crash three weeks ago. He was 55 years old.

title: Stormy Seas for Canadian Economy
description: The news coming from Canada about the nation's troubled economy is as chilling and forbidding as its February .weather. Inflation is booming at a 9 percent annual rate, unemployment is record 8.3 percentone of the highest rates in the inciustrializea worldand the Canadian dollar is at a historical low. But last week the Government announced plans to increase official spending during the next fiscal year almost 10 percent.

title: K. S. Glasser Fiance Of Meri N. Yarmark
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ted Saretsky of Hewlett Neck, LI., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Saretsky's daughter, Meri Nan Yarmark, to Kerry Stuart Glasser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Glasser of Manhattan. A June wedding is planned.

title: Around the Nation
description: CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 25 (AP)The Center for Disease Control has finally won permission to study some Navy records in connection with possible radiation deaths at the Portsmouth Naval Yard, and one of the health experts says the investigation may be expanded to other shipyards.

title: BRIDGE
description: Thirty hirty years ago New York experts used standard bidding methods and had little to discuss when they sat down to play. Since then systerns, styles and conventions have proliferated. There is still a common denominator, but not the same one. This was demonstrated at the Blue Ribbon Individual here earlier this month, where only three of the 36 players, B. Jay Becker, Morrie Elis and Matt Granovetter opted for the methods of the 1930's. The remainder, apart from handful who played strong club systems when they faced regular partners, played Eastern Scientific.

title: Stan Kenton And His Band. Play at Pace
description: Stan Kenton brought his band to New York Friday evening for the first time since he suffered a brain concussion last.May. Mr. Kenton still looked wan and drawn from his illness as he led his 19piece orchestra in a concert at Schimmel Center of Pace University. He spent most of the evening seated at the piano, listening to his musicians, playing only an occasional chorus on slow ballads such as Body and Soul and Chelsea Bridge as well as his traditional introductory chorus to his theme, Artistry in Rhythm.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Our whole society operates on the principle of the carrot and stick, so why not incentives for students? said Bill Maher, a member of the San Francisco Board of Education.

title: Phoebe Montgomery Becomes the Bride Of Dr. Mark Moeller
description: Phoebe Sands Montgomery, daughter of Mrs. Rees Evans Howard and Rodman Bowne Montgomery Jr., both of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Mark Bolton Moeller of Durham, N.J., son of Dr. and Mrs. Dade W. Moeller of Bedford, Mass.

title: The Innovative Jazz Arsenal Of Roscoe Mitchell
description: Five years ago, the proposition that Roscoe Mitchell was one of the most important musicians in jazz would have seemed questionable, at best, to most musicians and critics. Although he made two interesting and somewhat influential albums in 1966 and 1968, the Chicagoborn alto saxophonist, who also plays a battery of other wind instruments and is now 37 years old, spent 196973 playing almost exclusively with the collectively organized and leaderless Art Ensemble of Chicago. Almost everyone agreed that the Art Ensemble was important, but many jazz tastemakers also found the group's music dense and abstruse. And anyway, it was difficult to pick out individual threads in its determinedly collective fabric.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Hindu Homer. Only a few authors whose work is acclaimed for. its literary style and perception ever see three of their books issued in paperback within a few weeks span, Certainly unique among them is a writer who has been totally blind since he was 3  Ved Mehta. His new paperbacks:

title: How Costly Is a Held Door?; NOT RESPONSIBLE FOR PERSONAL ARTICLES; By JUDITH VIORST
description: By Lois Gould.

title: 25 Years Later, New Baubles and Bangles for Kismet
description: 25 Years Later, New Baubles and Bangles for Kismet

title: Katherine Keesling Engaged to Student
description: Col. Earl Lloyd Keesling, U.S.A., and Mrs. Keesling of Madrid and Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Joan Keesling, to W. Ross Newland 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy M. Newland of Madrid, formerly of Essex Fells, N.J., and Mexico City.

title: Reds Get Relief Pitcher For Revering and Cash
description: CINCINNATI,Feb. 25 (UPI)  The Cincinnati Reds today traded first baseman Dave Reveringthe minor leaguer who was included in the canceled Vida Blue dealto the Oakland A's in exchange for relief pitcher Doug Bair.

title: Article 6 -- No Title
description: Article 6 -- No Title

title: I Turned In Empty Milk Bottles for 3 Cents. My Son Can't
description: MASSAPEQUA PARK, N.Y.Though I am now a suburbanite, I am really a city person at heart. I was born and reared in a Bronx ghetto, lived in a firetrap of a building, spent my boyhood on hard pavement, and played out my fantasies in schoolyard sports. Then marriage and children came, and the inevitable decision, in 1963, that suburbia would be a more ideal place for our son, who is now 16, to grow up than the inner city. Little did I realize we were cutting him off from a vital link from our own past.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: I saw him as the tragic image that stirred my imagination, William Butler Yeats wrote of Michio Ito. Elsewhere, Yeats described Ito this way: He was able, he rose from the floor where he had been sitting crosslegged, or as he threw out an arm, to recede from into some more nowerful life. Who was Michio Ito?

title: London Casinos: A Clubby World
description: Since 1960, when Britain legalized casinos, gambling has been a major tourist attraction in London and it is now the liveliest aspect of London night life. Affluent cosmopolitan visitors flock to London for a variety of reasons, and for many these include an opportunity to wager in the urbane and clubby atmosphere of the city's top casinos.

title: CRIME
description: The ingredients in TALON by James Coltrane (BobbsMerrill, $8.95) are rather familiar: little man, caught between two big forces, goes on the run. But Mr. Coltrane handles the material in an altogether superior manner.

title: The Facelift: Is It Worth It?; Facelift for the Home: Is It Worth It?
description: Some people still shudder at the mention of aluminum sidingor, for that matter, any siding with a plastic look.

title: An AgeOld Problem: Finding Work After 70
description: Ireally did not expect to be back in the unemployment line so soon but after six months, I was filling out forms again with a potential employer. It seemed to me that the reasons for being in the line were, once again, about the same: retrenchment and reduction of staff. The first time, I was no longer a member of the working force, because I was mandatorily retired. The second time I was replaced by a computer.

title: U.S. CAUTIONS SOVIET ITS ACTION IN AFRICA MAY HURT RELATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The United States cautioned the Soviet Union today that relations between the two countries could be impaired by continued Soviet military involvement in the conflict between Ethiopia and Somalia.

title: Mexican Banditry: A Reverse Twist
description: We are coasting through an apparently deserted Mexican hamlet some distance from Oaxaca, when one of our party spots an elderly woman frantically trying to flag us down. We make Uturn, pulling up in front of a shabby cafe of peeling stucco. The woman, ele- gantly dressed and complete with pearl choker, earrings and brooch, sprints over to our camper.

title: DINING OUT
description: BOCCACCIO in Hicksville has undergone some changes in the last year. The bar area was shortened, making the dark-wood-trimmed dining room far more spacious and comfortable. Then, last September, Vincenzo Torre sold the restaurant. (He has just opened a new place in Freeport)

title: The Job: Some Find It, Some Must Wait
description: THE Federal Comprehensive Employment and Training Act program was intended. to ease the recession's impact by finding jobs in the public or private sectors for those people who cannot find them on their own. Nassau's $60 million CETA program encompasses people from various ethnic and economic backgrounds, and has had varying degrees of success. Sometimes CETA works; sometimes it doesn't.

title: MARKETS
description: The script for the stock market remained the same for most of last week. There were the same familiar worries of investors over the economic impact of the coal strike, rising interest rates and a jittery United States dollar in foreignexchange dealings. One result was a continuing string of daily declines in stock prices and successive new 34month lows for the Dow Jones industrial average. On Friday, however, hopes for a settlement of the coal strike and encouraging figures in the nation's latest moneysupply report sent stock prices ahead in a brisk rally.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: The CamerataOrchestra of Salzburg has for years been familiar to American listeners through its recordings under Bernhard Paumgartner and Geza Anda. Surprisingly enough,, its appear&nee last .Sunday afternoon at Town Hall marked the group's. first New York concert. The conductor was Antonio Janigro, its artistic director since 1975.

title: IN BRIEF
description: West Germany and the United States agreed to be more polite to each other (in public) when the talk turns to Germany's role in the world economy. The Carter Administration has been urging. faster German economic growth to help keep the world's economy perking, but Bonn has steadfastly rejected the sort of fiscal pumppriming necessary to achieve that pace.... Japan, another ally who has been the object of American advice, last week announced what may be its largest postwar bankruptcy. The Eidai Sangyo Company, the country's biggest producer of plywood, is the latest casualty of the general Japanese economic stagnation. Last year's losses were said to be $58 million, while liabilities ballooned to an estimated $750 million.

title: County En Route to Roadbuilding Again
description: County En Route to Roadbuilding Again transportation officials and others concerned with county planning, emphasis has been swinging from building limitedaccess routes to rehabilitating and improving existing roads and rights of way, including major upgradings, widenings and safety improvements.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Madeline Kahn asks the key question quite early in the new Betty ComdenAdolph GreenCy Coleman musical, On the 20th Century. pops up in a flashback, one devoted to that historic moment in which zany Broadway impresario Oscar Jaffee (John Cullum) first lays eyes and hands on the girl who will become Lily Garland, his star, his, true love and, quite naturally as these things go, his mortal enemy.

title: Filming the Saga Of a Sage With Peter Brook
description: The unpredictable, versatile Peter Brook, who electrified audiences here and in England with his unconventional stage productions of King Lear, A Midsummer Night's Dream and Marat /Sade and who has since been experimenting in France, Africa and Asia with integrating new languages and ancient cultures into novel theater experiences, has for the past six months been absorbed in filmmaking on an epic scale. Though best known for his stage productions, Brook has worked in film before (Lord of the Flies, MaratSade and Lear, for example), but never on as grand or as unconventional an undertaking as his present effort, which recounts nothing less than a philosophical quest for meaning in life.

title: Celebrating Man's Compulsion to Fly
description: Twenty years after his epic flight to Paris in the Spirit of St. Louis, Charles Lindbergh quietly revisited the plane as it hung in the old Arts and Industries Building of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. Requesting a ladder, so the story goes, the aviator climnea to the darkened cockpit and sat there for 20 minutes. When he came down he compli- mented a museum official on the plane's excellent condition.

title: The A.F.L.C.I.O. Takes a New Tack on TradeProtection Policy
description: If the winds of protectionism didn't subside, they at least changed direction last week as the A.F.L.C.I.O. abandoned its call for a single comprehensive trade bill and asked instead for series of legislative steps to protect American workers from foreign competition.

title: New York to Get Road Safety Grant
description: New York State will receive a special $3.5 million Federal award for reducing traffic deaths in 1976, but the number of fatalities in vehicle accidents rose in 1977, accordipg to reports issued by two state agencies last week.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Aid May Help State to Farm Sea
description: AQUACULTURE sounds like something that a farmer who had had one too many might have said when talking about his business. Actually, aquaculture and agriculture have a lot in common.

title: Events Today
description: Winter Carnival: children's festival, with puppet shows, dance, magic, food, games, entertainment; 1 to 5 P.M.; Brownstone Learning and Day Care Center 128 West 80th Street.

title: Maxine Schaeffer Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Schaeffer of Oceanside, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maxine Nan Schaeffer, to Scott Brad Ehrenpreis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Ehrenpreis of Fayetteville, N. Y.

title: The Begin Government Apparently Believes the Answer Is Land.
description: JERUSALEM - For years, many Israeli political and military leaders have used the phrase secure and defensible borders to explain their opposition returning the Arab territory Israel captured in the 1967 Middle East war. But in view of Anwar elSadat's peace overture, and the influx of modem weaponry on both sides of the ArabIsraeli dispute, there have been the stirrings of a debate in Israel over whether the post1967 borders really mean security.

title: China's Nominal Congress Opening Session Today; Will Vote a 10Year Plan
description: PEKING, Feb. 25 (Reuters)China's nominal parliament meets tomorrow to approve the Government's policies in the postMao era and a 10year economic plan running to 1985.

title: Director of Kidney Disease Institute Foresees the Day When Donating Body Organs Will Be Commonplace
description: Eventually the donation of organs and body parts will be as commonplace as donating blood, said Dr. Bernard Pollera, director of the Kidney Disease Institute of the New York State Department of Health.

title: What Feminists Really Believe
description: As a member of the National Organization for Women and as a Roman Catholic whose heart is fully with the Right to Life movement, I protest against Miss Lengers's narrow accusations. To state, as she has, that feminists hate men is to insult and ignore the majority of feminists who seek a healthy, loving equality with men as an alternative to the parasitically imbalanced marriages of the past. Whereas Miss Lengers would prefer the stagnancy of destructive sex roles, feminists dare to be human beings, integrating all facets of their personalities into self-acceptance.

title: A Programmed Look at Cuba: Fascinating and Frustrating
description: In the dusty village of San Pedro de Mayabon, a woman lovingly hugged her new electric refrigerator as she showed a visitor through her poor but spotlessly clean shack.

title: Chronic Repression and Corruption Undermine the Somozas Alliances
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  Sporadic demonStratIons against the Somoza regime in Nicaragua continue, including one violent episode last week in the city of Masaya where several people were reported killed in a clash between soldiers and antigovernment groups. But the air of crisis that prevailed earlier this year is less obvious. This has provided breathing room for President Anastasio Somoza Debayle but It has not apparently influenced him to change his attitudes toward country. government or family.

title: Janina Longtine Engaged to Steven Walske
description: Janina Ann Longtine, who is in her first year at the University of Massachusetts Medical School, plans to be married in June to Steven Carl Waiske, a secondyear student at the Harvard

title: Arezzo, an Old Tuscan Town, Preserves a Bright and Lively Air
description: Roma, Firenze, Venezia, said my Italian friend sadly. That's all you tourists think there is to Italy. You miss so much.

title: Eudice Sheade Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Sheade of Elmhurst, III. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eudice Sheade, to Robert L. Fogel, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Fogel of Northampton, Mass.

title: Carter Picks an ExAstronaut
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Feb. 25 (AP)Maj. Gen. Thomas P. Stafford of the Air Force, who spent more than 500 hours in space, has been nominated by President Carter to be deputy chief of staff of the Air Force for research and development. The 47-year-old former astronaut, who is the commander of the Flight Test Center here would replace Lieut. Gen. A.D. Slay and would be promoted to the rank of lieutenant aeneral. The nomination, announced yeslerday, is subject to Senate confirmation.

title: SHOP TALK
description: HEWLETT

title: Inventing at 14: It's Not Just a Game
description: SAY goodbye to chess, put your backgammon board on the top shelf and mortgage your Monopoly set. There's a whole new generation of board games on the horizon, and if a group of Lawrence, teenagers are any judges, it won't be long before the nation's gamesters are wheeling and dealing in Supply and Demand, setting a strategic across-theboard course in Arrow and seeking the elusive Omega force in Omega.

title: The Legislature--A Profile Of Changing Power
description: TRENTON THE new New Jersey Legislature has a new look. It is relatively young, it is well educated and although oldline lawmakers still hold seats power, the legislators have indicated that they are not going to blindly follow their leaders down the wellworn path of partyline voting.

title: Heiden Scores Twice, Near World Skate Crown
description: GOTHENBERG, Sweden, Feb. 25 (UPI)Eric Heiden of Madison, Wis., neared his sixth consecutive title by winning both the 500- and 5,000meter races before 6,700 spectators at the world speedskating championships today.

description: politan Arts. V ohnist Ruggiero Ricci, guest.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: What is the formula for a Sidney Sheldon novel, we asked Sidney Sheldon, and why do so many people read his books?

title: ART
description: MIDDLETOWN WITH the still growing belief that everyone is capable of art, the categories of amateur and professional are getting ever harder to define. Were money the only criterion, interesting anomalies would result, for there are Sunday painters who live by the art they make, while numerous professionals must work at other occupations, such as teaching, in order to survive. On the other hand, if caliber of performance were the measure, one can think of professionals who would be demoted to amateurs. A difficult case in point is Joseph Reed, whose decorated alphabets are on view in the North Gallery of Wesleyan's Center for the Arts (through March 10).

title: GARDENING
description: GARDENERS will go to any length at this point to hasten spring. All of them are a little weary of looking out at the snowcovered landscape.

title: 30% SAVINGS IN FUEL SEEN IF TRUCKS CUT SPEED TO 55
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI)  The trucking industry says that, its drivers can cut fuel consumption by more than 30 percent if they observe the national speed limit of 55 miles an hour.

title: The Last of the Gentleman Producers?; Deathtrap is the first thriller for de Liagre since Mr. and Mrs. North in 1941.
description: BOSTON is full name is Alfred GusHtav Etienne de Liagre Jr., his friends in the theater world know him as Deily and Katharine Hepburn called him the last of the great gentleman producers.

title: Kay Sutler and Charles Spencer 3d Wed
description: Kay Leigh Sutler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Sutler of Arlington, Tex., was married in Dallas yesterday to Charles Burr Spencer 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer of Bronxville, N.Y., and East Orleans, Mass. The Rev. Richard Schafer performed the ceremony in the Wesley Chapel at Lovers Lane Methodist Church.

title: Sunday Observer
description: You have to be fast nowadays. Things go by at such a rate!

title: Hiyo Dyson!
description: When a state official invests $1 million of precious funds in an advertising campaign to lure business to New York, you would think his watchdogs in the Legislature would demand results. When he informs them that the first ads brought 3,400 inquiries from American investors and 374 from businesses abroad, you would think they might inquire whether that's a good return. When the official is known to be a zealot, who lobbied his Governor and everyone else for huge tax cuts for businesses and businessmen, you would think liberal Democrats would begin to squirm while Republican conservatives cheered. And when the zealot turns out to have a sense of humor, you would think everyone would smile and carry away some hope for New York after all.

title: Gerulaitis and Nastase Toppled in Semifinals
description: OCEAN CITY, Md., Feb, 25 (AP)Both favorites, Ile Nastase and Vitas Gerulaitis, were upset today in the semifinals of a $100,000 international tennis tournament.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: I must take exception to the data in the chart accompanying the article on school aid [A Third Try at School Aid Plan, Jan. 29]. It appears that once again our elected officials in Albany have gone to great pains to reinforce the old adage: Figures don't lie; liars figure.

title: Red Wings 2 Flames 2
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 25 (AP)Dennis Polonich flipped the puck over the Atlanta goalie, Dan Bouchard, midway through the third period tonight and gave the Detroit Red Wings a 22 tie with the Flames in the N.H.L. Polonich's shot in front of the crease caught the top of the net over Bouchard's left shoulder.

title: POLITICS
description: THE influence of the Republican county chairmen on the state legislators from their counties was unusually evident in the recent vote of the State Senate Republican majority on whether to support a September or a June primary. The question of a primary date was not being decided on its governmental merits, but on its impact on the contest for the Republican gubernatorial nominationputting the whole question in a political context.

title: Man Who Gave Name to Report Faced Scandal
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 25Everyone in Wthingtcn called it the Kerner commission, because that was much easier to say than the President's National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders.

title: The Coming Impact of Technology on the Arts Computer Violins and the Electronic Palette
description: New technology is bringing the arts into the 21st century. Computers, once thought to be the enemy of all things creative, are being discovered as tools for composers, painters and choreographers. Television, once looked down on by people in the arts, is becoming seen as a means of rescuing financially strapped arts organizations. At Stanford University, there's a musical instrument that can imitate the sounds of an entire symphony orchestra. Boston technicians and artists are collaborating to create radically new holographic scenic effects for a forthcoming production of Berlioz Damnation of Faust. In the years ahead, modern technology is likely to have a profound effect on music, dance, theater and the visual arts in ways that can only be guessed at 1978.

title: Todd Lowe to Wed Barbara E. Bernald
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Bernald of Ossining, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara i Elaine Bernald, to Lieut. (jg.) Todd Davis Lowe, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lowe of Silver Spring, Md.

title: Year's 10th Snowfall Lightly Mantles Area
description: It was only a dusting, but there was again yesterdaysnow.

title: Israelis Said to Be Seeking Use of Lebanese Villages
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 25The Israelis have tried and failed to win the cooperation of seven Moslem villages in the southeastern border area of Lebanon, according to a spiritual leader of the Shia Moslem community.

title: S. S. Weiss Fiance Of Judith M. Garb
description: Judith Mollie Garb and Samuel Scott Weiss, buyers for Lord & Taylor, plan to be married May 7.

title: New York Revises Rules On Asphalt Bids in Effort To Insure Lowest Prices
description: Major revisions in the bidding process for New York City's huge summer asphalt Contract, which were announced yesterday, will enable city officials to examine the books of asphalt companies and take other steps in an effort to insure that the city is charged the lowest possible prices, an official said.

title: PatriciaK,Ray Becomes Bride
description: In Christ Episcopal Church in Aiber. merle, N. C., yesterday afternoon, Patricia Kennedy Ray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Blacksher Calhoun Ray Jr. of Albermarle, became the bride of James Bridwell Igleheart Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Igleheart of Evansville, Ind.

title: 35 Choice Captures Widener

title: Harvard Is Debating Curriculum To Replace General Education

title: Leon Russell Joined by His W ife In Bill at WellFilled Music Hall
description: As a brooding, mysterious rock-androil presence, Leon Russell knew few peers. The organizer and inspiration for the Joe Cocker Mad Dogs and Englishmen tour, Mr. Russell could let Mr. Cocker _command the limelight and still emerge as almost the star of the show. His piano playing, steeped in  the style of early rock and its various antecedents, was fluent and energetic, and his overall musicality seemed joyful and communal.

title: 489 Residents of Cities Questioned in Survey
description: The latest survey by The New York Times and CBS News was based on telephone interviews with 932 respondents in Eastern and Midwestern cities with populations of 250,000 or more. Of the total, 489 respondents were white, 374 were black and 69 were other nonwhites.

title: GARDENING
description: ONIONS and their relatives were a staple in the diet of the Sumerian culture in 2300 B.C. The Egyptian laborers who constructed the pyramids subsisted on a diet of coarse bread, onions and beer in 1200 B.C. The citizens of Imperial Rome are said to have taken pride in their pungent breath, brought about by eating onions laced with evilsmelling asefetida. Nero was given the nickname of leek breath for his habit of chewing leeks to clear his throat.

title: Carter And the Communists
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Carter Administration is going through another of those periodic reappraisals of its policies toward the Communist nations, and several subtle changes are under way.

title: Robert Payne, Over 100
description: HE thinks of himself as lazy and inefficient; and the day slips by as he wanders through bookstores and libraries; and evenings he spends with friends; and half thenight he dozes and dreams and paces and looks out the window; and all he has managed to do in 66 years is write 110 books.

title: Blair Fawcett Fiance Of Mary Templeton
description: The engagement of Mary Templeton to Blair Redding Fawcett has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Templeton of Riverdale, the Bronx, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. W. H. Fawcett Jr. of Norwalk, Conn., and Pogosa Springs, Colo., and the late Mr. Fawcett, who was chairman of Fawcett Publications of Greenwich, Conn. An October wedding.is planned.

title: LEVITT AUDIT CITES SCHOOL BOARD ABUSES
description: New York State's Comptroller, Arthur Levitt, said yesterday that despite his warning five years ago, the city's Board of Education had failed to correct its salary and retirement practices and continued to misuse its assigned chauffeurs.

title: Food
description: We have been speaking much of revolutions in the kitchen recently, pondering and writing about the wondrous avenues that food processors have opened to home cook. At the same time that this revolution has been taking place, interest breadmaking has greatly increased. When we have written of making bread especially the hard-to-achieve welltextured loaf of French bread  we have, more often than not, described the traditional technique for making it  mixing and kneading by hand and so on. We have often, too, recommended the use of special bread pans for making bread. In the method photographed here, a food processor does all the mixing, kneading by hand is kept to a minimum, and the bread is made by simply shaping and baking the loaf on a baking sheet.

title: STAMPS
description: Segments from an unusual American quilt done in colorful basket design constitute the format of new 13cent block of four stamps being put out on March 8 at Charleston, W. Va. It is the second issue in the American Folk Art Series that began last year with the Pueblo Indian Pottery block of four.

title: Battle Over U.S. Lands in the West Centers on Wild Horses in Nevada

title: THE HUMAN FACTOR IN GRAN GREENE
description: Where is Graham Greene now and what is he up to? We've been asking this question for years. The most accomplished of English novelists has been making only fitful visits to London in the last 10 years and, anyway, in the manner of the old Jacobite spies, he is man of disappearances on the longest possible air flights, in mysterious company, usually simply his own. Even in London he had the habit of resigning from clubs. The last I had heard of him was that he had turned up with Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos at the recent Panamanian Conference in Washingtonstrange for one who has never been a conference man. Was it some lark, some personal affection or whim that drew him there? He flew track, of course, on the Concorde how many novelists have done that? skipped off to Belfastnot exactly a pleasure dome nowfor a cold whiff of fearbut he might as well have been in Asunci6n drinking with his Honorary Consul, in Cuba, Haiti, Hawaii, Saigon, the Congo, his house in Anacapri, or with the Third Man in Vienna or in the Lawless Roads of Mexico at the time of the of the Church.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Acouple of years ago we had what was widely known as the Roots phenomenon, a reference to the popularity of Alex Haley's book. Now, on a lesser scale, we have what might be called the Origins phenomenon. This phenomenon embraces both a book and a genre. The book is Richard E. Leakey's and Roger Lewin's Origins, a popular treatment of the origins of man and evolution, which has been on the bestseller list a number of times, has sold more than 60,500 copies retail in addition to 80,000 through the Literary Guild and enjoys a steady demand, according to the publisher, E.P. Dutton.

title: The World
description: ROME  Giulio Andreotti, the Christian Democrat who resigned as Italy's Prime Minister in midJanuary under pressure from the Communists and has since been trying patch together a new government with their support, has reputation for being unflappable, adept and charming to opponents and supporters. Yet the compromise has eluded him for seven weeks. One difficulty, which arose again last week, is that the leadership of his party has not decided whether wants to accept the Communists minimum demand: a contractual agreement making the Communist Party formally Member of the government coalition and thus creating precedent for its participation in future governments.

Our reviewer, Lois Gould, described Brooke Hayward's `memoir as a glowing tapestry spun with equal parts of gold and pain. A best seller in hardcover.

title: WrapAround Audience:, Is Coming to Denver
description: At the March 4 inaugural concert of the Denver Symphony's new $13million home, Boettcher Symphony Hall, after the last notes of Vaughan Williams's Serenade to Music have died away, conductor Brian Priestman will hear the usual applause behind him. But he will also hear applause in front of him and on both sides. For Boettcher Hall will have 360degree surround seating, the first indoor concert facility with such a design in the United States.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: This year is the 150th anniversary of the death Franz Schubert, and observances are being made everywhere, especially in Schubert's native Vienna. Last year Beethoven was being celebrated; he had died in 1827, the year before Schubert, and the music world took due note of the sesquicentennial. The year before that saw the sesquicentennial of the ieatn Carl Maria von Weber. Alas ! Nobody paid it any mind. Weber, who died in London in 1826, was the founder of German Romantic opera. He was a prolific composer, and to the 19th century he was a lodestar. He was one of the greatest pianists of his day, and the first of the great conductors as we understand the term today. But hardly any of his music remains in the active repertory.

title: Briton, in Jordan, Warns Of Risks If Negotiations In the Mideast Collapse
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 25 (Reuters)Foreign Secretary David Owen of Britain warned Middle Eastern countries today of the risks inherent in the failure of the Egyptian peace initiative.

title: Marxism

Russian weapons, technical and economic aid, and legions of Cuban soldiers brought Marxist revolutionaries to power in Angola three years ago and are keeping them there despite continued local resistance. In Ethiopia. they are helping a Marxist military regime consolidate its control over rebels in Eritrea and the Ogaden desert and expel force of invaders from Somalia.

It came in the second half of the opening game against Fox Lane. Valerie was down near the goal when a Fox Lane tuIlback passed the ball. Valerie intercepted it, trapped it, and passed to a second Greeley forwardwho made a clean shot for the score. Horace Greeley won the game 32.

title: Mr. Miller Should Step Aside
description: As difficult as it may be for him and for the Carter Administration, G. William Miller should now step aside and decline the President's nomination to serve as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Questions raised during the stalled confirmation process about Mr. Miller's activities as chairman of Textronthe giant conglom- crate that he would leave to go to Washingtonhave multiplied. Now a cloud hangs over Mr. Miller's head that cannot be blown away by telephone calls from the White House urging key senators to speed the nomination or by a few more days of public hearings before the Senate Banking Committee.

The twodisk set's catchy compendium of popsy stylings by the Bee Gees, inflated middle-of-theroad disco arrangements by David Shire and a mixed bag of older disco hits by other artists reaffirms the genre's ability to appeal to the tastes of mainstream record buyers.

But the company's last major laCIllty Or manuluuturing passenger tires in this city of 270,000the 1,585,000-square-foot threestory Plant 2was not suited for inline radial tire making. title: Choreography Conceived as
description: In a dance by Viola Farber stately paradings may without warning become staggers or crouches, and during graceful turns arms may start flailing like windmills. Skittery runs may expand into wide strides, and grand entrances and exits may be deflated when dancers bump into one another. There are no explicit dramatic situations, and movements appear to relate to nothing but the other movements in the dance, with every movement seeming about to transform itself into a different sort of movement altogether. Is Viola Farber, then, an abstract choreographer? Many dancegoers would say so. But Miss Farber calls her dances reporting.

title: Hal Borland (19001978)
description: For 35 years, Hal Borland was our correspondent the universe. There were snowflakes on his beat, and spring rain, a wood thrush singing in the dusk, an apple tree in bloom. He found them all on his Connecticut farm beside the Housatonic River in the lower Berkshires, but it wasn't just nature he was covering. Of everything in sight, as he once put it, he asked three questions: Who an I? Where am I? What time is it?

Reichley, a vice president at the school: Mr.1 Reichley said Wednesday that he and other school officials believed the budget deficit could be reduced before the fiscal year ends June 30.

These same people, however, would have to be blind not to see that the demographics of the Hamptons are changing rapidly and graphically and will continue to do so with or without a world trade park.

title: The Monastic Life in France: A Quiet Refuge for Paying Guests
description: I am sitting on a stone bench in the courtyard of a small monastery in the Auvergne, an ancient French province in the heart of the Massif Central. A high stone wall and wooden gate shut out the sounds of the traffic streaming across the bridge on the River Allier. A bell on the roof has just rung, and presently there issues from the chapel the sound of sweet thin voices chanting the noon office.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: What I am doing in this space is writing a love letter to Dover Books. Dover has been in business since 1995; I have been acquiring its wellmade, often oversized and always handsome books for years. The majority of them are published in nailer- back. They endure. They open flat without cracking. They are sewn in signatures. The paper on which they are printed is opaque, so that halftones and color plates do not bleed to the other side of the page. They are priced low, averaging about $4 a volume. Dover publishes nearly 150 books a year. A surprising number of them are interesting or instructive, or both.
