title: The Buck Stopped
description: Eightyone days after the first picket line went up, and following intense pressure from the White House, the United Mine Workers and the mine operators finally agreed late last week on terms for ending the coal strike. That did not mean, however, that the 160,000 union miners would immediately go back to work or that the threats of power cutbacks. and layoffs would vanish at once. Rank-and-file miners still have to ratify the agreement, and it is by no means a foregone conclusion that they will do so. That voting could take 10 days; if the agreement is accepted, another week or two could pass before trucks and rail cars start mined coal.

title: Beauty
description: air coloring of one type or another is used by an estimated 33 million American women and an unknown number of men. Recent news articles have reported that, as a result of National Cancer Institute feeding tests on animals, six common haircoloring ingredients are suspected of presenting a cancer hazard to users. (The six ingredients are: 4-methoxy-mphenylenediamine (4MMPD); 2,4-toluene diamine; 4-amino-2-nitrophenol; 2-nitro-p-phenylenediamine; Direct black 38, and Direct blue 6.) The hazards stem from the fact that chemicals in hair dyes can be absorbed into the body through the skin and scalp.

title: AROUD THE Garden
description: Control peach leaf curl, a fungus disease that causes crinkled leaves and hampers tree vitality; use a dormant fungicide spray applied anytime now when the temperature is well above freezing ; mix ferbam or zineb, onehalf cup of wettable powder to five gallons of water. . . Continue checking trees and large shrubs for damage from winter ice wind storms; prune weakened or broken limbs. . . . Cut a few branches of earlyspring flowering shrubs ,to force into bloom indoors.

title: States Rights in India
description: An OId Issue In New Guise Hints Trouble For. Desai

title: GARDENING
description: ONE exhibit at the annual New Jersey Flower & Garden. Show, which is now in full swing at the National Guard armory in Morristown, demonstrates hospitable horticulture. It is a delightful planting

title: Rangers Stun Canadians, 6 to 3, End Montreal Unbeaten Streak
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 25Truth became stranger than fiction tonight at the Forum, Hardy Astrom, a Swedish goaltender who never had played a minute in the National Hockey League, led the Rangers to a startling 63 upset over the Canadiens and ended Montreal's record 28game unbeaten streak.

title: South Africa Fines Journalists
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 25 (AP)A judge has fined 26 black South African journalists $115 each for violating thp Riotous Assemblies Act by holding a protest march Nov. 30. One of those fined yesterday said the march protested the detention of other black journalists in the white minority Government's crackdown on opponents of its segregation policies last fall.

title: Cyprus Decides to Drop Charges Against Writer Who Covered Battle
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 25 (Reuters)The Cyprus Attorney General has decided not to go ahead with criminal proceedings against a Reuters correspondent, John Bierman, over an article he wrote on last Sunday's fighting at Larnaca Airport.

title: A Tennis Prodigy at 12 Is Beaten by the Villain
description: A photograph from The Patriot Ledger in Dedham, Mass., on. May 2, 1966, records the apex of my sporting career. It shows two tennis players holding silver trophies.

title: CAMERA
description: JANET KEALY

title: Joseph Durso
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb.,25When Gil Hodges became manager of the New York Mets in 1968, he gathered the team on the grass here on the first day of spring training and announced: 'My name is Hodges. Nobody realized it, but that was the beginning of an era in baseball: the rise of the Amazing Mets.

title: INTERVIEW
description: HARTFORD AT 58 years old, Sister Clare Markham looks like a perfect choice to play a grandmother with cookies in the oven and knitting needles in her hands in a Walt Disney movie. Instead of the nun's habit, she wears classic suits, practical shoes and a small modern silver cross around her neck.

title: The Politics of Police Leadership
description: IN Nassau County, Samuel J. Rozzi has just taken office as Police Commissioner with the full realization that change in county administrations would probably lead his ouster. This, he says, is as it should be.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Watching Daniel Petrie's giggly, not unamusing film version of The Betsy, Harold Robbins's breathless novel about four generations of a Detroit auto family who may may not resemble the Fords, the Dodges the Chryslers (were there ever any Pontiacs who weren't Indians?), I was suddenly panicked by the fear that we might soon run out of the realitte prototypes Inal inspire such fiction. They are going fast and the supply is not inexhaustible. So far Mr. Robbins has already had his way with characters apparently suggested by Howard Hughes (The Carpetbaggers), Porfirio Rubirosa (The Adventurers) and Hugh Heffner/Larry Flynt (Dreams Die First), among others. He even helped himself to the late Jacqueline Susann in his The Lonely Lady, a rather ungentlemanly thing to do, all things considered, since Miss Susann was a colleague in the same big business of the literary hustle, recycling the publicdomain reputations of such people as James Aubrey, Doris Duke, Judy Garland, Jacqueline Onassis and, only heaven knows now, who else, plotting her human comedies as if she were Grant attempting to encircle Richmond (mostly with the same results).

title: Kennedy Center Chamber Group Relates Past. and Present Music
description: The Theater Chamber Players of Kennedy Center in Washington, formed 10 years ago by Leon Fleisher and Dina Koston, is in some respects a counterpart to New York's Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society. The main difference is. that the Kennedy group has a very specific mission in mind, to present music of our time in relation to music of the past.

title: H. H. Stothers Jr Plans to Marry Martha Dillon
description: Martha Langford Dillon, assistant cashier and a lawyer with Citibank, and Hilton Hedley Stothers Jr., a lawyer with Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside & Wolff, New York law firm, will be married in June.

title: Blanket Coats: Colorful WrapUps
description: There have been Peruvian skirts and Mexican shirts. Now there are Indianstyle blanket coats, in another expression of the ethnic movement in fashion. Spotted on New York streets were young women in blanket coats they purchased at Indian reservations in New Mexico. They were made from blankets sold by the Hudson's Bay Company, which also sells coats priced from $50 to $130. A brochure is available. from the company at 33 Stevenson Road, Winnepeg, Manitoba, Canada. The blankets are made in England. Ilie Wacs, a Seventh Avenue coat designer, made some coats from the blankets two years ago and says he sold every pieceabout 500 of them. He may add some for net fall. Wearing their white blankets with red, green, yellow and blue bands are Rim Hastreiter, left, and Rosemary Kent.

title: A Tanglewood Right Here
description: EXCEPT for two highly successful concerts in Eisenhower Park, the world-renowned New York Philharmonic has limited its summer programs to performing a dozen free con- certs in the city's public parks. Would it be feasible to expand its programming to include suburban summer festivals?

title: Met's Otello Saved By Milnes's Arrival
description: Sherrill Milnes, the baritone, was called in to save Friday night's performance of Verdi's Otello at the Metropolitan Opera because the regular substitute for the role of Iago, Anselmo Coizani, was on board a plane to Florida for a rehearsal with the Miami Opera.

title: Yonkers Hits the Wire And Finishes in Money
description: YONKERS, Feb. 25To the surprise of many doomsayers who had insisted that the track would not survive its winter meeting, Yonkers Raceway finally made it to the wire tonight. And while the track may still not be a winner, Yonkers finished in the money and threw the gauntlet to Roosevelt Raceway, which opens Monday.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: By James Tiptree Jr. 319 pp. New York:

title: Treacy Sets 2Mile Marks
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 25 (AP)John Treace of Providence set a New England indoor record for the twomile run and broke the meet record by 10 seconds today in the New England in??? ppiate, championships act Harvard.

title: PEOPLE
description: If the career fits, wear it. John Schumacher was discharged last October as chairman of Bonwit Teller, the retail fashion chain, after being accused of misusing company funds. Now he has found another retailing niche. Mr. Schumacher reported last week that he had become a partner in M. Ferrari Diffusions Inc. This New York concern sells women's clothes made by the Italian company of the same name.

description: Article 7 -- No Title

title: Jane Goldberg Taps With Hoofers
description: Years after the golden days of tap in the 1920's, 30's and early 40's, the days of streetcorner competitions and the Hoofers Club in Harlem, a dancer named Jane Goldberg was bitten by the tap bug. During the last few years, she has absorbed a good deal or that vernaculat f6rm fiom teachers like Charles Cook, Bett Gibson and Jazz Richardson.

title: Better Mousetrap Builders  Beware
description: Assume, for a moment, that you are the chairman of a major corporation and that your research and development department has just reported glad tidings: It has come up with a better mousetrap. But your reaction is sub dued. If you introduce a new mousetrap on the market without first giving notice to your competitors, you may be in violation of the antitrust laws. Indeed, the mousetrap's very introduction may be challenged as monopolization.

title: Cosmos Awaiting Several Starters
description: MIAMI, Feb. 25Only six of the 20 players who have been training here with the Cosmos for the last two weeks will be starters when the regular season opens on April 2.

title: News Summary
description: The United States cautioned the Soviet Union that relations with Washington could be impaired by continued Soviet military involvement in the conflict between Ethiopia and Somalia. The State Department statement was a response to a speech by Leonid I, Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, who said that improved relations were blocked by all kinds of obstacles raised by the United States. [Page 1, Column 3.]

description: CROTONON-HUDSON

title: U.S. IS SAID TO APPROVE UNION GROUP LEGAL PLAN
description: DETROIT,Dec. 25 (AP)A group legal insurance plan for 150,000 members of the United Automobile Workers employed by the Chrysler Corporation has won Federal approval and will be in partial operation within three Months, according to the union.

title: POLITICS The Uncertainties Of the Job Market
description: POLITICAL or party loyalty is often used as an argument for reward, but such rewards are often unevenly distributed and loyalty is one of those words that can be given a dozen subjective definitions.

title: Tanglewood's 9 Weeks To Feature: Innovations
description: The Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., will be extended from its customary eight weeks to nine next summer. The festival, function of the Boston Symphony and Orchestra, is America most famous summer music event; it will open June an and continue through Aug. 27.

title: John M. Brownback And Elizabeth Heppe Set September Bridal
description: Mrs. John E. Krout of Rosemont, Pa., and Price D. Heppe of Newtown Square, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Laudimore Heppe, to John M. Brownback, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse E. Brownback Jr. of Elmira, N.Y, The wedding will take place in September. Miss Heppe, a graduate of the Agnes Irwin School and Centenary College, is an executive secretary with the Tredwffrin Veterinary Hospital in Berwyn, Pa. A member of the Philadelphia Junior League, she made her debut in 1972 at the Philadelphia Charity Ball. Her father is a private investor and her stepfather is president and chairman of the Germantown Savings Bank in .Philadelphia.

title: Nassau Revamps job Training
description: NASSAU COUNTY's federally financed manpowertraining program, described recently by County Executive Francis T. Purcell as an absolutely appalling administrative disaster, is being restructured in an effort to improve its efficiency in finding jobs for the needy.

title: Headliners
description: I fear for my life, Joan Little told a Judge In state supreme Court in Brooklyn. I'd rather take my chances here. With that, Miss Little began what is expected to be a long fight against Governor Carey's order last week that she be returned to North Carolina, where she escaped from prison last October while serving a sentence for breaking and entering. He insistent that Joan Little be returned, Mr. Carey said, referring to North Carolina Governdr James B. Hunt Jr. and citing his own constitutional obligation. Miss Little, who attracted national attention in 1975 when she was acquitted of murdering a white jailer who allegedly had tried to rapeher, has been living in Brooklyn and working as a legal aide.

title: FIRST VOTERS REJECT PATTERN COAL PACT
description: MADISONVILLE, Ky., Feb. 25Tha tentative agreement fashioned in Washington five days ago in independent negotiations and hailed as the catalyst that could lead to the end of the 81day soft coal strike was rejected today by the first miners to vote on it.

title: Carol O'Brien, Bank Aide, Betrothed to T. C. Phelan
description: Mr. and Mrs. James M. O'Brien of Venice, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol O'Brien, to Thomas C. Phelan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Phelan of Westfield. N.J.

description: While St. John's assistant basketball coach, John Kresse, was aiding Lou Carnesecca yesterday in guiding the Redmen to a victory over Providence, Kresse's wife, Vicki, was performing coaching feats of her own. She guided St. John's women's team to a 6855 victory over Brooklyn College in the semifinals of the New York State championships. LingLing hou and Carmen Fletcher scored 18 points apiece,

title: Louise Sharp Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Willoughby Sharp of Moorestown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Louise Hollyday Sharp, to George Foster Hulme, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Harvey Hulme of Framingham, Mass.

title: Miss Navratilova Scores 29th Straight Victory
description: DETROIT, Feb. 25 (UPI)  Top, seeded Martina Navratilova set a winter tour record with her 29th straight victory tonight by scoring 64, 62, over thirdseded Virginia Wade in the semifinals of a $100,000 tennis event.

title: Karen A. Heintges Plans July Wedding
description: Karen Anne Heintges, who teaches French and German at the New Canaan (Conn.) High School, and Philip Emile Gaucher of Weston, Conn., a manager with the TransLux Corporation in Norwalk, Conn., plan to be married next July.

title: Afitz Wins Hep Mile, But Loses in 2Mile
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 25Curt Alitz won his first Heptagonal mile championship tonight. The Army distance running star, who is better known for his exploits at longer distances, outkicked the field with a last quartermile of 59 seconds, and won the event by three yards with a time of 4 minutes 8.23 seconds

title: Linda Hellenbrand Engaged
description: Samuel H. Hellenbrand and Sheila Hellenbrand, both. of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Caryn Hellenbrand, to Dr. Jan David Silberstein, son of Mrs. Sol Richman of Lido Beach, L.I., and the late Dr, Edward L. Silberstein, who. was an obstetrician, gynecologist and endocrinologist. Mr. Hellenbrand is a vice president of ITT. A spring wedding is planned.

title: State of Emergency Is Lifted in Tunisia
description: TUNIS, Feb. 25 (Reuters)The Tunisian Government lifted a state of emergency today that was imposed last month when rioting swept the capital and other cities.

title: U.S.Vatican Cooperation Grows Over Issues in Eastern Europe
description: VIENNA, Feb. 25Specialists on Eastern Europe note that the interests of the United States and the Vatican in that region converge in sane respects and that informal, littlepublicized cooperation between the State Department and Vatican diplomats has developed.

title: Patience Merck Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert W. Merck of Mendham, N. J., and Mattapoisett, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patience Evarts Merck, to Thomas Bowman Chamberlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fletcher C. chamherlin of Sherborn. Mass.

title: Catherine Ciccolella Fiancee Of Ralph Waldo Emerson Jr.
description: Catherine Anne Ciccolella, a senior editor of Mart magazine, a division of MorganGrampian Publishing Company in New York, and Ralph Waldo Emer- son Jr., administrator, news and information, for RCA Corporation's government systems division in Cherry Hill, N. J., will be married May 6 in New York.

title: Spinners Perform at Fisher Hall
description: The Spinners were at Avery Fisher Hall Friday night. One is tempted to call them the new Spinners'.because Philippe. Wynn, their personable and distinctive, lead singer for most of the present decade, left the group a year ago to pursue a solo career. His re- placement, John Edwards, is a different sort of stylist and seems to be leading the group, if only by example, in a different direction. The change is so pronounced that most of the group's old numbersthe ones that featured Mr. Wynnno longer seem appropriate.

title: Celebrating Yankee Gumption
description: IN his article on adopting Yankee Doodle as the state song [Discordant Dandy, Feb. 5], Lawrence Fellows says that the real measure of a good tune played by skilled, fullblown group of fifers and drummers is its ability to shake green apples off the trees.

description: NAIROBI, KenyaIn a mystery thriller published here last year titled The Men From Pretoria, the improbable hero is former child of the Nairobi slums named Scoop Nelson who, after studying physics Eind mathematics at Harvard, returns to Kenya to become a crusading crime reporter. Scoop Nelson is the creation of an equally improbable Kenyan named Hilary

title: The Region
description: A mostly white middleclass school district in Queens, torn between, its need for Federal funds and its policy of resisting Federal disclosure requirements, declared last week that it was willing to pass up $1.1 million for remedial reading projects rather than provide a racial breakdown of teachers and supervisors in its schools.

title: Case Assails Young's Criticism of Rhodesian Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The ranking Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee criticized Andrew Young today for his criticism of a Rhodesian settlement effort and said the, United States delegate to the United Nations disagreed with the State Department on the issue.

title: The Sociaite and the `Windy City Prince
description: CHICAGOWhen the socialite from the fashionable Near North Side married the politician from workingclass Bridgeport on the Southwest Side, it mighttave looked like an impossible combination of extremes. Somebody would have to change. Now, seven months later, Heather Bilandic is credited by one magazine with having transformed her husband, Mayor Michael Bilandic, from an 11th Ward frog into the Windy City Prince.

title: Ideas &
description: Perhaps wolves would like to wear sheep's clothing, but now an insect has been discovered that can really do the trick: Four Cornell scientists have found that larvae of the lacewing Chrysopa slossonae literally dress up as aphids to escape detection by the ants who guard the aphids against intruders.

title: Carolyn Veerman, Librarian, Married To John Goodrich
description: Carolyn Bryan Veermaa of New York, a librarian at the Spence School and a member of the New York Junior League, was married yesterday to John Keith Goodrich of New Milford, Conn., a vice president and senior consultant with Calan Associates, financial consultants in New York.

title: Michigan State 89. Illinois 67
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 25 (UPI) Gregory Keiser scored 32 points and had 13 rebounds today to lead Michigan State to an 89.67 victory over Illinois. The victory assured the Spartans of at least a tie for the Big Ten championship. Michigan State is 133 in the Big Ten and 214 over all. Illinois dropped to 610 and 1213 over all.

title: _ ransit Policemen Rescue One of Three Auto Accident Victims From Icy Harlem River
description: A transit police officer, lowered on ope by his partner into the nearfreezing vaters of the Harlem River, rescued 0yearold woman yesterday after the ar in which she and two others were iding. slipped from the Harlem River )rive into the water.

title: DINING OUT
description: JASON'S styles itself An Eating and Drinking Emporium, and as such could easily be overlooked in the forest of pseudoVictorian parlors that have populated the county. However, on examination, neither the interiors nor the food live down to the stereotype.

title: Public Hearings on N.C.A.A. Begin Tomorrow
description: A Congressional subcommittee that has been investigating the National Collegiate Athletic Association since last October will begin public hearings in Washington tomorrow. At first, the hearings will focus nn the N.C.A.A.'s methods of investigation and punishment of colleges, coaches and athletes suspected of violating association rules.

title: Knicks Beat Slumping Suns, 122115
description: Bob McAdoo, noted for his scoring but stymied by poor shooting last night, turned to rebounding for his major contribution in the Knicks 122115 victory over the Phoenix Suns before a crowd of 17,197 at Madison Sauare Garden.

title: Bush to Help Yale. Fund Drive
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 25 (AP)George Bush, who has headed both the Republican National Committee and the Central.Intelligence Agency, has agreed to become national cochairman of Yale University's $370 million fundraising campaign. Mr. Bush, a Yale graduate who has been advising the campaign since 1974, will share with J. Irwin Miller the second highest post In the drive.

title: 45 On the Sly Captures Grey Lag at Aqueduct
description: On the Sly, the Balmak Stable's outstanding stakes horse who was purchased for $6,000 in 1975 when he was a 2-year-old in Florida, added $48,915 to his burgeoning bankroll at AqueCuct yesterdaywith the greatest of L

title: A New Swashbuckler
description: CROSSED SWORDSOliver Reed duels his way through the adventurecomedy which opens with the Easter show, Thursday at Radio City Music Hall.

description: A year at Harvard now costs $7,650 before books, transportation and hifi equipment, and if tuition, room and board escalate at the expected 6 percent compound rate, the bill will soar to $87,000 a year for a freshman in the class. of 2000,

description: If the lengthening days of winter into spring have made you think of taking down your 10speed bicycle and of getting out the backpack gear from a closet corner, then this is for you. title: Britain to Curb Price of Tea
description: LONDON, Feb. 25 (Reuters)  The British government has announced that it will force companies to reduce the price of tea. The decision, announced yesterday, will invoke the 1974 Prices Act for the first time on a food that is not subsidized. It means that the retail price of tea will go down about 20 percent.

title: Follower of. Rev. Moon Is Found Slain in Yard. Of a Harlem Tenement
description: The battered body of a 29year-old follower of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon was found in the backyard of an East Harlem tenement yesterday afternoon, according to the police.

title: Electronic Communications the Glittering Prize
description: Postmaster General Bailor was always cautious about introducing electronic mail. But others had a other views. The Commission on the Postal Service reported last spring that electronic communication should be given a careful look. The chairmen of the two postal subcommittees in Congress urged Mr. Bailar to take electronics seriously as a way to get the service ahead of the communications revolution. Mr. Bailar has since acknowledged that a limited prototype electronic communication system was likely to be put into operation this year. It would be a partnership with another company agency, he said. The prototype will be a kind of international Mailgram service linking several American cities with overseas post offices through the facilities of Comsat.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on highway repair bill to provide emergency assistance for the repair of certain weather related damages to highways and urban mass transportation systems due to the winterof 19771978, passed, 274 to 137, Feb. 21.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Army hit the beaches of Atlantic City over the weekend to haul away piles of dead clams and save the city $200,000.

title: Czech Catholic Church Struggles With Itself and the State
description: PRAGUEThe Roman Catholic Church in Czechoslovakia is going through a critical period of selfexamination and transition that, in the view of many inside and outside its leadership, may hopelessly fragment what Is left of the Catholic population.

title: Human Rights At Home
description: BOSTON, Feb. 26For 20 years, from 1953 to 1973, the C.I.A. secretly went through bags of international mail in New York and other postal centers, opened firstclass letters to and from Americans and made copies.

title: THEORIST ON EARTH SHIFTS AWARDED $50,000. PRIZE
description: Dr. J. Tuzo Wilson, a major contributor to the revolutionary theory of the earth known as plate tectonics, has been awardecl the Vetlesen Prize, carrying with it a cold medal and $50,000.

title: Greek Defense Chief on U.S. Visit
description: ATHENS, Feb. 26 (Reuters)Defense Minister Evanghelos AveroffTositsas left today for New York and a 10day visit to the United States. He has been invited by Columbia and Harvard Universities to lecture on Greece's position in the Western world. He is expected to meet with American officials.

title: In Their New Foster Family, The Ladies'Are Doing Fine
description: Having a spare room but no resident grandmother, Ruby Gibbs and family went looking for one, five years ago, through the city's Foster Homes for Adults program. This led them to. Edna Baumgarten, a tiny sweetfaced woman in her 60's with no prior experience as a grandmother, but with lots of natural talent. Soon she was playing Scrabble with the children, drying the supper dishes and making music on the organ in the living room.

title: EDITH MILLER MACAULAY
description: Edith Miller Macaulay, a former copywriter and copy director of leading cosmetic manufacturers, died Saturday of heart attack in Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. She was 74 years old and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Skating: Heiden Takes Another World Crown
description: GOTHENBURG, Sweden, Feb. 26 (UPI) Eric Heiden of Madison, Wis., winning three of the four races during the weekend, captured his sixth consecutive world title today in a successful defense of his world speedskating championship.

title: Mental Health Centers Booming As Campus Competition Rises
description: The anguish of increased competition for grades, jobs and graduate school admission is weighing heavily on the nation's college students, and a sign of their desperation is the booming business at the mental health counseling centers that have become fixtures on so many campuses.

title: Carter Says Agreement on Coal Has Good Chance of Approval
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  President Carter prayed for it, Labor Secretary Ray Marshall hoped for it and Arnold R. Miller, the union president, predicted today that it would happen: that the 160,000 striking coal miners would agree to the terms of Friday night's tentative settlement and end their 83day coal walkout.

title: Letters
description: Peter Berger's emotional Optd piece of Feb. 14 ('Now, Boat People From Taiwan?') further muddies the waters surrounding the island. Although he fails to tell us how the United States should have extracted itself from what he calls an unjust war in Vietnam without abandonment of those who trust us, he is right, of course, about the horrible plight of the Vietnamese boat people. But it hardly follows that Washington is getting ready to do it againthis time in Taiwan.

title: Around the Nation
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 26 (UPD. Organized labor endorsed the farm strike today, saying farmers, too, deserve a,fait return for their toil.

title: Music: Jazz by Ahmed Abdullah
description: AHMED ABDULLAH used to sound like a conservative when he played solos with Fun Ra's jazz orchestra. Instead of the cracked tone, skittering runs and huffing intensity favored by so many trumpet players in avantgarde contexts, Mr. Abdullah always displayed a bright, brassy sound and a more measured flow of inspiration.

title: 7,000 Take 7Minute Bus Rides For 8 Hours Over Nixon Estate
description: SAN CLEMENTE. Calif., Feb. 26For more than eight hours on a gloomy, overcast day, former President Richard M. Nixon's oceanfront estate was turned into a tourist attraction today.

title: Moon Follower Was Stabbed Repeatedly and Strangled, Autopsy Finds
description: A 29-year-old woman who gave up prospective medical career in France to become a missionary for the Rev. Sun Myung Moon was, according to an autopsy released yesterday, stabbed repeatedly and strangled.

title: Golf: First Victory For Nancy Lopez
description: SARASOTA. Fla.. Feb. 26 (UPI)Nancy Lopez birdied the 171h hole today to win the $100,000 Bent Tree Classic by one stroke from her playing partner, Jo Ann Washam. The victory was the first for Miss Lopez, a 21-yearold who turned pro last July. She earned a $15,000 first prize as she carded a finalround one-over-par 72 fir a 72hole total of 289.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Can you offer a simplified and concise explanation of tennis scoring?

title: BEGIN LEADS THOUSANDS TO AMICHAI PAGLIN RITES
description: TEL AVIV, Feb 26Thousands of Israeli underground veterans led by Prime Minister Menachem Begin attcnarl the funeral today of Amichai Paglin, who made headlines daily three decades a!;cy while managing personally to stay oui, of the news.

title: Islanders
description: The laughter traveled to the front of the New York Islanders bus as the handdrawn cartoon passed from player to player. It showed Coach Al (Radar) Arbour as Star Wars robot, antennae projecting from his head. scoreboard above read, Islanders 7, Flyers 0, and the clock showed one second remaining. Howie, take half shift, read the balloon from the robot's mouth.

title: News Summary

title: U.S. Boxers Beat Yugoslav Team, 83

Burns. When the com- mittee meets again in March, its composition should be significantly different.

title: `Good Bears Aid Neediest Cases

title: 'Dona Flor' Film On Local Screen:Indivisible
description: DONA FLOR'S first husband is dead, but that's just as well, since he was a grievous no-goodnik in his lifetime. He was a gambler, a wise guy and a womanizer, and he beat his pretty young wife shamelessly, pacifying her with the occasional moonlight serenade or nice gesture. Once he took her out to a fancy nightclub, where he bought her champagne and caviar and didn't even pinch the waitress.Apparently, this man's only note-worthy talent was for lovemaking, and "Dona Flor and Her Two Husbands," at the Paris Theater, devotes more than enough screen time to that aspect of the marriage. And Dona Flor's second husband, a dopey druggist who drops a medicine bottle the first time he sees the pretty widow, is a sorry successor. So Dona Flor mopes and broods and smiles wanly, until one day her prayers are answered. Husband Number One is such a devil that he manages to come back, sans clothing, and pay his wife amorous visits while Husband Number Two isn't looking. Even if Husband Number Two were looking he wouldn't catch on, because he is slow-witted anyway and because death has conveniently rendered Husband Number One invisible.This story, adapted from the novel by the Brazilian author Jorge Amado, would seem to have the makings of a bawdy "Topper," and indeed the film's final 20 minutes make reasonably amusing use of the dead man's return. But Bruno Barreto, who directed the film, devotes far more time to setting up the situation than he finally does to exploiting it, and the early part of the film has a dangerously uncertain tone. Dona Flor's life looks terrible, yet this is not a didactic film or even a particularly satirical one, so there's little to be learned from her plight.There are various glimpses of Bahia and its customs, circa the 1940's, but the only interesting bit of local color is Dona Flor's recipe for crabmeat casserole. Dona Flor teaches a class in gourmet cooking: Husband Number One liked to sit in on the class and, by the by, fondle the students.Sonia Braga, a Brazilian model and actress who plays Dona Flor, is called upon alternately to frown and to engage in various soft-core shenanigans. She is adequate to these demands, but her role is really little more than that of the butt of a family dirty joke.

title: TV SPORTS
Pat Haden at Oxford
description: It is the offseason now, and Pat Haden is still working. But, instead of throwing passes to wide receivers, he is writing essays about Soviet politics, economic theories of inflation and Cartesian metaphysics. Haden, an unassuming 25-year-old Rhodes scholar who displaced Joe Namath as the starting quarterback for the Los Angeles Rams early last season, will receive a degree in politics, philosophy and economics from Oxford in June, culminating threeyear cultural and educational stint that, he says, has been the best thing that has ever happened to him.

description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 26 (Reuters)John Alexander produced another singles victory today, extending Australia's. lead over New Zealand to 40 in the fivematch Eastern Zone Davis Cup final. Witliwaw, a new 46foot sloop designedRICHMOND, Feb. 26 (AP)Benny Parsons scored a 100yard victory over Lennie Pond today in the $80,000 Richmond 400 Grand National stock car race. Pond seemed well on his way to winning until a controversial bumping incident with Darrell Waltrip.

title: Story of the World Cup Tour
description: The American leg of the World Cup ski competition begins Thursday in Stratton Mountain, Vt., with the women's giant slalom.

title: ISRAEL TO CONTINUE POLICY OF EXPANDING SINAI SETTLEMENTS
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 26The Israeli Cabinet decided today not to change its policy on settlements in occupied Arab lands. The action approved the Begin Government's plan to expand Jewish settlements in northern Sinai and establish three new ones on the West Bank of the Jordan River.

title: Cortland Five Takes Title
description: Cortland State, led by its 6foot center, Bev Carter, who had 19 points and 17 rebounds, upset. St. John's in the final of the New York State Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women basketball tournament in Brooklyn yesterday.

title: Governors Gather in Washington To Seek Roles in National Policies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Most of the nation's governors gathered in Washington today for their annual winter meeting and, as usual, they were here to ask for expanded roles and authority over such problems as developent of a new urban policy, fashioning of water policy and the fields of energy and production of fuel.

title: Stage: Opening Of Deathtrap
description: THERE WAS a bleak cartoonSpanish, I believethat showed a woman performing a striptease. She removed her clothes, piece by piece, and when they were all off she proceeded to take off her legs, her head, her torso, until finally there was nothing.

title: Letter: On Rhodesia
description: The Times editorial of Feb. 2 expressing opposition to the internal settlement being negotiated by Ian Smith in Rhodesia states that the fruit of his effort may be civil war.

title: Chefs Compete in a Ski Race, And Special of the ay Is Ham
description: HUNTER, N.Y., Feb. 26If service seems a bit slow at La Grenouille this week, try to he patient. Today 14 of the famous French restaurant's staff competed in the annual chefs ski race here at Hunter Mountain.

title: Gorge Mostly Serious
description: WHAT does a comedian do when he has a 104piece symphony orchestra as a straight man? He conducts, naturally. This could be embarrassing.

title: No Comment at State Department
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The State Department had no comment today on the Soviet charge of premeditated distortion on the part of the Carter. Administration with regard to the Soviet military involvement in Ethiopia.

title: Horowitz Plays for Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Vladimir Horowitz played at the White House this afternoon for President and Mrs. Carter and an invited audience of 300.

title: Harrel and Ax at Tully Hall
description: GREAT virtuosos do not invariably demand great partners. In fact, some of the most celebrated musicians insist upon being accompanied in their recitals by faceless colleagues who trot along be- hind, making themselves invaluable by being inconspicuous. But there are other important instrumentalists, such as Lynn Harrell, who regularly ally themselves with artists of equal caliber, and somehoW manage to survive.

title: Commodities
description: Traders expect gold price,s to be buffeted in March by the coal situation, the corning bullion auction by International Monetary Fund and by the French national elections. Page D3.

title: Tennessee Residents Returning; More Cars With Fuel Jump Rails
description: WAVERLY, Tenn., Feb. 26A derailed tank car carrying 20,000 gallons of highly volatile liquid propane gas was safely unloaded here early today, 36 tense hour's after efforts to drain another tanker resulted in an explosion that left nine per sons dead, 51 injured and 14 buildings destroyed.

title: Chess:
description: It is easy to become complacent in a drab, quiet position, to ease up on concentration in the belief that there is nothing important for either you or your opponent to undertake. Most of the time this is quite harmless and you can sleepwalk your way to a draw. Nevertheless, there are occasions when the opponent's great zeal to win, backed by a rampant imagination, can turn peaceful dreams into nightmares.

title: The Divine Right to the Unearned
description: On Dec, 13, by a margin of 33 to 7, the New York City Council voted itself a 50 percent increase in pay.

title: Television
CAREY SEEKS TO PLACE SUBURBS ON A PANEL
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26Under pressure from the suburbs, Governor Carey, in shift, is supporting legislation to place suburban representatives on the Tristate Regional Planning Commission, which plays a key role in the allocation of Federal funds.

title: The Techniques Of Winter Camping
description: CAMPING in the winter is not for the timid, the out-of-shape or the unprepared, but it does offer the solitude that usually cannot be achieved in summer. Thirty years ago the typical winter camper experienced more suffering than enjoyment, but since then, much firstrate equipment has become available to those who daily in the snowfilled woods.

title: Dash Says No One Told Him He Is Not Philadelphia Choice
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Samuel Dash, the former chief counsel to the Senate Watergate committee, said today that he had not been told that he was no longer the Carter Administration's choice to be United States Attorney in Philadelphia.

title: Dreams of Big Top Made Real
description: Michael Moschen stands juggling three balls, his manner seemingly casual, with the intense focus of his eyes the sole betrayal of his deep concentration. Beside a ladder that leads to the trapeze bar 14 feet overhead, Dale Scott warms up with a series of plids Others work out on mats and apparatus, each absorbed in practice, each oblivious to the action around him.

title: Market Place
description: Growth stocks were the darlings of the investment community for many years, but the situation began to change with the bear market of 1974.

title: Miners Reject TatternSetter Pact by 21 Margin
description: MADISONVILLE, Ky., Feb. 26The proposed contract designed as the socalled patternsetter to lead to the end of the 82day coal strike has been decisively rejected in voting by United Mine Workers union members, both union and coal company management officials said here today.

title: Zenith Reports Loss Of $4.7 Million for 77
description: The Zenith Radio Corporation has announced a net loss of $4.7 million for 1977, equal to 25 cents a share, compared with a 1976 net income of 38.6 million and $2.05.

title: $5 Million Gift Restores Conservatory
description: In a shimmering glass house shaped like a cross, a hippopotamus will be standing, as delicately as he can, in bed of white pansies. Nearby will be giraffe.

title: Quantas Orders 2 More 747's
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 26 (Reuters) The Australian airline Quontas has ordered two more Boeing 747 jumbo jets at a cost of almost $100 million, it was announced here today.

title: U.S. Had Expected No Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The State Department had no formal comment today on the decision by Israel's Cabinet not to make a decision affecting the settlements policy.

title: LowIncome Youngsters in Jersey Given More U.S. SummerJob Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25A new Federal fomula to direct more Federal money to lowincome areas with high unemployment will provide 33.000 summer jobs for disadvantaged young people in New Jersey this year, 5,000 more than in 1977.

title: $5 Million Gift Restores Conservatory
description: In a shimmering glass house shaped like a cross, a hippopotamus will be standing, as delicately as he can, in bed of white pansies. Nearby will be giraffe.

title: Cass Piano Recital
description: RICHARD CASS'S recital in Alice Tully Hall Saturday night was apparently his first New York appearance in 18 years, The pianist's last local concert took place in Carnegie Hall in 1960, and Mr. Cass has since confined his playing primarily to Europe and the Middle West where he is professor of music at the University of MissouriKansas City Conservatory.

title: Larnaca, PostMortem
description: The burst of violence in Cyprus at Larnaca airport, which left 15 Egyptian commandos dead and relations between Egypt and Cyprus in tatters, raises in the most direct way the question of when, if ever, a state may use force within the territory of another. The answereven had the affair not ended in tragedyshould very, very seldom.

title: Esther Hinds As Butterfly
description: THE first Madama Butterfly of the New York City Opera's spring season, performed Saturday night at the State Theater, featured the young. West Indian soprano Esther Hinds in the demanding title role.

title: Tennis: Navratilova Wins
description: DETROIT, Feb. 26 (AP)Topseeded Martina Navratilova, starting out by taking the first 12 points, defeated Dianne Fromholtz of Australia, 6.3, 62, today to win her sixth consecutive pro tennis tournament, setting a record.

title: Pop Concert: Thorogood's `Destroyers
description: EVERYBODY has prejudices, and this reporter must confess a general suspicion of collegiatelooking white men who slavishly imitate black music. George

title: Jamesburg Vote Upsets Planners
description: JAMESBURG, Feb. 26This borough's recent rejection of a proposal to close its 46-year-old high school has raised new .questions about an ambitious but controversial plan to redistrict four other public high schools in Middlesex County.

title: Does Boston's Plan Show How to Go on Westway?; Additional Aid Cited; Boston's Transit Plan May Show New York How to Goon Westway; Both Plans Abandoned; Boston Explains Argument; 3Mile Replacement Urged
description: A densely populated Northeast city has a decaying elevated highway that feeds clogged traffic through a main commercial and residential corridor of town. Planners come up with a visionary $1.07 billion scheme to replace tne overhead road with an underground one, plus a rail line, be topped by parks, houses, pedestrian malls, retail shops and office space. The Federal Government will pay 90 percent of the cost. -

title: The U.N. Today
In Poor Black America
description: The disintegration of some inner cities has turned once peaceful black neighborhoods into no-man's-lands where neither blacks nor whites are safe, a condition that further alienates whites. The high unemployment rates among poor blacks, and the crime associated with this group, also forces older blacks to live in fear.

title: 2 Yank Prospects Look Bueno
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 26Damaso Garcia and Domingo Ramos, two young infielders from the Dominican Republic, made their first appearances in the Yankee camp today, much changed by their threeyear exposure to American baseball.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE HUMAN FACTOR has an interesting plot and number of promising ideas for characters. It is occasionally puckish. It talks about politics

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Andrea Schaffner Becomes the Bride Of Geoffrey Herter
description: Andrea Schaffner and Geoffrey Elvin Herter, fourthyear students at the College of Physicians and Surgeons 01 Columbia University, were married yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg of the Temple of Universal Judaism and the Rev. Dr. Richard E. Strum of the Park Avenue Christian Church.

title: 1975 TEXTRON MEMO STIRS SENATE DOUBT ON IRAN TESTIMONY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The Senate Banking Committee has for the first time uncovered an internal Textron Inc. memorandum that casts doubt on the testimony to Senate Investigators of at least one highly placed official of Bell Helicopter, a Textron division. The committee's sixweek investigation has twice delayed a vote on the confirmation of G. William Miller, chairman of Textron and President Carter's nominee to head the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Making Paper From Scratch: A Brew Of Flowers, Vegetables and Cloth
description: Craftsmen who've already tried their hands at needlepoint or stenciling or tiedyeing have been looking around for something new. What many of them have found is very, very old. Two thousand years old. The art of papermaking.

title: Erasers, Rock Band, At CBGB's
description: THE general press seems all In a dither about punk rock these days. But it's the British variety they're denouncing, when some people in London say the punk movement there has crested. In the meantime, we hear less about new bands coming out of SBGB's, the original home of the whole punk movement. But in fact the Bowery club is still hotbed of young bands that play hard, original andat their bestdistinctive rock-and-roll, Whether you choose to label it 'punk or not seems almost irrelevant.

title: A Last Look At Havlicek
description: He was the most challenging player I ever played against, recalls Bill Bradley. He made me play at my best, and playing at my best made basketball enjoyable for me. Bradley, now a candidate for the United States Sen ate from New Jersey, was talking about the Boston Celtics John Havlicek, who will retire after the season and will make his last Madison Square Garden appearance, against the Knicks, Saturday at 8 P.M. He's the kind of player, adds the New Yorkers coach, Willis Reel, every player wished he was. The Knicks have some ceremonies in store for him.

title: Pickup Basketball Offers Court Time for PartTime Stars
description: FINDING a place to play basketball is easy enough in warmer weather, for outdoor courts abound. On a bitter day of gray winter, however, it takes little for the twice-a-week enthusiast to turn his back on the park or playground or schoolyard that was so inviting on golden afternoon in late September. No matter. There' s always the indoors.

title: Deaths
description: BANKEREleanor. We record with deep sorrow the passing of the sister of our loyal and devoted member, Mrs. Eli Resnikoff. To the members of the family we extend our sincerest condolences.

title: Tennis: Practice Alleys
description: ARE you a tennis player who wants to practice but cannot find the time, a partner or an available court? An indoor practice alley, many of which have opened recently, may be the answer.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Slate Wins State Vote
description: NEW DELHI, Monday, Feb. 27Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's new political party won a decisive victory today in legislative elections in the southern state of Karnataka. Although limited to one of India's 22 states, the victory provided a significant psychological boost for Mrs. Gandhi's effort to make a political comeback after her defeat in the national election 11 months ago.

title: Trash Is Hurled Into Street in Bay Ridge Protest
description: Residents of a Brooklyn block, frustrated by sluggish refuse collections after the last big snow storm, flung bags of uncollected trash into the streets over the weekend, jamming the block from curb to curb with mounds of garbage.

title: In Black MiddleClass America
description: Nearly every black community America has its stories of blacks who, after clearing the economic hurdles, vowed never to leave the ghetto and the less fortunate but who finally despaired of their ability to change things and joined the spiritual exodus.

title: I.R.S. SAYS 555 TAXPAYERS IN JERSEY SENT IN TOO MUCH
description: NEWARK, Feb. 26 (UPI)More than 500 New Jersey taxpayers already have paid the Government too much this year.

title: Some Restive West Virginia Miners Support Contract
description: CEDAR GROVE, West Va., Feb. 26They are not easy to find, but District 17, one of the most militant and politically volatile in the United Mine Workers union, has its pockets of support for the newly negotiated coal contract.

title: Albany's Patronage Roots Hidden by Change in Law; Albany ??? Notes
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24It seemed like a good idea at the time when the Legislature voted last year to amend New York State's Freedom of Information law to ease the restrictions on the types of government documents that must be made public.

title: Legal Woes Beset McDermott on Merger's Eve
description: Last year, J. Ray McDermott & Company, the world's largest builder of offshore oil rigs, snatched a victory from the United Technologies Corporation by emerging as the successful suitor for the Babcock & Wilcox Company in what was by far the most dramatic takeover battle of 1977.

title: Commodities
description: March promises to be a cruel month for gold futures traders, a period strewn with potentially costly traps for both bulls and bears. The first is scheduled for this Wednesday, when the International Monetary Fund holds its next monthly auction of 524,800 ounces of eold bullion.

title: TRUSTEE FOR W. T. GRANT PLANS PAYMENT TO BANKS
description: Twentysix bank creditors of the W. T. Grant Company will receive an initial $16] million and other possible payments in settlement of their claims of $650 million against the defunct retail chain, according to Charles G. Rodman, Grant's trustee in bankruptcy.

title: Nicklaus Birdies Last 5, Wins
description: LAUDERHILL, Fla., Feb. 26If Jack Nicklaus ever gets tired of being the world's best golfer, he can always get a job as a producer of television spectaculars.

title: Young Denies Letter On Rhodesia Urged Full Guerrilla Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  Andrew Young, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that he had never urged that power in Rhodesia be turned over exclusively to the Patriotic Front, which is waging a guerrilla war against the white minority Government.

title: DE GUSTIBUS Keep the Heat On- From Kitchen to Dining Table
description: As readers of this or related columns through the years may know, I have an absolute ide fixe when it comes to serving hot food on hot plates. Not just warm plates. Hot plates. That is why the following from a reader in Pleasantville, N.Y., went far to warm my heart's cockles:

title: St. Francis Five Gets Bad News
description: At 12:30 yesterday afternoon, Lou Rossini, the St. Francis College basketball coach, received the news he didn't want to hear at his home in Rego Park, Queens. It was a telephone call from

title: PEKING PARTY CHIEF PLEDGES TO IMPROVE STANDARD OF LIVING
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 26In a lengthy report today to China's National People's Congress, Hua Kuofeng, the chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, formally detailed Peking's new commitment to rapid economic development, better living standards for its people and a more satisfying cultural life.

title: Ellen Kearney, Singer, Is Wed
description: The marriage of Ellen Kearney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Philip Kearney of Newburgh, N. Y., to Peter Lieberson took place at the Karma Dzong Buddhist Meditation Center in Boulder, Colo., yesterday afternoon.

title: ONE OF 3 AT CITY U. NEEDS REMEDIAL AID
description: One of every five classes taken by freshmen and sophomores at the City University of New York is in a remedial course, and the cost of this noncredit work is at least $30 million a year, according to a study by the university's office of academic affairs.

title: WELFARE FRAUDS TARGETS OF MORE U.S. INQUIRIES
description: Fraud in federally financed welfare programs has become a major target of investigations in New York, according to an annual report issued yesterday by Robert B. Fiske Jr., the United States Attorney in Manhattan.

title: Notes on People
description: Charles Evers, the black mayor of Fayette, Miss., has :called for the resignation of Aaron Henry as Mississippi state president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.. Mr. Henry, a pharmacist from

title: SUPREME COURT BARS EFFORT TO ROLL BACK BIG RISE IN GAS RATES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The Supreme Court rejected today an attempt by consumers and municipalities to roll back an increase of $1.5 billion a year in national rates for natural gas approved by the Federal Power Commission in 1976.

title: Kentucky 78, Georgia 67
description: ATHENS, Ga., Feb. 27 (AP)Jack Givens and Rick Robey each scored 15 points tonight and powered topranked Kentucky to a 78.67 Southeastern Conference victory over Georgia.

title: The U.N. Today
DENIAL OF A GRANT TO BRONX IS REVERSED
description: The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare yesterday approved a $44,000 grant for a program in a Bronx school district that his department had earlier rejected as ethnically unbalanced.

title: MiddleClass Gains Create Tension in Black Community
description: When it predicted the emergence of two separate societies, the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders never foresaw two separate societies within the black community.

title: Dispute Over Westway Upstages Transportation Policy Hearing
description: Wrangling among New York City politicians about the proposed Westway all but submerged a hearing on national transportation policy yesterday.

title: KOCH HALTS THE SALE OF SOUTH BRONX LOTS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday stopped the sale of 38 pieces of property in the South Bronx that were auctioned off last November.

title: Jazz: Anthony Davis and Quartet
description: Anthony Davis was already a strikingly gifted pianist when he began performing in New York several years ago. He was still attending Yale, and sometimes he seemed to want to condense everything he was learning into his improvisations, which ranged tram McCoy Tyner's modern romanticism to Thelonious Monk's acerbity with multitude of stops along the way. But everything he played was lucid and well executed, andwith Jay Hoggard on vibraphone, Mark Helias on bass, and Ed Blackwell on drumshe was developing an appealing combo sound that seemed to owe very little to the one important jazz group with identical instrumentation, the Modern Jazz Quartet.

title: STRATEGY TO REVIVE WESTERN ECONOMIES TAKES A NEW TACK
description: PARIS, Feb. 27High economic officials from the major Western nations today opened discussions o'n new proposals for a coordinated moderate expansion of demand in the several leading industrial economies in an attempt to break policy deadlock over how to end the lingering economic ills of the West.

title: Cyprus Starts Hearing On Killing of Editor
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 27 (AP)Two Arabs! accused of killing a prominent Egyptian newspaper editor, sat impassively In court today during the first day of a hearing to determine whether they would stand trial for the assassination.

title: Bridge:
description: Few players ever have the experience of bringing home a difficult contract and hearing a thunderous burst of applause from several hundred spectators.

title: French Left Expected to Gain in Depressed Vosges Textile Region
description: EPINAL, France,Feb. 22'No more dismissalswork for everyone proclaim he slogans scrawled on the factory walls. But it is an unlikely prospect.

title: Another Town Is Evacuated
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Fla., Feb. 27 CAP)The deadly chlorine gas that escaped from a ruptured railway car yesterday, killing eight persons and injuring 90, headed toward another small town today, forcing all 250 residents from their homes.

title: Bills in Legislature Call for New Aquaculture Agency
description: TRENTON, Feb. 27'Bill's were introduced in the State Legislature today that would create a division of aquaculture in the State Agriculture Department to take advantage of new federal legislation that provides money for increasing the ocean harvest of food fish.

title: Medal of Honor Awarded
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI)The Navy today posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor to Capt. Michael J. Estocin, a pilot who was listed as missing in action for more than 10 years in North Vietnam but was declared dead only three months ago. Captain Estocin, of Turtle Creek, Pa.,, received the medal for his heroism on April 20 and 26, 1967, as leader of a three plane group.

title: WILLIAM H. RADEBAUGH
description: William H. Radebaugh, a partner for 31 years in the New York law firm of Dunningten, Bartholow & Miller, died Friday in a convalescent home in Fairfield, Conn., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived at 157 Cedar Road in Southport, Conn.

title: Governor Byrne Returns to Reality
description: Last month, Gov. Brendan Byrne pledged in his State of the State Message that his second term would be marked by major initiatives on behalf of New Jersey's cities. The news created high expectations; mayors hardpressed. urban areas looked forward to new as- sistance. However, it turns out that the Governor's $4.4 billion budget, submitted to the Legislature last week, has no new funds for urban programs. There is a $50 million increase for human services which includes 5 percent increase in welfare benefits for families with dependent children. But nothing has been added for jobs or housing.

title: Messing Signs With Oakland
description: Shep Messing signed a oneyear contract with the Oakland Stompers yesterday for more than $100,000. The 29-year-old goalkeeper became a free agent at the end of last season after helping the Cosmos capture their second North. American Soccer . League championship.

title: NUCLEAR FUEL PLAN THWARTS DIVERSION
description: The development of a nuclearfuel recycling system that would prevent the  diversion of plutonium from future breeder power plants into weaponry was disclosed yesterday by research officials from the United States and Britain.

title: Beame Gets TV Post As Expert on Cities
description: Former Mayor Abraham D. Beame has accepted a post as an urbanaffairs consultant for WNBCTV's NewsCenter 4 and will appear on various Channel 4 news programs from time to time to comment on municipal problems and other matters, Norman Fein, the station's news director, said yesterday.

title: 22 Die in Collision in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 27 (AP)1 Twentytwo persons were killed and 901 were injured when a passenger bus and a train collided today at Shandara, 170 miles southeast of Islamabad.

title: INFLUENCEBUYING DENIED IN COURT BY TONGSUN PARK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)Tongsun Park pleaded not guilty today to 36 criminal charges of trying to buy influence in Congress for the South Korean Government.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Mussorgsky's Boris Godunov, 8.

title: EGYPT WITHDRAWING SPECIAL PRIVILEGES OF ITS PALESTINIANS
description: CAIRO, Feb. 27Prime Minister Mamdouh Salem announced today that privileges granted for over two decades to Palestinians living in Egypt would be withdrawn and that thereafter Palestinians would be treated the same as other Arab aliens.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in TheTimes yesterday. inadvertently stated that J. Ray McDermott & Company had admitted, making illegal kickbacks and political contributions between 1965 and 1976 totaling $1.1 billion. The questionable payments and contributions cited actually totaled $1.1 million.

title: City Legal Staff Indicts Working Conditions
description: In a room on the 17th floor of the Municipal Building, six lawyers of the general litigation division of the city's Department of Law toil away with the benefit of only three telephones.

title: California Marshal
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb, 26  Waiting his turn to go before the cameras the other. night, Big Ed Davis, the tough cop turned gubernatorial candidate, was watching a sports broadcast. At the mention of Carroll Rosenbloom, the wealthy owner of the Los Angeies Rams, this city's former police chief suddenly snapped his fingers.

title: 13 POLICE, 54 AIDES ARRESTED IN 2 YEARS IN NEW YORK INQUIRY
description: Thirteen police officers and 54 civilian employees of the Police Department have been arrested in a twoyear undercover investigation of gambling and narcotics activities in Brooklyn and other parts of the city, authorities said yesterday. With the indictments of eight of the policemen and two civilian community service officers yesterday, the police disclosed that five police officers and 52 civilian employees had been charged earlier.

title: Braniff FliNits to London Blocked
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The start of direct airline service between Dallas and London was put in jeopardy today by dispute between the British and American Governments.

title: Irving J. Feist, 71, President Of Manhattan Real Estate Concern
description: Irving J. Feist, president of the real estate concern of Feist & Feist Inc. of Newark and New York and president of the Boy Scouts of America from 1968 to 1971, died yesterday in Jacksonville, Fla., during a business trip. He .was 71 years old and lived at 200 East Street in Manhattan.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Holy Cross 99, Boston Col. 98
description: NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 27 (AP)Ronnie Perry's fivefoot jump shot with two seconds left in overtime gave Holy Cross a 9998 victory over Boston College tonight in the regularseason finale for both teams.

title: Steel Production for Last Week 0.2% Below. Preceding Period
description: Steel production for the week ended Feb. 25 fell to 2.403 million tons, down 0.2 percent from the week before, the American iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry produced 2.407 million tons in the preceding week.

title: Publishing: David Frost, Two Most Confusing Fellows
description: David Prost is a 41-year-old bearded, bespectacled chief copy editor at the New York publishing house of Grosset & Dunlap. He is highly regarded by his colleagues for his accuracy and modesty. His job is to work on other peo- pie's books, anonymously. His name is barely known to the writers of the books whose grammar, stylistic inconsistencies and facts he checks and corrects.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.8% FOR JANUARY, DOUBLE AVERAGE RISE
description: WASHINGTON: Feb. 27Led by food, housing and medicalcare costs, consumer prices rose rapidly in January after several months of relatively small increases, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: Widening Jersey Parkway Stretch Is Bigger Job Than Original Road
description: WOODBRTDGE, N.J., Feb. 27 (AP)The widening of a 23mile southcentral stretch of the Garden State Parkway may take up to two years longer than it took to build the original toll road more than 25 years ago, the New Jersey Highway Authority says.

title: MiddleClass Gains Create Tension inBlack Community
description: When it predicted the emergence of two separate societies, the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders never foresaw two separate societies within the black community.

title: Roosevelt Lifts Ban on Jersey Horses
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 27Roosevelt Raceway began its 39th season tonight with a new opendoor policy, a covenant somewhat less significant than the opening of Japan to Western trade or the political recognition of Cuba.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: A few weeks ago, Amnesty International, the Nobel Prize-winning human rights organization, resolved to begin campaign against the death penalty. William Buckley, the conscience of conservatism, promptly resigned on the ground that a group dedicated to freedom of thought has no business telling any society how to treat its wrongdoers. He observed in his statement of resignation that fulltime bleeding hearts tend to notice depredations from the right while ignoring depredations from the left. To be sure but such congenital astigmatism, as he called it, also afflicts parttime bleeding hearts like himself who tend to go soft over regimes that do their dirty work under the banner of antiCommunism.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WORDS OF WISDOM Three contrasting lectures today should prove stimulatingone about a great photographer, another by a major, contempormy playwright and the third on the business of proper eating.

title: SUBURBANITES URGED FOR PLANNING PANEL
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27Amidst charges that New York City would be shortchanged, the Assembly today passed a bill to put suburban representatives on the Tristate Regional Planning Commission.

title: Sharing of Profits Expected
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 27 (AP) Profitsharing revenues generated by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority will end dependency of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development

title: Head of Citizens &
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 27Richard L. Kattel, chairman and president of the Citizens and Southern National Bank, resigned today after struggling unsuccessfully to clear up the big financial institution's problems with realestate loans.

title: West Side Highway: TrafficPattern Shift
description: To ease West Side traffic jams caused by the recent closing of a portion of the West Side Highway, traffic patterns will be changed, starting Thursday, to make it posssible for northbound motorists to enter the highway at 57th Street.

title: Trudeau Is Adopting a Personalized Campaign Style
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 27Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Liberal Party has apparently decided on a highly personalized campaign for national elections expected this year, with the failing Canadian economy as the principal substantive issue.

title: Hired Farm Labor Force Drops
description: WASHINGTON,Feb. 27 (AP)The nai tion's hired farm work force last month dropped substantially from a year ago, reflecting in part severe weather conditions in areas that depend on seasonal labor, according to the Agriculture Department. A quarterly report said that about 764,300 hired workers were on farms during the survey week of Jan. 814, as against 817,300 a year earlier.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERICAN ARCHER (USL). Rotterdam Mar. 14, Felix. stave 15; Le Havre 16 and Hamburg 17; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island. Letters, prints and parcel nest for the Netherlands, Gambia, Gibraltar, Great Britain, France, Gabon Republic and Switzerland.

title: S.E.C.StudiesNewCharge On Bell Helicopter's Fees
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating another allegation that Bell Helicopter, a subsidiary of Textron Inc., has made questionable commission payments in connection with the sale of helicopters to Jamaica in the early 1970's.

title: N.Y.R.A. Said To Bid for Ringer Horses
description: ALLENTOWN, N.J., Feb. 27The New York Racing Association is attempting to purchase the Camijo Stables As De Pique II, a thoroughbred in the ringer cases involving Dr. Mark J. Gerard, a source close to the situation said today.

title: `Loose Change': A Flap for TV
description: Television viewers in Idaho and Montana who watched the first installment of NBC's. Loose Change miniseries Sunday night did not get to see three minutes and 45 seconds of It Viewers across the nation wno tuned in for the second installment last night got an unscheduled sneak preview of the first 17 minutes of the third and final installment due to be aired tonight. The Sunday night cut was attributed to a technical problem at KUTV in Salt Lake City. which serves as the network feed station for about 10 NBC affiliates in Idaho and Montana.

title: Price Index Rises By 0.9% in Month InNew York Area
description: Prodded by the sharpest local January food price increases in five years, the new urbanoriented Consumer Price Index registered a rise of ninetenths of 1 percent for the New York region last month, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Seaver: No Met Regrets
description: TAMPA, Feb. 27Tom Seaver lay on the trainer's table In the camp of the Cincinnati Reds today reading Trinity by Leon Uris. He reflected that this was the first spring in his 11year baseball career that he had been apart from the New York Mets, and said;

title: MINERS AND INDUSTRY HOLD SEPARATE TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27Leaders of the coal industry and the miners union held separate caucus sessions here today on the terms of a tentative settlement on which 160,000 strikers are to begin voting this weekend.

title: Uncertainty and Rumors Are Rife at NBC in Pre - Silverman Days
description: Staff meetings are held with the same regularity as before, programs are purchased and scheduled, air time is being sold and, to all outward appearances, the National Broadcasting Company is conducting business as usual while it awaits the arrival on June 8 of its new president and chief executive, Fred Silverman.

title: Should a Gentleman Look?; OBSERVER
description: My knowledge of what goes on in singles bars comes entirely from reading reviews of Looking For Mister Goodbar. I gather they are places where a girl like Diane Keaton can get herself murdered. Also that, they are filled with what Steve Martin calls wild and swinging guys and a species of femininity called chicks.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4) Perspective on Education

title: Czech Sentenced for Spying
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 27 (AP)A Czech, named Frantisek Swejda was sentenced to 10 years in prison by the Prague Regional Court for espionage for a Western power, the official press agency reported today.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: Article 1 -- No Title

title: F.A.S.B. Proposes Ending 2 Rules
description: Bowing to pressure from small business, the Financial Accounting Standards Board yesterday proposed .dropping two disclosure rules for nonpublic companies. The board, the private sector's authority on accounting rules, recommended that nonpublic companies no longer be required to report earnings per share or break down financial information by segments, such as geographic area or major customers,

title: Flight Attendants Break Away From Union
description: What do subway motormen and airline stewardesses have in common?

title: Price Index Rises By 0.9% in Month InNewYork Area
description: Prodded by the sharpest local January food price increases in five years, the new urbanoriented Consumer Price Index registered a rise of ninetenths of I percent for the New York region last month, the United .States Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Advertising
description: When the marketing people at Fro. mageries Bel Inc. moved their cheesy account to TBW/Baron Costello & Fine, they were expecting another print advertising campaign  which was, after all, what they were used to and thought they could afford.

title: Egypt and the Palestinian Cause: The .Bitterness Boils Over After the Cyprus Episode
description: CAIRO, Feb. 27It is time to forget about the Palestinians and their cause, said Sayed Fouad, a 38-year-old Cairene, the other day. If they are able to kill people, why don't they go and free their own lands?.

title: Lehigh 67, Rider 60
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa. Feb. 27 (AP)Jeff Vandermark scored 20 points and led Dehigh past Rider, 6760, tonight in the first round of E.C.C. playoffs.

title: Mayor Koch Stalks Out of Meeting In Queens in Dispute Over Agenda
description: Mayor Koch stalked out of a meeting of more than 1,000 Queens residents last night When they insisted he stick to their agenda and he insisted on making a twominute opening speech.

title: DEFENDANT ESCAPES BEFORE SPANISH TRIAL
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Feb. 27On the eve of what promised to be a sensitive political trial, the principal defendant, theatrical director named Albert Boadella, escaped custody in a downtown Barcelona hospital this afternoon.

title: Fiat Account Is Lost, Says Ally &
description: Ally & Gargano has lost the Fiat Motors of North America account, according to a letter from the client received by Carl Ally, chairman of the agency. Alberto Fava, the client's director of marketing services, declined to verify this. .

title: EGYPT WITHDRAWING SPECIAL PRIVILEGES OF ITS PALESTINIANS
description: CAIRO, Feb. 27Prime Minister Mamdouh Salem announced today that privileges granted for over two decades to Palestinians living in Egypt would be withdrawn and that thereafter Palestinians would be treated the same as other Arab aliens.

title: Rivers, in Happy Mood, Joins Yankees
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 27Mickey Rivers, one of the most memorable of all the characters that abound in the Yankee clubhouse, joined the team for the 1978 season today, much happier than a year ago but still a source of confusion.

title: Metals Futures Up In Bullish Trade; Orange Juice Falls
description: Traders in precious metal futures were a bit more bullish yesterday, despite steadier dollar and a sharp drop in the Swiss franc. Brokers also said the tentative coal settlement was being generally taken as inflationary in the long run.

title: Peruvian Students and Workers Clash With Police During Strike
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 27 (AP)Students and workers clashed with police in Lima slums yesterday and stone  throwing demonstrators were reported to have shut down some bus lines in the city of Cuzco. It was the first day of a 48hour general strike called by Communistled labor unions.

title: New Swiss Action Bolsters Dollar
description: The dollar moved sharply upward against major world currencies in trading abroad yesterday, then lost some of the gains in later New York trading. The Associated Press reported.

title: COAST STUDY OPPOSES NUCLEAR POWER PLAN
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27California energy officials, bucking national inclinations toward nuclear power as the simplest solution to the energy problem, have published a comprehensive report that might have been entitled: How to Avoid Building an Atomic Power Plant.

title: Canal Pact Foes Lose Senate Test
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The Senate today rejected, 55 to 34, an effeort by opponents of the Pariama Canal treaties to allow the United States to maintain military bases in Panama to the year2020, 20 years longer than is allowed under the negotiated pacts.

title: U.S. Reportedly to Urge Pensions to Buy City Bonds
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27The most recent version of Treasury Secretary W, Michael 'Blumenthal's longawaited proposal for Federal financing assistance for New York City has met with criticism from Mayor Koch and others over a Treasury Department's suggestion that municipal pension funds increase their holdings of city or cityrelated bonds in the years ahead.

title: Sun Oil Bid for Reichhold Reported.
description: Reichhold Ltd. said in Toronto that it had been told that the Sun Oil Company of Canada planned to make a bid for all of the Canadian company's shares. George Hagan, president of Reichhold, said the company preferred to remain independent.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHISTLE. By James Jones. 457 pages. Delacorte. $10.95.
